question_text: Serum concentrations of which of the following decrease during inflammation?
explanation: During inflammation, there are reduced levels of albumin. This occurs in order to allow an increase in the liver's capacity to synthesize acute phase reactants. Hence, albumin is called a negative phase reactant. Negative acute-phase proteins concentration decreases during inflammation. These are: Albumin Transferrin Retinol-binding protein Antithrombin Transcortin Alpha 2-HS glycoprotein Alpha-fetoprotein Thyroxin-binding protein Insulin-like growth factor 1 Factor 12 Acute-phase proteins are plasma proteins synthesized by the liver in response to inflammation. These include C-reactive protein (CRP), fibrinogen, and serum amyloid A (SAA) protein. The synthesis of these molecules in hepatocytes is stimulated by cytokines. IL-6 stimulates the synthesis of CRP and fibrinogen and IL-1 or TNF for SAA.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 39-year-old woman is being evaluated for anemia. She is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis. Increased levels of which of the following is responsible for her anemia?
explanation: In this scenario, the woman has a chronic illness, rheumatoid arthritis. In chronic disease states, elevated plasma concentrations of hepcidin cause anemia. Increased hepcidin reduces the availability of iron. Fibrinogen binds to red cells and causes rouleaux formation. They sediment more rapidly at unit gravity than do individual red cells. This is the basis for measuring the erythrocyte sedimentation rate in inflammation. C-reactive protein (CRP) and serum amyloid A (SAA) bind to microbial cell walls. They act as opsonins and fix complement. They also bind chromatin.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is not true for platelet-activating factor?
options: It is secreted by mast cells
It is involved in leukocyte adhesion
explanation: Platelet-activating factor (PAF) primarily causes vasoconstriction. PAF is a phospholipid-derived mediator known to have multiple inflammatory effects. It may be secreted by the following: Platelets Basophils Mast cells Neutrophils Macrophages Endothelial cells. Its functions include: Platelet aggregation Vasoconstriction Bronchoconstriction Leukocyte adhesion Vascular permeability and vasodilation at low doses
subject: Pathology

question_text: The critical step in complement activation involves the proteolysis of the which component?
explanation: The critical step in complement activation is the proteolysis of the third (and most abundant) component, C3. The complement system can be activated by one of three pathways: Classical pathway - antibody-mediated and triggered by fixation of C1 to antibody (IgM or IgG) that has combined with antigen Alternative pathway - triggered by microbial surface molecules in the absence of antibody Lectin pathway - plasma mannose-binding lectin binds to carbohydrates on microbes and directly activates C1. All three pathways of complement activation lead to the formation of an active enzyme called the C3 convertase. It splits C3 into two functionally distinct fragments, C3a and C3b.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Patients with an inherited deficiency of C1 inhibitor will have which of the following?
explanation: The deficiency of C1 INH causes hereditary angioedema. C1-inhibitor (C1 INH)is the largest member of the serpin superfamily of proteins. It normally inhibits the following: Complement system Kallikrein system Factor XII or Hageman factor Deficiency of C1 INH is associated with hereditary angioedema (hereditary angioneurotic edema). It leads to decreased C4 and C2 levels and bradykinin accumulation. There is swelling due to leakage of fluid from blood vessels into connective tissue. It is an autosomal dominant disorder.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not caused by bradykinin?
options: Pain at the site of injection
explanation: Bradykinin results in vasodilation. Kinins are vasoactive peptides derived from plasma proteins called kininogens, by the action of specific proteases called kallikreins. The enzyme kallikrein cleaves high molecular weight kininogen, to produce bradykinin. Actions of bradykinin: Increases vascular permeability Potent vasodilator Contraction of smooth muscle Dilation of blood vessels Pain when injected into the skin
subject: Pathology

question_text: During an inflammatory response, which of the following does not increase vascular permeability?
explanation: IL-4 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine and does not have any effect on vascular permeability. question_text: Fever occurs during inflammation due to all except:
explanation: Histamine is involved in the mediation of vascular events of inflammation, not fever. Fever is characterized by an elevation of body temperature, usually by 1° to 4°C. It is one of the most prominent manifestations of the acute-phase response, especially if associated with infection. Substances that induce fever are called pyrogens. They may be exogenous or endogenous. Endogenous pyrogens - IL-1, TNF, prostaglandins Exogenous pyrogens - Lipopolysaccharides of bacterial walls They stimulate leukocytes to release endogenous pyrogens (IL-1 and TNF) Cytokines result in an increase in cyclooxygenases that convert arachidonic acid into prostaglandins. These prostaglandins are produced in the vascular and perivascular cells of the hypothalamus. In the hypothalamus, they stimulate the production of neurotransmitters that reset the temperature setpoint to a higher level. This is especially by PGE2.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is true about fever?
options: Aspirin increases fever by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis
PGD2 is responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level
Fever occurs during inflammation due to release of histamine
explanation: IL-1 is an endogenous pyrogen Substances that induce fever are called pyrogens. They may be exogenous or endogenous. Endogenous pyrogens - IL-1, TNF, prostaglandins Exogenous pyrogens - Lipopolysaccharides of bacterial walls They stimulate leukocytes to release endogenous pyrogens (IL-1 and TNF) In the hypothalamus, prostaglandins such as PGE2 stimulate the production of neurotransmitters that reset the temperature setpoint at a higher level. Aspirin decreases fever by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: IL-1 is activated by :
explanation: Caspase- 1 activates the biologically active form of IL-1. IL-1 is involved in pyroptosis, a form of programmed cell death that is different from apoptosis and necrosis. It is involved in the clearance of necrotic and microbe-infected cells. It occurs in the following sequence: Activation of the inflammasome complex Activation of caspase-1 Generation of IL-1 - results in fever, inflammation, leukocyte recruitment
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not secreted by T-helper type 2 cells?
explanation: TH2 cells secrete IL4, IL5, and IL13. Three subsets of CD4+ T cells secrete different types of cytokines and elicit different types of inflammation.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In patients with which of the following conditions would you observe tertiary lymphoid organs?
explanation: Tertiary lymphoid organs are seen in autoimmune conditions such as: Hashimoto thyroiditis - in the thyroid Rheumatoid arthritis - in the synovium SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus) - in the kidneys Tertiary lymphoid organs are a feature of chronic inflammatory conditions. Here, the accumulated lymphocytes, antigen-presenting cells, and plasma cells cluster together to form lymphoid tissues resembling lymph nodes.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Lymph node biopsy of a patient with tuberculosis demonstrated the following findings. From which of the following are these cells derived?
explanation: The given histopathological findings in a patient with tuberculosis are suggestive of granulomatous inflammation, with epithelioid and multinucleated giant cells. These cells are derived from the monocyte-macrophage lineage. Macrophages activated by IFN- develop into cells with abundant cytoplasm. They resemble epithelial cells and are thus called epithelioid cells. Some activated macrophages may fuse, forming multinucleated giant cells. Collections of activated macrophages, often with T lymphocytes are seen in granulomatous inflammation. Sometimes it is associated with central caseating necrosis. Granulomas may be formed in response to various stimuli: Immune granulomas - due to T-cell mediated response; macrophages activate T cells to produce cytokines, such as IL-2 and IFN- Foreign body granulomas - due to inert foreign bodies in the absence of a T-cell mediated response
subject: Pathology

question_text: Epithelioid granulomas are not seen in which of the following diseases?
explanation: Kikuchi's lymphadenitis is associated with histiocytic necrotizing lymphadenitis. It does not show epithelioid granulomatous lesions. Common conditions characterized by epithelioid granuloma formation: Tuberculosis Sarcoidosis (non-caseating granuloma) Brucellosis Cat scratch disease (stellate shaped or round granuloma) Syphilis (gumma ) Lymphogranuloma inguinale Leprosy Inflammatory bowel disease Toxoplasmosis
subject: Pathology

question_text: A pathologist observes the given findings during the examination of a lymph node sample. Which of the following is the least likely cause?
explanation: The given histopathological image of a lymph node shows a non-caseating granuloma. Tuberculosis is least likely as it is commonly associated with caseating granulomas. Non-caseating granulomas can be seen in the following conditions: Leprosy Cat-scratch disease Sarcoidosis Berylliosis Crohn's disease Hypersenitive pneumonitis Foreign body granuloma Q fever Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's). Hodgkin's lymphoma
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Stellate granuloma is seen in :
Sarcoidosis
explanation: Stellate granuloma is seen in cat-scratch disease. It is also known as subacute regional lymphadenitis. It is a bacterial infection caused by Bartonella henselae. It is acquired following contact with infected animals (commonly cats). Regional lymph nodes demonstrate: Follicular hyperplasia with circumscribed central stellate necrosis with neutrophils Surrounded by palisading histiocytes (suppurative granulomas) Sinuses packed with monocytoid B cells Usually, there are no perifollicular and intrafollicular epithelioid cells Tissue Repair
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following structures lack labile cells?
explanation: The liver contains stable cells, not labile cells. Based on the regenerative capacity of cells, tissues are classified into 3 types: Labile tissues Stable tissues Permanent tissues Labile cells refer to continuously proliferating cells that are lost and replaced by the maturation of stem cells and the proliferation of these mature cells. Tissues containing these cells can readily regenerate after an injury as long as the pool of stem cells is preserved. Some examples of labile cells include: Hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow Majority of surface epithelia - Stratified squamous epithelia of the skin, oral cavity, vagina, and cervix Cuboidal epithelia of the ducts draining exocrine organs (salivary glands, biliary tract) Columnar epithelium of the GIT, uterus, and fallopian tubes Transitional epithelium of the urinary tract
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following tissues does not consist of stable cells?
explanation: Cardiac muscle does not contain stable cells. It contains permanent cells which are terminally differentiated and non-proliferative. Based on the regenerative capacity of cells, tissues are classified into 3 types: Labile tissues Stable tissues Permanent tissues Stable cells are quiescent (in the G0 stage of the cell cycle) and have only minimal proliferative activity in their normal state. However, they can divide in response to injury or loss of tissue mass. They include the following: Parenchyma of solid tissues (liver, kidney, and pancreas) Endothelial cells Fibroblasts Smooth muscle cells
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following does not contain permanent cells?
explanation: Smooth muscle does not contain permanent cells. It consists of stable cells that are capable of dividing in response to injury or loss of tissue mass. Based on the regenerative capacity of cells, tissues are classified into 3 types: Labile tissues Stable tissues Permanent tissues Permanent cells are those which are considered to be terminally differentiated and non-proliferative in postnatal life. In permanent tissues, the repair is typically dominated by scar formation. These cells include: Neurons Cardiac muscle Skeletal muscle - contains satellite cells attached to the endomysial sheath which have some regenerative capacity
subject: Pathology

question_text: Oval cells are seen in which of the following?
explanation: Oval cells refer to stem cells in the liver. They are located in the canals of Hering. Regeneration of the liver occurs by two major mechanisms: Proliferation of remaining hepatocytes - occurs following partial hepatectomy (resection of up to 90% of the liver can be corrected by this mechanism) Repopulation from progenitor cells (oval cells) - occurs following chronic liver injury or inflammation
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding TGF- ?
options: It increases the synthesis of collagen
It increases the degradation of the extracellular matrix
It is involved in the development of fibrosis in solid organs
explanation: TGF- (transforming growth factor- ) decreases the degradation of the extracellular matrix by inhibiting metalloproteinases. It is produced by most cells in granulation tissue, including alternatively activated macrophages. The functions of TGF- include: Stimulates fibroblast migration and proliferation Increases synthesis of collagen and fibronectin (connective tissue proteins) Decreased degradation of ECM by inhibiting metalloproteinases Involved in scar formation after injury Development of fibrosis in lung, liver, and kidneys following chronic inflammation Anti-inflammatory action by inhibiting lymphocyte proliferation and activity
subject: Pathology

question_text: All of the following delay healing except:
explanation: Glucocorticoid excess results in delayed healing, not glucocorticoid deficiency. Various factors affect wound healing including mechanical factors (pressure and torsion and site of injury) and location and extent of the injury. Vitamin C helps in the activation of prolyl and lysyl hydroxylases which help in the hydroxylation of procollagen. As inadequately hydroxylated procollagen is vulnerable to enzymatic degradation, vitamin C plays an essential role in wound healing.

question_text: A 38-year-old man underwent excision of a lipoma. The swelling had been excised with a clear linear incision and was sutured cleanly. In this wound, when would you expect peak neovascularization?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of a clean surgical incision that is sutured is an example of healing by primary intention. In this type of healing, neovascularization reaches its peak by day 5, as granulation tissue fills the incisional space. These new vessels are leaky, allowing the passage of plasma proteins and fluid into the extravascular space. Hence, new granulation tissue is often edematous.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient presented with an abscess on his back. Septic precautions were taken and the abscess was drained. On follow up, a healthy scar was visible. What is the type of collagen seen in the provisional matrix in this type of healing?
explanation: The given scenario is an example of wound healing by secondary intention. The initial provisional matrix in this type of healing is composed of type III collagen, fibrin, and plasma fibronectin. It is later replaced by a matrix composed primarily of type I collagen. This type of healing occurs when cell or tissue loss is more extensive, such as in large wounds, abscesses, ulceration, and ischemic necrosis in parenchymal organs. The repair process involves a combination of regeneration and scarring.
subject: Pathology

question_text: The accumulation of excessive amounts of collagen during repair may give rise to which of the following?
explanation: Accumulation of excessive amounts of collagen during repair leads to the formation of hypertrophic scar. When this scar tissue grows beyond the boundaries of the original wound, it is known as a keloid. Collagen plays a role in the normal adherence of tissue edges at the site of injury. Contraction in the size of a wound is an important part of the normal healing process. An exaggeration of this process gives rise to contractures. They are particularly prone to develop on the palms, soles, anterior thorax and are commonly seen after serious burns. Inadequate formation of granulation tissue or formation of a scar leads to wound dehiscence and ulceration. The following image shows a hypertrophic scar.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 24-year-old man comes with the following findings. He says that he cut himself while shaving 3 months back. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The history of a shaving cut and the image showing a large area of scar tissue are suggestive of a keloid. A keloid refers to excess accumulation of collagen at the scar site with growth of the scar tissue beyond the boundaries of the original wound. It does not regress. Option A: Exuberant granulation or proud flesh refers to the protrusion of excessive amounts of granulation tissue above the level of the surrounding skin. This blocks re-epithelialization. Option B: The accumulation of excessive amounts of collagen may give rise to a raised scar known as a hypertrophic scar. However, it remains within the boundaries of the original scar. Option D: Pyogenic granuloma is a benign, vascular tumor.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient presented to the OPD with the following finding on her finger. She says that she cut her finger while chopping vegetables 2 weeks ago. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario and clinical findings are suggestive of exuberant granulation. It is a deviation in wound healing where excessive amounts of granulation tissue protrude above the level of the surrounding skin and blocks re-epithelialization. It is also known as proud flesh.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
In postoperative patients, what is the strength of the incision site in comparison with normal skin following suture removal at the end of 1 week?
10
explanation: When sutures are removed, usually at 1 week, the wound strength is approximately 10% of that of normal skin. This increases rapidly over the next 4 weeks. Wound strength reaches approximately 70 to 80% of normal by 3 months. Beyond this, there is not much improvement. Disorders of Hemodynamics and Hemostasis
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient presented with the following finding. Which of the following can cause this condition?
explanation: The finding seen in the given image is pitting edema. Edema can be caused by elevated hydrostatic pressure and reduced colloid osmotic pressure. Under normal circumstances, there is little net movement of fluid out of vessels due to the balance of: Vascular hydrostatic pressure which has the tendency to push water and salts out of capillarie into the interstitial space Plasma osmotic pressure or colloid oncotic pressure which has a tendency to pull water and salt back into vessels. The pressure dynamics seen inside a capillary is given below. options: It is a non-inflammatory edema or effusion
It is a protein-poor and cell-poor fluid
It has a specific gravity of less than 1.012
It is caused by increased vascular permeability
explanation: Transudate results from increased fluid pressures or diminished oncotic forces in the plasma and is not due to increased vascular permeability.
