question_text: A patient is suspected to have megaloblastic anaemia. Which of the following will not be helpful in differentiating vitamin B12 deficiency from folate deficiency?
explanation: Increased serum homocysteine levels are common to both vitamin B12 deficiency and folate deficiency. Hence, it cannot be used to differentiate between them.

question_text: You are examining the peripheral smear of a patient with anaemia and see the following finding. Name the finding and its pathogenesis.
options: Howell Jolly body - ineffective RBC enucleation
explanation: The marked structure in this peripheral smear showing figure of 8 appearance is a Cabot ring. They are RBC inclusion bodies seen in conditions due to ineffective erythropoiesis. It is considered a remnant of microtubules during cell division. Cabot rings can be seen in the following conditions: Megaloblastic anaemia Post-splenectomy patients Lead poisoning Hemolytic anemias Option A: Heinz bodies are due to oxidative damage, seen in G6PD deficiency. Option B: Basophilic stippling is due to ribosomal precipitation, seen in heavy metal poisoning, thalassemia and sickle cell disease. Option D: Howell Jolly bodies are due to ineffective RBC enucleation, characteristic of asplenia.

question_text: Schilling's test can be used for all the following except
options: To differentiate between vitamin B12 and folate deficiency
To identify the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
To identify the extent of megaloblastic anaemia
explanation: Schilling test cannot identify the extent of megaloblastic anaemia.

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the antibodies of pernicious anaemia?
options: Type I antibodies are found in both plasma and gastric juice
Type I antibody blocks the binding of vitamin B12 to intrinsic factor
Type II antibodies prevent the binding of the IF-B12 complex to ileal receptors
Type III antibodies are against haptocorrin
explanation: Type III antibodies are not against haptocorrin. They recognize the  and  subunits of the gastric proton pumps. Pernicious anaemia is a specific form of megaloblastic anaemia caused by autoimmune gastritis. It impairs the production of intrinsic factor, which is required for vitamin B12 uptake from the gut. Types of antibodies in pernicious anaemia are: Type I antibodies - block the binding of vitamin B12 to intrinsic factor. They are found in both plasma and gastric juice Type II antibodies - prevent binding of the intrinsic factor-vitamin B12 (IF-B12) complex to its ileal receptor Type III antibodies - recognize the  and  subunits of the gastric proton pump of parietal cells
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 53-year-old woman presents with complaints of light-headedness every time she stands up. She is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis on methotrexate. On examination, she has pallor and brittle nails. Which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?
options: Serum iron and tissue iron levels are norma
Anemia can be normocytic and normochromic
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of anaemia of chronic diseases (ACD). In this condition, the anaemia initially can be normocytic normochromic. ACD occurs in the setting of persistent systemic inflammation. It is associated with Low serum iron Reduced total iron-binding capacity Abundant stored iron in tissue macrophages Inflammatory mediators like IL-6 stimulate an increase in the production of hepcidin. This inhibits ferroportin function in the macrophages and reduces the transfer of iron from the storage pool to developing erythroid precursors in the marrow. As a result, erythroid precursors are starved for iron despite the availability of plenty of iron in tissue macrophages.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Identify the cell in the given peripheral blood smear and the likely diagnosis.
options: Acanthocyte in anemia of renal disease
Acanthocyte in anemia of liver disease
Echinocyte in anemia of renal disease
Echinocyte in anemia of liver disease
explanation: Acanthocyte or spur cells are seen in anaemia of liver disease. These cells are characterized by only a few spicules of varying sizes that project from the cell surface at irregular intervals. Conditions where acanthocytes can be seen include: Severe liver disease Abetalipoproteinemia Post splenectomy Hyposplenism The image given below shows a peripheral smear with acanthoctye. Echinocytes or burr cells are seen in anaemia of renal disease. These cells are characterized by smaller, regularly spaced projections, smoothly rounded crenulations which are uniform in shape and distribution compared to acanthocytes. Conditions where echinocytes can be seen include: Anaemia of renal disease (uremia) In premature infants, after exchange transfusion Storage artefact The image given below shows a peripheral smear with echinocytes.

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of aplastic anemia?
explanation: From the given options, the most common cause of aplastic anemia is drugs. question_text: A 35-year-old woman presents with progressive weakness and fatigue. Her hemogram is given below. What is the best investigation to arrive at the diagnosis?
explanation: The given hemogram is suggestive of pancytopenia. Cause of pancytopenia can be aplastic anaemia (hypocellular bone marrow) or myeloid neoplasms (hypercellular bone marrow). Hence, the best investigation is bone marrow biopsy to differentiate between them. Findings in bone marrow biopsy in aplastic anaemia: Markedly hypocellular bone marrow largely devoid of hematopoietic cells Abundant fat cells Fibrous stroma, scattered lymphocytes, and plasma cells Bone marrow aspiration often yields a dry tap, so biopsy is preferred.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Bone marrow biopsy of a patient with pancytopenia is given below. What is the most common infectious cause of this condition?
explanation: The given bone marrow biopsy shows a hypocellular bone marrow with abundant fat cells which is suggestive of aplastic anaemia. In this condition, the most common infectious cause is viral hepatitis of the non-A, Non-B, Non-C, and Non-G type. The images given below show the normal and hypocellular bone marrow. Note- Viral hepatitis, parvovirus B19, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), cytomegalovirus and Epstein-Barr virus can cause aplastic anemia. Viral hepatitis is however the most common cause.

question_text: Which of the following is likely to develop in a patient with aplastic anaemia?
explanation: Aplastic anaemia can transform into both acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).

question_text: Which of the following causes pure red cell aplasia?
explanation: Causes of pure red cell aplasia include: Neoplasms - thymomas and large granular lymphocytic leukemia Drug exposure - phenytoin, azathioprine and isoniazid Auto-immune disorders - neutralizing antibodies against erythropoietin Parvovirus infection Hereditary - Diamond Blackfan syndrome
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common cause of myelophthisic anaemia?
explanation: The most common cause of myelophthisic anaemia is metastatic cancer from the breast, lung, and prostate. Myelophthisic anaemia describes a form of marrow failure in which space-occupying lesions replace normal marrow elements. Causes include: Metastatic cancer Granulomatous diseases Myeloproliferative neoplasms. This leads to the release of nucleated erythroid precursors and immature granulocytic forms into peripheral blood (leukoerythroblastosis) and tear-drop shaped red cells. The image given below shows a peripheral smear with teardrop cells.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 70-year-old man presents with progressive weakness and chronic fatigue. Physical examination reveals a hard nodule of about 1cm in the prostate. His lab reports reveal low Hb and elevated PSA. Peripheral blood smear shows a normocytic normochromic picture. There are some occasional myelocytes, a few tear-drop cells and 2 nucleated RBCs per 100 white
cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myelophthisic anaemia. Prostatic mass with elevated PSA and age suggestive of prostatic carcinoma, which could be the likely cause in this case. It is a form of marrow failure in which space-occupying lesions replace normal marrow elements. The most common cause is metastatic cancer from the breast, lung, and prostate. Lab findings of myelophthisic anaemia include: Myelocytes + nucleated RBCs = leukoerythroblastic image Presence of tear-drop cells
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 52-year-old male patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils and an endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is likely to be seen this patient?
Vitamin B12 deficiency
explanation: The given findings are suggestive of pernicious anemia, which is associated with atrophic gastritis and vitamin B12 deficiency. Anemic patient with a peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils are important characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia. Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency are the main causes of megaloblastic anemia. Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies which impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF). This is required for the uptake of vitamin B12. There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include: Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intinsic factor (IF). Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors. Autoantibody type III acts against the  and  subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factor. These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells. Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

question_text: Enzyme deficiency in which of the following pathways can cause hemolysis?
explanation: Enzyme deficiency in the glycolytic pathway can cause hemolysis. The following enzyme deficiencies can cause hemolysis: In the glycolytic pathway: Pyruvate kinase deficiency Hexokinase deficiency In the HMP shunt pathway: G6PD deficiency Glutathione synthetase deficiency Note: Orotic aciduria causes megaloblastic anaemia.

question_text: What is the normal reticulocyte count?
explanation: Normal reticulocyte count is 0.5–1.5% of total red cells. Causes of increased reticulocyte count: Hemolytic anaemia Acute and chronic blood lo Causes of decreased reticulocyte count: Iron deficiency anaemia Megaloblastic anaemia Aplastic anaemia Anaemia of chronic disease Myelodysplastic syndrome
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about reticulocytes?
options: They are larger in size than red cell
explanation: Reticulocytes are red cell precursors, which are non-nucleated. They have blue-red polychromatophilic cytoplasm due to the presence of a reticular (mesh-like) network of ribosomal RNA. They can be visualized using supravital stains like methylene blue and brilliant cresyl blue, which stain the ribosomal RNA. Reticulocytosis (increased reticulocytes) indicates effective erythropoiesis i.e. good bone marrow response to anaemia. It is seen in: Hemolytic anaemia Acute blood lo Reticulocytopenia (decreased reticulocytes) indicates ineffective erythropoiesis i.e. poor bone marrow response to anaemia. It is seen in: Chemotherapy Aplastic anaemia Bone marrow malignancy Anaemia of chronic disease Iron-deficiency anaemia Vitamin B12 and folate deficiency The peripheral smear shows reticulocytosis and spherocytosis seen in non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 25-year-old woman had severe blood loss during delivery 2-days ago. Her current hemoglobin is 5 gm/dL and reticulocyte count is 9%. What is her corrected reticulocyte count?
explanation: In the given scenario, the corrected reticulocyte count is 3. It is given by the following formula: Corrected reticulocyte count = Reticulocyte count × (patient's hemoglobin or hematocrit  standard hemoglobin or hematocrit) So, in this case, the corrected reticulocyte count = 9×5/15 = 9/3 = 3 This formula corrects for hemoglobin. It will show you if the patient is making enough reticulocytes for the degree of anemia present. As the hemoglobin drops, reticulocytes increase from the normal range of 0.5–2.0%. The standard reference range of hemoglobin concentration in females is 12-15 g/dl. Accordingly, in this scenario, corrected reticulocyte count would range between 3-3.75%. So, the best answer to this question remains option C. Absolute reticulocyte count is the percentage of red cells that are reticulocytes (normal is about 0.5 – 2.0%). However, it does not reflect the fact that as the hemoglobin drops, there should be more reticulocytes, percentage-wise (for example, at a hemoglobin of 5, you should have a much higher percentage of reticulocytes than you should at a hemoglobin of 10). To take this into account, we use corrected reticulocyte count. Reticulocyte Index = Corrected reticulocyte count / maturation factor This corrects for the longer life span of prematurely released reticulocytes in the blood which is a phenomenon of increased red blood cell production. Hematocrit Maturation fact or  35% 1.0 35% > Hct  25% 1.5 25% > Hct  20% 2.0 < 20% 2.5
subject: Pathology

question_text: In a patient with microcytic hypochromic anaemia, red cell distribution width was measured. What is this parameter used to identify?
explanation: Red cell distribution width (RDW) deals with anisocytosis of RBCs. It refers to the unequal size of the RBCs. Normal values are: RDW-SD (Standard deviation) - 39-46 fL RDW-CV (Coefficient of variation) - 11.6-14.6% RDW is of great use in two clinical situations. They are: To differentiate between thalassemia and iron deficiency anaemia (IDA) Thalassemia - the RBCs are small (low MCV) and of uniform size (normal RDW) IDA - the RBCs are small (low MCV) but vary greatly in size (high RDW). To diagnose dimorphic anaemia (anaemia due to both iron and vitamin B12 deficiency) High RDW Normal MCV
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not increased in intravascular hemolysis?
explanation: Haptoglobin is decreased in intravascular hemolysis. Types of hemolysis based on location: Intravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs mainly within the blood vessel Extravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs via macrophages of the reticuloendothelial ystem in the spleen, liver, bone marrow, and lymph node Features of intravascular hemolysis are: Decreased haptoglobin Increased lactate dehydrogenase Hemoglobinemia Hemoglobinuria Hemosiderinuria Methemoglobinemia Methemoglobinuria Indirect hyperbilirubinemia
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following does not cause intravascular hemolysis?
explanation: Thalassemia causes extravascular hemolysis. Causes of intravascular hemolysis: Mechanical injury Trauma caused by cardiac valve Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura ) Repetitive physical trauma Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction) Hemolytic disease of the newborn Transfusion reaction Drug-induced Infections of red blood cell Malaria Babesiosi Exogenous toxic factors - Clostridial sepsi Causes of extravascular hemolysis: Hereditary spherocytosi Thalassemia Sickle cell anaemia Causes of both intravascular and extravascular: G6PD deficiency Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following pairs of mutation and involved genes describes paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
explanation: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a disease that results from acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA). This gene codes for an enzyme that is essential for the synthesis of certain membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins. It is the only hemolytic anaemia caused by an acquired genetic defect. PNH blood cells are deficient in 3 GPI-linked proteins that regulate complement activity: Decay Accelerating Factor or CD55 Membrane Inhibitor of Reactive Lysis or CD59 C˜-binding protein CD59, a potent inhibitor of C3 convertase, prevents the spontaneous activation of the alternative complement pathway. Red cells deficient in these GPI-linked factors are abnormally susceptible to lysis or injury by C5b-C9 membrane attack complex of the complement system.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following cells are involved in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
explanation: All three cell lines, RBCs, WBCs, and platelets are affected in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). PNH occurs from acquired mutations in the gene PIGA which affect GPI-linked proteins. These causative mutations occur in a hematopoietic stem cell. Hence, all of its clonal progeny, i.e., red cells, white cells, and platelets, are deficient in GPI-linked proteins. Clinical features of PNH include: Intravascular hemoglobinuria - cola-colored urine Pancytopenia + hypercellular bone marrow Thrombosis (if hepatic vein involved  Budd–Chiari syndrome)
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 23-year-old man with pancytopenia is suspected to have PNH. Which of the following findings is inconsistent with this condition?
explanation: In PNH, the leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is decreased. Alkaline phosphatase activity is found predominantly in mature segmented neutrophils. LAP score is obtained by assessing the staining intensity in 100 consecutive neutrophils, with each neutrophil scored on a scale of 1–4. Conditions that result in an increase in leukocytes in all stages of maturity will reflect a corresponding increase in LAP. Increased LAP Decreased LAP Leukemoid reactionPregnanc yPolycythemia veraHodgkin's disease CMLPNHSickle cell ane mia

question_text: Which of the following is most likely the cause of death in a patient with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
explanation: Among the following, Budd-Chiari Syndrome is the most likely the cause of death in a patient with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). Thrombosis (particularly venous thrombosis) is the leading cause of disease-related death in patients with PNH. 40% of PNH patients suffer from venous thrombosis, which commonly affects the hepatic, portal, or cerebral veins. The pathophysiology of thrombosis in PNH is not completely understood, but two main mechanisms may be responsible: Nitric oxide (NO) is absorbed by free hemoglobin (which is released during hemolysis). Endothelial damage caused by the C5-9 membrane attack complex (due to deficiency of CD59).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Flow cytometric analysis in a patient with pancytopenia shows a deficiency of GPI-linked proteins on blood cells. Which of the following is not a complication of this condition?
explanation: The deficiency of GPI linked proteins on blood cells is seen in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). Cryoglobulinemia is not a complication of this condition. Thrombosis is the leading cause of disease-related death in individuals with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). About 5% to 10% of patients eventually develop acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or myelodysplastic syndrome.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the gold standard for the diagnosis of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
explanation: The gold standard for the diagnosis of PNH is flow cytometry. It provides a sensitive means for detecting red cells that are deficient in GPI-linked proteins such as CD59. Investigations in PNH include: Flow cytometry (gold standard) - deficiency of CD59 and CD55 Ham test (acidified serum lysis) - lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH due to complement fixation Bone marrow biopsy - Hypercellularity with erythroid hyperplasia is seen in classical presentation Patients who develop pancytopenia will have hypocellular bone marrow Imaging - to evaluate venous thrombosi
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 37-year-old man presents with a history of dark coloured urine in the morning for 2 months. His lab investigations and flow cytometry are given below. What is the curative therapy for this condition?

Eculizumab
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of PNH (paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria). The curative therapy for this condition is a hematopoietic stem cell transplant. Pancytopenia is seen in this condition. Flow cytometry shows 2 populations of red cells: Marked red in the left lower quadrant - deficient in both CD55 and CD59, characteristic of PNH. Marked black in the right upper quadrant - CD55+ and CD59+ cells from the residual normal hematopoietic cell Eculizumab is a monoclonal antibody that can be used in PNH. It prevents the conversion of C5 to C5a and reduces hemolysis. Immunosuppressive drugs are sometimes beneficial for those with evidence of marrow aplasia. Note: FDA has approved the following drugs for treatment of adults with PNH: Ravulizumab injection, a long-acting C-5 complement inhibitor Pegcetacoplan, which acts by binding to complement protein C3 and increasing hemoglobin concentration Extravascular Hemolysis
subject: Pathology

explanation: The most common types of mutations causing thalassemia are: The different splicing mutations are: Mutations that destroy the normal RNA splice junctions - completely prevent the production of normal  -globin mRNA resulting in  0-thalassemia Mutations that create an ectopic splice site within an intron with normal splice regions - some normal  -globin mRNA is made resulting in  + thalassemia There are two subtypes of chain terminator mutations: New stop codon within an exon Small insertions or deletions that shift the mRNA reading frame Thalassemia Most common mut ation  + thalasse mia Splicing mutation  0thalassem ia Terminator mutati on  thalassemi a Gene deletion

question_text: Which chromosome is affected in alpha-thalassemia?
explanation: Chromosome 16 contains an identical pair of -globin genes which is affected in alpha-thalassemia. This condition is due to decreased synthesis of alpha chains. The two  chains are encoded by a single  -globin gene on chromosome 11.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding -thalassemia?
options: Free  and  chains are more soluble than free  chain
 chains are coded by a pair of gene
Hb Barts is the most severe form
explanation:  chains are coded by 4 genes i.e. two pairs of genes located on chromosome 16. Free  and  chains are more soluble than free  chains. They also form more stable homotetramers. Hence, hemolysis and dyserythropoiesis in  thalassemia are less severe when compared to  thalassemia. In HbH disease, excess  -globin chains form  4 tetramers. They are seen in older children with -thalassemia. Hydrops fetalis is the most severe form of -thalassemia. It is caused by the deletion of all four -globin genes. This leads to excess -globin chains forming -globin tetramers (hemoglobin Barts).
subject: Pathology

question_text: A woman with an obstetric score of G3P2A0L0, in a consanguinous marriage, delivered a hydropic stillborn at 32 weeks of gestation. Further evaluation revealed the presence of Hb Barts in the fetal blood. Which of the following globin chains tetramer is found in thi condition?
explanation: Hb Barts is a tetramer of -globin chains (4). This type of hemoglobin is seen in newborns with the most severe form of -thalassemia and results in hemoglobin Barts hydrops fetalis. There is no production of  chains. Hb Barts has a higher affinity for oxygen. This leads to intrauterine hypoxia, eventually leading to stillbirth. The image given below shows (a) immature red cell precursors in peripheral smear and (b) stillborn hydropic infant in Hb Barts hydrops syndrome. In HbH disease, excess  -globin chains form  4 tetramers. They are seen in older children with -thalassemia.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 26-year-old Chinese translator presents with fever, jaundice and splenomegaly. His Hb is 6 g% and peripheral smear with brilliant cresyl blue is given below. Which of the following globin chains would you expect to see in this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of extravascular hemolysis (jaundice and splenomegaly) and peripheral smear showing golf ball cells is suggestive of HBH disease. It is a type of  thalassemia where the HbH is composed of tetramers of  chains ( 4). Hb-H disease is one type of alpha-thalassaemia with inactivation of 3 of the 4 alleles. It is more common in the Asian population. It usually manifests in the 1st year of life. It causes acute episodes of hemolysis when triggered by infections or oxidant drugs. The decreased  chain production leads to a relative excess of  chains. This leads to the formation of HbH which has a high affinity for oxygen. Such RBCs are more prone to oxidation which causes precipitation of HbH to form golf ball inclusion bodies. This leads to increased sequestration and phagocytosis in the spleen.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient has a HbA2 of 3% and HbF of 97%. A peripheral blood smear is taken. Which of the following blood pictures will be seen in this patient?
explanation: The presence of HbA2 3% and HbF 97% indicates that it is a case of thalassemia major. In thalassemia major, hematological findings in image 1 showing poikilocytes and image 3 showing target cells are seen. Image 2 showing Howell Jolly bodies are seen in post-splenectomy thalassemia patients and not in this case. Hematological findings in thalassemia major include the following: Anisopoikilocytosi Target cells (codocytes) Nucleated RBC’ Dacrocyte Basophilic stippling Polychromatophilic cell

question_text: The following test was performed with blood sample from a patient with anaemia. What is this test used for?
explanation: The given image shows NESTROFT i.e. Naked Eye Single Tube Red cell Osmotic Fragility test. It is a very useful screening tool for thalassemia, particularly in poor resource settings. The principle is based on the decreased osmotic fragility of red cells in thalassemia. It is performed as follows: Mix EDTA blood and 0.36% buffered saline solution. Shake the tube and leave it at room temperature for 30 minutes. Shake the tube again and immediately hold the tube in front of a piece of paper with text or lines. The image given below shows the NESTROFT. question_text: A couple with a family history of thalassemia comes for genetic counselling. Their HPLC reports are given below. What is the risk of their offspring having thalassemia major?
explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the risk of their offspring having thalassemia major is 0%. From the given HPLC reports, the husband is normal (normal value of HbA2 is 2.5%±0.3%) and the wife has  thalassemia minor (HbA2 level 4.9%). This disease is transmitted with an autosomal recessive inheritance. Hence, the chance of their offspring having full blown thalassemia is zero. In  thalassemia minor, the Hb A2 levels are increased to 4–8%. This is due to an elevated ratio of  chain to  chain synthesis. Hb F levels are generally normal or slightly increased. Note: Increased HbF (diagnostic) and normal HbA2 levels are features of thalassemia major.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 25-year old man presents with chronic anemia and gall stones. His family history i ignificant for a similar illness. His peripheral blood smear is given below. What is the mode of the inheritance of the given clinical condition?
explanation: The given peripheral smear showing spherocytes, along with the history, is suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis. Inheritance of this condition is mainly autosomal dominant. Hereditary spherocytosis is a structural RBC disorder making the RBCs more spheroid. The RBCs are less deformable and more vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction. This decreases the lifespan of RBCs.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common protein deficiency associated with hereditary spherocytosis?
explanation: Ankyrin is the most common protein deficiency associated with hereditary spherocytosis (HS). The chief protein component of the RBC membrane skeleton is spectrin. It consists of two polypeptide chains, alpha and beta. These dimers associate with actin oligomers. The spectrin–actin skeleton is then connected to the cell membrane by two distinct interactions. Ankyrin and band 4.2 binds spectrin to the transmembrane ion transporter, band 3 Protein 4.1 binds the tail of spectrin to the transmembrane protein glycophorin A Defect in any of the components of the red cell membrane skeleton results in hereditary spherocytosis. The image given below shows the pathogenesis of this condition. Note: Few one-liners on membrane skeleton - Most abundant integral proteins - glycophorin, band 3 Responsible for biconcave shape of RBC - spectrin Most severe deficiency - spectrin Hereditary elliptocytosis is due to deficiency of alpha spectrin Mushroom cells appearance due to deficiency of band 3 Never involved in HS - glycophorin
subject: Pathology

question_text: The peripheral smear of a patient with anaemia, jaundice and splenomegaly shows pincer cells. Which protein deficiency is responsible for this finding?
explanation: Pincer cell or mushroom cell is seen in hereditary spherocytosis associated with deficiency of cytoskeletal protein band 3.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following features would you least expect to see in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis?
explanation: Hemoglobinuria is not seen in hereditary spherocytosis where extravascular hemolysis occurs. It is a feature of intravascular hemolysis. Pigment gallstones, pallor and splenomegaly can be seen in this condition. Cinical features of extravascular hemolysis include: Anaemia Jaundice Splenomegaly Causes of extravascular hemolysis: Hereditary spherocytosi Thalassemia Sickle cell anaemia Note: G6PD deficiency and autoimmune hemolytic anaemia can cause both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the life span of affected red cells in patients with hereditary spherocytosis?
explanation: The life span of affected red cells in hereditary spherocytosis is 10 to 20 days. The normal life span of RBC is 120 days.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In a patient with hereditary spherocytosis, MCHC of 38 g/dL was noted. What could be the probable reason for this finding?
explanation: Increased MCHC in hereditary spherocytosis is due to dehydration caused by the loss of K+ and H2O. MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) is given by the formula hemoglobin / PCV (g/dL). It indicates the amount of hemoglobin per unit volume. Note: MCV (mean corpuscular volume) is given by the formula PCV / RBC (fL). It denotes the size of the RBCs. MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) is given by the formula hemoglobin / RBC (pg). It quantifies the hemoglobin in the RBCs.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In the following osmotic fragility curve, A occurs in .
explanation: Osmotic fragility curve shifts to the right in hereditary spherocytosis. In hereditary spherocytosis, the cells are spherocytic in normal plasma (0.9% NaCl) and hemolyse readily at higher concentrations than normal discoid red cells do, hence shifting the curve to the right. Osmotic fragility is the susceptibility of the RBC to rupture under osmotic stress. In hypotonic solutions, RBCs swell to become spherical and eventually hemolyse. In the graph, the x-axis represents the saline concentration while the y-axis represents the percentage of red cells that have undergone hemolysis. When osmotic fragility is normal, red cells begin to hemolyse at 0.5% saline, with 50% of hemolysis occuring at 0.40-0.42% saline and complete hemolysis occuring at 0.35% saline as represented in the curve. In thalassemia and sickle cell anemia on the other hand, the cells are resistant to hemolysis and don’t hemolyse unless the concentration of saline is very low, shifting the graph to the left.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 7-year-old girl presents with fever and jaundice for 5 days. On examination, splenomegaly is noted. Her lab reports are given below. What is the likely trigger to have caused thi condition?
explanation: The given hemogram showing pancytopenia and spherocytes in peripheral smear is suggestive of aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis. It is usually triggered by parvovirus infection. Parvovirus infects and kills the red cell precursors. This creates a transient arrest of erythropoiesis i.e. aplastic crisis as the life span of RBCs are shortened. The immune response clears the virus in 1-2 weeks. Blood transfusions may be necessary during acute phases of the infection. This crisis can also occur in other hemolytic anaemias.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which amino acid lies at the sixth position of the beta chain of hemoglobin?
explanation: Glutamate lies at the 6th position of the beta chain of hemoglobin. Sickle-cell disease is caused by a point mutation in the sixth codon of  -globin. This leads to the replacement of a glutamate residue with a valine residue.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A blood sample is taken from a suspected case of sickle cell anaemia. Which of the following properties can be used to differentiate HbS from HbA?
explanation: Solubility can be used to differentiate as HbS is less soluble than HbA. The function, stability and affinity of HbS are similar to that of HbA. In HbS, glutamic acid, which is a polar amino acid, is replaced by a non-polar amino acid valine at the 6th position. HbS molecules have the tendency to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. This process converts the red cell cytosol from a free-flowing liquid into a viscous gel. This causes a change in the solubility of the hemoglobin. The major pathologic manifestations of decreased solubility and polymerisation of HbS are chronic hemolysis, microvascular occlusions, and tissue damage.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 35-year-old man was diagnosed to have heterozygous sickle cell trait. What will be the approximate percentage of HbS in this patient?
explanation: In heterozygotes with sickle-cell trait, about 40% of the hemoglobin is HbS. The rest of hemoglobin (60%) is HbA. Sickle cell trait is a largely asymptomatic condition characterised by heterozygosity seen for HbS (sickle hemoglobin). As only a fraction of the Hb are HbS, polymerization leading to sickling only occurs in severe and prolonged hypoxia. Offsprings of 2 heterozygotes have a 1 in 4 chance of having sickle cell disease. In HbSC heterozygotes, HbS is 50% and HbC is 50%.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Patients with which of the following combinations of beta-globin chains tend to have a more severe sickle cell disease?
explanation: Among the given options, the heterozygous combination of HbS and HbC causes a more severe form of the disease. Overall severity is more in homozygous HbS. Severity sequence is HbSS > HbSC > HbSA > HbSF. In HbC, lysine is substituted for glutamate in the sixth amino acid residue of  -globin. The percentage of HbS is 50% in HbSC red cells and 40% in HbAS cells. Moreover, HbSC cells tend to lose salt and water and become dehydrated, which increases the intracellular concentration of HbS. Both of these factors increase the tendency for HbS to polymerize. As a result, individuals who are compound heterozygotes for HbS and HbC, have symptomatic sickling disorder (termed HbSC disease). However, it is milder than sickle cell disease (HbSS). HbF inhibits the polymerization of HbS even more than HbA. Hence, infants do not become symptomatic until they reach 5 or 6 months of age when the level of HbF normally falls.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In patients with sickle cell anaemia, which of the following factors promote sickling of RBC?
explanation: HbC promotes the sickling of RBC, whereas HbF opposes it. Factors that promote sickling are: Increased MCHC Hb C Acidic pH Hypoxia HbF has a high affinity for oxygen than other hemoglobins. Hence, high oxygen content prevents sickling. HbF inhibits the polymerization of HbS. So the infants do not become symptomatic until they reach 5 or 6 months of age when the level of HbF normally falls.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following reagents is used for sickling test?
explanation: The reagent used for the sickling test is sodium metabisulfite. It is an oxygen-consuming reagent, which induces the sickling of red cells in the presence of HbS. Sickling test with sodium metabisulfite is used as a screening test for sickle cell anaemia.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 12-year-old girl presents with fever and severe pain in her hands and feet. There is no history of trauma. Her lab reports reveal Hb to be 8.2 g/dL and peripheral smear as shown below. Which of the following parasitic infections is this condition protective against?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sickle cell anaemia. HbS gives protection against Plasmodium falciparum malaria. Hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of bones of hands and feet is a severe acute inflammatory response seen in sickle cell anaemia. It is caused by vaso-occlusive episodes leading to ischemia and finally infarction of the distal portions of the extremities. Sickle cells impair the formation of membrane knobs containing a protein made by P. falciparum called PfEMP-1. This decreases the adherence of infected red cells to the endothelium. Individuals with sickle cell trait are significantly less likely to have severe disease or to die from malaria. It is because of the increased phagocytosis of sickled cells in the spleen, which keeps the parasite load down. The image given below shows sickle cells seen on peripheral smear in sickle cell anemia.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
What happens to the severity of hemolytic anaemia in concurrent sickle cell anaemia and
-thalassemia?
explanation: The concurrence of sickle cell anaemia and -thalassemia results in less severe hemolytic anaemia. Sickle cell anaemia is caused by point mutations in  globin synthesis leading to defective HbS synthesis. When these RBCs release oxygen, the HbS polymerises leading to membrane distortion Thalassemia is due to germline mutations causing decreased globin chain synthesis ( or  ). Since these diseases have a different pathogenesis, they can occur concurrently. In alpha-thalassemia, the concentration of hemoglobin is decreased. Therefore the concentration of HbS in sickle cell anaemia is also decreased. Since HbS molecules should be close to each other for polymerization to occur. Since there is a decreased concentration of HbS in alpha-thalassemia, the HbS molecules are far apart. So there is a decreased polymerization of HbS and therefore less severity of the disease.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 23-year-old patient with sickle cell anaemia presents with fever and malaise. IgM ELISA confirms a parvovirus B19 infection. Which of the following crises will you expect to see in this patient?
explanation: Aplastic crisis in sickle cell anaemia is caused by parvovirus B19. It is a transient arrest of erythropoiesis, usually triggered by an acute parvovirus infection. Parvovirus infects and kills red cell precursors. It occurs in sickle cell disease and other hemolytic anaemias. Vaso-occlusive crises (pain crises) are episodes of hypoxic injury and infarction that cause severe pain in the affected region. The most commonly involved sites are the bones, lungs, liver, brain, pleen, and penis. Acute chest syndrome is a type of vaso-occlusive crisis involving the lungs. It typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates. Pulmonary inflammation may cause blood flow to become sluggish and “spleenlike,” leading to sickling and vaso-occlusion. Sequestration crises occur in children with intact spleens. Massive entrapment of sickle red cells leads to rapid splenic enlargement, hypovolemia, and sometimes shock. Both sequestration crises and acute chest syndrome may be fatal and sometimes require prompt treatment with exchange transfusions.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
During USG examination in a patient with hemolytic anemia, the spleen was not visualized. There is no past history of trauma or surgery. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Sickle cell anaemia
explanation: Non-visualisation of the spleen on routine USG is suggestive of autosplenectomy, which is seen in sickle cell anemia. Splenomegaly is seen in thalassemia and hereditary spherocytosis. In children with sickle cell anaemia, there is moderate splenomegaly. This is due to red pulp congestion caused by the entrapment of sickled red cells. As age advances, chronic erythrostasis produces hypoxic damage and infarcts. By adulthood, the spleen is reduced to a band of fibrous tissue. This process is called autosplenectomy. G6PD deficiency and Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemias

question_text: A 29-year-old African American man receives primaquine chemoprophylaxis before traveling for a business trip. Four days later, he presents with jaundice and dark urine. Laboratory investigations show anemia, reticulocytosis, and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The peripheral blood smear shows the presence of Heinz bodies. What is the most likely mode of inheritance of the given clinical condition?
explanation: The given clinical history suggestive of hemolysis after the antimalarial (primaquine) and Heinz bodies on PBF, points to a diagnosis of G6PD deficiency (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency). It is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait. G6PD is an enzyme belonging to the hexose monophosphate shunt (HMP) pathway. Deficiency of enzymes of this pathway causes hemolysis as the protective ability of RBCs from oxidative stress is impaired. The image given below shows the Heinz bodies seen on peripheral smear.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common trigger for hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency?
explanation: The most common trigger for hemolysis in G6PD deficiency is infection. Viral hepatitis, pneumonia, and typhoid are the common infections that trigger hemolysis. Episodic hemolysis (both intravascular and extravascular) is seen in G6PD deficiency. It is due to exposures that cause oxidative stress. The triggers include: Infections - oxygen-derived free radicals produced by activated leukocytes Drugs Antimalarials - primaquine and chloroquine Sulfonamides Nitrofurantoin Diet - fava bean
subject: Pathology

question_text: Peripheral smear of a patient with viral hepatitis is given below. Which of the following statements is false about this finding?
options: These are seen in G6PD deficiency
They are due to denaturation of globin chains
They are plucked out by macrophages in the spleen
They do not cause intravascular hemolysis
explanation: The given peripheral smear shows Heinz bodies which are dark stained inclusion bodies in red cells. They can cause intravascular as well as extravascular hemolysis. In G6PD-deficiency, the RBCs are exposed to high levels of oxidants. This causes cross-linking of reactive sulfhydryl groups on globin chains. The globin chains become denatured and form membrane-bound precipitates known as Heinz bodies. These can be detected by supravital staining. Heinz bodies can damage the membrane sufficiently to cause intravascular hemolysis. As RBCs with Heinz bodies pass through the spleen, the macrophages pluck out the Heinz bodies. As a result, some of these partially devoured cells retain an abnormal shape i.e. as if a bite was taken out of them. Such cells are called bite cells. Bite cells are trapped in splenic cords and removed by phagocytes leading to extravascular hemolysis. The images given below show Heinz bodies and bite cells seen in G6PD deficiency.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with G6PD deficiency was suspected to have acute hemolytic episode. Which of the following features would you expect to see in this patient?
explanation: Acute hemolysis in G6PD deficiency is intravascular. This is marked by anaemia, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria. These episodes are self-limited and intermittent. Reticulocytosis occurs during the recovery phase. Hence, features related to chronic hemolysis (e.g., splenomegaly, cholelithiasis) are absent.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 23-year-old food blogger presents with complaints of icterus and abdominal fullness. She returned yesterday from a vacation in Egypt where she tried fava beans. Her peripheral smear is given below. This condition is protective against which of the following malarial parasites?
explanation: The peripheral smear shows RBCs with anisopoikilocytosis with polychromasia and many bite cells (arrows) suggestive of G6PD deficiency. This condition is protective against Plasmodium falciparum malaria. Malarial parasites preferentially invade RBCs which are rich in G6PD. G6PD deficiency causes oxidative stress and hemolysis, preferably in the older RBCs. Reticulocytes and young erythrocytes have much higher G6PD activities and are less susceptible to oxidant damage. P. falciparum can invade erythrocytes of all ages. P. vivax, and P. ovale invade reticulocytes (immature erythrocytes) preferentially. Hence, a low G6PD level in older RBC is protective against P. falciparum malaria. Episodic hemolysis in this condition can be triggered by fava beans which is a staple in Egyptian cuisine. The images given below show Heinz bodies and bite cells seen in G6PD deficiency.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is not true about G6PD-deficiency anemia?
options: Hemolytic episodes occur both intravascularly and extravascularly
G6PD Mediterranean deficiency is the most severe form.
Older RBCs are more prone to hemolysis than younger ones
Hemolysis continues as long as there is exposure to oxidant drugs
explanation: Hemolysis in G6PD-deficiency anemia does not continue for the entire period that the patient takes the offending drug. It stops after a few days. Two variants of G6PD, designated as G6PD– and G6PD Mediterranean, cause most of the clinically significant hemolytic anemias. The half-life of G6PD- is moderately reduced, whereas that of G6PD Mediterranean is markedly reduced; hence, the severity of deficiency is greater with the Mediterranean variant. The most common normal variant is G6PD B. The hemolysis in G6PD deficiency is both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis. The damaged red cells are sequestered in the spleen and killed by macrophages, causing extravascular hemolysis. The oxidative stresses can denature hemoglobin, resulting in intravascular hemolysis. In individuals with G6PD deficiency, acute intravascular hemolysis begins 2 to 3 days after exposure to oxidants. Only older RBCs are at risk for lysis. The hemolytic episode is self-limited because hemolysis stops when only younger G6PD-replete red cells remain, even if the patient continues to take the offending drug.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What class of antibodies are involved in the most common form of immunohemolytic anaemia?
explanation: Warm antibody type is the most common form of immunohemolytic anaemia. Most of the causative antibodies in this condition belong to the IgG class. Immunohemolytic anaemia is caused by antibodies that cause premature destruction of the red cells. Based on the temperature at which the different types of antibodies bind to the RBCs stably, they are classified as: Warm antibody type - most common Cold agglutinin type Cold hemolysin type
subject: Pathology

question_text: Match the immunohemolytic anaemia with the type of hemolysis.
explanation: The type of hemolysis seen in the different immunohemolytic anemia are: Autoimmune hemolytic anemias (AIHA) cause both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis. In warm antibody type, hemolysis is extravascular. IgG-coated red cells are phagocytosed and destroyed in the spleen. In cold agglutinin type, hemolysis is extravascular and intravascular. In the peripheral vascular bed (low temperature), IgM binds to the red cells. This causes agglutination and complement-fixing. They are unbound when they reach the general circulation. However, the IgM interaction causes deposition of sublytic quantities of C3b. It is an excellent opsonin, which leads to the removal of RBCs by phagocytes in the spleen, liver, and bone marrow. Cold hemolysin type is a rare subtype of AIHA. Hemolysis is intravascular. IgG binds to the P blood group antigen on the red cells, which leads to complement-mediated lysis. Type Hemolysis Warm antibo dy Extravascular Cold agglutini n Extravascular and intravascul ar Cold hemolys in Intravascular
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old woman was brought to the casualty with loss of consciousness. On examination, pallor, icterus and splenomegaly were noted. Her past history was significant for meningitis 2 weeks ago which was treated with iv antibiotics. Lab investigations showed anemia and increased osmotic fragility. Which of the following statements is false regarding the probable diagnosis?
options: Rh blood group complex are involved in the pathogenesis
Direct Coombs agglutination test is diagnostic
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of drug-induced warm antibody type of immunohemolytic anemia. In this condition, primarily extravascular hemolysis is present. LDH may be increased when there is hemolysis. Two different mechanisms for drug-induced immune hemolytic anemias are: Antigenic drugs: Anemia occurs 1-2 weeks after initiation of large IV dose of the offending drug These drugs bind to red cell membrane and are recognised by anti-drug antibodies They can cause both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis E.g. penicillin, cephalosporins, quinidine Tolerance-breaking drugs: Antibodies are produced against red cell antigens, particularly Rh antigens E.g. alpha-methyl dopa
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria?
options: IgG class of antibodies are involved
Antibodies are directed against Rh antigen
It mostly occurs in children following a viral infection
explanation: In paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH), antibodies are directed against the P blood group antigen. PCH is a cold hemolysin type of hemolysis caused by IgG autoantibodies classically. They are also called Donath Landsteiner antibodies and are produced often in response to a viral infection. This antibody is a biphasic hemolysin. i.e., the antibody binds to RBC at colder temperature but hemolysis occurs at core temperature 37°C. This can cause substantial, sometimes fatal, intravascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria. Most cases are seen in children following viral infections and usually recover within 1 month. Immuno-hemolytic anaemias are of 3 types: Antibody ty pe Antigen on the RBC surface Temperature for hemolys is Warm aggluti nin IgG Rh antigen 37°C or higher Cold agglutini n IgM I antigen (adults)i antigen (in fants) 30°C, usually 0-10°C Cold hemolys in IgG P antigen Biphasic hemolysis (37°C)

question_text:
In which of the following conditions is microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia most commonly seen?
Disseminated intravascular coagulation
explanation: Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia is most commonly seen with disseminated intravascular coagulation. It occurs in the following conditions: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS) Malignant hypertension Systemic lupus erythematosus Disseminated cancer A common pathogenic feature in these disorders is a microvascular lesion. Deposition of fibrin and platelets result in luminal narrowing. These vascular changes produce shear stresses. These changes mechanically injure the passing red cells producing schistocytes or helmet cells on the peripheral smear. The image given below shows schistocytes or helmet cells. Platelet Disorders

question_text: Which of the following is the most potent vasoconstrictor?
explanation: The most potent vasoconstrictor is urotensin2 followed by endothelin and angiotensin.

question_text: Which of the following is a component of  granules of platelets?
explanation: Epinephrine is a component of  granules of platelets. The different components of platelet granules are:  granules Fibrinogen Fibronectin PF4 Factor V, VIII PDGF TGF  granules ADP Calcium Serotonin Histamine Epinephrine

question_text: Rees and Ecker diluting fluid is used in
explanation: Rees and Ecker's solution is used as a diluting fluid in the RBC pipette for performing platelet counts. Its composition is: The steps involved in platelet count are: I - Filling the pipette Diluting fluid is drawn to mark 1 of the RBC pipette and expelled Blood is aspirated to 0.5 mark of the RBCs diluting pipette Diluting fluid is aspirated to 101 mark Blood and diluting fluid are mixed mechanically for 5 min II - Filling the counting chamber Allow the counting chamber to stand for 20-30 minutes to allow the platelets to settle. To prevent drying out of the preparation, it should be kept in a moist atmosphere, this is most easily arranged by placing the filled counting chamber in the bottom of a clean Petri dish, alongside which arrange a small piece of cotton wool which has been soaked in water and squeezed out. Petri dish lid is additionally put over the dish. After 20-30minutes, the counting chamber can be removed and carefully transferred to the microscope stage. III - Counting the number of platelets Focus on the surface of the hemocytometer chamber with a high power dry objective. Dim the ight to make the thrombocytes visible, and count all of the thrombocytes in the entire center 1 mm² (erythrocyte counting area) of both sides of the hemocytometer. This gives the number of thrombocytes in 0.2 l of 1: 200 dilution of blood. The number of thrombocytes counted X 1000 = number of thrombocytes/l of undiluted blood. Components Valu e Sodium citrate 3.8 g Formaldehyde (40 %) 0.2 ml Brilliant cresyl blue 0.1 g Distilled water 100 ml

question_text: A 12-year-old girl with dengue hemorrhagic fever is being monitored by measuring platelet count. Spontaneous bleeding is associated with platelet values below /µL.
explanation: Spontaneous bleeding (non-traumatic) is associated with platelet values below 20,000 platelets/µL. It most often involves small vessels. The common sites for such hemorrhages are: Skin Mucosa of gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts Intracranial bleeding - most feared site of bleeding The production of the platelets is regulated by the hormone thrombopoietin produced in the liver. The platelet synthesis is also specifically increased by interleukin 6. The average lifespan of the platelets is 7–10 days. The normal platelet count is 1,50,000 - 4,00,000 /µL.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding functional platelet disorders?
options: Normal platelet count and normal bleeding time
Normal platelet count and increased bleeding time
Decreased platelet count and increased bleeding time
Decreased platelet count and decreased bleeding time
explanation: Functional platelet disorders have normal platelet count and increased bleeding time. Classification of platelet functional disorders: Defect in platelet-vessel wall interaction (disorders of adhesion) Von Willebrand disease - deficiency or defect in plasma vWF Bernard–Soulier syndrome - deficiency or defect in GP Ib IX Defects in platelet-platelet interaction (disorders of aggregation) Congenital afibrinogenemia - deficiency of plasma fibrinogen Glanzmann thrombasthenia - deficiency or defect in GPIIb-IIIa Disorders of platelet secretion and signal transduction Storage pool deficiency - -Granule deficiency and gamma-Granule deficiency Quebec platelet disorder Chediak–Higashi syndrome Gray platelet syndrome Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome Disorders of platelet coagulation-protein interaction Scott syndrome - defect in factor Va-Xa interaction on platelets
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about vonWillebrand factor?
options: Its deficiency can also cause factor VIII defect
Its deficiency may cause defective platelet adhesion
It serves as a carrier for factor VIII
explanation: Von Willebrand factor (vWF) is not synthesized by hepatocytes. They are produced by endothelial cells of liver and megakaryocytes. It is also found in: Platelet granules - lesser compared to endothelial cells Endothelial cells within cytoplasmic vesicles called Weibel-Palade bodies Subendothelium - binds to collagen It mediates the adhesion of platelets to sites of vascular injury (subendothelium). It links the exposed collagen to platelets. It facilitates platelet to platelet interaction and also stabilizes the hemostatic plug against shear forces. It is a carrier protein for factor VIII and also protects it from proteolytic degradation and stabilizes it. The half-life of factor VIII is about 2.4 hours when free and 12 hours when bound to vWF in the circulation. Since vWF stabilizes factor VIII, a deficiency of vWF gives rise to a secondary decrease in factor VIII levels. This may be reflected by a prolongation of the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) in von Willebrand disease types 1 and 3.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 24-year-old woman is found to have uncontrolled bleeding after a minor cut injury. Her lab investigations are given below. Which of the following statements are false about her condition?
options: Type 3 is inherited as autosomal dominant
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of von Willebrand disease (vWD). Type 3 vWD is inherited as an autosomal recessive disease. The characteristics of different subtypes of vWD are: Type 1 is the most common subtype of vWD. In Type 2, vWF is expressed in normal amounts, but missense mutations are present that lead to defective multimer assembly. This type has several subtypes, of which type 2A is the most common. Laboratory findings in vWD: Prolonged bleeding time Normal platelet count Hess test - positive tourniquet test due to defective platelet adhesion Ristocetin-induced aggregation - defective and diagnostic of this disease Platelet aggregation with ADP, collagen, and thrombin - norma Increased aPTT Though the synthesis of factor VIII remains normal, the half-life of VIII in plasma decreases due to reduced vWF (carrier) levels. This leads to secondary VIIIC deficiency in plasma. So, the intrinsic pathway of coagulation is affected. Hence, aPTT is increased in these patients. question_text: Which of the following occurs due to a defect in  granules of the platelets?
explanation: Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome occurs due to a defect in platelet  granules. Platelet granules disorders include: Gray platelet syndrome - involves  granules and characterized by thrombocytopenia with large platelets that appear pale on the peripheral smear (due to deficiency of the  granules) Quebec platelet syndrome - defect in  granules Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome - defect in  granules and characterized by hypopigmentation and bleeding manifestation Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome - mutations in the WASp gene expressed in the X chromosome and characterized by microthrombocytopenia, eczema, recurrent infections

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about Bernard-Soulier syndrome?
options: There is defective adhesion of platelets to sub-endothelial matrix
Deficiency of the platelet membrane glycoprotein complex Ib-IX is seen
Platelet aggregation by ristocetin is norma
It has an autosomal recessive inheritance
explanation: In Bernard–Soulier syndrome, platelet aggregation by ristocetin is abnormal. The receptor for vWF i.e. Ib-IX is essential for normal platelet adhesion to the subendothelial extracellular matrix. In this condition, there is deficiency of Gp Ib/ IX. Clinical manifestations include epistaxis, ecchymoses, menorrhagia, gingival bleeding, and gastrointestinal bleeding. Laboratory findings seen in Bernard-Soulier syndrome: Prolonged bleeding time Moderate thrombocytopenia Platelet aggregation by ristocetin is deficient (but ADP, arachidonic acid, epinephrine, collagen - normal). Clot retraction - norma Abnormally large platelets The image given below shows the abnormally large platelets on peripheral smear seen in Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

question_text: A 4-year-old girl with a history of easy bruising was referred for further evaluation. Her previous lab reports showed that platelet count and morphology were normal. Platelet aggregations tests are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Glanzmann thrombasthenia. It is an abnormality of platelet GPIIb-IIIa (fibrinogen receptor). Platelets are unable to adhere to each other and to the underlying tissue of the damaged blood vessels. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. The symptoms include mucocutaneous bleeding in the neonatal period, menorrhagia, ecchymoses, epistaxis, and gingival hemorrhage. Types of Glanzmann thrombasthenia include: Type 1: Absence of GPIIb-IIIa Type 2: Reduced surface expression of GPIIb-IIIa/ Essentialis athrombia - clot retraction is norma Type 3: Dysfunction of GPIIb-IIIa Laboratory features of Glanzmann thrombasthenia: Normal platelet count and morphology Platelet aggregation occurs in response to ristocetin, but not to other agonists (such as ADP, thrombin, collagen or epinephrine) Clot retraction is absent
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 1-year-old boy is brought with a history of recurrent impetigo. Physical examination findings are given below. Platelet counts are low and peripheral smear shows abnormally small-sized platelets. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome (WAS). The given image shows (A) multiple petechiae over face and hematoma under the right eye and (B) eczema of the foot. This syndrome is an X-linked recessive, primary immunodeficiency disorder involving the WAS gene. It is characterised by the triad of: Severe eczema Thrombocytopenia Recurrent infections Small platelets are seen in: Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome X-linked thrombocytopenia Large platelets are seen in: Bernard-Soulier syndrome Myeloproliferative syndrome Myelodysplastic syndrome May–Hegglin anomaly Gray platelet syndrome
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 28-year-old woman presents with epistaxis, easy bruising and menorrhagia. There is no history of drug intake. Physical examination shows scattered petechiae and a normal-sized spleen. Her lab investigations are given below. Antibodies against which of the following can lead to this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). Autoantibodies seen in ITP are most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It is a diagnosis of exclusion due to the following findings: Bleeding tendency - petechiae Low platelet count, elevated bleeding time Presence of megathrombocytes in the peripheral smear - a sign of accelerated thrombopoiesis Female preponderance Absence of splenomegaly Note: Prothrombin time (PT) is normal in ITP.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which class of antiplatelet antibodies are seen in patients with chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura?
explanation: Antiplatelet antibodies in chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) are mainly IgG class. Autoantibodies most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins are IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It can be demonstrated in the plasma and bound to the platelet surface in about 80% of patients.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 27-year-old woman is diagnosed to have idiopathic ITP. Which of the following features is least likely to be seen in her?
explanation: Lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly are uncommon in idiopathic (primary) ITP. They are seen in secondary ITP. Chronic ITP occurs most commonly in adult women younger than 40 years of age. The female-to-male ratio is 3: 1. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction. It is of 2 types: Primary or idiopathic - without any risk factors Secondary - presence of predisposing conditions like SLE, HIV, CLL Signs of accelerated thrombopoiesis that are seen in this condition are: Megakaryocytes in bone marrow Megathrombocytes (abnormally large platelets) in peripheral blood The image given below shows 2 megakaryocytes seen in bone marrow aspirate (Wrights stain). Acute ITP is mainly a disease of childhood. It occurs with equal frequency in both sexes, mostly after a viral illness. It is self-limited condition, resolves within 6 months.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Patients with which of the following predisposing conditions are likely to develop chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura?
explanation: Systemic lupus erythematosus, HIV infection, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome can predispose to the development of secondary immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). The predisposing conditions of secondary chronic ITP include: Autoimmune conditions Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) Immune thyroid disease Evans syndrome Lymphoproliferative diseases Chronic lymphocytic leukemia Large granular T-lymphocyte lymphocytic leukemia Chronic infection Helicobacter pylori Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) Hepatitis C virus (HCV)

question_text: A 63-year-old man with moderate COVID pneumonia developed DVT. Therapeutic anticoagulation with heparin was started. His lab investigations are given below. Which of the following is false about this condition?
options: Lesser incidence with use of LMWH
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of type II heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). It is not self-resolving. Thrombocytopenia occurs in about 5% of persons receiving heparin and is of two types: Feature Type I Type II Incidence More common Less common Occurrenc e Rapidly after onset of therap y 5 to 14 days after therapy Pathogene sis Direct platelet-aggregating ef fect of heparin Antibodies against heparin-pl atelet factor 4 complexes Severity Less severe Often leads to life-threatenin g venous and arterial thromb osis Treatment Self-resolving Immediate discontinuation o f heparinAlternate non-hepar in anticoagulant to be used

question_text: All of the following commonly cause drug-induced thrombocytopenia except
explanation: Terlipressin does not cause drug-induced thrombocytopenia. Drug-induced thrombocytopenia can be caused by: Vancomycin Quinine Rifampin They cause thrombocytopenia through direct effects on platelets or secondary to immunologically mediated platelet destructions. Quinine, quinidine, and vancomycin bind to platelet glycoprotein and create antigenic determinants that are recognized by antibodies.

question_text: A post-operative patient was started on prophylactic unfractionated heparin for DVT. Which of the following is false regarding this drug?
options: It is an indirect thrombin-factor Xa inhibitor
It is safe in patients with renal impairment
On development of HIT, LMWH can be started alternately
explanation: The risk of severe heparin-induced thrombocytopenia is lowered with LMWH but not eliminated. Hence, once severe HIT develops even LMWH exacerbates the thrombotic tendency and must be avoided. Management of HIT includes the immediate withdrawal of heparin therapy and instituting an alternative non-heparin anticoagulant.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Patients with which of the following conditions is associated with ADAMTS13 deficiency?
explanation: ADAMTS13 deficiency is associated with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). ADAMTS13 is also called vWF metalloprotease which degrades very high-molecular-weight multimers of von Willebrand factor (vWF). Its deficiency causes accumulation of these multimers in the plasma and promotes platelet activation and aggregation. TTP is a part of a spectrum of clinical syndromes called thrombotic microangiopathy. They are caused by insults that lead to excessive activation of platelets, which deposit as thrombi in small blood vessels. Features of TTP include: Fever Thrombocytopenia Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia Transient neurologic deficits Renal failure
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 7-year-old girl is brought with complaints of hematuria and melena for 10 days. Laboratory investigations reveal mild thrombocytopenia and normal coagulation tests. Peripheral smear is given below. Which organism is most frequently involved in this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing helmet cells or schistocytes are suggestive of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). This condition is most commonly associated with enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli strain O157: H7 worldwide. This strain releases Shiga-like toxin. This toxin is absorbed from the inflamed gastrointestinal mucosa into the circulation and causes endothelial dysfunction. It leads to platelet activation and aggregation. Children and older adults are at the highest risk. The image given below shows schistocytes or helmet cells seen in HUS.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Deficiency of which of the following complement components is not associated with atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome?
explanation: Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome is not associated with deficiency of CD59. It is associated with deficiency of the following components: Complement factor H Membrane cofactor protein (CD46) Complement factor I These three proteins prevent excessive activation of the alternative complement pathway. Deficiencies of these proteins can be caused by inherited defects or acquired inhibitory autoantibodies. The disease may be associated with a remitting, relapsing course.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Coombs test is found to be positive in a patient with thrombocytopenia. Which of the following conditions could be a likely cause?
explanation: Coombs test is positive in immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) as it is an immunogenic cause of thrombocytopenia. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) are nonimmunogenic causes. Hence, Coombs test is negative in these conditions.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Which of the following is affected in patients with Weber-Osler-Rendu syndrome?
Collagen
explanation: Weber–Osler–Rendu syndrome is a disorder of the blood vessels. It is an autosomal-dominant disorder caused by mutations that modulate TGF- signalling. It is also known as hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia. This condition is characterized by dilated, tortuous blood vessels with thin walls that bleed readily. Bleeding is most common in the mucous membranes of the nose (epistaxis), tongue, mouth, and eyes, and throughout the gastrointestinal tract. Platelet count, prothrombin time (PT), and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) are normal. Clinical conditions in which abnormalities of vessel wall cause bleeding include: Infections - meningococcemia, infective endocarditis, rickettsioses Collagen defects - Ehlers–Danlos syndrome, scurvy, and Cushing's syndrome Perivascular amyloidosis - most common with amyloid light-chain (AL) amyloidosis Henoch–Schönlein purpura Drug reactions Coagulation Pathway Disorders
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common hereditary disease associated with life-threatening bleeding?
explanation: The most common hereditary disease associated with life-threatening bleeding is hemophilia A. It is caused by mutations in factor VIII, an essential cofactor for factor IX in the coagulation cascade. N te: von Willebrand disease is the most common inherited bleeding disorder.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 12-year-old boy presents with the following finding after a trivial fall. His lab investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario showing hemarthrosis and elevated aPTT is suggestive of hemophilia. Specific tests for measuring levels of factor VIII and factor IX can determine whether it is hemophilia A or hemophilia B respectively. Clinical features of hemophilia: Hemarthroses - joint hemorrhages, later causing progressive deformities Recurrent bleeding Pseudotumour syndrome - fascial hemorrhages that occur as blood-filled cysts with calcification and proliferation of fibroblasts, giving the appearance of the tumor It is associated with elevated aPTT and normal platelet count, bleeding time, and PT. Option A: In ITP, the platelet count is low and bleeding time is prolonged. Option B: In functional platelet disorders, like Bernard Soulier syndrome, the platelet count is normal and bleeding time is prolonged. Option D: In vitamin K deficiency, both PT and aPTT are prolonged. PT is relatively more prolonged than is the aPTT.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 7-year-old boy was found to have excessive bleeding following tooth extraction. Lab investigations revealed prolonged aPTT, decreased serum factor VIII levels and normal VwF activity. What is the mode of inheritance of this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency). It is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait. Hence, it affects mainly males and homozygous females. Hemophilia B is also inherited as X-linked recessive trait. Hemophilia C is inherited as an autosomal-recessive trait.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about hemophilia?
options: Hemophilia A in female may indicate unfavourable lyonization
Hemophilia A can occur without any family history
explanation: Hemophilia A and B mostly affect males, but rarely can affect females also. Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder, affecting mainly males and homozygous females. Rarely, excessive bleeding occurs in heterozygous females. It is due to the inactivation of the X chromosome bearing the normal factor VIII allele by chance in most cells (unfavourable lyonization). About 30% of patients have no family history and the disorder is caused due to new mutations. Hemophilia B is inherited as X-linked recessive trait. There is a deficiency of factor IX. Hemophilia C is an autosomal-recessive condition and hence can occur in females. There is a deficiency of factor XI.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 10-year-old child with easy bruising was diagnosed to have moderate hemophilia A. What will be the percentage of normal factor VIII in her?
explanation: Patients with moderate hemophilia A have 2% - 5% of normal levels of factor VIII. The clinical manifestations of Hemophilia A vary in severity, corresponding to the level of factor VIII present. They can be classified as: Severi ty Levels of factor VIII Mild 6-50% Mode rate 2-5% Sever e <1%
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following lab findings are seen in patients with hemophilia A?
explanation: Patients with hemophilia A have: Prolonged partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) - intrinsic pathway abnormality Normal prothrombin time (PT) Normal bleeding time Normal platelet count
subject: Pathology

question_text: A newborn baby develops severe umbilical cord bleeding soon after birth. Lab investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of factor XIII deficiency. A positive urea lysis test confirms the diagnosis. Factor XIII is also known as clot-stabilizing factor that converts unstable fibrin clot into a stable clot. Its deficiency typically presents as excessive umbilical cord bleeding in the newborn. Laboratory findings in this condition are: Normal levels of bleeding time (BT), platelet count, prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), and thrombin time (TT) Positive urea lysis test - confirmatory test which demonstrates lysis of clot by hyperosmolar urea in affected individuals The parameters for the given diseases: Condition PT aPTT BT TT Platelet count Urea lysis te st Vitamin K deficiency increa sed increased increa sed normal/incre ased normal/decre ased negative Von Willebrand disease norma l normal/incre ased increa sed normal normal negative Hemorrhagic disease of ne wborn increa sed increased increa sed normal/incre ased normal/decre ased negative Factor XIII deficiency norma l normal norma l normal normal positive
subject: Pathology

question_text: A Hemogram of a 23-year-old patient with a bleeding disorder is given below. Which of the following would you use to differentiate between heparin-induced thrombocytopenia and afibrinogenemia in this patient?
explanation: Reptilase is a thrombin agonist which is used to differentiate heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) and afibrinogenemia. It is resistant to the action of heparin. The differential diagnosis for normal platelet count with elevated PT, aPTT and TT are HIT and afibrinogenemia. After adding reptilase, if the TT is corrected, it points to HIT. In afibrinogenemia, since there is an absence of fibrin, there is no change in the TT.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 1-year-old child was diagnosed to have Kasabach-Merritt syndrome. What is this condition associated with?
explanation: Kasabach–Merritt syndrome is associated with DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation). This syndrome is characterised by the following features: Rapidly growing vascular tumour Thrombocytopenia Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia Consumptive coagulopathy An unusual form of DIC occurs in association with giant hemangiomas. In this type, stasis and recurrent trauma to the fragile blood vessels cause thrombi to form within the neoplasm. The image given below shows a reddish-blue lesion covering the lower part of the abdomen. It is a caverno-capillary haemangioma seen in Kasabach–Merritt syndrome.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following clotting factor deficiency will not affect clotting in vivo?
explanation: Factor XII deficiency will not affect the clotting in vivo. Unlike the clotting cascade in the lab (in vitro), the cascade in the body (in vivo) differs slightly - as tissue factor (TF) is the major initiator of the cascade. The TF/VIIa complex is the most important activator of factor IX and factor IXa/factor VIIIa complex is the most important activator of factor X. Factor V is involved in both the pathways as shown in the image below. The coagulation cascade in the laboratory: Extrinsic pathway sequence (in a test tube): Tissue factor  Factor VII  Factor X. Intrinsic pathway sequence (in a test tube): Factor XII  Factor XI  Factor IX  Factor X Laboratory methods to initiate clotting include: Intrinsic pathway - adding phospholipids, calcium, and either a negatively charged substance such as glass beads Extrinsic pathway - a source of tissue factor
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which test evaluates the extrinsic pathway?
explanation: Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.
