PT measures the clotting time of plasma in the presence of an optimal concentration of tissue extract (thromboplastin). This indicates the overall efficiency of the extrinsic clotting system. Causes of prolonged PT: Administration of oral anticoagulant drugs - vitamin K antagonists Liver disease - obstructive jaundice Vitamin K deficiency Disseminated intravascular coagulation Previously undiagnosed factor VII, X, V or prothrombin deficiency or defect (rare) Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) measures the clotting time of plasma after the activation of contact factors and the addition of phospholipid and CaCl2, but without added tissue thromboplastin. It indicates the overall efficiency of the intrinsic pathway. Causes of prolonged APTT: Disseminated intravascular coagulation Liver disease Massive transfusion with plasma-depleted red blood cells Administration of or contamination with heparin or other anticoagulants A circulating anticoagulant (inhibitor) Deficiency of a coagulation factor other than factor VII Intake of oral anticoagulant drugs Vitamin K deficiency
subject: Pathology

question_text: You are collecting a blood sample to send for prothrombin time in a patient in the ward. Which of the following is true about this investigation?
options: Test must be done within 2 hours of sample collection
explanation: The test for prothrombin time is done within 2 hours. The differences between PT and aPTT are: Feature PT aPTT Coagulation pathway teste d Extrinsic and com mon Intrinsic and common N rmal value 11-13 seconds 25-35 seconds Sample Platelet-poor plasm a Platelet-poor plasma Activating agent Thomboplastin KaolinSilicaEllagic acid
subject: Pathology

question_text: At what temperature should you store the sample for antiphospholipid antibody factor assays?
explanation: The sample for antiphospholipid antibody assay must be stored at <4°. Samples for coagulation studies should be stored always at room temperature (20 to 25°).
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the casualty with severe bleeding following a road traffic accident. He is a known cardiac disease patient on anticoagulant therapy. As an intern, you were asked to collect blood for coagulation studies. Which colour vacutainer will you pick?
explanation: The most commonly used vacutainer for coagulation studies is a blue vacutainer containing trisodium citrate. The benefits of trisodium citrate are that the calcium ion is neutralized more rapidly in citrate. Other anticoagulants are unacceptable for coagulation studies. The labile factors (factors V and VIII) are unstable in oxalate (grey), whereas heparin (green) and EDTA (lavender) directly inhibit the coagulation process and interfere with end-point determinations. Also, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) tests are more sensitive to the presence of heparin (green). The image given below shows colour coding of vacutainers with the anticoagulant used and their practical uses. N te: Heparin is used for blood sample collection for electrolyte estimation.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the color of vacutainer containing sodium fluoride as a content?
explanation: S dium fluoride is present in the grey coloured tube. S dium fluoride inhibits glycolysis. Hence, is used for the estimation of blood glucose and alcohol.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A child was brought to the emergency department with a big lesion on his forearm. As a surgery resident you decide to excise the lesion in the emergency operation theatre. Which of the following investigations will test the entire coagulation pathway?
Activated partial thromboplastin time
explanation: Thromboelastography (TEG) tests the entire coagulation pathway. It measures coagulation cascade, platelet function, and fibrinolysis. It is a test that quantitatively measures the ability of whole blood to form a clot. The advantages are: Global assessment of blood coagulability, including coagulation cascade, platelet function, and fibrinolysis Rapid real-time bedside test with a simple methodology (point-of-care testing) Diagnosis of coagulopathic bleeding Guide transfusion therapy and decrease the use of blood products Detect dynamic changes in blood coagulation during resuscitation Predict the clinical efficacy of therapeutic agents affecting blood coagulability Blood Products and Transfusion Reactions
subject: Pathology

question_text: Choose the correct option regarding the storage temperatures of blood components.
explanation: The recommended storage temperatures of different blood components is as follows: Blood component Storage temperatu re Whole blood and red blood c ells 2–6°C Fresh frozen plasma -30°C or lower Cryoprecipitate Below -30°C AlbuminFreeze-dried factor VIII 2–8°C Platelet 20–24°C
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following can be used to store blood for up to 35 days?
explanation: Citrate dextrose phosphate adenine-1 (CDPA-1) can be used to store blood for up to 35 days. It helps in improving ATP synthesis during storage. Hence, it increases the shelf life. The disadvantage of using CDPA-1 is that it increases uric acid stone formation. The shelf life of storage with other components are: Acid Citrate dextrose – 21 days Citrate-phosphate dextrose – 21 days
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is correct regarding transfusion of the blood received from blood bank?
options: It should be started within 4 hours of receiving it from the blood bank.
It should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from the blood bank.
No such time restraint and can be done anytime.
It should be completed within 6 hours of receiving from the blood bank.
explanation: Blood received from blood bank should be completely transfused within 4 hours of receiving. Principles of blood administration: All blood products should be given through an appropriate blood administration set containing a filter. A careful aseptic technique should be practised at all times. Vital signs should be documented before and after transfusion and as clinically required. For the first 15 minutes after the infusion has begun, the patient should be kept under close observation to detect any signs of a serious transfusion reaction. If none is observed, the infusion rate may be increased. One unit of red cells is often given in 1 to 4 hours, depending on the amount to be transfused and on the patient’s cardiovascular status. Infusion of a unit for longer than 4 hours is not recommended, as there is a risk of bacterial proliferation because the opened unit is at room temperature. No other solution and no medication should be added to or infused through the same tubing as a blood product. Ringer’s lactate or other solutions containing calcium must never be added to a blood product because the calcium present leads to coagulation. After the transfusion has been completed, the transfusion tag or record should become part of the patient’s chart.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following patients receiving blood transfusions are more prone to develop bacterial sepsis?
options: A young women with severe anaemia
explanation: Patients with thrombocytopenia receiving blood transfusions (platelets) are more prone to develop bacterial sepsis. Sepsis is mostly due to significant bacterial contamination of the blood products. Platelets have the maximum risk of causing this condition when compared to red cell preparations. Since patients with thrombocytopenia receive platelet transfusion, they are at an increased risk of infections. Platelets (unlike red cells) must be stored at room temperature. This is a condition that is favourable for bacterial proliferation. Broad-spectrum antibiotics must be started while waiting for the culture reports. The blood components that are preferred for the other conditions are: Anaemia - RBCs Hemophilia - FFP vonWillebrand disease - cryoprecipitate
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient has been brought with severe bleeding to your ER. His blood group is unknown. Fresh frozen plasma from which of the following blood groups can be given?
explanation: Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) from AB blood group can be given to this patient as it is the universal plasma donor. AB plasma does not contain antibodies against antigens on RBCs of AB blood group. O Rh-negative blood is the universal blood donor. It is used during emergency packed cell blood transfusion with an unknown blood group. It is preferred because it lacks the A and B and Rh antigens. Hence, it cannot be hemolyzed by anti-A, anti-B or anti-D antibodies in the recipient’s blood.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common reaction occurring in patients undergoing blood transfusions?
explanation: The most common blood transfusion reaction is the febrile nonhemolytic reaction.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Blood transfusion was started in a patient with severe anaemia. Within a few minutes she developed generalised pruritis, swelling of the tongue and stridor. Which antibody deficiency in the recipient most commonly causes this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe, potentially fatal, allergic reactions. These are most likely to occur in patients with IgA deficiency. Such reactions may occur when blood products containing certain antigens are given to previously sensitized recipients. It is triggered by recipient IgG antibodies that recognize IgA in the infused blood product.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Following blood transfusion in a post-operative patient, the following finding was noted. Which of the following is responsible for this reaction?
explanation: The given image, showing a raised and erythematous lesion, is suggestive of urticaria. Such reactions may be triggered by the presence of an allergen in the donated blood product that is recognized by IgE antibodies in the recipient. These are mild reactions occurring more commonly in 1% to 3% of transfusions.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with thalassemia developed pallor and dizziness 1 week following blood transfusion. His lab reports are given below. Which of the following is seen in this condition?
options: Direct coombs test negative, IgG mediated
Direct Coombs test positive, IgG mediated
Direct coombs test negative, IgM mediated
Direct coombs test positive, IgM mediated
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of delayed hemolytic reaction following blood transfusion. It is IgG mediated and gives a positive result in direct Coombs test. These antibodies recognize foreign protein red cell antigens in a previously sensitized recipient (through a prior blood transfusion). They present with laboratory features of hemolysis like low haptoglobin level and elevated LDH. Acute hemolytic reactions are usually caused by preformed IgM antibodies against donor red cells that fix complement. The direct Coombs test is usually positive.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient who was admitted for blood transfusion developed transfusion-related acute lung injury. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
options: Pre-existing lung diseases are a risk factor
Incidence with platelet transfusion is more than that with whole blood
Symptoms develop after 2 days of transfusion
Subsequent transfusions from the same donor increases the incidence
explanation: Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is sudden-onset respiratory failure that occurs during or soon after the transfusion. It occurs within 6 hours, and not after 2 days following transfusion. TRALI is a severe fatal complication of blood transfusion. The incidence of TRALI is low (1 per 10,000 transfusions). However, it may occur more frequently in patients with preexisting lung disease. The pathogenesis involves a two-hit hypothesis: Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the microvasculature of the lung Second hit - the factor (most commonly MHC class I antigens) present in the transfused blood roduct activates the primed neutrophils TRALI can occur in transfusions with all plasma-containing blood products. However, it is more likely to occur following the transfusion of fresh frozen plasma and platelets. This is because these products contain high levels of donor antibodies. Note: TRALI is important to recognize because donor products that induce complications in one patient are much more likely to do so in a second. Indeed, recent measures to exclude multiparous women from plasma donation have resulted in reduced incidence of TRALI.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 33-year-old man is receiving massive blood transfusion following a fall from height. 4 hours after transfusion, he becomes breathless and oxygen saturation decreases. Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral lung infiltrates. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
options: Treatment involves discontinuation of blood transfusion
It is mediated by macrophages in lung vasculature
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of TRALI (transfusion-related acute lung injury). It is mediated by neutrophils entrapped in the lung vasculature. Features of TRALI are: Fever Hypotension Hypoxemia Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates - not responsive to diuretics Treatment is mainly supportive and blood transfusions are discontinued. The mortality rate in this condition is 5-10%.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A CKD patient had to undergo dialysis and his Hb was 5.2gm/dL. So two blood transfusions were to be given. The first bag was completed in 2 hours. The second was started and in the midway, he developed shortness of breath and hypertension. Vitals were BP - 180/120 mmHg and pulse rate - 110/min. What is the cause?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). TACO is caused by rapid or excess transfusion of red cell preparations or plasma products. This condition is characterized by: Dyspnea with O2% <90 at room air Bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray Systolic hypertension Elevation of brain natriuretic peptide, 1.5 times that of pre-transfusion levels It can be prevented by administering the transfusion slowly, at the rate of 1 to 2 ml of blood/kg of body weight per hour. Diuretics are also used if necessary.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills during this time. There is no evidence of hemolysis. Which of the following measures can decrease the rate of transfusion reactions?
Leukoreduced RBCs
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR). Such reactions can be prevented by using leukoreduced RBCs. Removal of leukocytes from the blood is called leukoreduction. It is done before storage to prevent cytokine formation. FNHTR may occur due to the following: Sensitization to the WBC antigens by previous blood transfusions or pregnancy Cytokines produced by the donor leukocytes during storage Bacterial contamination Note: Luspatercept is an erythroid maturation agent, a receptor fusion protein consisting of a modified extracellular domain of human activin receptor type-2B linked to the human Ig-G1 Fc domain. The drug was recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of transfusion-dependent thalassemia. Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL)
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of these is not a pre-leukemic condition?
explanation: Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria is not a preleukemic condition. It is an autoimmune hemolytic anemia due to IgG autoantibodies that bind to the P blood group antigen and cause intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. Most cases are seen in children and show recovery within a month. Option A: Few patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) develop acute non-lymphocytic leukemia. This is thought to arise from the injured marrow as a secondary hematopoietic disorder. Option B: Bone marrow aplasia preceding acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is a rare condition that usually affects children. It generally follows the recovery of normal blood counts and most commonly occurs within 6 months of the onset of aplasia. Option C: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) occurs in 10% to 40% of individuals with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). It is usually accompanied by the appearance of additional cytogenetic abnormalities.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of acute leukemia?
options: Arrest in differentiation and increased apoptosi
Arrest in differentiation and decreased apoptosi
explanation: In acute leukemia, there is an arrest in differentiation and decreased apoptosis. Genomic aberrations create oncoproteins. They arrest normal maturation, turn on pro-growth signaling pathways, or protect cells from apoptotic death.
subject: Pathology

question_text: As per WHO classification, what percentage of blast cells in bone marrow biopsy is required to diagnose a patient with acute leukemia?
explanation: As per WHO classification, 20% of blast cells must be present in the bone marrow and / peripheral smear for the diagnosis of acute leukemia. In FAB criteria, the cut-off is more than 30%.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following conditions does not increase the risk of acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
explanation: Polycythemia vera increases the risk of developing AML, not ALL. Inherited diseases that are associated with a higher risk of developing leukemias are: Bloom syndrome Fanconi anemia Ataxia–telangiectasia Down syndrome Type-1 neurofibromatosi Other germline risk factors for the development of ALL: Li-Fraumeni syndrome Familial ALL syndrome Note: AML has a higher incidence during the neonatal period than ALL among children with Fanconi anemia, Bloom syndrome, and Down syndrome.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common type of acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
explanation: Precursor B-cell or pre B cell (previously classified as L1) type is the most common subtype of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a primary T-cell marker?
explanation: CD10 is not a primary marker of T cells. It is a marker of pre-B cells and germinal-center B cells. Note: Although CD10/ Common ALL antigen (CALLA) can be found in B-ALL and T-ALL, it is primarily expressed by pre-B cells and germinal centre B cells. Lymphoblasts of both B and T cell lineages, express CD10 that is lost upon progression to a mature phenotype. It is variably expressed by a few mature B cell tumours. However, the expression of CD10 by mature T cells has not been well established.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Block-like positivity for PAS on immunohistochemistry of a bone marrow sample is seen. Which of the following cells show this finding?
explanation: Lymphoblasts in acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) show block-like or dot-like PAS positivity. Erythroblasts in acute myeloid leukemia-M6 (AML-M6) show diffuse periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) positivity. The image given below shows dot-like positivity for periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) in lymphoblasts.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following cells does not stain positively with Sudan black?
explanation: Lymphocytes do not stain positively with Sudan black dye. Although some positivity may be seen in azurophilic granules of lymphoblasts. Sudan Black B (SBB) is a lipophilic dye that binds irreversibly to an undefined granule component in granulocytes, eosinophils, and some monocytes.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most commonly affected gene in patients with T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
explanation: The most commonly affected gene in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) is NOTCH1. B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia is associated with mutations of genes such as PAX5, E2A, and EBF. It may be associated with balanced t(12;21) involving the genes ETV6 and RUNX1.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with acute lymphoblastic leukemia is found to have t(9;22). What will be the size of BCR-ABL fusion protein produced?
explanation: The size of BCR-ABL protein in t(9;22) associated with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is 190 kDa. BCR-ABL fusion transcript protein with t(9;22): Major BCR (M-BCR) 210 kDa size in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) with weaker tyrosine kinase activity Minor BCR (m-BCR) 190 kDa size in acute lymphoblastic leukemia ( ALL) with stronger tyrosine kinase activity Micro BCR (-BCR) 230 kDa size in myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN) with exuberant neutrophilia
subject: Pathology

question_text: On immunophenotyping of a patient with early pre-B acute leukemia, which of the following marker will be negative?
explanation: Cytoplasmic immunoglobulins and CD10 are negative in early pre-B acute leukemia but become positive in pre-B ALL.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not usually involved in the immunohistochemistry of acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
explanation: Cytokeratin is not a marker of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It is an epithelial cell marker for thymoma. Tdt, CD1a, and CD3 are markers of ALL.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 10-year-old boy with fever, weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale and had significant lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow histology of the person is as given below. Your diagnosis is?
explanation: The given scenario with bone marrow histology showing lymphoblasts (condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, scanty agranular cytoplasm) is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. ALL is more common in childhood. Clinical features of ALL include: Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, plenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsie B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly
subject: Pathology

question_text: An adolescent male patient presents with fatigue. His total leucocyte count is 138 x 10^9 / L with 80% blasts on the peripheral smear. Chest X-ray shows a large mediastinal mass. The bone marrow aspirate is as shown below. What would the immunophenotyping of this patient’s blasts most likely demonstrate?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and bone marrow aspirate are suggestive of T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Thus, immunophenotyping of the blasts would demonstrate an immature T-cell phenotype (Tdt/CD34/CD7 positive). The bone marrow aspirate shows lymphoblast with condensed nuclear chromatin, small inconspicuous nucleoli, and scanty cytoplasm lacking granules. ALL is usually seen in adolescent boys with thymic involvement in 50% to 70%. It has an abrupt stormy onset, within days to a few weeks of the first symptoms. Clinical features of ALL include: Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, plenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsie B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly
subject: Pathology

question_text: In a patient with acute leukemia, the immunophenotype pattern of the blasts is positive for CD10, CD13, CD19, and CD33. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) based on immunophenotyping. CD10 and CD19 are markers for B-cell lineage and this patient most probably have B-ALL. Although CD13 and CD33 are myeloid antigens, their expression does not exclude the diagnosis of B- ALL. Option B: The diagnosis of mixed phenotypic acute leukemia (MPAL)/ acute leukemia of ambiguous lineage (ALAL) (previously known as biphenotypic leukemia) requires a demonstration of multiple lineages in blast cells. According to WHO's latest update (2022), the requirements for assigning more than one lineage to blast cells are : In the absence of MPO or evidence of monocytic differentiation, expression of CD13 and CD33 is not sufficient for a diagnosis of MPAL. Hence, biphenotypic leukemia is not the answer here. B cell lineage CD19 strong:1 expressed CD 10, CD22, CD79aCD 19 weak:  2 or more strongly expresse d CD10, CD22, CD79a T cell lineage CD3 positive Myeloid linea ge Myeloperoxidase (MPO)ORM onocyte differentiation (non- specific esterase, CD11c, CD1 4, CD64, lysozyme)
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with weight loss and fever is diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Which of the following is a good prognostic indicator of this condition?
explanation: The presence of t (12;21) indicates a good prognosis in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It involves genes ETV6 and RUNX1. Conversely, a translocation involving the MLL gene, t(9;22), and hypodiploidy are associated with a bad prognosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Bone marrow biopsy of a patient shows > 20% immature blasts with scanty cytoplasm, no granules, and inconspicuous nucleoli. They also stain positive with PAS. Which of the following are good prognostic markers of this condition?
2, 3, and 5
explanation: The given bone marrow biopsy report is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). The good prognostic markers of ALL include trisomy 7, hyperdiploidy, and age of 5 years. Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a myeloid marker?
explanation: CD3 is not a myeloid marker. It is a T-cell lymphoid marker. Cell markers: B-cell: CD10, CD19, CD20, CD22, CD23, CD24, CD79b, CD103, Pax-5, kappa, lambda, CD200, cytoplasmic kappa, cytoplasmic lambda T- cell: CD1, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD6,CD7, CD8, TCR apha-beta, TCR gamma-delta, cytoplasmic CD3 Myeloid: CD11b, CD13, CD14, CD15, CD33, CD64, CD 117, myeloperoxidase
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common type of acute myeloid leukemia?
explanation: The most common type of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is AML - M2 or AML with maturation. The least common type of AML is AML M7 or megakaryocytic.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common subtype of acute myeloid leukemia seen in patients with Down's syndrome?
explanation: The most common subtype of AML seen in Down's syndrome is acute myeloid leukemia-M7 (AML - M7) or acute megakaryocytic leukemia. Myeloid proliferations of Down's syndrome are usually megakaryoblastic. It includes: Transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM) - occurs at birth or within days of birth and resolves in 1 to 2 months Myeloid leukemia associated with Down syndrome - occurs later, but usually in the first 3 years of life. Both are characterized by GATA1 mutations and mutations of the JAK-STAT pathway.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 35-year-man presents with nosebleeds, bleeding gums, and multiple ecchymoses. Lab investigations show the following findings. The blasts are positive for CD33. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). AML is a tumor of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that impede differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow. It occurs at all ages, but the incidence rises throughout life, peaking after 60 years of age. The peripheral smear shows blasts with abundant cytoplasm, fine azurophilic granules, Auer rods, and delicate nuclear chromatin with 1-4 prominent nucleoli. The blasts are positive for CD33. Occasionally, blasts are entirely absent from the blood (aleukemic leukemia). Bone marrow examination is essential to exclude acute leukemia in pancytopenic patients.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Peripheral smear of a patient with acute promyelocytic leukemia shows myeloblasts with the following finding. What are these made of?
explanation: The image shows Auer rods in myeloblasts. These are needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by the fusion of lysosomes. Auer rods contain peroxidase and lysosomal enzymes. Myeloblasts with bundles of Auer rods are called faggot cells and are seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In which of the following conditions are Auer rods seen?
explanation: Auer rods are seen in: Acute promyelocytic leukemia Myelodysplastic syndromes Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia These are not seen in acute monocytic leukemia and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 20-year-old male patient is diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. The peripheral blood smear picture is given in the image. The cell indicated by the arrow is best described as:
explanation: The given cell shows multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks. Such cells have been termed as faggot cells (faggot in French means bundle of sticks). Since the question specifically asks about the cell, the best answer is faggot cell (not Auer rods). Option A: Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules present in many cases but particularly numerous in AML with the t(15;17) aberration (acute promyelocytic leukemia). Option B: The term flaming promyelocyte refers to cells that appear to be breaking apart, taking on a vibrant reddish-purple hue with the apparent liberation of granules into the surrounding cellular matrix. Option C: Promyelocytes containing fine granules appear dusky or hazy and are referred to as dusky promyelocytes.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Increased levels of serum muramidase are seen in patients with which of the following conditions?
explanation: Serum muramidase or lysozyme levels are seen to be increased in patients with acute myelomonocytic leukemia (AML - M4). It is also increased in chronic myelomonocytic leukemia and chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which type of AML is known as Di Guglielmo disease?
explanation: Acute myeloid leukemia-M6 (AML-M6) or acute erythroid leukemia is known as Di Guglielmo disease. AML-M6 accounts for 1% of AML cases. It has two subtypes: Erythroid/myeloid leukemia (M6a, more common) - Dyserythropoiesis is prominent Pure erythroid leukemia/ erythemic myelosis/ Di Guglielmo disease (M6b, rare) - >80% erythroid precursors. Clinical findings include anemia, thrombocytopenia, and variable neutropenia. Positive stains for erythroid cells are glycophorin A, hemoglobin A, CD36, CD71, CD117, and PAS.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In patients with which of the following conditions, a dry tap may be seen on bone marrow aspiration?
explanation: Acute megakaryocytic leukemia (AML M7) may yield a dry tap on marrow aspiration. It may be associated with extensive bone marrow fibrosis as a result of the stimulation of the normal fibroblasts by the local secretion of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) by the leukemic cells.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Bone marrow aspirate of a patient diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia shows the presence of faggot cells. What is the most likely subtype of acute myeloid leukemia, the patient is suffering from?
explanation: The presence of faggot cells is highly suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia - M3 (AML - M3) or acute promyelocytic leukemia. A cluster of Auer rods is known as a faggot cell. It is characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) M3. The image given below shows AML M3 with a cluster of Auer rods (faggot cell).
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia presents with a one-day history of bleeding gums, subconjunctival bleed, and purpuric rash. Investigations done are given below. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely to be detected?
explanation: The patient shows features of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). It is most likely to be associated with acute myeloid leukemia - M3 or acute promyelocytic leukemia. The pathogenesis behind this is t(15,17) or PML-RARA fusion gene. Option A: Inversion 16 is seen in acute myelomonocytic leukemia or AML - M4. Option B: t(8;21) is seen in AML with differentiation or AML - M2. Option C: Inversion 3 is seen in AML - M7 (megakaryoblastic) which shows normal or increased platelet count. It has a poor prognosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which type of acute myeloid leukemia is myeloperoxidase negative?
explanation: AML M0 is negative for myeloperoxidase (MPO). AML-M5 (monocytic), AML-M6 (erythroid), and AML-M7 (megakaryocytic) are also negative for MPO. Myeloperoxidase (MPO) is located in the primary granules of neutrophils and their precursors, in eosinophil granules, and in the azurophilic granules of monocytes. The most primitive myeloblasts are negative, with granular positivity appearing progressively as they mature toward the promyelocyte stage. Promyelocytes and myelocytes are the most strongly staining cells in the granulocyte series. Monoblasts and monocytes may be negative or positive. AML-M4 shows both myelocytic and monocytic differentiation. Hence, it shows both MPO and non-specific esterase (marker for monocytes) positivity.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A patient with fatigue and recurrent infections undergoes bone marrow evaluation. It shows
> 20% myeloblasts, which stain positive for CD61. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with myeloblasts that stain positive for CD61 is suggestive of acute megakaryocytic leukemia (AML-M7). AML M7 is the least common type of AML. Blasts of megakaryocytic lineage predominate and are associated with marrow fibrosis. There is also frequent budding of cytoplasmic margins. They are CD41+ and CD61+. They stain negatively with Sudan black B (SBB) and myeloperoxidase (MPO). Blasts are reactive with PAS and acid phosphatase. The prognosis for this type of acute leukemia is poor.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient who developed the following lesions over the body was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia. Which subtype of AML does this patient most likely have?
explanation: The given image shows leukemia cutis. It is seen in acute myeloid leukemia - M4 and acute myeloid leukemia - M5. It refers to leukemic cells infiltrating the skin. Signs and symptoms related to the involvement of tissues other than the marrow are usually less striking in AML than in acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL). But tumors with monocytic differentiation (AML M4, M5) often infiltrate the skin (leukemia cutis) and the gingiva. This probably reflects the normal tendency of monocytes to extravasate into tissues.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 38-year-old man presents with bleeding gums for 20 days. He has gingival hyperplasia, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. Investigations done are given below. Bone marrow biopsy shows 100% cellularity with many blasts cells that are peroxidase negative and non-specific esterase positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia-M5 (AML-M5) or acute monocytic leukemia. The patients with AML - M5 develop organomegaly, lymphadenopathy, gingival hyperplasia, C•S involvement, and other tissue infiltration. The bone marrow aspirate shows 20% or more blasts. Monoblasts have folded or lobulated nuclei, lack Auer rods, and are nonspecific esterase positive. Myeloperoxidase is present in the azurophilic granules of neutrophils and their precursors. It is positive in AML M1, M2, M3, M4 and negative in AML M0. Monoblasts and monocytes may be negative or positive. When positive, the granules are smaller than in neutrophils and diffusely scattered throughout the cytoplasm. The image given below shows bone marrow aspirate in AML - M5.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A child presents with bilateral proptosis. After evaluation, he is diagnosed with chloroma. Which of the following is not a marker for this condition?
explanation: CD61 is a marker of acute megakaryoblastic leukemia, not chloroma. Lysozyme, CD43, CD45, CD117, and MPO are positive markers of chloroma. Chloroma, also called myeloid sarcoma, granulocytic sarcoma, or myeloblastoma is an extramedullary tumor that occurs in 2% to 14% of patients with AML. Frequent sites of involvement are: Skin Lymph nodes Gastrointestinal tract Bone Soft tissue, testis Peritoneum Orbital involvement of myeloid sarcoma is rare without any evidence of systemic involvement. Proptosis is the most common presentation. Other symptoms include lacrimal swelling, conjunctival mass lesion, retinal hemorrhages, ptosis, dystopia. Decreased visual acuity and ocular movement restriction have also been reported.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In which of the following conditions are Arbiskov cells seen?
explanation: Arbiskov cells are monocytes seen in myeloblastoma or chloroma. Chloroma, also known as granulocytic sarcoma, is a hematopoietic stem cell tumor, where myeloblasts are located at extramedullary sites. Orbit is one of the most common sites of occurrences in pediatric population. It is seen in AML - M2 most commonly. Other conditions associated are myelodysplastic and myeloproliferative syndromes. The image given below shows Arbiskov cells in chloroma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: All-trans retinoic acid is used in the treatment of tumor that is associated with which of the following genetic aberrations?
explanation: All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML), which is associated with PML-RARA fusion gene. Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) is associated with a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17 producing a PML-RARA fusion gene. This fusion gene encodes for a chimeric protein, which consists of a part of the PML protein and a part of the retinoic acid receptor- (RAR). The normal RAR binds to the D•A and activates the transcription in the presence of retinoids. However, the chimeric protein produced by PML-RARA has reduced affinity for retinoids. This causes inhibition of transcription, thereby preventing gene expression for cellular differentiation. This leads to the accumulation of myeloid progenitor cells. The condition is treated with all-trans retinoic acid. It binds to the PML-RARA chimeric protein. This causes conformational change such that the protein regains its normal function and activates D•A transcription.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following cytogenetic changes suggest a favorable prognosis in patients with acute myeloid leukemia?
options: t (11q23;v) with diverse MLL fusion genes
explanation: •ormal karyotyping with mutated •PM indicates a favorable prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Which among the following patients with acute myeloid leukemia has a good prognosis?
A 56-year-old patient who developed post-chemotherapy AML
options: An infant with AML having complex karyotype
A 60-year-old patient diagnosed with AML-M0 type
A patient with AML having Inversion 16
explanation: Inversion 16 is associated with a good prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Hodgkin's Lymphoma
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which is the most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma?
explanation: Nodular sclerosis is the most common type of Hodgkin's lymphoma, while mixed cellularity is most common in India. The incidence of nodular sclerosis is equal in men and women. It commonly involves the lower cervical, supraclavicular, and mediastinal lymph nodes. It commonly affects adolescents and young adults. It has an excellent prognosis. Mixed-cellularity Hodgkin lymphoma is seen in patients older than 50 years of age. There is a male predominance. The image given below shows the histology of nodular sclerosis showing a lacunar variant of Reed–Sternberg cells
subject: Pathology

question_text: A lymph node biopsy specimen of a patient shows giant cells with an owl-eyed appearance. Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to the diagnosis in this case?
options: Single axial group of lymph nodes is affected
Spleen is the first extranodal tissue to be involved
explanation: An owl-eyed appearance of giant cells in lymph nodes is characteristic of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL). Mesenteric lymph nodes are infrequently involved in HL. Hodgkin’s lymphoma is a group of lymphoid neoplasms arising in a single group of lymph nodes. Extranodal involvement is uncommon. However, if it spreads from the nodes, the first organ to be involved is the spleen, then the liver, and finally the bone marrow. This pattern of spread is known as the contiguous spread. This predictable route of spread is important clinically as it aids in staging and prognosis as well as treatment of HL.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Activation of which of the following is a common event in classical Hodgkin's lymphoma?
explanation: Activation of the transcription factor NF-B is a common event in classical Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL). NF-B may be activated by Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) infection. EBV+ tumor cells express latent membrane protein-1 (LMP-1) which upregulates NF-B. Activation of NF-B may occur in EBV tumors as a result of the acquired loss-of-function mutations in TNF alpha-induced protein 3 (TNFAIP3). Activation of NF-B by EBV rescues crippled germinal center B cells that cannot express Igs from apoptosis, eventually leading to the formation of Reed–Sternberg cells.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Copy-number gains of which proto-oncogene on chromosome 2p are common in Hodgkin lymphoma?
explanation: Copy-number gains in the REL proto-oncogene on chromosome 2p are particularly common in Hodgkin's lymphoma. It may also contribute to increased NF- activity. Reed-Sternberg cells are aneuploid and possess diverse clonal chromosomal aberrations. Note: the MYC gene, commonly associated with Burkitt lymphoma is present on chromosome 8.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In which of the following lesions can we see the Reed-Sternberg-like cells?
explanation: Reed–Sternberg-like cells (RSLC) can be seen in the following: Infectious mononucleosis Large-cell non-Hodgkin lymphomas (most common in immunoblastic NHL) Solid tissue cancers While Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells) are seen in Hodgkin’s lymphoma, there can be presence of Reed-Sternberg like cells which that may have morphologic features resembling RS cells. Diagnostic Reed–Sternberg cells are large cells with multiple nuclei or a single nucleus with multiple nuclear lobes, each with a large inclusion-like nucleolus, about the size of a small lymphocyte with abundant cytoplasm (owl-eye appearance). The image given below shows the classic Reed Sternberg cells.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a variant of the Reed-Sternberg cell?
explanation: Monomorphic is not a variant of RS cell. Reed–Sternberg cell (RS cell) is the characteristic tumor giant cell of Hodgkin Lymphoma. It is derived from the germinal center B cell. It has a classic owl-eyed appearance due to the presence of a symmetric or mirror-image bilobed nucleus, with prominent nucleoli surrounded by a clear space. It has the following variants: Lacunar Classic L&H Popcorn cells Pleomorphic Mononuclear RS cells should be present in a background of non-neoplastic inflammatory cells like lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils, to make a diagnosis of Hodgkin’s lymphoma. The image given below shows the diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cell, with two nuclear lobes, large inclusion-like nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm, surrounded by lymphocytes, macrophages, and an eosinophil. The image below shows Reed-Sternberg cell, mononuclear variant. The image below shows Reed-Sternberg cell, lacunar variant. This variant has a folded or multilobated nucleus and lies within an open space, which is an artefact created by disruption of the cytoplasm during tissue sectioning. The image below shows the Reed-Sternberg cell, lymphohistiocytic variant. Several such variants with multiple infolded nuclear membranes, small nucleoli, fine chromatin, and abundant pale cytoplasm are present.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with generalized lymphadenopathy and Pel-Ebstein fever is diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma. Which of the following is a characteristic finding seen in this condition?
options: Pain in nodes relieved by alcohol
Pain in nodes aggravated by alcohol
explanation: In the case of Hodgkin's Lymphoma, the pain in the lymph nodes aggravates following the intake of alcohol. Clinical features of HL: Painless enlargement of lymph nodes is the most common presenting symptom. Cyclical fever (Pel–Ebstein fever) - cyclical increase, which then decreases over an average period f one or two weeks and night sweats in disseminated disease. This cyclical fever may be due t the release of cytokines. A unique paraneoplastic syndrome associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma is the occurrence of pain in the affected lymph nodes during alcohol consumption. This has been attributed to the enlargement of the affected lymph nodes following alcohol consumption, which stretches the capsule of the lymph node and produces pain.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A lymph node biopsy sample of a patient showed Reed-Sternberg cells that were CD15 & CD30 negative. Which of the variants of Hodgkin lymphoma is the patient most likely to have?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with biopsy findings of CD15 and CD30 negative Reed–Sternberg cell is suggestive of nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma. The Reed–Sternberg cells are positive for CD15 and CD30 for most subtypes, except in lymphocyte-predominant HL, in which the neoplastic cells stains for CD20 and BCL-6.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma has an incidence as shown in the graph given below?
explanation: The given graph shows a disease with a biphasic incidence which is characteristically seen in mixed cellularity type of Hodgkin lymphoma. It has a male predominance, biphasic incidence, peaking in young adults and again in adults older than 55 years. It has more systemic symptoms like night sweats and weight loss. There is diffuse involvement of the entire lymph node. It consists of a mixture of cells composed of T cells, eosinophils, plasma cells, and benign macrophages mixed with Reed–Sternberg cells. The mononuclear variant and diagnostic Reed–Sternberg cells are seen in this type. Reed–Sternberg cell is infected with Epstein–Barr virus in 70% of cases. It has very good prognosis. Image given below shows mononuclear variant of RS cell.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma is associated with older age, systemic symptoms, and advanced tumor stage?
explanation: Mixed-cellularity Hodgkin's lymphoma is associated with older age, systemic symptoms like night sweats and weight loss, and advanced tumor stage. It has a biphasic incidence peaking in young adults and again in adults more than 55 years of age. It also has a strong association with HIV. It is more common in males than females. Nonetheless, the overall prognosis is very good.
subject: Pathology

question_text: The given histological findings were noted on a lymph node biopsy of a patient with lymphadenopathy. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given image shows a lacunar variant of Reed–Sternberg cell. These are common in the nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma. Subtypes of Hodgkin's lymphoma along with their characteristic types of RS cells is given below: Hodgkin lymphoma (subty pes) Diagnostic cells in histology Immunophenotype Nodular sclerosis Lacunar variant CD 15+, CD 30 + Mixed cellularity Mononuclear and Diagnostic RS cells (70% EBV +) CD 15+, CD 30 + Lymphocyte Rich Mononuclear and Diagnostic RS cells (40% EBV +) CD 15+, CD 30 + Lymphocyte Depletion Reticular variant; (most EBV +) CD 15+, CD 30 + Lymphocyte predominance Lymphocytic and histiocytic variant, popcorn cells (EBV -) CD 20+, BCL6+CD 15 -, CD 3 0 - The image given below shows nodular sclerosis type of HL with lacunar cells.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the nodular sclerosis variant of Hodgkin lymphoma?
options: Reed-Sternberg cells are positive for PAX 5
It is uncommonly associated with Epstein Barr Virus
Reed-Sternberg cells are positive for CD45
explanation: Reed–Sternberg cells in nodular sclerosis variant of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) are negative for CD45. It is the most common variant. These are characterized by the presence of lacunar variant Reed–Sternberg cells and the deposition of collagen bands. These bands divide involved lymph nodes into circumscribed nodules. The Reed-Sternberg cells are found in a polymorphous background of T cells, eosinophils, plasma cells, and macrophages. Diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cells are often uncommon. The Reed–Sternberg cells are positive for PAX5 (a B-cell transcription factor), CD15, and CD30, and negative for other B-cell markers, T-cell markers, and CD45 (leukocyte common antigen). This subtype is uncommonly associated with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV). Involvement of the spleen, liver, bone marrow and other organs and tissues can occur later in the disease. The prognosis is excellent.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Lymph node biopsy of which of the following variants of Hodgkin lymphoma will show the maximum area of necrosis?
explanation: The lymphocyte-depleted subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma is associated with maximum necrosis of the lymph nodes. Lymphocyte-depleted is the least common type (<5%). It is seen in older and HIV-infected individuals and can present with systemic symptoms. There is a paucity of lymphocytes and a relative abundance of Reed–Sternberg (RS) cells or their pleomorphic variants. RS cells are CD15+ and CD30+ RS cells are infected with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) in 90% of the cases. It has a poor prognosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma is most commonly associated with HIV?
explanation: The Mixed cellularity subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL) is most commonly associated with HIV. Note: Although both mixed cellularity and lymphocyte depletion are seen in patients with HIV, mixed cellularity is more commonly associated with HIV.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 15-year-old male patient came to the OPD with cervical lymph node enlargement. The biopsy was examined, which showed a variant of the Reed-Sternberg cell given in the image. Which of the following types of Hodgkin's lymphoma frequently has this cell in its histology?
explanation: The given image shows the lymphohistiocytic variant (L&H) of Reed–Sternberg (RS) cell. It is seen frequently in lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma. The cell has the following features: Polypoid nuclei Inconspicuous nucleoli Moderately abundant cytoplasm As it resembles popcorn in its morphology it is also termed popcorn cell. Note: A unique paraneoplastic syndrome associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma is the occurrence of pain in the affected lymph nodes during alcohol consumption. This has been attributed to the enlargement of the affected lymph nodes following alcohol consumption, which stretches the capsule of the lymph node and produces pain.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A young male presented with cervical lymphadenopathy. The biopsy of the lymph node showed RS cells with vague nodule formation and a background of reactive T-lymphocytes. The cells were positive for CD20, LCA, EMA and negative for CD 15 and CD30. What is the diagnosis?
options: T cell rich B cell lymphoma
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL). Axial group (cervical) lymphadenopathy and along with the L&H variant of Reed-Sternberg cells is characteristic. RS cells are neoplastic giant cells. In NLPHL, the cells have vague nodular formation. Immunophenotyping is positive for CD20 (B cell-associated), LCA (CD45), EMA (epithelial marker), and negative for CD15 (monocyte or macrophage-associated) and CD30 (activation marker). The image given below shows the L&H variant of RS cells seen in NLPHL.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In a patient with lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma, cells are found to be positive for which of the following marker?
explanation: Nodular-lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin Lymphomas have Reed Sternberg cells(aka L&H CELL) that are BCL-6 positive & CD 20 positive and CD 15 & CD 30 negative. Note: CD30 is the most sensitive marker of Reed–Sternberg cell. PAX5 is the most specific marker of Reed–Sternberg cell.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma?
options: It can progress to a tumor resembling DLBCL
The bone marrow involvement is rare
A strong association with EBV is seen
explanation: Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL) is not associated with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) infection. In 3% to 5% of cases, this type transforms into a tumor resembling diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. A majority of patients are males, usually younger than 35 years of age, who typically present with cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Mediastinal and bone marrow involvement is rare. This form of HL is more likely to recur than the classical subtypes, but the prognosis is excellent.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 23-year-old man is diagnosed to have Stage II (A) Hodgkin's lymphoma. What staging system was most likely used to classify the tumor of this patient?
explanation: Clinical staging of both Hodgkin and Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is done by Ann-Arbor classification. Option B: Masaoka staging is used for thymoma. Option C: Modified Durie–Salmon staging is used for multiple myeloma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Who among the following patients is likely to have the best prognosis?
options: A patient with mononuclear variant of Reed-Sternberg cells on lymph node biopsy
A patient whose lymph node biopsy showed lacunar Reed-Sternberg cells
A patient with predominant reticular variant of Reed- Sternberg cells
A patient with Reed-Sternberg cells amid mixed variety of background cells
explanation: The prognosis of the nodular sclerosis ( a subtype of classical Hodgkin lymphoma) is excellent compared to the other subtypes mentioned in the options. Lacunar Reed-Sternberg cells are seen in this condition. The nodular sclerosis type occurs with equal frequency in males and females. It has a propensity to involve the lower cervical, supraclavicular, and mediastinal lymph nodes of adolescents or young adults. Subtypes of Hodgkin's lymphoma along with their characteristic types of RS cells is given below: Nodular lymphocyte-predominant non-classical Hodgkin lymphoma also has an excellent prognosis. Hodgkin lymphoma (subty pes) Diagnostic cells in histology Immunophenotype Nodular sclerosis Lacunar variant CD 15+, CD 30 + Mixed cellularity Mononuclear and Diagnostic RS cells (70% EBV +) CD 15+, CD 30 + Lymphocyte Rich Mononuclear and Diagnostic RS cells (40% EBV -) CD 15+, CD 30 + Lymphocyte Depletion Reticular variant; (most EBV +) CD 15+, CD 30 + Lymphocyte predominance Lymphocytic and histiocytic variant, popcorn cells (EBV -) CD 20+, BCL6+CD 15 -, CD 3 0 -
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which among the following is incorrect about Hodgkin's lymphoma?
options: Histologic type is the most important prognostic variable.
The cure rate of patients with stages I and IIA is close to 90%.
Long-term survivors treated with radiotherapy had a much higher incidence of secondary malignancies.
It most commonly presents as painless lymphadenopathy.
explanation: With current treatment protocols, the tumor stage is the most important prognostic variable, not histologic type. Hodgkin's Lymphoma most commonly presents as painless lymphadenopathy. The cure rate of patients with stages I and IIA are close to 90%. Long-term survivors treated with radiotherapy had a much higher incidence of certain malignancies, such as lung cancer, melanoma, and breast cancer.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Which of these parameters would be considered a poor prognostic factor in patients with Hodgkin's lymphoma?
Serum albumin level <5g/dL
explanation: Absolute lymphocyte count <600 cells/cumm is a poor prognostic factor for Hodgkin lymphoma. Poor prognostic factors for Hodgkin's lymphoma: Age >45 years Male gender Haemoglobin <10.5 g/dl Total WBC count >15000 cells/mm3 Lymphocytopenia: absolute count <600/mm3 or lymphocytes <8% of leukocytes Serum albumin level: <4g/dl Stage IV Non Hodgkin Lymphomas: General Considerations
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the areas in the histology of lymph nodes show small-unchallenged B cells surrounding pale-staining germinal centres?
explanation: The mantle zone of the lymph nodes shows small, unchallenged B cells surrounding pale-staining germinal centres. Structures in a follicle: Germinal centre - round/oval zone containing pale-staining cells surrounded by darker cells. Mantle zone - small, unchallenged B cells surrounding pale-staining germinal centres. Marginal zone - Light zone surrounding follicles; contains post-follicular memory B cells derived fter stimulation of recirculating cells from T-cell-dependent antigen.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a B lymphocyte marker?
explanation: CD13 is an antigen of monocyte/macrophage and not B-cell.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Non-Hodgkin lymphoma?
options: It involves multiple peripheral lymph nodes
Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring are rarely involved
explanation: Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring are commonly involved in non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which is the most common non-Hodgkin lymphoma in adults?
explanation: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) in adults and children over the age of 15 years, worldwide and in India. Burkitt's lymphoma is the most common NHL in children under the age of 15 years.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a B-cell neoplasm?
explanation: Anaplastic large cell lymphoma is a T-cell lymphoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common site for primary extranodal lymphoma?
explanation: The most common site for primary extranodal lymphoma is the stomach. The term primary extranodal non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma (PE-NHL) refers to lymphomas that present with the disease at any organ or tissue other than lymph nodes or spleen. Gastrointestinal lymphoma is the most common form of primary extranodal lymphoma, accounting for 30%–40% of cases. The most common site involved is the stomach (60%–75% of cases), followed by the small bowel, ileum, cecum, colon, and rectum. Note: The most common site for extranodal non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) in AIDS is Primary CNS lymphoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which lymphoid neoplasm is associated with the human herpesvirus 8?
explanation: Primary effusion lymphoma is associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8). It is a rare type of diffuse large B cell lymphoma with lymphomatous effusions in pleural, pericardial, and abdominal cavities, but no tumor mass. Only one body cavity is typically involved. It is strongly associated with HHV8 and advanced HIV and usually EBV. It can also occurs in non-immunosuppressed patients, often the elderly.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Which of the following is correctly matched with its associated etiological factor?
1-b, 2-c, 3-e, 4-a, 5-d
explanation: The correctly matched neoplasms with their associated etiological factor: Extranodal marginal cell lymphoma - H.pylori infection (c) Intestinal T-cell lymphomas - Gluten-sensitive enteropathy (d) Anaplastic large cell lymphoma - Breast implants (b) Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma - Hepatitis C infection (e) Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma - HIV infection (a) Non Hodgkin Lymphomas: Low Grade
subject: Pathology

question_text: The peripheral smear finding of a patient with fever and lymphadenopathy is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The peripheral smear finding shows Downey cells or ballerina skirt cells. These are typically seen in infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and cytomegalovirus (CMV). They are atypical lymphocytes with abundant basophilic cytoplasm containing clear vacuolations and prominent nucleoli. They become large as a result of antigen stimulation.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Bruton tyrosine kinase is involved in which type of B-cell lymphoma?
explanation: Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) is associated with B-cell chronic lymphocytic lymphoma/ small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL). Tumour cells in CLL rely on signals generated by the B-cell receptor for growth and survival. These signals are transduced by a cascade of kinases that include BTK. Note: BTK is also defective in patients with congenital X-linked agammaglobulinemia.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 65-year-old man presents with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. On examination, he is found to have generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Investigations show a total WBC count of 1 lakh per microliter, with 80% lymphocytes. Peripheral smear is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical presentation and peripheral smear findings point toward a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The peripheral smear shows smudge cells and increased lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm, round to slightly irregular nuclei containing clumped chromatin. This large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes is often described as a "convent-girl" appearance. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) / Small lymphocytic lymphoma(SLL) is the most common leukemia among adults in the western world. The differentiating point between CLL and SLL is that in CLL the absolute lymphocyte count is >5000 per mm³ and in SLL:<5000 per mm³. It is usually asymptomatic at diagnosis but can present with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are usually seen. Total blood count: Total leukocyte count is highly variable; leukopenia is seen when the marrow is involved. Hypogammaglobulinemia is common and contributes to increased susceptibility to infections. 10% to 15% of patients develop hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia due to autoantibodies made by nonneoplastic B cells. Peripheral smear: Predominantly shows small lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm Smudge cells or basket cells or parachute cells - artifacts of the lymphocytes which are disrupted during the process of making smears. Contains a large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes, which is often described as a convent-girl appearance. Spherocytes (due to coexisting autoimmune hemolytic anemia) and nucleated RBCs (due to premature release of progenitors in face of severe anemia, marrow infiltration by the tumor, or both) Lymph node biopsy: Diffuse effacement composed of small lymphocytes admixed with variable numbers of larger activated lymphocytes that often gather in loose aggregate Referred to as proliferation centers, which contain mitotically active cells. Proliferation center are pathognomonic for CLL / SLL. The chromosomal defects: Deletion of 13q (commonest and has a good prognosis) Deletion of 11q Trisomy 12q Deletion of 17p (poor prognosis).
subject: Pathology

question_text: The neoplastic cells in chronic lymphocytic leukemia/ small lymphocytic lymphoma originate from which of the following?
explanation: The cell of origin for chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL) is either a post-germinal center memory B cell or a naive B cell. The cells of CLL show both unmutated Ig segments (those of naive B-cell origin) and somatic hypermutated Ig segments (those of post-germinal center memory B cell). Tumours with unmutated Ig segments (those of naive B-cell origin) pursue a more aggressive course.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a genetic anomaly seen in patients with chronic lymphocytic lymphoma/ small lymphocytic lymphoma?
explanation: Deletion of 17p is a genetic anomaly seen in chronic lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL)/ small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL), not trisomy 17p. The genetic anomalies seen in CLL/SLL are: Trisomy 12q Deletion of 13q Deletion of 17p (bad prognosis) Deletion of 11q (bad prognosis)
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 70-year-old man presents with weakness and generalized lymphadenopathy. Lymph node biopsy shows difuse effacement with small lymphocytes and proliferation centers. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL). Lymph node biopsy in CLL/SLL shows effacement of normal nodal architecture by sheets of predominantly small lymphocytes. They have round to slightly irregular nuclei, condensed chromatin, and scant cytoplasm. Admixed are a variable number of larger activated lymphocytes that often gather in loose aggregates referred to as proliferation centers. These contain mitotically active cells. When present, proliferation centers are pathognomic for CLL/SLL (also known as a pseudofollicular pattern). The image given below shows a lymph node biopsy of CLL in a low-power view. It shows loss of normal architecture and a large, pale-staining area in the center of the node (a proliferation center)
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 58-year-old man with cervical lymphadenopathy is suspected to have chronic lymphocytic leukemia. What should be the absolute lymphocyte count/mm3 to diagnose this condition?
explanation: The diagnostic requirement for chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is absolute lymphocyte count >5000 per cubic millimetre. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL) differ only in the degree of peripheral blood lymphocytosis: CLL - 5000/mm3 SLL - <5000 cells/mm3 Note: CLL is the most common leukemia of adults in the western world.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Flow cytometric analysis of four patients is given below. Who among the following is most likely suffering from chronic lymphocytic leukemia?
explanation: Small lymphocytes of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/ small lymphocytic leukemia (SLL) are CD23 and CD5 positive. Hence, the flow cytometry of patient 1 (CD23 and CD5 positive) correctly represents the phenotype of CLL. The tumour cells also express the pan B-cell markers CD19 and CD20 Low-level expression of surface Ig (usually IgM or IgM and IgD) is also typical. Given below is the explanation of how to interpret flow cytometry results: Interpretation of results: œuadrant 1- Cells marked in green: -VE for A antigen, +VE for B antigen œuadrant 2- Cells marked in purple: -VE for both the antigens. œuadrant 3- Cells marked in yellow: +VE for both the antigens œuadrant 4- Cells marked in red: +VE for A antigen, -VE for B antigen
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 73-year-old man came with complaints of malaise and low-grade fever. He had generalized lymphadenopathy. The histopathological examination of the lymph node is as shown below. These cells showed positivity for CD5, CD19, CD20, and CD23. Which of the following does not indicate a poor prognosis in this condition?
explanation: The given scenario and histopathological findings are suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). The presence of NOTCH1 mutation is associated with a poor prognosis in chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL). The histopathological image shows small, darker staining lymphocytes with prominent nucleoli which are typically seen in chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL). Variables that correlate with a worse outcome include: The presence of deletions of 11q and 17p Lack of somatic hypermutation Expression of ZAP-70 Presence of NOTCH 1 mutation
subject: Pathology

question_text: A middle-aged woman presented with chronic fatigue and generalized lymphadenopathy. Investigations revealed overexpression of BCL2. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of follicular lymphoma. This condition is associated with overexpression of BCL2. It usually presents in middle age as painless generalized lymphadenopathy. The involvement of extranodal sites is relatively uncommon. It has an indolent waxing and waning course. In almost 50% of patients, this cancer gets transformed to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The median survival rate is for 7-9 years. The cell of origin for follicular lymphoma is germinal centre B cells. It shows (14;18) translocation. Lymph node biopsy shows closely packed follicles. Centrocytes (small cells with the cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm) and centroblasts (large cells with open nuclear chromatin and multiple nucleoli) are seen. Bone marrow is involved in 85% of the cases and shows para-trabecular lymphoid aggregates.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following chromosomal abnormality is likely to be seen in patients with follicular lymphoma?
explanation: Follicular lymphoma shows t(14;18). Its hallmark is a translocation that juxtaposes the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the BCL2 locus on chromosome 18. It is seen in up to 90% of follicular lymphomas and leads to overexpression of BCL2. BCL2 inhibits apoptosis and promotes the survival of follicular lymphoma cells.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 45-year-old man presents with painless generalized lymphadenopathy and weakness. Lymph node biopsy shows the following picture. Which of the following is not true for this condition?
options: Possible transformation into diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
explanation: The lymph biopsy shows closely packed back-to-back follicles of variable areas and very less inter-follicular area. It is suggestive of follicular lymphoma. Follicular lymphoma usually follows an indolent waxing and waning course, not an aggressive course. Lymph node (LN) biopsy shows a nodular pattern with centrocytes and centroblasts as shown below. Immunophenotyping: The cell of origin is germinal-center B cell, so it is positive for CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL6, and urface Ig. BCL2 expression is positive in over 90% of cases. Histologic transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) occurs in 30 to 50% of cases. Note: In contrast to follicular lymphoma, DLBCL has an aggressive course, shows a diffuse pattern of growth in lymph node biopsy and shows BCL-6 positivity.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with longstanding cervical lymphadenopathy was diagnosed with mantle cell lymphoma. What is the cell of origin for this condition?
explanation: Mantle-cell lymphoma arises from the mantle-zone B cells which are naive B cells as they lack somatic hypermutation IgH gene. Mantle-cell lymphomas have an (11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and overexpression of cyclin D1. It is CD5 positive and CD23 negative. Comparison between mantle-cell lymphoma and chronic lymphocytic leukemia/ small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/ SLL): Mantle cell lympho ma CLL/S LL CD5 Positive Positi ve CD23 Negative Positi ve CyclinD 1 Positive Negat ive Mantle cell lympho ma CLL/S LL FMC7 Positive Negat ive CD10, B CL6 Negative Negat ive
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements about mantle cell lymphoma is false?
options: Most common presentation is painless lymphadenopathy
Associated with overexpression of cyclin D1
Tumor cells are CD5 + and CD23 +
explanation: The neoplastic cells in mantle cell lymphoma are CD5 positive and CD23 negative. Mantle cell lymphoma usually presents as painless lymphadenopathy. Centroblasts and proliferation centers are absent, differentiating it from chronic lymphocytic lymphoma. Immunophenotyping reveals the cells expressing cyclin D1, CD5, CD19, CD20, surface Ig. CD23 is negative in these cells.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 53-year-old man was evaluated for painless lymphadenopathy. Biopsy showed a homogenous population of small lymphocytes with cleaved nuclear contours. Which translocation is seen in this condition?
explanation: The given clinical picture and pathological findings point toward the diagnosis of mantle cell lymphoma. The lymph node biopsy typically shows proliferation consisting of a homogenous population of small lymphocytes. The nuclei of these cells have irregular or deeply cleaved contours. Mantle cell lymphoma has(11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the cyclin D1 locus on chromosome 11 that leads to overexpression of cyclin D1. Option A: Follicular lymphoma has t(14:18), not t(18:14). Hence, it is not the answer.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with cervical lymphadenopathy has t(11;14) positive. Which of the following markers should be done to confirm the diagnosis?
explanation: Translocation (11;14) is characteristic of mantle cell lymphoma. The markers to be done to confirm the diagnosis, are Sox11 and Cyclin D1. Mantle cell lymphoma is seen in the fifth and sixth decades of life and has a male predominance. It is characterised by painless lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. In some cases, there is multifocal mucosal involvement of the small bowel and colon known as lymphomatoid polyposis. It has (11;14) translocation. Lymph node biopsy shows nodal tumour cells may surround reactive germinal centres. A homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours is typically seen. Large cells resembling centroblasts and proliferation centres are absent, distinguishing mantle cell lymphoma from follicular lymphoma and CLL/SLL, respectively. Immunophenotyping is positive for cyclin D and SOX-11. SOX11 variant that often presents with circulating disease with splenomegaly but without significant lymphadenopathy and with a low Ki67 index (<10%). Other markers include: CD 5, CD19 and CD20 +ve CD 23 -ve Moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with  or  light chain) The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the immunohistochemistry marker for cyclinD1 negative mantle cell lymphoma?
explanation: SOX11 is the marker used for cyclinD1 negative mantle cell lymphoma. Note: MYD88 is a marker for Waldenstorm macroglobulinemia.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements about marginal zone lymphoma is false?
options: They arise within tissues involved by chronic inflammatory disorder
They spread rapidly to other site
They may regress if the inciting agent is eradicated
Transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma may occur
explanation: Marginal zone lymphoma does not spread rapidly to other sites. It remains localised for prolonged periods and spread systematically in the later course of the disease. They are B-cell tumours that arise within lymph nodes, spleen, or extranodal tissues. It is the most common primary extranodal lymphoma. They arise within tissues involved by chronic inflammatory disorders of autoimmune or infectious aetiology: Salivary gland in Sjögren disease Thyroid gland in Hashimoto thyroiditi Stomach in Helicobacter gastriti They may regress if the inciting agent is eradicated. Antibiotic therapy directed against Helicobacter pylori leads to tumour regression. Translocations are associated with MALToma are t(11;18),t(14;18) and t(1;14). These translocations then upregulate BCL-10/MALT1, a protein that activates NF-kB and promotes the growth and survival of B-cells. They may invade epithelial structures to form lymphoepithelial lesions. Transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma may occur.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with long-standing Hashimoto's thyroiditis was noted to have a swelling in the thyroid region. After evaluation, it was diagnosed as a marginal zone lymphoma. What is the cell of origin of this lymphoma?
explanation: Marginal zone lymphomas are considered to be of memory B cell origin. In most cases, they show evidence of somatic hypermutation. The category of marginal zone lymphoma encompasses a heterogeneous group of B cell tumours that arise within lymph nodes, spleen, or extranodal tissues. They are often referred to as MALTomas.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient presents to you with rapidly growing swelling on her right cheek. Past history is significant for Sjögren syndrome. You suspect a lymphoid neoplasm in her. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: Lymphomas arising in the setting of Sjögren syndrome in the salivary gland is marginal-zone lymphomas. They often arise in tissues involved by chronic inflammatory disorders of autoimmune or infectious aetiology such as: Salivary gland in Sjögren syndrome Thyroid gland in Hashimoto thyroiditi Stomach in Helicobacter gastritis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following translocations is seen in extra-nodal marginal-zone lymphoma?
explanation: The translocation seen in marginal-zone lymphoma is t(11;18). Other translocations include t(14;18), t(1;14). Marginal-zone lymphoma begins as a polyclonal immune reaction. Signals from the antigen-stimulated T helper cells, drive the growth and survival of the clonal B-cells. At this stage, it is reversible, as in gastric MALToma after antibiotics against Helicobacter pylori. With time tumour cells may acquire mutations that render their growth and survival antigen-independent. Translocations such as t(11;18), t(14;18), or t(1;14) up-regulate the expression and function of BCL10 or MALT1 and promote the growth and survival of B cells. These translocations are relatively specific for extranodal marginal-zone lymphomas.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 34-year-old woman came with complaints of chronic lethargy and weakness. Complete blood counts revealed pancytopenia. The peripheral smear showed the following picture. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hairy cell leukemia. It is a B-cell neoplasm and not a T-cell lymphoma. The peripheral smear shows leukemic cells with fine circumferential cytoplasmic hairy projections as shown below. Patients present with massive splenomegaly and pancytopenia. There is an increased incidence of atypical mycobacterial infections, possibly related to frequent unexplained monocytopenia. Activating point mutations in the serine/threonine kinase BRAF is seen in 90% of cases. Peripheral smear shows fine circumferential cytoplasmic hairy projections which are best recognized under the phase-contrast microscope. The bone marrow aspirate produces a dry tap. A trephine biopsy reveals infiltration by the cancer cells often in the pattern of a honeycomb appearance. Leukemic cells have nuclei surrounded by a cytoplasmic halo (fried egg appearance). The neoplastic cells stain positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP). Markers for hairy cell leukemia include: pan-B-cell markers- CD 19, CD2O CD11c CD25 CD103 annexin A1
subject: Pathology
