question_text: A 65-year-old man with a dragging sensation in his abdomen is found to have massive splenomegaly. The peripheral blood smear findings are as follows. Which of the following markers would you test to confirm the diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical features and peripheral smear showing fine circumferential cytoplasmic hairy projections point towards the diagnosis of hairy cell leukaemia. It's a rare but distinctive neoplasm of the B cells where splenomegaly is often the only abnormal finding. Pancytopenia from marrow involvement and sequestration of cells in the enlarged spleen is seen in half the cases and infections are seen in one-third of the affected patients. CD103 must be tested among the markers to confirm hairy cell leukaemia. Hairy-cell leukaemias typically express the following markers: Pan B-cell markers CD19, CD20, surface Ig (usually IgG) CD11c CD25 CD103 Annexin A1. Annexin A1 is the most specific and sensitive marker.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A histological specimen of the spleen is shown below. Which non-Hodgkin's lymphoma does not arise from the area marked as 1?
explanation: The area marked '1' in the image is the white pulp of the spleen. Hairy-cell leukemia does not arise from the white pulp, it involves only the red pulp of the spleen. The other condition involving the red pulp is hepato-splenic lymphoma. All the other non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs) involve white pulp. Splenomegaly is the most common and often the only abnormal physical finding in hairy-cell leukemia. The spleen in this condition is described as a beefy red spleen. The image given below shows the normal histology of the spleen.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 60-year-old woman presented with generalized itching and mild hypoaesthesia of the skin. On examination, maculopapular patches were seen on her back. Biopsy revealed the presence of atypical lymphocytes with cerebriform nuclei infiltrating the dermis and epidermis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given pathological feature is characteristic of a Pautrier's microabscess. These are seen in mycosis fungoides. It is a mature, cutaneous, CD4+ T-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Skin lesions include truncal scaling, red-brown patches, plaques, and fungating nodules. Lesions may evolve into a systemic lymphoma, with visceral and nodal spread. Sezary syndrome is a variant of mycosis fungoides. It is the leukemic seeding of blood by malignant T cells from the skin (CD4+). It presents with diffuse erythroderma and scaling. Histological hallmark includes: Sézary-Lutzner cells - cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane). Pautrier's microabscesses - tumor cells invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters. Epidermotropism - invasion of the tumor cells into the epidermis. The image shows sezary cells with cerebriform nuclei in the peripheral smear.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient presents with generalized exfoliative erythroderma. The peripheral blood smear shows the following cell. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image shows a classical Sezary cell with cerebriform nuclei which points towards a diagnosis of Sezary syndrome. These are neoplastic T cells. Sezary syndrome and mycosis fungoides are different manifestations of tumors of CD4+ helper T cells that are home to the skin. Sezary syndrome is a variant presenting as generalized exfoliative erythroderma. It rarely goe into tumefaction and there is associated leukemia of Sezary cells. In Mycosis fungoides, only the epidermis and upper dermis are infiltrated by neoplastic T cells with the characteristic cerebriform appearance. In the later stages of the disease, progression occurs to lymph nodes and bone marrow. Tumour cells are not seen in blood. The disease progresses through the premycotic phase, plaque phase, and tumour phase.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
You suspect a lymphoid neoplasm in a patient who is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis. On workup, she has splenomegaly and her blood count showed neutropenia and lymphocytosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Marginal zone lymphoma
explanation: A triad of rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia is known as Felty's syndrome. Some patients with Felty's syndrome have large granular lymphocytic leukemia as an underlying cause. Large granular lymphocytic leukemia is a T-cell (CD3+) and NK-cell (CD56+) variant leukemia. They are associated with mutations in the transcription factor, STAT3. Patients usually presents with mild to moderate lymphocytosis and splenomegaly. Neutropenia and anemia are also present. Lymphadenopathy and hepatomegaly are usually absent. There is an increased incidence of rheumatological disorders associated with this condition. The peripheral smear picture shows large lymphocytes with abundant blue cytoplasm and few azurophilic granules. Non Hodgkin Lymphomas: High Grade
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 5-year-old boy presents with weight loss, fever, and a painless swelling in the area of his jaw. CBC reveals anaemia and lymphocytosis. Biopsy findings from the swelling are shown in the image below. Which of the following is not true about this patient’s condition?
options: All forms of this tumour are associated with translocations of the MYC gene
Endemic forms are latently infected with EBV
Tumor exhibits a high mitotic index
Neoplastic cells are usually BCL2 positive
explanation: The clinical presentation and biopsy findings point to a diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma. Neoplastic cells in Burkitt's lymphoma are usually BCL2 negative. The biopsy image shows the classical finding of Burkitt's lymphoma called the starry sky appearance. Tumour cells show multiple small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm and a high mitotic index. They are closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (sky). The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debris. They are called tingible body macrophages. Upon fixation, the cytoplasm of these phagocytes washes away leaving behind white spaces filled with debris (the stars). Burkitt lymphoma is the most common NHL in children <15 years. Three distinct clinical forms of Burkitt's lymphoma are: Endemic- affects children in Africa, affects jaw, maxilla, and is EBV-associated. Sporadic- in adults in western countries. Immunodeficiency associated- is associated with HIV infection. It is the most rapidly proliferating human tumor, Ki-67 stains for 100% of cells (DLBCL- 40% staining with Ki-67). Histology shows the characteristic starry sky pattern. Immunophenotypic markers include: Surface IgM type and immunoglobulin light chains (kappa > lambda) B cell-associated antigens -CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a Germinal centre-associated markers- CD10 & BCL-6 HLA-DR and CD43 Expression of CD21 -the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)/C3d receptor, is dependent on the EBV status of the tumors Endemic BL: EBV (+), express CD21 Non-endemic BL: EBV (--) and lack CD21 expression Treatment must begin within 48h of diagnosis in both children and adults with an intensive combination of chemotherapy regimens with high doses of cyclophosphamide and CNS prophylaxis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 7-year-old boy who presented with the following finding was diagnosed with Burkitt's lymphoma. Which of the following translocations is most likely to be seen in this condition?
explanation: The translocation seen in Burkitt's lymphoma is t(8;14) causing translocation of the MYC gene. It is the most common translocation and is seen in 70% of the cases. Other translocations that may be present include t(2;8) and t(8;22).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Translocations of which of the following proto-oncogenes is most likely present in patients with Burkitt lymphoma?
explanation: All forms of Burkitt lymphoma are highly associated with translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8 that lead to increased MYC protein levels. In addition to the MYC translocations in Burkitt lymphoma and a subset of other B and T cell tumours, MYC is amplified in some breast, colon, lung, and many other carcinomas. The functionally identical NMYC and LMYC genes are also amplified in neuroblastomas and small-cell cancers of the lung, respectively.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common site for sporadic Burkitt's lymphoma?
explanation: Sporadic Burkitt's lymphoma most often presents as a mass involving the ileocecum and peritoneum. About 15 to 20% of these are associated with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV). Endemic Burkitt's lymphoma, in contrast, presents as a mass involving the mandible. It shows an unusual predilection for the involvement of abdominal viscera, particularly kidneys, ovaries and adrenal glands. Involvement of the bone marrow and peripheral blood is uncommon. Immunodeficiency-associated Burkitt's lymphoma commonly involves the gastrointestinal tract (GIT) and central nervous system (CNS).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which lymphoma has ki67 index near 100%?
explanation: Burkitt's lymphoma is a very aggressive tumour, having a very high mitotic index and a ki67 of about 100%. ki67 is a proliferation marker used to assess the mitotic index of the tumour. It is high in high-grade tumours and low in low-grade tumours. Both mantle-cell lymphoma and DLBCL also have a high ki67, but it is not as high as that seen in Burkitt's. Follicular lymphoma is a low-grade tumour, and hence, it has a low ki67 index. The following are the images of Burkitt's lymphoma. Image a - sheets of medium-sized cells with numerous tingible body macrophages showing the classic starry-sky pattern. Image b - BCL 6 stain positivity in lymphoma cells. Image c - the Ki-67 proliferation rate of virtually 100%. Image d - EBER (Ebstein-Barr encoding region) in situ hybridization with numerous positive cells.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 35-year-old presented with fever and ulcerated tonsils. His peripheral smear showed lymphocytosis. The Monospot test was negative. Tonsillectomy was done, and the biopsy showed the following picture. The larger cells were positive for CD20, EBVLMP1, MUM1, and CD79a and negative for CD15. Background cells were positive for CD3. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) positive diffuse large-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). The histopathological findings show large cells with multilobed irregular nuclei. These cells are positive for CD20, CD79a, IRF4/MUM1, EBVLMP1. The smaller cells in the background are CD3+ which is a T-cell marker. It is seen in the elderly (>50 years) and without immunodeficiency or prior lymphoma. 70% of the cases are extranodal and mainly affect skin, lung, tonsil, and stomach with or without LN involvement. 30% of the cases have LN disease alone. Option A: This is not infectious mononucleosis as the monospot test is negative. Option B: It is not Hodgkin lymphoma because it is positive for CD20 and CD79a and negative for CD15. Option D: It is not EBV positive mucocutaneous ulcer as the patient is immunocompetent and it is strongly positive for CD20. Note: EBV positive mucocutaneous ulcer occurs in immunocompromised patients and reverts to treating the immunocompromised state. It shows polymorphous infiltrate and atypical large B cells with RS cell-like morphology admixed abundant T cells. There is a uniform expression of CD30, MUM1, PA›5, OCT2. There is variable expression of CD20,CD45, CD15, CD79a, BCL6.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A lymph node biopsy of a patient suffering from follicular lymphoma shows the presence of large cells with prominent multilobulated nuclei and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. Which of the following will test positive in this condition?
explanation: The given history and histopathological examination point towards the diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). It is molecularly heterogeneous and can show the given abnormalities: BCL6 (transcription factor) overexpression is most common 10 to 20% cases have t(14;18) leading to overexpression of BCL2 (a proto-oncogene) 5% are associated with MYC translocations (like Burkitt's lymphoma) Mutations in gene encoding histone acetyltransferases DLBCL and follicular lymphoma, both are positive for CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6 (germinal-center B-cell origin). While BCL2 is positive in >90% of the cases of follicular lymphoma, it can also be positive in DLBCL. To differentiate DLBCL from follicular lymphoma, the ki67 index is used. If ki67 >40% (high) it suggests DLBCL.
subject: Pathology

question_text: You have been asked to use the International prognostic index for lymphomas to predict the prognosis of a patient suffering from DLBCL. Which of the following is not the component of this index?
options: Number of extra lymphatic sites involve
explanation: Hemoglobin levels are not a part of the International prognostic index (IPI) score. IPI is based on the presence or absence of five adverse prognostic factors: Age >60 years Raised serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) Performance status >2 (ECOG) or <70 (Karnfosky) >1 site of extranodal (extra lymphatic) involvement Ann Arbor stage III or IV
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 55-year-old woman, on treatment for chronic lymphocytic leukemia, notices rapidly growing swellings in her neck and axilla. She also complains of fever and weight loss. The physician suspects a transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. What is this condition called?
explanation: The transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/ small lymphocytic leukemia (SLL) to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma is called Richter syndrome. It is seen in approximately 5% to 10% of the cases. Option B: Chédiak–Higashi syndrome is an autosomal-recessive disorder that arises from a mutation of a lysosomal trafficking regulator protein. It leads to a decrease in phagocytosis, recurrent pyogenic infections, albinism, and peripheral neuropathy. Sézary syndrome (SS) is a triad of erythroderma, generalized lymphadenopathy, and the presence of clonally related neoplastic T cells. These cells have cerebriform nuclei (Sézary cells) and are seen in the skin, lymph nodes, and peripheral blood. Kostmann's syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by severe neutropenia. It is associated with mutations in G-CSF.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 58-year-old woman came with complaints of swelling in her hard palate. Biopsy from the swelling showed the following picture. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario and histopathological image point towards a diagnosis of anaplastic large cell lymphoma. The biopsy shows characteristic large anaplastic cells, some containing horseshoe-shaped nuclei and voluminous cytoplasm called hallmark cells. It is a type of T-cell lymphoma that consists of large lymphoid cells. This occurs due to rearrangements in the ALK gene and usually affects children and young adults. It frequently involves soft tissue and carries a good prognosis. T-cell lymphomas with similar morphology without ALK positivity occur in older adults and have a bad prognosis. CD markers: T cell markers (CD3, CD4, CD8 etc) +, CD30+.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which is an aggressive lymphoid neoplasm that classically occurs in the oral cavity of immunosuppressed patients?
explanation: Plasmablastic lymphoma is an aggressive lymphoid neoplasm that classically occurs in the oral cavity in immunosuppressed patients. Plasmablastic lymphoma usually occurs in HIV+ patients (73%), immunosuppressed or elderly patients without known immunodeficiency, and EBV+ patients. Lymphomas more specific to HIV+ patients: Primary effusion lymphoma Plasmablastic lymphoma Primary CNS lymphoma
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 44-year-old man with nasal obstruction, nasal secretion, and facial erythema was diagnosed with facial cellulitis. When his condition did not improve on antibiotics, a CT scan was performed. It showed a destructive mass in the right nasal cavity extending into the nasopharynx. Which of the following is most likely to present this way?
explanation: Extranodal NK/T-Cell Lymphoma is most likely to present as a destructive nasopharyngeal mass. Less common sites of presentation include the testis and the skin. It accounts for 3% of all non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs) in Asia. Extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma is highly associated with EBV. The tumor cells typically surround and invade the small vessels leading to extensive ischemic necrosis. In touch preparations, large azurophilic granules are seen in the cytoplasm of the tumor cells. They express NK-cell markers (CD16, CD56) supporting an NK-cell origin. Most extranodal NK/T-cell lymphomas are highly aggressive neoplasms that respond well to radiation therapy but are resistant to chemotherapy.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 63-year-old man presented with severe pallor and giddiness. Clinical examination revealed bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. Peripheral blood examination showed lymphocytosis and the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear findings showing cloverleaf cells, point towards a diagnosis of adult T-cell leukemia/ lymphoma. Adult T-cell leukemia/ lymphoma occurs in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). Common findings include skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly and hypercalcemia. Peripheral smear blood shows characteristic cloverleaf cells or flower cells which are tumour cells with multilobulated nuclei. Lymphocytosis is also observed. It is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year. The image given below shows peripheral blood smear findings in adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma. Note: Apart from adult T-cell leukemia, HTLV-1 may also give rise to progressive demyelinating disease of the CNS and spinal cord.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 35-year-old man presents with weight loss and abdominal pain. He is a known case of celiac disease on a strict gluten-free diet. CT of the abdomen revealed a thickened loop of small bowel with stricture and associated lymphadenopathy. A lymphoid neoplasm is suspected.
What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The most probable diagnosis in this patient is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma. Individuals with celiac disease have a higher than normal rate of malignancy. The most common cancer associated with celiac disease is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma. It is an aggressive lymphoma of intraepithelial T lymphocytes. When the symptoms in a celiac disease patient deteriorate, even being on a strict gluten-free diet, cancer must be considered. Note: Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also more frequent in individuals with celiac disease.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 56-year-old woman came with complaints of pain and swelling in the left side of the abdomen. Investigations revealed multiple polyps in the rectum and sigmoid colon. A preliminary biopsy report was suggestive of a lymphoid neoplasm. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario points towards the diagnosis of lymphomatoid polyposis. The most common among the non-Hodgkin's lymphoma to present like this is mantle cell lymphoma. Lymphomatoid polyposis is characterized by multifocal mucosal involvement of the proliferating lymphocytes. It has aggressive behavior and a relatively poor prognosis. It must be treated accordingly as a high-grade lymphoma with systemic chemotherapy.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
BRAF V600E mutation is not seen in which of the following condition?
Hairy cell leukaemia
explanation: BRAF V600E (valine to glutamate substitution at residue 600) mutation is not seen in glioblastoma multiforme. BRAF is a serine/threonine kinase positioned immediately downstream of RAS in the MAPK signalling cascade. It is seen in the following conditions: Hairy cell leukaemia Malignant melanoma Langerhans cell histiocytosis Papillary carcinoma thyroi Pilocytic astrocytoma Erdheim–Chester disease Multiple Myeloma and Plasma Cell Disorders
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the normal ratio between kappa and lambda light chains?
explanation: The normal ratio of kappa to lambda light chains is 60:40. In multiple myeloma, usually this ratio is skewed, i.e., favorable secretion of one type of light chain occurs at the expense of the other. Serum-free light chain assay is a recommended part of the initial diagnostic workup for multiple myeloma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Patients with which of the following can be classified under smoldering multiple myeloma?
options: Lack of symptoms and a high plasma M component with bone marrow plasma cells >10%
Plasma cells >10% in the bone marrow, no paraprotein in blood and presence of lytic bone lesions
Plasma cells >10% in bone marrow, abnormal serum free light chain ratio and hypercalcemia
Presence of symptoms and a low plasma M component with plasma cells <10%
explanation: Smoldering multiple myeloma refers to an uncommon variant defined by a lack of symptoms and a high plasma M component. The difference between MGUS, smouldering multiple myeloma, and multiple myeloma is given below: MGUS Smouldering multiple Myelo ma Multiple Myeloma Asymptomatic Asymptomatic Symptomatic M protein in serum <3g/dL M-protein in serum:IgG 3 g/ dL,IgA >1 g/dL M protein in serum and urin e Bone Marrow (BM) plasma c ells <10% BM plasma cells 10-60% BM plasma cells 60% No other organ or tissue imp airment No other organ or tissue imp airment Related impairment is seen.( CRAB)
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 76-year-old man presents for a routine health check-up and is found to be mildly anemic. Physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation demonstrates an IgG-kappa monoclonal protein with markedly reduced IgM and IgA levels. Bone marrow biopsy shows 12% plasma cells. A skeletal survey reveals osteopenia and several punched-out lytic lesions, but no fractures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of multiple myeloma. Plasma cell dyscrasias are B-cell proliferations that contain neoplastic plasma cells that secrete a monoclonal Ig or Ig fragment. Multiple myeloma is a malignant neoplasm of plasma cells characterized by the presence of monoclonal immunoglobulin or light chains in the serum and urine. It is a disease of older adults, with a peak age of incidence of 65 to 70 years. Signs and symptoms include: Hypercalcemia Pathologic fractures/ lytic bone lesions Renal failure Anemia Investigations reveal: Radiography - Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray Electrophoresis - Monoclonal elevation of one immunoglobulin Urinalysis - Free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence Jones proteins) Bone marrow biopsy - 10 to 20%plasma cells (normal is < 5%) Peripheral smear - Rouleaux formation. A high level of M proteins in myeloma causes red cells in the peripheral blood smears to stick to one another in linear arrays, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation. Plasma cell tumors are positive for CD138.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common cytogenetic abnormality in multiple myeloma?
explanation: The most common cytogenetic abnormality in multiple myeloma is translocation 14q. Cytogenetic abnormalities in multiple myeloma include: Translocations involving IGH on chromosome 14q - most frequent Monosomy or partial deletion of chromosome 13 (13q14) - Found by FISH (nearly half the cases) Translocation of the IgH occurs frequently with cyclin D1 on chromosome 11q and cyclin D3 on chromosome 6p Deletions of chromosome 17p involving TP53 tumor-suppressor locus Translocations with cyclin D1 are associated with a good outcome, whereas deletion of 17p and t(4;14) portend an aggressive course.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which cytokine is an important growth factor for plasma cells in multiple myeloma?
explanation: The proliferation and survival of plasma cells are dependent on several cytokines, most notably IL-6. It is an important growth factor for plasma cells. It is produced by the tumor cells themselves and by resident marrow stromal cells. IL6, along with other cytokines, promotes osteoclastic activity and lytic bone lesions. High serum levels of IL-6 are seen in patients with active disease and are associated with a poor prognosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common monoclonal immunoglobulin seen in patients with myeloma?
explanation: The most common monoclonal Ig (M protein) in myeloma is IgG (approximately 55% of patients), followed by IgA (approximately 25% of cases). The immunosecretory disorders are a diverse group of diseases associated with the proliferation of an abnormal clone of immunoglobulin-synthesizing, terminally differentiated B cells. These disorders include: Multiple myeloma (MM) and its variants Plasmacytoma Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance Monoclonal Ig deposition diseases - Includes primary amyloidosis and nonamyloidotic types. The immunoglobulin can be complete or can be composed of either heavy or light chains and is termed M-(monoclonal) protein. Most myelomas are associated with more than 3 gm/dL of serum immunoglobulin. Myelomas expressing IgM, IgD, or IgE occur, but they are rare.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In patients with multiple myeloma, lytic lesions are most commonly seen in which bone?
explanation: Lytic bony lesions in myeloma patients are most commonly seen in the vertebrae. Multiple myeloma usually presents as destructive plasma cell tumors involving the axial skeleton. The bones most commonly affected (in descending order of frequency) are: Vertebral column Ribs Skull Pelvis Femur Clavicle Scapula Pathologic fractures are common in this condition. The bone lesions appear radiographically as punched-out defects, usually 1 to 4 cm in diameter. The image given below shows osteoblastic lesions of vertebra in multiple myeloma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which substance is responsible for the marked increase in bone resorption and hypercalcemia in patients with multiple myeloma?
explanation: MIP1 secreted by myeloma cells is responsible for the marked increase in bone resorption and hypercalcemia. Factors produced by neoplastic plasma cells mediate bone destruction, the major pathologic feature of multiple myeloma. Of particular importance, myeloma-derived macrophage inflammatory protein 1 (MIP1) upregulates the expression of the receptor activator of NF-B ligand (RANKL) by bone marrow stromal cells, which in turn activates osteoclasts. Other factors released from tumor cells, such as modulators of the Wnt pathway, are potent inhibitors of osteoblast function. The net effect is a marked increase in bone resorption, which leads to hypercalcemia and pathological fractures. Serum alkaline phosphate levels are normal in multiple myeloma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A pathologist observed the following finding in a peripheral blood smear. In patients with which of the following conditions is this seen?
explanation: The given peripheral smear shows rouleaux formation. It is seen in patients with early HIV, SLE, and multiple myeloma. Conditions that cause rouleaux formation are: Multiple myeloma Connective tissue disorders like SLE Early HIV Infections Rouleaux formation is retarded by albumin.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is least likely to be seen in patients with multiple myeloma?
explanation: Mooser bodies are seen in Typhus fever, not in multiple myeloma. Histopathological findings seen in multiple myeloma: Dutcher bodies - pale-staining intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). Russell bodies - Hyaline intracytoplasmic inclusions containing Ig Mott cells/ morula cells - Plasma cells containing multiple grape-like cytoplasmic inclusions comprised of Ig Flame cells - Vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections Thesaurocytes - Dilated endoplasmic reticulum cisternae
subject: Pathology

question_text: The peripheral smear of a patient diagnosed with multiple myeloma is shown below. What does the marked structure contain?
explanation: The given image shows a Mott cell which is a plasma cell with globular cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russell bodies. Inclusions containing Ig are frequently seen in the cytoplasm (Russell bodies) or the nucleus (Dutcher bodies) of some of the plasma cells in myeloma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: The marked finding in plasma cells is due to:
explanation: The marked finding is perinuclear hof (perinuclear clearing) in plasma cells. It occurs due to a prominent Golgi apparatus. Plasma cell characteristics include: Eccentric nuclei Moderate to abundant basophilic cytoplasm Pale perinuclear hof, representing the Golgi zone The image given below shows plasma cells with perinuclear hof.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 60-year-old male presented with a history of intractable diarrhea. Based on the histological image shown below which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis:
explanation: The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The image shows Russell bodies which are eosinophilic, large, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing inclusions usually found in a plasma cell undergoing excessive synthesis of immunoglobulins. Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Globular inclusions are Russell bodies (if cytoplasmic) and Dutcher bodies (if nuclear). The below image shows Russell bodies:
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with pallor and pathological fracture is diagnosed with multiple myeloma. Which of the following is not a kidney finding of such patients?
explanation: Wire-loop lesions are seen in systemic lupus erythematosus and not in multiple myeloma. Renal insufficiency occurs in half the patients with multiple myeloma and several factors are responsible for it. They develop acute kidney injury with ologuria and chronic kidney disease. Tubular casts, amyloidosis, and renal tubular necrosis are all described in the myeloma kidneys. Features of myeloma kidney: Bence–Jones proteinuria and cast nephropathy - The main cause of renal dysfunction is related to Bence–Jones (light-chain) proteinuria. Ig light chains are directly toxic to epithelial cells. Bence-Jones proteins form large, histologically distinct tubular casts that obstruct the tubular lumens and induce a characteristic inflammatory reaction (light-chain cast nephropathy). Amyloidosis of AL type, formed from free light chains (usually of  type) Light-chain deposition disease - light chains (usually of  type) deposit in the glomerular basement membrane and mesangium causing a glomerulopathy and in tubular basement membranes, which may cause tubulointerstitial nephritis. Hypercalcemia - Nephrocalcinosis
subject: Pathology

question_text: What do Bence Jones proteins in the urine of multiple myeloma patients represent?
explanation: Bence Jones proteins are immunoglobulin light chains (paraproteins) produced by neoplastic plasma cells. They can be kappa (most of the time) or lambda. The light chains can be immunoglobulin fragments or single homogeneous immunoglobulins. In patients with plasma cell tumors, the level of free light chains is usually elevated. One of the light chains is elevated with a reduction in the other. Free light chains are excreted in the urine because they are small in size, where they are referred to as Bence Jones proteins. Tests for Bence Jones protein are: Heat test Urine protein electrophoresis Immunofixation
subject: Pathology

question_text: Hyperviscosity symptoms in patients with multiple myeloma occur due to which of the following types of M protein?
explanation: Symptoms related to hyperviscosity in multiple myeloma occurs due to excessive production of M proteins, usually of IgG3 or IgA subtype. Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (IgM myeloma) is the most common cause for hyperviscosity syndrome due to excess IgM paraprotein. Less commonly, it also occurs in multiple myeloma (with myeloma proteins IgA and IgG3 types) and connective tissue diseases. Normal relative serum viscosity ranges from 1.4 to 1.8 units. Symptoms are not seen at <4, and hyperviscosity syndrome typically requires a viscosity of >5 units. Clinical features include: Visual impairment Neurologic problems Bleeding Cryoglobulinemia
subject: Pathology

question_text: Multiple myeloma patients associated with which type of M protein has the highest risk of renal insufficiency?
explanation: IgD type of multiple myeloma has the highest risk of renal insufficiency. IgG is most commonly involved in multiple myeloma. The higher the level of IgG, the more is the risk of renal failure in patients with multiple myeloma overall. But the rarer IgD predominant multiple myeloma has the highest risk of renal insufficiency when compared to other types. IgD type multiple myeloma is a rare type of multiple myeloma. In this condition, there is monoclonal IgD in serum. On serum electrophoresis, there is no or absent M spike. There is a higher incidence of extramedullary involvement, amyloidosis, proteinuria, and renal insufficiency in comparison to IgG or IgA type multiple myeloma. It has a poor prognosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following tumor markers is least likely to be positive in a patient with multiple myeloma?
explanation: Plasma-cell tumors are least likely to show positivity for CD 21. They are positive for CD138, an adhesion molecule also known as syndecan-1, CD 38, and often express CD56.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not considered as a myeloma-defining event, according to the revised criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma?
options: More than one focal lesionon MRI of 5 mm or more
60% or more clonal plasma cells on bone marrow examination
Serum involved/uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater
explanation: Biopsy-proven plasmacytoma is not considered as a myeloma-defining event (MDE). Revised International Myeloma Working Group criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma: Clonal bone marrow plasma cells 10% (or) Biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma. AND Myeloma defining events (one or more): Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder, specifically- HyperCalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL Renal insufficiency: Creatinine clearance <40 mL/min or serum creatinine >2 mg/dL Anemia: Hemoglobin level of >20 g/L (2gm/dl) below the lowest limit of normal, or Hb <10 g/dL Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on skeletal radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron emission tomography (PET)/CT. Any one or more biomarkers of malignancy: Clonal bone marrow plasma cells 60%; Serum involved/uninvolved free light-chain ratio  100; >1 focal lesion on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that is  5 mm in size.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 60-year-old lady presents with complaints of pallor, recurrent UTI, and bone pain in lower limbs. Peripheral smear shows rouleaux formation. X-ray done is given below. Which is the best immunohistochemical marker for this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and X-ray showing lytic lesions on the bone are suggestive of multiple myeloma. The best immunohistochemical (IHC) marker for this condition is cyclin D1. Multiple myeloma is associated with diverse translocations involving the IgH locus; overexpression of D cyclins—cyclin D1 and D3. Plasma cell tumors are positive for CD138 and often express CD56.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient diagnosed with multiple myeloma develops features of restrictive cardiomyopathy and macroglossia. Which of the following amyloid is responsible for this?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of amyloidosis. The amyloid of the AL type is produced from free Ig light chains secreted by a monoclonal population of plasma cells and its deposition is associated with multiple myeloma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common cause of death in patients with myeloma?
explanation: Infections are the most common cause of death in patients with myeloma. Complications of multiple myeloma include: Infections Renal failure Cardiac failure Hypercalcemia Anemia
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, pain over the ribs, and confusion. Lab investigations reveal anemia, hypercalcemia, and increased serum creatinine. X-ray shows lytic lesions on the bones. Which of the following is the most powerful prognostic indicator of this condition at the time of diagnosis?
options: Number of myeloma cells in the marrow
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of multiple myeloma. The most powerful prognostic indicator of this condition at the time of diagnosis is serum  2 microglobulin. Beta-2 microglobulin is a low-molecular-weight protein found on the surface of all nucleated cells. It is the light chain of the HLA histocompatibility complex.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not associated with poor prognosis in a patient with multiple myeloma?
explanation: t(11;14) is associated with a good prognosis in patients with myeloma. t(4;14), high serum beta-2 microglobulin, and low serum albumin are all poor prognostic factors in myeloma.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 70-year-old man presents with chronic low back pain. On examination, he has pallor and bony tenderness. A skeletal radiographic survey reveals several punched-out lytic lesions.
Serum protein electrophoresis shows an M band in the gamma globulin region. Which of the following is not associated with a poor prognosis in this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of multiple myeloma. Translocations involving cyclin D1 are associated with a good outcome in this condition. t(14;16), deletions of 17p, and t(14;20) are associated with a more aggressive course.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which among these is not diagnostic of monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance?
explanation: Bence–Jones proteinuria is not diagnostic of monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) because it is seen in multiple myeloma also. MGUS is the most common monoclonal gammopathy. Diagnostic criteria of MGUS according to International Myeloma Working Group guidelines (2014): Serum monoclonal protein <3g/dL Clonal bone marrow plasma cells < 10% Absence of end-organ damage such as hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia and bone lesions (CRAB) No amyloidosis The three distinct clinical types of MGUS are: Non-IgM MGUS: Most common subtype of MGUS Approximately 1% of patients with MGUS develop a symptomatic plasma cell neoplasm, usually multiple myeloma, per year IgM MGUS: IgM MGUS accounts for approximately 15% of MGUS cases It can progress to Waldenström macroglobulinemia, but progression to multiple myeloma is rare Bence–Jones proteinuria has been reported in approximately 20% of these cases Light chain MGUS (LC-MGUS): LC-MGUS is a unique subtype of MGUS in which there is no immunoglobulin heavy-chain component Urinary M protein <500 mg/24 hour LC-MGUS may progress to light-chain smoldering multiple myeloma (idiopathic Bence–Jones proteinuria) and to light-chain multiple myeloma
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with complaints of blurred vision, bleeding gums, and tingling sensation over the extremities is diagnosed with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. Which of the following immunoglobulins is this condition associated with?
explanation: High levels of IgM are seen in lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. In lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, high levels of IgM lead to symptoms related to hyperviscosity of the blood. This is known as Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia. ‘M’ or monoclonal spike is seen in this condition. Here, it is caused by IgM; in multiple myeloma, it is caused by IgG. It is characterized by the absence of lytic lesions and normal serum calcium levels. IgM greatly increases the viscosity of the blood, giving rise to a hyperviscosity syndrome characterized by the following: Visual impairment Neurologic problems Bleeding Cryoglobulinemia The normal relative viscosity of the serum is 1.8. Hyperviscosity is seen in: Multiple myeloma Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia Cryoglobulinemia Myeloproliferative disorders
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 40-year-old man is diagnosed with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. Which of the following genes is mutated in this condition?
explanation: Virtually all cases of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma are associated with acquired mutations in MYD88. The most common cytogenetic abnormality associated with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma is deletion of 6q.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not seen in patients with Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia?
options: M spike in serum protein electrophoresis
Absence of lytic lesions on imaging
explanation: Serum calcium levels remain normal in Waldenström macroglobulinemia. Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a syndrome characterised by the following: Hyperviscosity syndrome due to high levels of IgM Most commonly occurs in association with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma ‘M’ or monoclonal spike Absence of lytic lesions Normal serum calcium levels Diffuse marrow infiltration by plasma cells, plasmacytoid lymphocytes, and lymphocytes (all from the same clone) Cells do not form tumor masses or produce lytic lesions Lymphocytes commonly contain Dutcher bodies (intranuclear inclusions) Bence–Jones proteins in 20–30%
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common site for extramedullary plasmacytoma?
explanation: Extramedullary plasmacytomas are seen in the upper respiratory tract. Most of them are seen in the nasopharynx, oropharynx, sinuses, and larynx. Plasmacytoma is a tumor of plasma cells of bony or soft tissue. It can occur anywhere in the body without evidence of systemic disease.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is Seligmann's disease?
explanation: - heavy chain disease (HCD) is known as Seligmann's disease. There are three heavy chain diseases: - heavy chain disease - Seligmann's disease - heavy chain disease - Franklin's disease - heavy chain disease - Associated with light-chain secretion (Bence–Jones proteinuria) in a few cases
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 60-year-old man presents with a history of bone pain, weakness, and loss of weight for 3 years. On examination, enlarged lymph nodes and organomegaly are noted. Peripheral smear shows 22% plasma cells, which are -chain restricted. Serum IgE level is elevated. X-ray image of the lumbar vertebra shows lytic punched-out lesions. What is the diagnosis?
Multiple myeloma
explanation: The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of plasma cell leukemia. In this case, the peripheral blood smear shows 22% of plasma cells and presents with organomegaly. Plasma cell leukemia is defined by the observation in blood of more than 20% clonal plasma cells by differential count of the leucocytes or by counting more than 2 × 109 per liter circulating clonal plasma cells. Plasma cell leukemia (PCL) is a rare and aggressive form of leukemia and plasma cell dyscrasia. PCL can be divided into primary PCL (PCL) and secondary PCL (sPCL) following previously diagnosed multiple myeloma (MM); the latter typically occurring at a late and advanced stage of MM. Patients with plasma cell leukemia are more likely to have extramedullary involvement of liver and spleen, causing organomegaly than in multiple myeloma. (Option A) Myelodysplastic Syndrome, Myeloproliferative Syndromes and Histiocytosis
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 73-year-old woman presents with chronic fatigue and easy bruising. She has had surgery for ovarian cancer 7 years ago along with chemoradiation. Her lab reports reveal pancytopenia and bone marrow biopsy shows the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of therapy-related myelodysplastic syndrome (t-MDS). The bone marrow biopsy stained with Perl's Prussian blue shows ringed sideroblasts. They are erythroblasts with iron-laden mitochondria visible as perinuclear granules as shown in the image below. Myelodysplastic syndrome is a group of clonal stem cell disorders characterized by maturation defects, associated with ineffective hematopoiesis. It is of two types: Primary MDS - develops slowly, usually after 50 years of age. Secondary or therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) - develops 2 to 8 years after toxic drug or radiation exposure with poor prognosis Patients usually present with weakness, infections and hemorrhages due to pancytopenia. Both types of MDS have a high risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). However, most frequent and rapid transformation occurs in therapy-related MDS (t-MDS).
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common cytogenetic change in children with myelodysplastic syndrome?
explanation: Monosomy 7 is the most common cytogenetic change seen in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) in children. 5q deletion is the most common cytogenetic change seen in MDS in adults. The del(5q) abnormality is the dominant clone in most cases of MDS. This involves the stem-cell compartment and hence occurs as an early or initiating event in disease pathogenesis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of these histopathological findings would you not expect to see in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome?
explanation: Pseudo–Pelger–Huet cells are seen in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and not Pelger–Huet cells. Pelger–Huet cells are seen in Pelger–Huet syndrome, which is due to mutations in the lamin B-receptor gene. It is a neutrophil differentiation disorder with leukocyte appearance as: Dumbbell-shaped bilobed nuclei Reduced number of nuclear segments Coarse clumping of the nuclear chromatin In MDS, pseudo-Pelger Huet cells are seen due to abnormal nuclear budding i.e. neutrophils with only 2 nuclear lobes.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following bone marrow and peripheral blood findings is not seen in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome?
explanation: Image 3 showing hypocellular bone marrow is not seen in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS.) In this condition, bone marrow is hypercellular. However, pancytopenia results from ineffective hematopoiesis. The image given below shows the histopathological findings seen in MDS.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, weight loss, and heaviness in the left hypochondrium for 6 months. His hemogram and peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). In this condition, the peripheral smear contains neutrophils and their precursors of various sizes and configurations like band cells, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and blasts. Hence, the histological picture is described to have garden party or college girl appearance. The image given below shows the peripheral smear in CML showing garden party or college girl appearance. CML is a myeloproliferative disorder with peak incidence in the 5th to 6th decades of life. It occurs due to the chimeric BCR-ABL gene. Clinical features of CML: Hypermetabolism Fatigability Weakness Weight loss and anorexia Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis causing - Splenomegaly Mild hepatomegaly Lymphadenopathy Hematological findings include: Mild-to-moderate anemia Leukocytosis Platelets - usually increased DLC shows predominantly neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils and blasts (>10%) Note: Convent girl appearance is seen in CLL.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What mutation results in Philadelphia chromosome?
explanation: Philadelphia chromosome results from t(9;22)(q34;q11). It is most commonly seen in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). CML is due to the formation of a chimeric BCR-ABL gene or Philadelphia chromosome. This gene is derived from a reciprocal translocation (9;22)(q34;q11). The image given below shows the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome. This translocation can be identified on fluorescence in situ hybridisation (FISH). The image given below shows (9;22) translocation as seen on FISH.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Bone marrow biopsy in a patient shows pseudo-Gaucher cells. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: Psuedo-Gaucher cells are characteristic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). These cells are scattered macrophages with abundant wrinkled, green-blue cytoplasm. Their presence indicates a good prognosis. Bone marrow findings in CML: Markedly hypercellular marrow - increased maturing granulocytic precursors Elevated eosinophils and basophils Increased megakaryocytes - include small, dysplastic forms Erythroid progenitors - normal or mildly decreased Increased reticulin deposition Overt marrow fibrosis - rare early in the course Pseudo-Gaucher cells Sea blue histiocytes The image given below shows pseudo-Gaucher cells in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 60-year-old woman with fever and splenomegaly was diagnosed to have chronic myeloid leukemia. She was started on imatinib therapy. After a few months of therapy, she had persistent progressive splenomegaly and fatigue. Which of the following will not be seen in this phase?
explanation: In a patient with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), progressive splenomegaly, not responsive to therapy is suggestive of an accelerated phase. In this phase, blasts are <20% in blood or marrow. Diagnosis of an accelerated phase of CML requires one of the following criteria: Persistent or increasing WBC (>10 × 109/L), unresponsive to therapy Persistent or increasing splenomegaly, unresponsive to therapy Persistent thrombocytosis (>1000 × 109/L), unresponsive to therapy Persistent thrombocytopenia (<100 × 109/L) unrelated to therapy 20% or more basophils in the peripheral blood 10%-19% blasts in the peripheral blood or bone marrow Additional clonal chromosomal abnormalities in Ph+ cells at diagnosis that include “major route” abnormalities (second Ph, trisomy 8, isochromosome 17q, trisomy 19), complex karyotype, or abnormalities of 3q26.2 Any new clonal chromosomal abnormality in Ph+ cells that occurs during therapy
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the percentage of blast cells in the blast phase of CML?
explanation: In the blast phase of chronic myeloid leukemia, there are >20% blasts in the bone marrow. The 3 phases of CML are: Chronic phase is the most common presentation. It is characterized by: Leukocytosis - bimodal distribution with higher proportions of mature segmented neutrophils and myelocytes Blast cells <10% Increased basophils and eosinophils Monocytosis <3% Accelerated phase occurs in 50% of the patients who present with increasing anemia, thrombocytopenia and splenomegaly. It is characterized by: Blast count 10-19% Basophilia >20% Blast phase in CML occurs in an average of 3 years after the diagnosis. It is characterized by: Large foci or clusters of blasts on the bone marrow biopsy >20%. Presence of extramedullary blastic infiltrates (e.g., myeloid sarcoma or chloroma)
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not seen in a patient with Myelodysplastic/Myeloproliferative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia?
explanation: Myelodysplastic/Myeloproliferative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia (previously named as atypical chronic myeloid leukemia) shows minimal absolute basophilia, i.e., <2% of total WBCs. Myelodysplastic/Myeloproliferative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia is a leukemic disorder having features of both myelodysplastic and myeloproliferative features at the time of diagnosis. It is classified under the WHO 5th edition (2022) MDS/MPN category. Characteristics of myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia: Peripheral blood leukocytosis with an increased number of mature and immature neutrophils Prominent dysgranulopoiesis Philadelphia chromosome-negative Neutrophil precursors (promyelocytes, myelocytes, metamyelocytes) >10% of WBCs Minimal absolute basophilia <2% of WBCs Absolute monocytosis <10% of WBCs Hypercellular bone marrow <20% blasts in blood and bone marrow Thrombocytopenia Differences between CML and myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia: Feature CML Myelodysplastic/Myeloprolife rative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia BCR-ABL gene Present Absent Feature CML Myelodysplastic/Myeloprolife rative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia Feature CML Myelodysplastic/Myeloprolife rative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia Feature CML Myelodysplastic/Myeloprolife rative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia Basophilia Present <2% Myeloblasts in peripheral blo odMyeloblasts in bone marro w <2%<5% <20%<20% Granulocytic dysplasia Minimal/ abs ent Prominent
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following patients will have a decreased leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score?
options: A 65-year-old-man with garden party appearance on peripheral smear
A 50-year-old man with Reed Sternberg cells on LN biopsy
A 35-year-old woman with Hb level of 23 g/dL
A 43-year-old woman with smudge cells on peripheral smear
explanation: Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is decreased in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) i.e. garden party appearance on peripheral smear.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following does not cause relative polycythemia?
explanation: High altitude produces absolute polycythemia and not relative polycythemia. Polycythemia denotes an abnormally high red cell count, usually with a corresponding increase in the hemoglobin level (> 16 ±2 g/dL). It is 2 types: Relative - hemoconcentration due to decreased plasma volume Absolute - increase in the total red cell mass Causes of relative polycythemia include: Dehydration - deprivation of water, prolonged vomiting or diarrhea, excessive use of diuretics Gaisböck syndrome - stress polycythemia where affected individuals are usually hypertensive, obese, and anxious Causes of absolute polycythemia include: Primary - intrinsic abnormality of hematopoietic precursors Polycythemia vera Inherited erythropoietin receptor mutations Secondary - red cell progenitors responding to increased levels of erythropoietin Compensatory due to cyanotic heart and lung disease, high altitude Paraneoplastic erythropoietin secreting tumours Note: In dengue hemorrhagic fever, increased vascular permeability causes plasma leakage and volume loss. Hence, relative polycythemia is seen.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports - Hemoglobin 17 g%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be:
options: Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Hence, erythropoietin levels (EPO) are estimated next, to differentiate between primary or secondary polycythemia. Based on EPO levels: Primary polycythemia - normal/ decreased Secondary polycythemia - increased Options A and B: JAK 2 mutation and Philadelphia chromosome analysis is only done as a last resort. Option D: Bone marrow estimation with reticulin is done for myelofibrosis which can be seen in the spent/ late stage of the disease. However, peripheral smear findings are not suggestive of primary myelofibrosis. Leukoerythroblastic reaction with dacrocytes is seen in myelofibrosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 24-year-old woman who presented with aquagenic pruritis had a Hb level of 20 g/dL. Her lab investigations are given below. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia vera. Hepatic failure is not seen in this condition. Polycythemia vera is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2. In this condition, clonal erythrocytosis occurs autonomously i.e. independent of erythropoietin. Clinical features of polycythemia vera: Headache Hypertension Dizziness Intense pruritis, aquagenic pruritis Peptic ulcer Venous thrombosis - Budd-Chiari syndrome (hepatic vein thrombosis), bowel infarction, stroke, myocardial infarction Minor hemorrhages - epistaxis, gum bleeding Laboratory findings in polycythemia vera: Panmyelosis - increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets Low erythropoietin Elevated hematocrit Hyperuricemia Complications of polycythemia vera: Myelofibrosis and extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis - spent /late phase Acute myeloid leukemia
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 63-year-old woman complains about throbbing pain over both palms. Her examination findings and lab reports are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of essential thrombocythemia (ET). The image showing erythematous hands is suggestive of erythromelalgia. Essential thrombocythemia (essential thrombocytosis) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is associated with mutations that increase JAK-STAT signaling. WHO criteria for diagnosis of essential thrombocythemia: Major criteria - Platelet count 450 × 109/L Bone marrow biopsy showing proliferation mainly of the megakaryocyte lineage with increased numbers of enlarged, mature megakaryocytes with hyperlobulated nuclei Not meeting WHO criteria for BCR-ABL1 chronic myeloid leukemia, PV, PMF, myelodysplastic syndromes, or other myeloid neoplasms Presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation Minor criteria - the presence of a clonal marker or absence of evidence for reactive thrombocytosis Diagnosis of ET requires meeting all 4 major criteria or the first 3 major criteria and the minor criterion Option A: Polycythemia vera can also present with erythromelalgia. However, it also presents with increased Hb levels. Option C: Fibrosis (not reticulin fibrils) is seen in bone marrow biopsy of primary myelofibrosis. Option D: WBC counts are increased in leukemoid reactions.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Patients with which of the following conditions do not have a leukoerythroblastic picture on peripheral smear?
explanation: Leukoerythroblastic picture is not seen in patients with thalassemia as it is a hemoglobinopathy and does not involve myeloid precursors. Abnormal presence of immature precursors of blood in the peripheral blood smear is called leukoerythroblastosis. Findings include: Nucleated red cells Dacryocytes (or teardrop RBC) - formed due to damage to red cell membrane caused by fibrous tissue in the marrow Immature cells of granulocytic series It occurs due to conditions causing marrow replacement like: Primary myelofibrosis - fibrosis of bone marrow Myelophthisic anemia - space occupying lesions of bone marrow Gauchers disease Spent phase of polycythemia vera The image given below shows a leukoerythroblastic blood picture with nucleated RBCs, tear-drop cells, and immature myeloid cells.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not included under MDS/MPN overlap syndromes?
options: MDS/MPN with SF31B mutation and thrombocytosis
explanation: Myelodysplastic syndrome/ myeloproliferative neoplasm (MDS/MPN) overlap syndromes are a group of chronic clonal myeloid malignancies in which there are features of both MDS and MPN at the time of presentation. According to the 5th edition WHO classification (2022), it includes: Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia MDS/MPN with neutrophilia (previously atypical chronic myeloid leukemia) MDS/MPN with SF31B mutation and thrombocytosis MDS/MPN not otherwise specified
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not compatible with a diagnosis of chronic myelomonocytic leukemia?
options: More than 20% blasts in blood or bone marrow
Absent or minimal dysplasia in myeloid lineages
explanation: More than 20% of blasts in the blood or bone marrow are not compatible with a diagnosis of chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML). In this condition, blasts are less than 20%. WHO 5th edition diagnostic criteria (2022_for chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML) include: Prerequisite criteria: 1. Persistent absolute (0.5 × 109/ L) and relative (10%) peripheral blood monocytosis. 2. Blasts constitute <20% of the cells in the peripheral blood and bone marrow. 3. Not meeting diagnostic criteria of chronic myeloid leukemia or other myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPN).b 4. Not meeting diagnostic criteria of myeloid/lymphoid neoplasms with tyrosine kinase fusions.c Supporting criteria: 1. Dysplasia involving 1 myeloid lineage.d 2. Acquired clonal cytogenetic or molecular abnormality. 3. Abnormal partitioning of peripheral blood monocyte subsets.e Pre-requisite criteria must be present in all cases: If monocytosis is  1 × 109/ L: one or more supporting criteria must be met. If monocytosis is 0.5 and <1 × 109/ L: supporting criteria 1 and 2 must be met. Subtype criteria: Myelodysplastic CMML (MD-CMML): WBC < 13 × 109/L Myeloproliferative CMML (MP-CMML): WBC  13 × 109/L Blasts and blast equivalents include myeloblasts, monoblasts, and promonocytes. MPN with monocytosis can mimic CMML. In these instances, a documented history of MPN excludes CMML. The presence of MPN features in the bone marrow and/or a high burden of MPN-associated mutations (JAK2, CALR, or MPL) tends to support MPN with monocytosis rather than CMML. Criteria for myeloid/lymphoid neoplasms with tyrosine kinase fusions should be specifically excluded in cases with eosinophilia. Morphologic dysplasia should be present in 10% of cells of a hematopoietic lineage in the bone marrow. Based on the detection of increased classical monocytes (>94%) in the absence of known active autoimmune diseases and/or systemic inflammatory syndromes.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 2-year-old boy with Noonan syndrome presents with hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. You are suspecting juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
explanation: HbF levels are increased in juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML), not Hb A2. JMML is a hematopoietic stem cell-derived myeloproliferative neoplasm of early childhood. It is one of the myeloproliferative neoplasms. It is associated with mutations in the RAS pathway. Neurofibromatosis 1, Noonan syndrome, and trisomy 8 mosaicism can predispose to this condition. Aggressive types include PTPN11 mutation and neurofibromatosis type 1. WHO diagnostic guidelines of JMML: *Germline mutation (indicating Noonan syndrome) needs to be excluded. It is associated with a poor prognosis and only a few patients undergo spontaneous regression. Category I (Mandatory):Clini cal and hematologic features Category II:Genetic (only 1 re quired) Category III: Category I + the se findings: SplenomegalyPeripheral bloo d monocyte count 1 × 109/L Blast percentage in periphera l blood and bone marrow <2 0%No Philadelphia chromos ome (BCR/ABL1 rearrangeme nt)Exclusion of KMT2A muta tion Somatic mutation inPTPN11 * orKRAS* orNRAS*Clinical d iagnosis of Neurofibromatosi s type 1 or NF1 mutationGer mline CBL mutation Hemoglobin F increased for ageMyeloid or erythroid prec ursors on the peripheral bloo d smearHypersensitivity to G M-CSF by colony assay and S TAT5 hyperphosphorylationT hrombocytopenia with hyper cellular bone marrow
subject: Pathology

question_text: JAK2 mutation is most commonly associated with
explanation: Polycythemia vera is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2. A mutation in JAK2, a key member of the cytokine intracellular signaling pathway, can be found in 90–95% of patients with polycythemia vera. It is characterized by : Increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis) Low erythropoietin levels and elevated hematocrit Blood viscosity and sludging lead to both thrombosis and bleeding. Headache, dizziness, hypertension, dizziness, venous thrombosis (Budd Chiari syndrome due to hepatic vein thrombosis), bowel infarction, and stroke. Intense pruritus especially aquagenic pruritus Peptic ulceration, hyperuricemia 15% to 20% of patients after an average period of 10 years ->Myelofibrosis and extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis, PCV transforms into AML in 2% of patients. Primary myelofibrosis Marrow fibrosis associated with extramedullary hemopoiesis in the spleen. Activating mutation in JAK2 (more commonly) or MPL. Presence of neoplastic megakaryocytes, which are responsible for the release of fibrogenic factors like PDGF (platelet-derived growth factor) and TGF- . Bone marrow aspiration yields dry tap due to fibrosis of the bone marrow. So, bone marrow biopsy is the investigation of choice, which shows the presence of hypocellularity with increased deposition of reticulin inside the marrow, abnorma megakaryocytes and the characteristic finding of dilated marrow sinusoids. Blood shows mild leukocytosis, decreased Hb and hematocrit levels, and elevated LAP scores. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) occurs in 5% to 20% of cases. Essential thrombocytosis (ET) may also be associated with JAK2, MPL, or CALR mutations. Essential thrombocytosis (ET) is often associated with activating point mutations in JAK2 (50% of cases) or MPL (5% to 10% of cases), a receptor tyrosine kinase that is normally activated by thrombopoietin. In addition, recent DNA sequencing studies have revealed that most of the remaining cases have mutations in calreticulin (CALR), a protein with several functions in the endoplasmic reticulum and the cytoplasm. Since JAK2 and calreticulin mutations are mutually exclusive, it is hypothesized that the calreticulin mutations also increase JAK-STAT signaling through mechanisms that are currently unknown. CML is the consequence of the balanced translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 (t[9;22]). PV, PMF, and ET are characterized by driver mutations that directly or indirectly constitutively activate JAK2, a tyrosine kinase essential for the function of the erythropoietin andthrombopoietin receptors and also utilized by granulocyte colony stimulating factor receptor.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following patients is least likely to have leukemoid reaction?
options: A patient with acute myocardial infarction
explanation: Myocardial infarction does not cause leukemoid reaction. Leukemoid reaction is defined as persistent leukocytosis above 50000 cells /mm3, where the cause is other than leukemia. Causes of leukemoid reaction include: Severe infections Malignancy Severe hemorrhage Acute hemolysis Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) Asplenia Diabetic ketoacidosis
subject: Pathology

question_text: Electron microscopic picture of which of the following conditions is shown below?
explanation: The given electron microscopy image shows tennis racket shaped Birbeck granules. These granules are characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. These granules are pentalaminar tubules with dilated terminal ends. This gives a characteristic tennis racket appearance on electron microscopy. They contain the protein langerin (CD207). The image given below shows the Birbeck granules as seen on electron microscopy. On peripheral smear, the proliferating Langerhans cells are characterised by: Abundant vacuolated cytoplasm Vesicular nuclei containing linear grooves or folds - coffee bean nuclei The image given below shows Langerhans cells with coffee bean nuclei and moderately abundant pale cytoplasm mixed with a few eosinophils. Note: Tennis racket cells in light microscopy seen in sarcoma botryoides.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a histiocytic neoplasm?
explanation: Rosai–Dorfman disease is not a histiocytic neoplasm. It is sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy. WHO classification of histiocytic/ hematolymphoid neoplasm 2016 includes the following: Histiocytic sarcoma Langerhans cell histiocytosis Langerhans cell sarcoma Indeterminate dendritic cell tumour nterdigitating dendritic cell sarcoma Follicular dendritic cell sarcoma Fibroblastic reticular cell tumour Disseminated juvenile xanthogranuloma Erdheim–Chester disease
subject: Pathology

question_text: You are suspecting Langerhans cell histiocytosis in a child with an enlarging scalp lesion. Which of the following markers will you test to confirm your diagnosis?
explanation: S-100 is a marker for Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Tumour cells in this condition typically express the following: HLA-DR S-100 CD1a
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to you by her father, who states that the girl is drinking a lot of water lately. Physical examination reveals exophthalmos. Further workup shows the presence of multiple lytic bone lesions involving her calvarium and the base of her skull. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hand–Schüller–Christian disease. Langerhans cell histiocytosis presents as multiple clinicopathological entities: Hand–Schüller–Christian disease is a multifocal unisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It usually affects young children. It is characterized by the triad of: Diabetes insipidus (excessive thirst) - involvement of the posterior pituitary stalk of the hypothalamus Exophthalmos Multiple lytic bone lesions It usually undergoes spontaneous regression. It is treated with local excision or irradiation. Letterer–Siwe disease is a multifocal multisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It occurs most frequently before 2 years of age, but occasionally affects adults. It is characterized by the following features: Cutaneous lesions, resembling a seborrheic eruption - caused by infiltrates of Langerhans cells over the front and back of the trunk and on the scalp Hepatosplenomegaly Lymphadenopathy Pulmonary lesions Destructive osteolytic bone lesions Due to marrow infiltration - anemia, thrombocytopenia, predisposition to recurrent infections (otitis media and mastoiditis) Treatment involves intensive chemotherapy. This condition is fatal if left untreated. Eosinophilic granuloma is a unifocal unisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It is characterized by the proliferation of Langerhans cells admixed with variable numbers of eosinophils, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and neutrophils. These lesions occur in the following sites: Medullary cavities of bones - most commonly the calvarium, ribs, and femur Skin Lungs Stomach Bone lesions can manifest as: Asymptomatic Pain Tenderness Pathologic fractures. Treatment is by local excision or irradiation. Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis is most often seen in adult smokers. It regresses spontaneously upon cessation of smoking.
subject: Pathology

question_text: The X-ray of a 65-year-old man is given below. Clinical examination, and hematological and urinary tests were normal. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given image showing a solitary punched-out lytic lesion without a sclerotic rim with a beveled edge appearance, along with the age of the patient with history of normal hematological and urinary tests is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells, called Langerhans cells. Their normal function is to present antigens. It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions. It can also infiltrate the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not true regarding the procedure done using the instrument given in the image below?
options: Procedure can be done in both lateral & prone position
Diagnosing an infiltrative or granulomatous disease
explanation: The image shows a bone marrow biopsy needle. Thrombocytopenia is not in itself a contraindication for bone marrow biopsy. However, a platelet count >20,000 is ensured for safety purposes. Indications of bone marrow biopsy: Evaluation of unexplained anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, pancytopenia Evaluation of polycythemia, thrombocytosis, leukocytosis Diagnosis and staging of lymphoma or solid tumors Diagnosis and evaluation of plasma cell disorders and leukemias Evaluation of suspected infiltrative and storage diseases Evaluation of fever of unknown origin, suspected mycobacterial, fungal, or parasitic infections, or granulomatous diseases Contraindications of bone marrow biopsy: Severe hemophilia Severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy Severe bleeding disorders Procedure for bone marrow biopsy: Prone or lateral position is chosen for the procedure. Posterior superior iliac spine is identified. After disinfection and local anaesthesia, the patient is asked to inhale slowly through the nose and exhale slowly through the mouth to relieve anxiety .The needle is inserted and rotated on its axis. On reaching the desired depth, the stylet is removed and needle is advanced. The needle is rotated in the opposite direction to loosen the specimen. It is then withdrawn using the same rotational movement.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Blood examination shows pancytopenia, which can be correct?
explanation: Megaloblastic anemia (hypocellular phase), hairy cell leukemia, and hypocellular MDS can show pancytopenia. Acute promyelocytic leukemia is not associated with pancytopenia. Causes of pancytopenia with hypocellular bone marrow: Acquired aplastic anemia Hypocellular myelodysplastic syndrome Rare aleukemic leukemia Some acute lymphoid leukemia Rare lymphomas of bone marrow Copper deficiency Causes of pancytopenia with cellular bone marrow: Myelodysplastic syndromes Systemic lupus erythematosus Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) Hypersplenism B12, folate deficiency, Copper deficiency Myelofibrosis Aleukemic leukemia HIV, Brucellosis, Leishmaniasis, Tuberculosis Sepsis Myelophthisis Bone marrow lymphoma Sarcoidosis Hairy cell leukemia
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Which of the following conditions will have the least chances of a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration?
Hairy cell leukemia
explanation: Follicular lymphoma is the least likely cause of a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration. Causes of dry tap are: Metastatic carcinoma infiltration Chronic myeloid leukemia Myelofibrosis Hairy cell leukemia Acute leukemia Hodgkin's lymphoma AML- M7 Causes of pancytopenia with cellular marrow are: Primary disease of marrow- Myelodysplastic syndrome Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) Myelofibrosis Aleukemic leukemia Myelophthisis Bone marrow lymphoma Hairy cell leukemia Secondary to systemic disease- SLE, sarcoidosis B12, folate deficiency Copper deficiency Hypersplenism Alcoho HIV infection, TB Brucellosis, leishmaniasis Note: Although marrow is hypercellular in CML, MDS etc., extensive marrow fibrosis (rare) has been proposed to account for a dry tap on bone marrow biopsy. Leukopenia, Leukocytosis and Lymphadenitis
subject: Pathology

question_text: From which period of embryogenesis does the liver become the chief site of hematopoiesis?
explanation: From the 3rd month of embryogenesis, the liver becomes the chief site of hematopoiesis. Development of hematopoietic tissues: Yolk sac - blood cell progenitors first appear during the 3rd week Liver - hematopoietic stem cells migrate to the liver during the 3rd month of embryogenesis Bone marrow - hematopoiesis starts in bone marrow during the 4th month of intrauterine life and becomes the predominant site after birth
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which cells in the bone marrow are referred to as nurse cells?
explanation: Nurse cells are specialized macrophages in the bone marrow that assist in the development of red blood cells (RBCs).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Bone marrow biopsy of a normal adult is given below. What is the ratio of structures marked A and B?
explanation: The structures marked A are fat cells and B are hematopoietic elements. The normal ratio of fat cells to hematopoietic elements in a normal adult is 1:1. In hypoplastic states (like aplastic anemia), the proportion of fat cells is greatly increased (increased fat to cell ratio). Conversely, fat cells often disappear in conditions like hematopoietic tumors and in diseases with compensatory hyperplasias (like hemolytic anemias) and neoplastic proliferations such as leukemias (decreased fat-to-cell ratio).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is a marker for pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells?
explanation: CD34 is an antigen of pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells and progenitor cells of many lineages.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is called leukocyte common antigen?
explanation: CD45 is called leukocyte common antigen because it is found in all leukocytes.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Kostmann syndrome?
explanation: Kostmann syndrome is characterized by neutropenia. It is a rare congenital condition in which inherited defects in specific genes impair granulocytic differentiation. This results in severe congenital neutropenia. It presents in young children as recurrent bacterial infections (such as otitis media, cellulitis) and oral ulcers. It is associated with an increased risk of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common cause of agranulocytosis?
explanation: The most common cause of agranulocytosis is drug toxicity. Causes of agranulocytosis include: Inadequate or ineffective granulopoiesis - Suppression of hematopoietic stem cells - aplastic anemia, infiltrative marrow disorders Suppression of committed granulocytic precursors Ineffective hematopoiesis - megaloblastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndromes Congenital conditions - Kostmann syndrome Increased destruction or sequestration of neutrophils - Immunological injury to neutrophils - idiopathic, systemic lupus erythematosus, drug exposure Increased peripheral utilization - bacterial, fungal, or rickettsial infections Splenomegaly
subject: Pathology

question_text: A atient who was started on chemotherapy 2 weeks ago is found to have a neutrophil count of 2000/mm3. Below what neutrophil count is he at risk of developing serious infections?
explanation: Serious infections are most likely when the neutrophil count falls below 500/mm3.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 5-year-old boy is brought with complaints of episodes of severe, violent coughs, followed by a high-pitch intake of breath that sounds like a whoop. These coughing episodes are usually followed by vomiting. He and his family are refugees and his prior vaccination records are not available. Lab investigations of this child will likely reveal which of the following?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of whooping cough or pertussis. It is due to Bordetella pertussis infection and results in lymphocytosis. Causes of lymphocytosis include: Pertussis Tuberculosis Brucellosis Hepatitis A Cytomegalovirus Epstein-Barr virus
subject: Pathology
