question_text: A 50-year-old man admitted to ICU develops sepsis 3 days after insertion of a central venous catheter. A peripheral blood smear reveals the following. What does the structure marked by the arrow indicate?
explanation: The given peripheral smear, prepared from an individual with bacterial sepsis, shows reactive changes in neutrophils. The arrow-marked structure is a Döhle body. Reactive changes in neutrophils associated with leukocytosis in severe inflammatory disorders are: Toxic granules, which are coarser and darker than the normal neutrophilic granules, represent abnormal azurophilic (primary) granules Döhle bodies are patches of the dilated endoplasmic reticulum that appear as sky-blue cytoplasmic puddles Toxic cytoplasmic vacuoles The image given below shows a neutrophil with cytoplasmic vacuoles.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following does not cause follicular hyperplasia of the lymph nodes?
explanation: B-cell lymphoma results in malignant proliferation within the lymph node, not follicular hyperplasia. Follicular hyperplasia is a benign condition caused by stimuli that activate humoral immune responses. It may occur in: Rheumatoid arthritis Toxoplasmosis Early stages of HIV infection It is defined by the presence of large oblong germinal centres (secondary follicles), which are surrounded by a collar of small, resting naive B cells (mantle zone).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a feature of reactive lymphoid hyperplasia?
options: No variation in shape and size of the follicles
explanation: In reactive lymphoid hyperplasia, there is marked variation in the shape and size of follicles. Features favoring reactive lymphoid hyperplasia, which are absent in neoplastic follicles are: Preservation of the lymph node architecture, including the interfollicular T-cell zones and the sinusoids Marked variation in the shape and size of the follicles Presence of frequent mitotic figures and phagocytic macrophages Recognizable light and dark zones
subject: Pathology

question_text: In which of the following organs are tingible body macrophages found?
explanation: Tingible-body macrophages are found in lymph nodes. A tingible-body macrophage is a type of macrophage predominantly found in germinal centers containing many phagocytosed apoptotic cell debris. This debris is referred to as tingible bodies (tingible meaning stainable). The presence of these macrophages suggests non-neoplastic reactive hyperplasia of the lymph node, or can be seen as the stars in the starry sky appearance of Burkitt lymphoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 16-year-old boy presented with complaints of fever, sore throat, and enlarged lymph nodes. Paul Bunnell's test was done and found to be positive. What type of lymphoid hyperplasia is seen in this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis. Acute viral infections, like infectious mononucleosis, produce paracortical hyperplasia. There are three types of lymph node hyperplasia. They are: Follicular hyperplasia Paracortical hyperplasia Sinus histiocytosis (reticular hyperplasia) Paracortical hyperplasia is seen in the T-cell-containing paracortical region of the lymph node. It is caused by stimuli that trigger T-cell–mediated immune responses. The involved regions typically contain: Immunoblasts Activated T-cells 3-4 times the size of resting lymphocytes t Round nuclei Open chromatin Several prominent nucleoli Moderate amounts of pale cytoplasm Hypertrophy of sinusoidal and vascular endothelial cells, with infiltrating macrophages and eosinophils
subject: Pathology

question_text: In patients with breast cancer with lymph node metastases, which of the following changes is seen in affected lymph nodes?
explanation: In the case of lymph node metastases, there is prominent reticular hyperplasia. Reticular hyperplasia or sinus histiocytosis refers to an increase in the number and size of the cells that line lymphatic sinusoids. Although nonspecific, this form of hyperplasia may be particularly prominent in lymph nodes draining cancers such as carcinoma of the breast. The lining lymphatic endothelial cells are markedly hypertrophied and macrophages are greatly increased in numbers, resulting in the expansion and distension of the sinuses. The image given below shows reticular hyperplasia in the lymph node.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements about hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis is false?
options: There is systemic activation of macrophages and CD8+ T cells
The most common trigger is infection with Epstein-Barr virus
It presents as an acute febrile illness with hepatosplenomegaly
Hemophagocytosis seen in bone marrow is sufficient for diagnosis
explanation: Hemophagocytosis is usually seen on bone marrow examination, but it is neither sufficient nor required to make the diagnosis of hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH). HLH is a reactive condition also known as macrophage-activation syndrome. The common feature of all forms of HLH is the systemic activation of macrophages and CD8+ T-cells. The most common trigger for HLH is an infection, particularly with EBV (Epstein-Barr virus). It is characterized by acute febrile illness associated with splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and cytopenias.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Which of the following is not a feature in patients with hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis?
Disseminated intravascular coagulation
explanation: Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) is associated with very high serum ferritin levels. Laboratory findings in HLH include: Anemia Thrombocytopenia High serum ferritin High plasma IL2 receptor levels Elevated liver enzyme levels High triglyceride levels Features of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) Hypertensive Vascular Disease and Atherosclerosis
subject: Pathology

question_text: Vascular injury causes intimal thickening by which of the following mechanisms?
explanation: Vascular injury results in intimal thickening due to smooth muscle proliferation. Vascular injury stimulates the migration of smooth muscle cells of the tunica media to the tunica intima. These smooth muscle cells proliferate and also synthesize extracellular matrix leading to intimal thickening. This is the stereotypical response of the vessel wall to an injury regardless of the cause of injury. The image below shows intimal thickening occurring in response to vascular injury.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Endothelial dysfunction is implicated in all of the following except:
explanation: Endothelial dysfunction is not implicated in aneurysm formation. An aneurysm occurs due to the pathology of connective tissue within the vascular wall. Endothelial dysfunction is the pathological alteration of the endothelium such that it becomes pro-inflammatory and prothrombogenic. It is caused by various injuries to endothelial cells: Hemodynamic stresses - responsible for vascular pathology in hypertensio Lipid products - leading to the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis Advanced glycation end-products (AGE) - responsible for diabetic microangiopathy Viruses, bacterial products, cytokines, and complement components
subject: Pathology

question_text: Identify the condition:
explanation: The given image shows arteriosclerosis and calcification in the tunica media, that does not encroach on the vessel lumen. This is suggestive of Monckeberg's medial sclerosis. Monckeberg's medial sclerosis affects medium-sized muscular arteries and is characterized by calcification of the medial walls of the affected arteries. Adults aged over 50 years are usually affected. Arteriosclerosis refers to the thickening of the arterial wall and loss of elasticity. There are four patterns of arteriosclerosis: Small vessel arteriosclerosis - involves small arteries and arterioles It has two variants - hyaline arteriosclerosis, and hyperplastic arteriosclerosis Monckeberg medial sclerosis - involves calcification of the walls of muscular arteries Fibromuscular intimal hyperplasia- usually a healing response to inflammation (eg: arteritis) or mechanical injury (eg: stent insertion) Atherosclerosis - mainly involves elastic and muscular arteries
subject: Pathology

question_text: The following incidental finding is seen on a radiograph of a 60-year-old man. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
options: It involves the internal elastic lamina
It involves the external elastic lamina
explanation: The given radiograph shows extensive calcification of the femoral arteries which is suggestive of Monckeberg medial sclerosis. It is characterized by the calcification of the walls of muscular arteries, typically starting along the internal elastic lamina and involves the media of the arteries. It occurs in people aged 50 years and above as a part of senile degeneration. It is not associated with hypertension or diabetes. It is usually an incidental finding.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following pathological changes occurs in the small vessels of patients suffering from hypertension?
explanation: Hypertension results in hyaline arteriosclerosis of the small vessels. Hypertension leads to a variety of vascular pathologies. In small blood vessels, hypertension may lead to arteriosclerosis which is the thickening of the vessel wall. It has two variants which are hyaline arteriosclerosis and hyperplastic arteriosclerosis. In large and medium-sized arteries, hypertension leads to degenerative changes in the vessel walls, leading to: Dissectio Aneurysm formatio Cerebrovascular hemorrhage Acceleration of atherosclerosis
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is responsible for arteriolar wall thickening in hyaline arteriosclerosis?
explanation: The arteriolar wall thickening in hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs as a result of plasma protein deposition. Hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs due to injury to the endothelial cells. This allows plasma protein leakage into the arteriolar wall. The endothelial injury also stimulates increased matrix synthesis by the smooth muscle cells. These lead to the deposition of homogenous pink hyaline material causing the thickening of arteriolar walls.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A pathology resident is studying a vascular biopsy sample. This vascular lesion is less likely seen in which of the following conditions
explanation: The given image shows hyaline arteriosclerosis. It occurs in the following conditions: Elderly patients who are normotensive Benign hypertension: due to chronic hemodynamic stresses Diabetes mellitus: due to hyperglycemia-induced endothelial dysfunctio Severe hypertension causes hyperplastic arteriosclerosis with the characteristic onion skin appearance as seen below:
subject: Pathology

question_text: The renal biopsy of a 50-year-old chronic hypertensive patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given image shows hyperplastic arteriosclerosis, as noted by the onion-skin appearance of the arteriole. This is seen in malignant nephrosclerosis. Nephrosclerosis is caused by sclerosis of the small arteries and the arterioles of the kidney leading to diffuse impairment of renal blood supply. It is of 2 types: Benignnephrosclerosis Malignantnephrosclerosis Seen in benign hypertension Seen in malignant hypertensi on Causeshyaline arteriosclerosi s Causeshyperplastic arterioscl erosisandfibrinoid necrosisof the arterioles. The characteristic flea-bitten appearance of the kidney is seen in malignant nephrosclerosis (shown below). This is due to small petechial hemorrhages resulting from the rupture of arterioles.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 65-year-old man presented with chest pain. Past history is significant for dyslipidemia and an ischemic stroke 2 years ago. Coronary angiography was performed and showed the following. What is the correct sequence of events leading to this condition?
explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing occlusion of the left circumflex coronary artery are suggestive of atherosclerosis. It progresses in the following sequence: Endothelial injury and dysfunctio Accumulation of lipoproteins in the vessel wall Monocyte adhesion to the endothelium Platelet adhesio Factor release from activated platelets, macrophages, and vascular wall cells Smooth muscle cell proliferation, extracellular matrix production, and recruitment of T cells Lipid accumulation both extracellularly and within cells Calcification of ECM and necrotic debris late in the pathogenesis Hence, atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory and healing response of the arterial wall to endothelial injury. The two most important causes of endothelial injury leading to atherosclerosis are hemodynamic disturbances and hypercholesterolemia. The image below shows partial occlusion of the left circumflex coronary artery.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most important independent risk factor for atherosclerosis?
explanation: The most important independent risk factor for atherosclerosis is family history. The familial predisposition to atherosclerosis is usually polygenic. It is related to the familial clustering of other established risk factors, such as hypertension or diabetes. It may also be due to inherited variations in pathophysiologic processes such as inflammation. Hyperlipidemia (specifically hypercholesterolemia) is a major risk factor for atherosclerosis. Even in the absence of other risk factors, hypercholesterolemia is sufficient to initiate lesion development.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common site of atherosclerosis?
explanation: The most common site of atherosclerosis is the lower abdominal aorta. In descending order, the most extensively involved vessels in atherosclerosis are: Lower abdominal aorta Coronary arteries Popliteal arteries Internal carotid arteries Arteries of the circle of Willis
subject: Pathology

question_text: The autopsy of a 14-year-old boy who died in a motor vehicle accident showed the following lesions on the inner surface of the aorta. What do these lesions indicate?
explanation: The above image shows yellow spots on the inner surface of the aorta, which represent fatty streaks. They indicate a collection of foamy macrophages in the intima of the vessel wall. Fatty streaks may be present in the aorta of infants, virtually all adolescents, and even individuals without known risk factors. These lesions are not indicative of atherosclerosis, but some of them may evolve into atheromatous plaques later in life by smooth muscle proliferation and extracellular matrix deposition.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Where are the following cells in an atheromatous plaque derived from?
explanation: The cells marked in the image above are the foam cells in atheromatous plaques. They refer to lipid-laden monocytes/ macrophages or smooth muscle cells within the plaques. These cells ingest lipoproteins accumulated within the intima of the vessel wall. Since these lipoproteins are modified due to the action of inflammatory mediators, they cannot be degraded further within these cells. This leads to the accumulation of modified lipids within these cells converting them to foam cells.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In which part of the atheromatous plaque are the T-cells and macrophages in abundance?
explanation: T-cells and macrophages are in abundance in the shoulder of an atheromatous plaque. Structure of an atherosclerotic plaque: Superficial fibrous cap - made up of smooth muscle cells and connective tissue, especially collagen. It also contains macrophages, foam cells, and lymphocytes. It determines the stability of plaque. Necrotic core - contains lipid (cholesterol and cholesterol esters), debris from dead cells, calcium, and foam cells. Shoulder - a more cellular area containing macrophages, T-cells, and smooth muscle cells. Periphery - shows neovascularization/proliferation of small blood vessels. The image below shows the structure of an atherosclerotic plaque.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is true regarding a stable atherosclerotic plaque?
explanation: A stable atherosclerotic plaque has abundant smooth muscle cells. These cells synthesize collagen which stabilizes the plaque. Both these features contribute to a thick fibrous cap that prevents the easy rupture of a plaque. Stable plaque Vulnerable plaque Dense collagen Less collagen Thick fibrous cap Thin fibrous cap Stable plaque Vulnerable plaque Stable plaque Vulnerable plaque Minimal inflammation Increased inflammation Less extracellular lipid Abundant extracellular lipid Abundant smooth muscle ce lls Few smooth muscle cells Few foam cells Abundant foam cells
subject: Pathology

question_text: In a 50-year-old normotensive patient with a 10-year history of dyslipidemia, which of the following complications is he at the least risk of developing?
explanation: A 50-year-old patient suffering from dyslipidemia for the past 10 years is likely to have atherosclerosis. Dissection is associated with hypertension, not atherosclerosis. An atherosclerotic plaque may undergo pathological changes such as: Thrombus formation - due to rupture, ulceration, erosio Increase in plaque size - due to hemorrhage into the plaque These consequences occlude the lumen of the vessel and impair the blood supply. Impaired blood supply may lead to claudication, ischemic heart disease, myocardial infarction, cerebral infarction, or even gangrene. The thrombus may dislodge and cause an embolism. Atherosclerotic debris released due to plaque rupture may produce microemboli, known as atheroembolism. Atherosclerotic plaques also cause ischemic atrophy of the underlying media. This causes weakness of the vessel wall leading to aneurysm formation. The image below depicts the late complications of atherosclerosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with anginal chest pain is planned for coronary angiography. What level of stenosis would you expect to see in the affected artery?
explanation: This symptomatic patient likely has >70% occlusion of his coronary arteries. This is known as critical stenosis. It refers to the stage at which the occlusion is sufficiently severe to produce tissue ischemia. This leads to clinical manifestations of ischemia such as: Stable angina Bowel ischemia Intermittent claudicatio
subject: Pathology

question_text: Elevated levels of which of the following is not a predictor for stroke?
explanation: Elevated plasminogen levels are not associated with stroke. Elevated levels of the following are predictors for stroke: C-reactive protein - also indicates risk for MI, PAD and used to monitor effectiveness of risk reduction measures like exercise, weight loss Homocysteine - also correlates with MI, PAD, venous thrombosis, and premature vascular disease Plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 - marker of hemostatic and/or fibrinolytic function and also predicts risk of MI
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient presented with symptoms of heart failure. He had undergone a coronary bypass procedure with a small-diameter graft 3 weeks ago. What is the likely cause for his presentation?
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of an early failure of a small diameter venous graft (8 mm). The likely mechanism for graft failure within the 1st month is acute thrombosis. Late vein graft failure (after months to years) is due to: Neointimal hyperplasia (1 month to 1 year) Atherosclerotic plaque (> 1 year) Aneurysm Based on the diameter of the synthetic or autologous vascular graft, it can be: Large diameter graft (12-18mm) - Used in high-flow locations such as the aorta Small diameter graft (8 mm) - Includes saphenous vein or left internal mammary artery Used in coronary bypass surgeries
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Which of the following is false regarding the KLF-2 transcription factor?
Activates atheroprotective genes
options: Production is induced by laminar blood flow
Responsible for the atheroprotective role of statins
explanation: Kruppel like factor-2 (KLF-2) is responsible for turning off the inflammatory gene transcription. KLF-2 production is induced by laminar blood flow which is seen in normal endothelium. This transcription factor activates the atheroprotective genes and turns off inflammatory gene transcription. Statins up-regulate KLF-2 expression in endothelial cells, and this activity is associated with an anti-inflammatory phenotype. Up-regulation of KLF-2 gene expression may be a novel strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. Aneurysm and Dissection
subject: Pathology

question_text: Pulsating hematoma is associated with which of the following conditions?
explanation: Pulsating hematoma is associated with a false aneurysm. An aneurysm is a localized abnormal dilation of a blood vessel or the heart. There are 2 types: True aneurysm Due to weakened and thinned, but intact arterial wall False aneurysm Due to a defect in the vascular wall Results in an extravascular hematoma that communicates with intravascular space Causes transmission of arterial pulsations to the hematoma (pulsating hematoma) Dissection occurs when blood enters a defect in the arterial wall and tunnels/dissects between its layers. The image below shows a pseudo/false aneurysm of the left ventricle. False aneurysm Dissection Defect across all the layers of the vessel wall Defect is usually an intimal t ear Hematoma is extravascular ( outside the vessel wall) Hematoma is within the laye rs of the vessel wall Hematoma is lined by extrav ascular connective tissue Hematoma is lined by the lay ers of the vessel wall
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient presented with a severe headache and transient loss of consciousness. On examination, neck rigidity was present and blood pressure was 160/110 mmHg. A CT brain was done as shown below. Which type of aneurysm could have been involved in causing this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) in a hypertensive patient. It may occur due to the rupture of Berry aneurysms, which are saccular aneurysms. Aneurysms are classified as: Saccular aneurysms are spherical outpouchings involving only a portion of the vessel wall. Fusiform aneurysms are diffuse, circumferential dilations involving long vascular segments. Both saccular and fusiform aneurysms are true aneurysms because they have an intact vessel wall. Dissecting aneurysm is produced when a dissection leads to an aneurysm. The image below shows the CT appearance of a SAH.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient who is a known case of hypertension was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. What is the likely underlying pathophysiology causing this condition?
explanation: The likely underlying pathophysiology causing this condition is increased metalloproteinase expression that degrades extracellular matrix and weakens the vessel wall. The two most important causes of aortic aneurysms are atherosclerosis and hypertension. Aneurysms occuring as a consequence of atherosclerosis occurs most commonly in the abdominal aorta and common iliac arteries. Option A: Obliterative end-arteritis of vasa-vasorum occurs in late stage syphilis and can contribute to aneurysms Option D: Medial hypertrophy of vasa-vasorum occurs in hypertension, which is associated most commonly with ascending aortic aneurysms.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Arterial aneurysms due to underlying cystic medial degeneration are seen in patients with which of the following conditions?
explanation: Cystic medial degeneration leading to aneurysms is a feature of Marfan syndrome. Cystic medial degeneration refers to the degenerative changes in the media of the vessel wall that lead to aneurysm formation. These include: Loss of smooth muscle cells Loss of elastic fibers Inadequate extracellular matrix synthesis Increased production of glycosaminoglycan It can be caused due to: Medial ischemia - atherosclerosis, hypertension Defective connective tissue - Marfan syndrome, scurvy The image below (Movat stain) shows a cross-section of the aortic media from a patient with Marfan's syndrome showing elastin fragmentation (stained black) and loss of smooth muscle cells (cells stained red and nuclei stained violet).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following causes aneurysm formation due to defective elastin?
explanation: Loeys–Dietz syndrome leads to aneurysm formation due to defective elastin (due to a defect in TGF- signalling pathway). Aneurysms are caused due to structural or functional defects in the connective tissue of the vascular wall. The following conditions cause intrinsic defects in connective tissue leading to aneurysm formation: Syndrome Defect in Loeys–Dietzsyndrome Synthesis ofelastinandcollage ns IandIII Ehlers–Danlossyndrome Synthesis oftype III collageni n some subtypes Marfansyndrome Synthesis of the proteinfibrill incausing weakening of elasti c tissue Scurvy(vitamin C deficiency) Collagencross-linking
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common site of syphilitic aneurysms?
explanation: Syphilitic aneurysms most commonly involves the ascending aorta. Late-stage syphilis causes obliterative endarteritis of vasa vasorum of the aorta. This leads to ischemic injury of the aortic media resulting in aneurysmal dilation.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 55-year-old normotensive patient with dyslipidemia is undergoing a regular check-up. He is at an increased risk of developing all of the following except:
explanation: Dyslipidemia is not a direct risk factor for deep vein thrombosis. Dyslipidemia is a risk factor for atherosclerosis and its complications, including abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA). AAA can also be associated with smaller aneurysms of the iliac arteries. Patients with AAA are also likely to have atherosclerotic lesions in other vascular beds that may lead to ischemic heart disease or stroke.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following myocardial infarcts cause aneurysm as a post-MI complication?
explanation: Anterior transmural infarcts are involved in causing aneurysm as a post-MI complication. Posterior transmural infarcts are more likely to be complicated by conduction blocks, right ventricular involvement, or both.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A patient was diagnosed with an asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm of a diameter of
3.6cm. On a follow-up visit 1 year later, the diameter was noted to be 3.8cm. What is the risk of rupture of the aneurysm in this patient at present?
explanation: Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) of size  4 cm with slow growth have no risk of rupture. The risk of rupture for AAA is directly related to the size of the aneurysm: 4 cm - nil 4–5 cm - 1% per year 5–6 cm - 11% per year >6 cm - 25% per year Most aneurysms expand at a rate of 0.2 to 0.3 cm/year. The risk of rupture increases when there is a growth of > 0.5 cm/6 months as well as in active smokers.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 55-year-old man presents with sudden onset chest pain radiating to the back between the scapulae. The CT of this patient is given below. What is the major risk factor for developing this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with the CT finding of a second column of blood after an intimal tear is the classic presentation of an aortic dissection. The major risk factor for aortic dissection is hypertension. Dissection occurs when blood enters into the media to form a blood-filled channel between the laminar planes of the media. It usually occurs due to a tear in the intima which allows blood in the lumen to flow into the media. It may also occur due to the rupture of vasa vasorum. It occurs due to: Hypertension Connective tissue defects like Marfan syndrome Iatrogenic trauma during coronary catheterization or cardiopulmonary bypass
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 2D echocardiography of a patient who presented with chest pain showed the following appearance of the aorta on suprasternal parasagittal view. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?
options: It is a severe type of dissection
explanation: The above image shows a double-barreled aorta with a superior and inferior lumen. It is a less severe type of dissection because it is less likely to cause hemorrhage. A double-barreled aorta is seen there are two intimal tears. Hence, the hematoma enters the media through an intimal tear but re-enters back into the lumen through another intimal tear present distally. As the blood enters the lumen back, this type of dissection does not progress, thus averting hemorrhage. This creates a false vascular channel in the blood vessel which, over time, can be endothelialized to become chronic dissections.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
How would you classify the following according to the DeBakey classification?

Type II
explanation: The above image shows proximal dissection of only the ascending aorta. This is classified as type II as per DeBakey's classification. Classification of aortic dissection: Stanford Type A - proximal lesions. These are more common and dangerous. It may involve: Both the ascending and descending aorta - DeBakey type I Only the ascending aorta - DeBakey type II Stanford Type B or DeBakey type III - distal lesions not involving the ascending part and usually beginning distal to the subclavian artery Vasculitis
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is a large vessel vasculitis?
explanation: Giant cell arteritis is a large vessel vasculitis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: All of the following vasculitides involves veins except?
explanation: Giant cell arteritis does not involve the veins. Vasculitides affecting the veins are as follows: Leukocytoclastic vasculitis Behcet disease Buerger disease (Thrombangiitis obliterans)
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 60-year-old man presents with sudden onset blindness. He gives a history of frequent headaches along the sides of his scalp. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of giant cell arteritis. Giant cell / temporal arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder of large to small-sized arteries that especially affects the temporal arteries. It is seen in people over 50 years of age. It usually presents with facial pain or headache along the course of the superficial temporal artery. It can also affect: Ophthalmic arteries- leading to sudden onset diplopia or blindness Aorta- leading to giant-cell aortitis Vertebral arteries A biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis. Giant cell arteritis needs to be promptly diagnosed and treated with steroids to prevent permanent blindness.
subject: Pathology

question_text: An elderly patient presented with temporal headache and jaw claudication. She was diagnosed to be a case of Giant cell arteritis. Which of the following statements about giant cell arteritis is incorrect?
options: A negative biopsy excludes the diagnosis
The classic lesions are medial granulomas
Fragmentation is seen in internal elastic lamina
explanation: A negative biopsy cannot exclude the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis. It is because the lesions are focally distributed. A biopsy sample may be taken from the normal part of the artery leading to a false-negative report. An adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment. Biopsy findings: Giant cell arteritis is primarily medial granulomatous inflammation. These lesions involve the internal elastic lamina leading to elastic lamina fragmentation. There is intimal thickening that reduces the luminal diameter. Granulomas with multinucleated giant cells, infiltrate of T cells (CD4+ >CD8+), and macrophages. Note : According to the 21st edition of Harrison's Medicine, as involvement of the vessel may be segmental, getting a biopsy segment of 3–5 cm together with serial sectioning of biopsy specimens would help to increase a positive yield. And Robbin's 10th edition mentions that an adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment. Image: Giant-cell arteritis with intimal thickening and internal elastic lamina fragmentation
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old lady presents with weakness of the left upper limb. On examination, the blood pressure recorded on the left upper limb was found to be lower than that of the right upper limb. Her aortic arch angiogram showed narrowing of the arch of the aorta and subclavian artery. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and radiological findings are suggestive of Takayasu arteritis. Takayasu's arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis affecting medium and large-sized arteries, in this case, the aortic arch and its branches. Clinical manifestations include vision disturbances and profound weakening of the pulses, especially in the upper extremities. Histopathology: Irregular thickening of the vessel wall is seen with associated intimal hyperplasia. Characteristic granulomatous inflammation, with the presence of giant cells and patchy media necrosis. Disease progression is associated with collagenous scarring and chronic inflammatory infiltrates across all layers of the vessel wall. Other options- Option A: Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and people aged >50 years. The clinical features include headache associated with scalp pain and jaw claudication, fever, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss. Half of the patients have temporal artery abnormalities such as enlargement, tenderness, nodular swelling, and loss of pulse of the temporal artery, either unilateral or bilateral. Gentle pressure on the scalp may elicit focal or generalized tenderness. Though the arch of the aorta may also be involved in giant cell arteritis (known as giant cell aortitis), it is seen in people more than 50 years of age. Whereas, Takayasu arteritis is seen more commonly in adolescents and young women. Option C: Thromboangitis obliterans, also known as Buerger's disease, is an inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder involving medium- and small-sized vessels in the distal extremities. It is most frequently seen in male smokers less than 40 years of age. Option D: Behcet's disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels that classically presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. There can also be gastrointestinal and pulmonary manifestations, with disease mortality related to severe neurologic involvement or rupture of vascular aneurysms.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A young girl with bilaterally unequal pulses is diagnosed with Takayasu Arteritis. Which of the following is the most commonly involved site in Takayasu arteritis?
explanation: The most commonly involved blood vessel in Takayasu arteritis is sublclavian artery. Takayasu arteritis is an inflammatory and stenotic disease of medium and large-sized arteries characterized by a strong predilection for the aortic arch and its branches. It is also known as aortic arch syndrome. The order of arteries affected in Takayasu arteritis is subclavian artery > common carotid artery > abdominal aorta > renal artery > aortic arch = vertebral > coeliac axis > iliac > pulmonary > coronary artery. Takayasu arteritis causes irregular thickening of the vessel wall with intimal hyperplasia leading to narrowing of the lumen and organ ischemia. It may have various clinical presentations depending on the vessel involved: Arch of aorta and its branches: Subclavian artery- leads to weak pulses in the upper extremities. Hence it is also known as pulseless disease Carotid arteries- leads to weak pulses, blindness, neurological deficits Distal aorta- leads to claudication of the legs Pulmonary artery- leads to pulmonary hypertension Coronary arteries- leads to myocardial infarction Renal arteries- leads to systemic hypertension
subject: Pathology

question_text: A young male presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. The small bowel is found to have a small infarcted area which is surgically removed. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen is given below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the small bowel infarction?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the histopathological findings are suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). PAN affects small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It typically affects young adults. The patient may present with rapidly accelerating hypertension due to renal artery involvement (most common) or abdominal pain and bloody stools caused by involvement of gastrointestinal vessels. Option A: Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is a vascular pathology seen in severe hypertension. Option B: Cystic medial degeneration leads to dissecting aortic aneurysm. Option C: Mönckeberg’s arteriosclerosis does not cause infarction.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is characteristically spared in polyarteritis nodosa?
explanation: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) characteristically spares the pulmonary circulation. PAN is a systemic vasculitis of small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It typically involves the renal (most commonly involved) and visceral vessels. It has no association with ANCA, but about 30% of patients have chronic hepatitis-B.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash and swelling of her hands and feet since past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, oedema of hands and feet, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the likely condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome. Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It is commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age. Clinical features include: Fever Conjunctival and oral erythema Blistering, edema of hands and feet Erythema of palms and soles Desquamative rash Cervical lymphadenopathy The disease is usually self-limiting. In some cases, the disease may involve coronary artery leading to thrombosis and acute myocardial infarction. Intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin may be given to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following antibodies is associated with vasculitis seen in patients with Kawasaki disease?
explanation: Antibodies to endothelial cells are associated with vasculitis in Kawasaki disease. Option A: Immune complex deposition is characteristic of vasculitis due to systemic immunologic disorders such as SLE. Option B: ANCA-associated vasculitis is seen in microscopic polyangiitis, Churg–Strauss syndrome, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Option D: Autoreactive T cells are seen in giant cell arteritis. Reports have been described in children with a multisystem inflammatory condition (MIS-C) linked to COVID-19 infection with some features similar to Kawasaki disease and toxic shock syndrome. Although shock is rarely associated with Kawasaki disease, many children with the inflammatory syndrome related to COVID show signs of shock.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome?
explanation: Kawasaki disease is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome. Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness occurring in children aged 4 years or younger. It is usually self- limiting. This vasculitis affects large to medium-sized vessels and even small vessels. It is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome because it can present with non-purulent conjunctivitis, oral erythema, edema of the hands and feet, desquamative rash, and cervical lymph node enlargement. It has a predilection for coronary artery involvement and is the leading cause of acquired heart disease in children. Untreated patients may develop coronary artery ectasia or aneurysms, leading to rupture or thrombosis, myocardial infarction, and sudden death. Espundia is the muco-cutaneous variant of Leishmaniasis
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 27-yr-old woman, presented to OPD with complaints of joint pain and photosensitivity. On examination, you see a butterfly rash on the face and petechial hemorrhages on the lower limbs. On serology ANA, turns out to be positive. Which of the following is the most likely cause of vasculitis in this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus. The vasculitis occurring in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus is due to immune complex deposition. Vasculitis is the inflammation of the vessel wall. The various mechanisms that cause vasculitis are: Immune-mediated inflammation- Vasculitis caused by immune-mediated inflammation may occur due to the following factors: Immune complex deposition: Seen in systemic immunological disorders like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA): Seen in Wegener's granulomatosis, Churg–Strauss disease, etc Anti endothelial cell antibodies: Implicated in Kawasaki disease Autoreactive T cells Infectious pathogens- by direct invasion, generating immune complexes or triggering cross-reactivity. Physical or chemical injury- from irradiation, trauma, toxins, etc.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 43 year-old-male patient came to the clinic with complaints of occasional hematuria and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Examination revealed tiny petechial
hemorrhages over his lower limbs. The patient tests positive for the anti-proteinase-3 antibody. Which of the following is true about this major antibody?
options: It is also known as p-ANCA
It shows perinuclear staining on immunofluorescence
explanation: Anti-proteinase-3/PR3-ANCA / c-ANCA is triggered by certain infections as proteinase 3 shares similarities with many microbial peptides. This is the major antibody responsible for Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA). Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are a heterogeneous group of autoantibodies directed against the constituents of neutrophils or monocytes. Many patients with vasculitis have circulating antibodies that react with neutrophil cytoplasmic antigens. The two most important ANCAs related to vasculitis are: Anti-proteinase-3/PR3-ANCA/c-ANCA - Directed against PR3 which is a neutrophil azurophilic granule constituent. Anti-myeloperoxidase/MPO-ANCA/p-ANCA - Directed against MPO which is a lysosomal granule constituent involved in oxygen free-radical generation. MPO-ANCAs are induced by severa therapeutic agents, particularly propylthiouracil.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is a pauci-immune rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis?
explanation: Type III or pauci-immune-type of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) may be a component of systemic vasculitis such as Wegener granulomatosis or microscopic polyangiitis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements about microscopic polyangiitis is not true?
options: It affects capillaries, small arterioles, and venules
It is also known as leukocytoclastic vasculitis
Lesions of different stages of activity coexist in the same vesse
explanation: All lesions of microscopic polyangiitis tend to be of the same age in any given patient, unlike polyarteritis nodosa where all stages of activity from early to late may coexist in different vessels or even within the same vessel. Microscopic polyangiitis is a necrotizing vasculitis that affects capillaries, small arterioles, and venules. It is associated with MPO-ANCA. It is also called leukocytoclastic vasculitis because of apoptotic neutrophils. It may involve the skin, mucous membranes, lungs, brain, heart, gastrointestinal tract, kidneys, and muscle. Therefore, the patient may present with hemoptysis, hematuria, proteinuria, bowel pain or bleeding, muscle pain or weakness, and palpable cutaneous purpura. Necrotizing glomerulonephritis (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis are particularly common.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 21-year-old boy, who is a known case of asthma, presents with wheezing and rhinitis. Laboratory results show peripheral eosinophilia and antibodies against neutrophil myeloperoxidase. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the lab findings are suggestive of Churg–Strauss syndrome. Churg-Strauss Syndrome / Allergic granulomatosis and angiitis is a small-vessel necrotizing vasculitis classically associated with: asthma allergic rhinitis asymmetric mono neuritis multiplex ung infiltrates peripheral hypereosinophilia extravascular necrotizing granulomata. It is a multisystem disease with cutaneous involvement (palpable purpura), gastrointestinal tract bleeding, and renal disease. Eosinophilic infiltrates may also be seen in the myocardium giving rise to cardiomyopathy. p- ANCA (MPO-ANCA) is positive in about 50% of cases. Histological features are similar to those observed in polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) or microscopic polyangiitis but characteristically accompanied by granulomas and eosinophils. Eosinophilic vasculitis seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome:
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 45-year-old man presents with hematuria, intermittent hemoptysis and chronic sinusitis. His chest radiograph shows multiple opacities and cavities. Renal biopsy suggests focal necrotizing glomerulonephritis. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
options: Necrotizing granulomas of the upper respiratory tract
explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Wegener's granulomatosis. It is associated with PR3- ANCA (and not MPO- ANCA) in about 95% of cases. Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis/Wegener granulomatosis is a necrotizing vasculitis characterized by a triad of necrotizing inflammation: Necrotizing granulomas of the upper respiratory tract or the lung Necrotizing or granulomatous vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels, most prominently in the lungs Focal necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis Males are affected more often than females. The most common clinical features include persistent pneumonitis with bilateral nodular and cavitary infiltrates, chronic sinusitis, mucosal ulcerations of the nasopharynx, and evidence of renal disease. Image: Chest radiograph showing pulmonary granulomatosis
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 15-year old boy comes to the clinic complaining about recurrent painful oral ulcers. He also experiences repeated episodes of eye redness and pain which subside with medication. On examination, ulcers are seen on his genitals. Which of the following features would you not expect to see in this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Behçet disease. Nail fold capillary abnormalities are typically seen in systemic sclerosis. Behcet disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels that classically presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. Other skin findings include erythema nodosa (red tender nodules on legs) and positive pathergy test (pustular reaction 24-48 hrs after sterile needle puncture or normal saline injection). There can also be gastrointestinal and pulmonary manifestations, with disease mortality related to severe neurologic involvement or rupture of vascular aneurysms. Dural sinus thrombosis is the most common CNS manifestation in children. Pulmonary aneurysms are the most severe feature of pediatric BD. It is associated with HLA subtype B51. T helper 17 (Th17) cells play an important contribution in the recruitment of neutrophils, which will later infiltrate into the vessel wall.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 5-year-old child presents with colicky abdominal pain and purpuric skin lesions on the extensor surfaces of the arms and legs. Urine analysis reveals hematuria and mild proteinuria. The most probable diagnosis is:
explanation: The clinical features and the investigations are suggestive of Henoch-Schonlein purpura. Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a systemic immune disorder, commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years. The patient may present with the following clinical features: Skin lesions- characteristically involve the extensor surfaces of arms and legs, and also the buttocks Abdominal manifestations- include pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding. Renal manifestations- include gross or microscopic hematuria, nephritic or nephrotic syndrome. Renal manifestations are more severe in the adults It is strongly associated with atopy in a few patients, and the onset often follows an upper respiratory infection. IgA is deposited in the glomerular mesangium in a distribution similar to that of IgA nephropathy.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following structures are involved in Buerger's disease?
explanation: Arteries, veins and nerves can be involved in thrombangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease). It is a vasculitis of small and medium-sized arteries and secondarily extends into contiguous veins and nerves. With time, all three structures can be encased in fibrous tissue.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 32-year-old male smoker presents with intermittent claudication and gangrene of the lower extremities. Biopsy of the blood vessels supplying this area shows acute and chronic inflammation, with luminal thrombosis containing small neutrophilic microabscesses.
Granulomatous inflammation appears to extend into the contiguous veins and nerves. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis is thromboangiitis obliterans / Buerger disease. It is the segmental, thrombosing, acute and chronic inflammation of medium-sized and small arteries. It principally involves the tibial and radial arteries. It is seen in heavy cigarette smokers, usually before the age of 35 years. HLA-A-9 and HLA-B-5 associated with a high risk of TAO. The patients present with intermittent claudication, chronic ulcerations of the extremity, and later progress to frank gangrene. The microscopy findings include luminal thrombosis (thrombangiitis), that is, thrombus containing microabscesses that occlude the lumen (obliterans). They contain small microabscesses composed of neutrophils. Berger disease refers to IgA nephropathy. It is seen within 3-5 days of sore throat. It is associated with purpuric rash in the lower limbs.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Which of the following histologic findings would be most suggestive of Buerger’s disease in a patient?
Mononuclear infiltrates with perivascular cuffing of the vasavasorum
explanation: Luminal thrombosis containing small microabscesses composed of neutrophils is seen in thromboangiitis obliterans or Buerger disease. Option A: Adventitial mononuclear infiltrates with perivascular cuffing of the vasa vasorum has been described in Takayasu arteritis. Option B: Fragmented neutrophils undergoing apoptosis infiltrating blood vessels termed leukocytoclastic vasculitis are seen in small vessel vasculitis. Option D: Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in immune reactions involving blood vessels seen in immunologically mediated vasculitis syndromes. Vascular Tumors
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following best describes angiosarcoma?
explanation: Angiosarcoma is a malignant neoplasm. It is a vascular tumor arising from the endothelial cells. Benign vascular tumors are characterized by well-formed vascular channels lined by normal endothelial cells. Whereas, malignant vascular tumors are characterized by poorly formed vessels with cellular atypia.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following vascular tumors are not derived from endothelial cells?
explanation: Hemangiopericytoma is not derived from endothelial cells. It is a malignant vascular tumor derived from supporting cells of the blood vessels. Vascular tumors derived from endothelial cells are: Hemangioma Lymphangioma Angiosarcoma The endothelial origin of vascular neoplasms can be confirmed using endothelial cell-specific markers such as CD31 or von Willebrand factor.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is a true neoplasm?
explanation: Cystic hygroma / cavernous lymphangioma is a true neoplasm. It is a benign vascular tumor arising from endothelial cells. Options A and B: Nevus flammeus and port wine stain are vascular ectasias which are not true neoplasms. They are congenital or acquired malformations. Option D: Bacillary angiomatosis is non-neoplastic reactive vascular proliferation in response to opportunistic bacilli.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common form of vascular ectasia?
explanation: The most common form of vascular ectasia is nevus flammeus. Vascular ectasias are the conditions involving the dilatation of blood vessels. They can be congenital or acquired malformations or hamartomas. Telangiectasia is the permanent dilation of small blood vessels. They lead to red lesions in the skin or mucous membranes. Various types of vascular ectasias are as follows: Nevus flammeus (birthmark): Pink/purple flat lesions on the head or neck. They regress spontaneously. Image showing nevus flammeus in a newborn: Port-wine stain: A special form of nevus flammeus. It thickens the skin surface. It grows during childhood and does not fade with time. Image showing port-wine stain in a child: Spider telangiectasias: They are pulsatile and blanch with pressure. These commonly occur on the face, neck, or upper chest. They are associated with hyperestrogenic states, such as pregnancy or liver cirrhosis. Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (Osler–Weber–Rendu disease) is caused by mutations in genes related to the TGF- signaling pathway. It is characterized by dilated blood vessels with thin walls that bleed easily. There can be bleeding from the mucous membranes of the nose (epistaxis), tongue, mouth, eyes, and the gastrointestinal tract. The image below shows multiple flat non pulsating telengiectasias in a patient with Osler-Weber-Rendu disease:
subject: Pathology

question_text: A young girl presents with recurrent seizures, mental retardation and a skin lesion as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the facial port-wine stain as seen in the image is characteristic of Sturge-Weber syndrome. This is characterized by a triad of: Facial port wine nevus - usually found in the distribution of the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve Glaucoma Ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomatosis (LAM) - can lead to seizures, mental retardation or hemiplegia and are seen as intracranial tram-track calcifications on CT as given below.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements about hemangioma is true?
options: Capillary hemangioma is the most common type of hemangioma
Cavernous hemangioma usually regresses completely by 7 years of age
Juvenile hemangioma is infiltrative and does not regress spontaneously
Pyogenic granuloma is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus
explanation: The most common type of hemangioma is capillary hemangioma. Hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors of infancy and childhood. They are of the following types: Capillary hemangiomas are the most common type. They occur in the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and mucous membranes of the oral cavities and lips. Cavernous hemangiomas are composed of large, dilated vascular channels. They are more infiltrative and frequently involve deep structures. They do not spontaneously regress. Juvenile hemangiomas/strawberry type hemangiomas of the newborn are extremely common. They arise in the skin and grow rapidly for a few months, and usually regress completely by the age of 7 years. Pyogenic granulomas are capillary hemangiomas that present as rapidly growing red pedunculated lesions on the skin, gingival, or oral mucosa. They bleed easily and are often ulcerated. It is not caused by bacterial infection.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A child is brought by her parents to the OPD with complaints of a swelling on the right thigh. Further evaluation led to the diagnosis of capillary hemangioma in this patient. What is the most appropriate next best step?
options: Explain about the risk of malignant transformation of the tumor
Test the child for retrovirus infection
Enquire about history of exposure to polyvinyl chloride
Assure the parents about spontaneous regression of the tumor
explanation: Capillary hemangiomas are present from birth and initially increase in size, but many eventually regress spontaneously. They are generally benign. Images show the gross and microscopic pictures of capillary hemangioma:
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with bilateral pheochromocytoma is diagnosed with von Hippel-Lindau disease. This condition is associated with which of the following?
explanation: von Hippel–Lindau disease is associated with cavernous hemangiomas. These vascular lesions are commonly found in the cerebellum, brain stem, retina, pancreas, and liver. Cavernous hemangiomas are large, cavernous blood-filled vascular spaces separated by connective tissue stroma. They are infiltrative and involve deep structures. They do not regress spontaneously. The given image shows the microscopic appearance of cavernous hemangioma:
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following vascular lesions are commonly seen in patients with Turner syndrome?
explanation: The vascular lesions commonly seen in Turner syndrome are cavernous lymphangiomas of the neck. Cavernous lymphangiomas (cystic hygromas) are massively dilated lymphatic spaces lined by endothelial cells and separated by connective tissue stroma. They are typically found in the neck or axilla of children and rarely in the retroperitoneum. They can be enormous causing gross deformities around the neck. Image shows cavernous lymphangioma of the neck associated with a girl having Turner syndrome:
subject: Pathology

question_text: A middle aged male patient presents with a swelling on his left thumb as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements about this swelling is false?
options: It is caused by a bacterial infection
It is a type of capillary hemangioma
explanation: The given image shows a pyogenic granuloma. It is not caused by bacterial infection. The term pyogenic granuloma is a misnomer as it neither contains pus nor is it a granulomatous lesion. These are capillary hemangiomas that appear as red pedunculated lesions on the skin, gingival, or oral mucosa. They are most commonly benign. They tend to grow rapidly, bleed easily and are often ulcerated. Histologic image of pyogenic granuloma:
subject: Pathology

question_text: Granuloma gravidarum is a type of .
explanation: Pregnancy tumor or granuloma gravidarum is a type of pyogenic granuloma that occurs infrequently in gingiva of pregnant women. These lesions may spontaneously regress, especially after pregnancy, or they may undergo fibrosis. Occasionally, they require surgical excision.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following vascular tumors arising from arteriovenous structures is involved in thermoregulation?
explanation: The vascular tumor arising from arteriovenous structures involved in thermoregulation is glomus tumor. These tumors arise from modified smooth muscle cells of the glomus bodies which are specialized arteriovenous structures involved in thermoregulation. They are benign but extremely painful due to abundant nerve fibers. Histopathology shows branching vascular channels separated by stroma containing glomus cells in nests:
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common site of glomus tumors?
explanation: Glomus tumors are most commonly found in the distal portion of the digits, especially under the fingernails.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 46-year-old HIV-positive female patient presents with fever, weight loss, and cutaneous lesions as shown in the image. Microscopic examination reveals capillary proliferation and neutrophilic infiltration. Which of the following is the causative organism?
explanation: The clinical vignette and the microscopic findings suggest the diagnosis of bacillary angiomatosis caused by Bartonella henselae. Bacillary angiomatosis is a vascular proliferation in immunocompromised hosts caused by opportunistic gram-negative bacilli of the Bartonella family like Bartonella henselae and Bartonella quintana. These lesions can involve the skin, bone, brain, and other organs. They contain stromal neutrophils, nuclear dust, and causal bacteria. Histology shows capillary proliferation with endothelial cells exhibiting nuclear atypia and mitosis. Modified silver (Warthin-Starry) stain is used for demonstrating clusters of tangled bacilli. The given image shows histologic appearance of bacillary angiomatosis:
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 50-year-old HIV seropositive male presents with skin lesions over the distal portion of the lower limbs as shown in the image below. Biopsy shows a lesion composed of proliferating spindle cells along with small vessels and spaces containing red cells. Which of the following
is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the histopathological findings are most suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma. Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) and is highly associated with AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome). Classic Kaposi sarcoma occurs in older men of Eastern European and Meditteranean descent. It has the following three clinical stages: Patches- red-purple macules on the distal lower extremities Plaques- patches progress to large violaceous raised plaques. Lesions spread proximally. Nodules- Lesions become nodular with more neoplastic features. This stage also progresses to involve nodes and viscera. Diseases caused by HHV-8 infection primarily in patients with HIV infection include: Kaposi sarcoma Multicentric Castleman disease (MCD) Primary effusion lymphoma (PEL) The given image shows sheets of proliferating spindle cells:
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which type of Kaposi sarcoma is most commonly seen in patients with HIV infection?
explanation: AIDS-associated or epidemic Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is an AIDS-defining illness, and worldwide, it represents the most common HIV-related malignancy. Four forms of KS are recognized, based on population demographics and risks: Type Classic Endemic African Transplant-associated AIDS- associated epi demic KS Epidemiolo gy Older men of eastern European and Meditt eranean descentNot a ssociated with HIV HIV seronegative indi viduals Solid organ transplan t recipients HIV-infected individ uals Clinical feat ures Skin plaques and nod ules Lymph node and visc eral involvement Cutaneous, mucosal a nd visceral lesions Lymph nodes involve d
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with vague upper abdominal pain is diagnosed with hemangioendothelioma of the liver. What is this classified as?
explanation: Hemangioendothelioma is classified as intermediate-grade neoplasm. It encompasses a spectrum of vascular neoplasms with clinical behavior intermediate between benign well-differentiated hemangiomas and anaplastic angiosarcomas.
subject: Pathology

question_text: An elderly male working in a factory manufacturing PVC pipes is at risk of developing which of the following cancers?
explanation: Hepatic angiosarcoma is associated with carcinogenic exposures to polyvinyl chloride. Angiosarcoma is a malignant endothelial neoplasm that primarily affects older adults. The tumor often involves the skin, soft tissue, breast, and liver. Angiosarcomas are locally invasive and can readily metastasize.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common causative agent for lymphangitis?
explanation: Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci are the most common agents responsible for lymphangitis. Lymphangitis represents acute inflammation elicited by the spread of bacterial infections into lymphatics. It is manifested by red, painful subcutaneous streaks (the inflamed lymphatics) and painful enlargement of the draining lymph nodes (lymphadenitis). Filariasis causes obstructive lymphedema and chronic lymphadenitis.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Which of the following best describes Milroy disease?
Simple congenital primary lymphedema
explanation: Milroy disease refers to heredofamilial congenital lymphedema. Causes of lymphedema: Primary lymphedema: Simple congenital lymphedema Heredofamilial congenital lymphedema (Milroy disease) Secondary or obstructive lymphedema: Malignant tumors obstructing lymphatic channels Surgical removal of regional groups of lymph nodes, e.g., radical mastectomy Postirradiation fibrosis Filariasis Post-inflammatory thrombosis and scarring Heart Failure and Ischemic Disease
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following layers is not present in the cardiac valve?
explanation: Adventitia is not a layer of the cardiac valves. It is the outermost layer of a blood vessel. It contains connective tissue, a few cells, macrophages, mast cells, fibroblasts, and the nerves and vessels that supply the vascular wall. Cardiac valves are lined by endothelium and share a tri-layered architecture: Fibrosa is a dense collagenous core at the outflow surface. It is connected to the valvular supporting structures. Spongiosa is a central core of loose connective tissue Ventricularis or atrialis is a layer rich in elastin on the inflow surface.
subject: Pathology

question_text: You are conducting an autopsy of an elderly patient who was found dead in his home. Which of the following changes in the heart will not be suggestive of normal aging?
explanation: In the given scenario, an increase in the size of the left ventricle is not normally seen in the heart of an elderly person. The size of the left ventricular cavity is decreased in the aged heart, particularly in the base-to-apex dimension. This change is exacerbated by systemic hypertension. Changes in the aging heart: Chambers: Increased left atrial cavity size Decreased left ventricular cavity size Valves: Fibrous thickening of valve leaflets Aortic and mitral valve calcific deposits Epicardial coronary arteries: Diminished compliance Calcific deposits Atherosclerotic plaques Myocardium: Increased subepicardial fat Brown atrophy Lipofuscin deposition Basophilic degeneration Amyloid deposits Aorta: Dilated with a rightward shift Elastic fragmentation and collagen accumulation Atherosclerotic plaque
subject: Pathology

question_text: What type of cells are heart failure cells?
explanation: Heart failure cells are hemosiderin-laden macrophages. They are telltale signs of previous episodes of pulmonary edema. In cardiac failure, red cells and plasma proteins extravasate into the edema fluid within the alveolar spaces. These are then phagocytosed and digested by macrophages. The iron recovered from haemoglobin is stored in the form of hemosiderin. The image given below shows heart failure cells within alveolar spaces.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common cause of left-sided diastolic heart failure?
explanation: Hypertension is the most common cause of left-sided diastolic heart failure. Left-sided heart failure can be divided into systolic and diastolic failure. Diastolic failure predominantly occurs in patients older than age 65 years. Here, the left ventricle is abnormally stiff and cannot relax during diastole. Causes of diastolic heart failure: Hypertension: most common Diabetes mellitus Obesity Bilateral renal artery stenosis Systolic failure is due to insufficient ejection fraction, i.e., pump failure. It occurs when the contractile function of the left ventricle is deranged.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following does not cause isolated right-sided heart failure?
explanation: Isolated right-sided heart failure is not caused by left-sided heart failure. Isolated right-sided heart failure is not common and usually occurs in patients with disorders affecting the lungs. Therefore, it is often referred to as cor pulmonale. It is caused by disorders of the lung parenchyma and pulmonary vasculature. It is also caused by conditions causing pulmonary vasoconstriction like obstructive sleep apnea and altitude sickness. Pulmonary hypertension is the common feature of these disorders, which leads to hypertrophy and dilation of the right side of the heart. Right-sided heart failure is most commonly caused by left-sided heart failure. This is because an increase in pressure in the pulmonary circulation from left-sided failure burdens the right side of the heart.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A massive pulmonary embolism occurs in a patient with acute cor-pulmonale. What pathological changes do you expect in the heart of this patient?
explanation: In the given scenario, the patient has acute cor pulmonale. This causes right ventricular dilation without hypertrophy. On cross-section, the normal crescent shape of the right ventricle is transformed to a dilated ovoid. In chronic cor pulmonale, the right ventricular wall thickens. The hypertrophied right ventricle may compress the left ventricular chamber. It can also cause regurgitation and fibrous thickening of the tricuspid valve.
subject: Pathology

question_text: The liver specimen obtained after the autopsy of a patient is given below. What could be the likely cause of this finding?
explanation: In the image, the liver specimen shows a nutmeg liver appearance, which occurs in congestive hepatomegaly. This is secondary to passive congestion due to right heart failure. In right heart failure, there is congestion of hepatic and portal vessels, greatest around the central veins. This leads to increased liver size and weight. The pericentral zones become congested and red-brown. The periportal regions are normal coloured and tan. This leads to a nutmeg liver appearance. With longstanding failure, the central areas can become fibrotic, eventually culminating in cardiac cirrhosis. Pathological changes are also seen in the spleen and the gastrointestinal tract. Portal venous hypertension also causes the enlargement of the spleen, with platelet sequestration. This is known as congestive splenomegaly. This can also contribute to chronic congestion and oedema of the bowel.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which hormone reduces the risk of myocardial infarction in women of reproductive age?
explanation: Estrogen reduces the risk of myocardial infarction in women in the reproductive age group. Accelerated coronary artery disease is associated with the postmenopausal decline in estrogen production. However, postmenopausal hormonal replacement therapy (HRT) has not been shown to be beneficial. The most common cause of death in older women is ischemic heart disease. Through middle age, males have a relatively increased risk of myocardial infarction.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 65-year-old man presented to the casualty with severe, sudden-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm. ECG showed ST-segment elevation in precordial leads. The person succumbed after 3 hours. On autopsy, the patient's heart was immersed in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution. What colour would be imparted to the heart?
options: Viable myocardium appears brick red and infarct appears pale
Viable myocardium appears red and infarct appears dark blue
Viable myocardium appears unstained and the infarct appears dark red
explanation: Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution imparts a brick red colour to the viable non-infarcted myocardium. The infarct appears unstained and pale. Myocardial infarcts < 12 hours old are usually not apparent on gross examination. However, if the infarct preceded death by 2 to 3 hours, it is possible to identify the area of necrosis. This is done by immersing the tissue slices in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution. The histochemical stain imparts a brick-red colour to intact, noninfarcted myocardium. Here, lactate dehydrogenase, LDH, activity is preserved. LDH leaks out through the damaged membranes of dead cells, so an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone. The image given below shows an ischemic brain after immersion in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution. The pale unstained region is the infarcted zone.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the approximate time of onset of microvascular injury in ischemic cardiac myocytes?
explanation: Microvascular injury begins >1 hour after the onset of ischemia.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the earliest detectable ultrastructural feature of myocardial infarction?
explanation: Relaxation of myofibrils is the earliest detectable ultrastructural feature of myocardial infarction. Myofibril relaxation, mitochondrial swelling and glycogen loss can be detected by electron microscopy within half an hour of myocardial infarction.
subject: Pathology

question_text: You are conducting the autopsy of a patient who passed away following myocardial infarction. What would be the earliest light microscopic change that can be observed in the heart of this patient?
explanation: The earliest light microscopic change that can be observed in the heart of this patient is the waviness of myocardial fibres. This is seen within ½-4 hours at the border of the infarct. These changes are a result of the forceful contractions of viable fibres. The contractions cause stretching and buckling of immediately adjacent, noncontractile dead fibres. Myocyte vacuolization or myocytolysis may also be seen in the infarct margins. It is due to the accumulation of salt and water in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Such myocytes are viable but poorly contractile. The image below shows microscopic features of myocardial infarction showing wavy myocardial fibres. There are wavy fibres that are elongated and narrow, as compared with normal fibres. The widened spaces between the dead fibres contain edema fluid and scattered neutrophils.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Following myocardial infarction, coagulative necrosis begins at?
explanation: Early coagulative necrosis begins in myocardial infarction by 4–12 hours. However, it is prominent between 1 to 3 days after myocardial infarction.
subject: Pathology

question_text: The heart of a patient who had suffered a myocardial infarction is subjected to a histopathological examination. The microscopic image is given below. What time following infarction would you observe this?
explanation: The given image shows neutrophilic infiltration into the myocardium. Early neutrophil infiltration starts by 12–24 hours following the infarction. It can be visualised by examination with a light microscope. The necrotic myocardium elicits acute inflammation most prominent between 1 and 3 days. During this time, there is a brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils. The image given below shows neutrophilic infiltration into the myocardium following MI.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient was admitted four days back following acute myocardial infarction. What type of cells would you expect to see in the infarcted area in this patient?
explanation: In the given scenario, 4 days after MI, macrophages are seen in the infarcted area. They phagocytose dead myocytes at the border of the infarct earliest by 72 hours. Removal of the necrotic myocytes is most noticeable by 3 to 7 days. The image below shows a macrophagic infiltrate in the infarcted area.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Match the following:
explanation: The correct match is: Well established granulation - 10 - 14 days Complete scarring - > 2 months Myocyte hypereosinophilia - 12 - 24 hours Grey white scar - 2-8 weeks Loss of nuclei and striations - 1 - 3 days
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 67-year-old woman is found dead in her home. On autopsy, hemopericardium secondary to ventricular wall rupture is seen. How long before her death did she probably have a myocardial infarction?
explanation: The given autopsy finding of hemopericardium secondary to ventricular wall rupture occurs most frequently 3-7 days after myocardial infarction (MI). During this time, the lysis of the necrotic myocardium is maximum. Thus most of the infarct has been converted to friable granulation tissue. The risk factors for free-wall rupture are: Age > 60 years Female gender First MI Large, transmural and anterior MI Absence of left ventricular hypertrophy Preexisting hypertension It is less frequent in patients with prior MI because associated fibrotic scarring inhibits myocardial tearing. Complications of MI: Heart failure - This is due to ventricular dysfunction caused by the infarct and ventricular remodeling Usually occurs within a day Cardiogenic shock - This is usually seen in severe multivessel coronary artery disease due to extensive involvement of myocardium Usually occurs within a day Arrhythmias - most common complication, occurring usually 2 days after infarction Most common arrhythmia within one hour of MI - ventricular fibrillation Most common arrhythmia after one hour of MI - supraventricular tachycardia Myocardial rupture - occurs when there is transmural necrosis of a ventricle. It includes the following - Left ventricular free wall rupture (most common) - leads to cardiac tamponade Interventricular septal rupture - leads acute ventricular septal defect (VSD) Papillary muscle rupture - leads to severe mitral regurgitation Mitral regurgitation (MR) - this can occur due to - Transient papillary muscle dysfunction - mid-systolic or late-systolic murmur Rupture of papillary muscle - pansystolic murmur Dressler syndrome (post-MI syndrome) - This is an immune-mediated reaction and presents as pericarditis, pleurisy, and fever It can occur even 48 hrs after MI but usually occurs 1–6 weeks after MI and often subside after a few days Ventricular aneurysm Infarct expansion associated with mural thrombus
subject: Pathology

question_text: What causes tigered myocardium?
explanation: Tigered myocardium appearance occurs as a result of prolonged moderate hypoxia due to fatty change. It is the gross appearance of the heart with bands of yellow myocardium alternating with normal myocardium.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following causes the maximum damage in reperfusion injury?
explanation: In reperfusion injury, the maximum damage is caused by free radicals. Reperfusion is the restoration of blood flow to the ischemic myocardium threatened by infarction. Reperfused infarcts are usually hemorrhagic because the vasculature is injured during ischemia. Once the flow is restored, there is bleeding. On microscopic examination, the irreversibly injured myocytes exhibit contraction bands that are intensely eosinophilic intracellular stripes. These contraction bands are composed of closely packed sarcomeres. Reperfusion injury may be mediated by: Oxidative stress Calcium overload Inflammatory cells recruited after tissue reperfusion
subject: Pathology

question_text: What creatine kinase isoenzymes do the heart muscle contain?
explanation: Heart muscle contains MM and MB isoenzymes of creatine kinase.
