question_text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought with blood in the urine. His mother says he had bloody diarrhea, fever, and vomiting 10 days ago. His BP is 130/•0 mm Hg, and he is jaundiced. Investigations reveal a platelet count of 50,000 cells/cu mm, BUN of 35mg/dl, and creatinine of 3.5mg/dl.
Which of the following cells would you expect to see in the peripheral smear?
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). It is characterized by the presence of schistocytes in peripheral smear. It indicates microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Cholemic nephrosis is associated with which of the following casts?
explanation: Cholemic nephrosis is associated with casts of bile. In patients with acute or chronic liver disease with advanced liver failure, renal function may be impaired. This is called hepatorenal syndrome. This can be associated with highly elevated bilirubin levels with bile cast formation (also known as cholemic nephrosis) in distal nephron segments.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 35-year-old man died in a road traffic accident. On autopsy, the following appearance of the kidney was noted. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
options: Cysts in liver, pancreas, and spleen
explanation: The gross image suggests that the patient had autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). This condition is not associated with hepatic fibrosis. However, patients with autosomal recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) have congenital hepatic fibrosis. ADPKD is associated with mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1, and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2. The multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure. Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia. The common extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD include: Hepatic cysts - most common Seminal vesicle cysts - can result in infertility Arachnoid membrane cysts - usually asymptomatic, may increase the risk of subdural hematoma Pancreatic cysts Splenic cysts Intracranial berry aneurysms Subarachnoid hemorrhages Mitral valve prolapse There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved. However, there is a three-fold increase in the incidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is false about the polycystin gene?
options: Polycystin-1 is most commonly involved in ADPKD
Polycystin-2 is a calcium ion channe
Mutation in polycystin-2 causes more severe form of ADPKD
Polycystin-1 is involved in cell interactions
explanation: The polycystin-2 mutation is less commonly involved and less severe. Polycystin-1 is encoded by the PKD1 gene located on chromosome 16p13.3. It is expressed in tubular epithelial cells, particularly those of the distal nephron. It contains domains that are usually involved in cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions. Mutations in PKD1 account for about 85% of cases of ADPKD (autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease) and it causes a more severe form of the disease. Polycystin-2 is an integral membrane protein that is expressed in all segments of the renal tubules and in many extrarenal tissues. It functions as a Ca2+ cation channel. Overall, it causes a less severe form of ADPKD disease.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common extrarenal site of cysts in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease?
explanation: The most common extrarenal site of cysts in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is the liver. 40% of individuals with autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) have one to several cysts in the liver (polycystic liver disease) that are usually asymptomatic. The cysts are derived from the biliary epithelium. Cysts occur much less frequently in the spleen, pancreas, and lungs. There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In patients with ADPKD, the mutated genes are located on which chromosomes?
explanation: The genes mutated in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) are located on chromosomes 16 and 4. This condition occurs due to mutations of the PKD1 gene (chromosome 16) and PKD2 gene (on chromosome 4). These genes encode for polycystin 1 and 2 proteins respectively.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Mutations in fibrocystin are seen in which condition?
explanation: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene on chromosome 6p21-p23 which encodes fibrocystin. The gene is highly expressed in adult and fetal kidneys and also in the liver and pancreas. Fibrocystin has been localized to the primary cilium of tubular cells. The serious manifestations of ARPKD are usually present at birth, and may cause death by renal failure. The following gross findings are seen: Enlarged kidneys with smooth external appearance Spongelike appearance due to numerous small cysts in the cortex and medulla Dilated elongated channels at right angles to the cortical surface, completely replacing the medulla and cortex On microscopic examination, there is cylindrical or, less commonly, saccular dilation of all collecting tubules with linning of cuboidal cells. In almost all cases, the liver has cysts associated with portal fibrosis and proliferation of the portal bile ducts, termed congenital hepatic fibrosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Hepatic fibrosis is a feature of which of the following conditions?
explanation: Hepatic fibrosis is a feature of childhood (autosomal recessive) polycystic kidney disease.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A routine urine examination of a 46-year-old woman shows thorn-apple crystals. Past history is significant for constipation and longstanding use of laxatives. What is the likely composition of these crystals?
explanation: Ammonium biurate crystals appear as spheres with radial or concentric striations and irregular projections or thorns, referred to as thorn apples. They are seen in laxative abuse.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
In patients with chronic kidney disease, what type of casts are seen?
Broad casts
explanation: Broad casts are seen in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD). They are also known as renal failure casts. Broad casts are defined as those with a diameter 2-6 times that of normal casts. They indicate chronically damaged tubules or collecting ducts. They indicate a poor prognosis. Renal Tumors
subject: Pathology

question_text: An 18-month-old child is brought to OPD with complaints of blood in his urine. Examination reveals a non-tender mass in the left flank that does not cross the midline. Blood pressure is also found to be elevated. Imaging reveals a left renal tumor and surgical resection is planned. The gross appearance of the mass is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing a well-circumscribed tumor with multiple necrotic, hemorrhagic, and cystic changes in the upper pole of the kidney are suggestive of a nephroblastoma or Wilms' tumor. It is the most common primary renal tumor of childhood (2-5 years of age). Around 10% of cases are associated with genetic syndromes and gonadal dysgenesis may be seen. Clinical manifestations of Wilms' tumor include: Large abdominal mass - usually unilateral and does not cross the midline Abdominal pain Hematuria Hypertension Intestinal obstruction (in some cases) Nephrogenic rests are the precursor lesions of Wilms' tumor and suggest an increased risk of developing a contralateral Wilms' tumor.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Wilms tumor?
options: It is inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder
It is associated with MIC-2 gene expression
It is associated with the deletion of chromosome 11p13
The most common presentation is hematuria
explanation: Wilms' tumor is associated with the deletion of chromosome 11p13. It is an autosomal-dominant disorder. The most common clinical presentation is an abdominal mass. Note: MIC-2 gene expression is seen in neuroblastoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In patients with Wilms tumors, which of the following microscopic features are indicative of resistance to chemotherapy?
explanation: In Wilms' tumor, the presence of anaplasia is indicative of resistance to chemotherapy. This correlates with the presence of TP53 mutations and, hence, is associated with a poor prognosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor in Wilms' tumor?
explanation: Anaplastic histology is the most important prognostic factor in Wilms' tumor. It is seen in about 5% of cases and is characterized by the presence of cells with large, hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei, and abnormal mitoses. It is associated with TP53 mutations and resistance to chemotherapy. Anaplasia is uncommon in children < 2 years. Hence, tumors presenting at an young age have a significantly better prognosis than those presenting in older children. Prognostic factors in Wilms' tumor include: Favorable prognosis Adverse prognosis Histologic type Classic triphasic componen t Anaplastic histology Tumor stage Low High Molecular alteration s ---- 11q deletion16q deletionGain of chromosome 1q Age of onset <2 years >2 years
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not associated with Wilms tumor?
explanation: Bilateral polycystic kidneys are not associated with Wilms tumor. Wilms' tumor can be associated with: Aniridia - WAGR syndrome Gonadal dysgenesis - Denys–Drash syndrome Hemihypertrophy and omphalocele - Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 16-year-old girl is being evaluated for a history of recurrent seizures and abdominal discomfort. Examination reveals the following nail findings. Which of the following should she be screened for?
explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing periungual fibromas are strongly suggestive of tuberous sclerosis. This condition is associated with renal angiomyolipomas (present in 25–50% of cases). Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem disorder that has an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16. The clinical features of tuberous sclerosis include: Skin lesions - Hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules Periungual fibromas or Koenen tumors (small fibromas or nodules of skin around fingernails or toenails) Shagreen patch- roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, primarily in the umbosacral region Facial angiofibromas Confetti skin lesions Neurological features - Epilepsy and intellectual disability (due to cortical tubers) Autism spectrum disorder Subependymal giant cell astrocytomas Other tumors - Cardiac rhabdomyoma Renal angiomyolipomas, renal cysts Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis Angiomyolipoma is a benign renal neoplasm (hamartoma) originating from perivascular epithelioid cells (PEComa). It consists of vessels, smooth muscle, and fat in variable proportions. They are highly susceptibility to spontaneous hemorrhage. The histological image of renal angiomyolipoma is given below:

question_text: A 50-year-old diabetic patient is being evaluated for chronic abdominal discomfort. CECT of the abdomen and pelvis shows a heterogeneously enhancing renal mass with a central stellate scar. On resection, the tumor appears mahogany brown. What is the site of origin of this tumor?
explanation: The given clinical history is suggestive of renal oncocytoma. It arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts. It is a benign epithelial neoplasm. Grossly, these tumors appear tan or mahogany brown and relatively homogeneous. They are usually well encapsulated with a central scar in one-third of cases. Microscopically, they are composed of large eosinophilic cells having small, round, benign-appearing nuclei that have large nucleoli. Ultrastructurally, these eosinophilic cells have numerous mitochondria. The gross and histological appearances of renal oncocytoma are shown in the images given below: Oncocytes refer to epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm (due to the accumulation of mitochondria). They can arise in various tissues and are referred to as: Hurthle cells/Ashkenazy cells in the thyroid gland Oxyphilic cells in the parotid gland Apocrine metaplasia in the breast
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most important determinant of malignant potential in the papillary type of renal tumor?
explanation: The most important determinant of malignant potential in the papillary type of renal tumor is the size of the tumor. The papillary type of renal tumors includes: Renal papillary adenoma ( 1.5 cm) Papillary type of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) - > 1.5 cm Small renal papillary growths are fairly common and incidentally found. Ruling out of malignancy is one of the processes carried out during the evaluation of donor transplant kidneys. Papillary renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the second most common type of renal cell carcinoma and it arises from proximal tubules. It can be multifocal or bilateral. It is typically hemorrhagic and cystic, especially when large. It is often a circumscribed tumor composed of papillae formed by delicate fibrovascular cores that often contain foamy macrophages and Psammoma bodies. It has two histological types: Type 1 papillary RCC - single layer of cells on the basement membrane and low-grade nuclear features Type 2 papillary RCC - pseudostratification of cells and usually has high-grade nuclear features
subject: Pathology

question_text: The following image shows a nephrectomy specimen of a patient diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma. What is the likely histopathological finding in this tumor?
options: Small cells with high N/C ratio
explanation: The given image shows a bright yellow variegated mass distorting the renal outline at the lower pole. This is suggestive of the clear cell type of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). question_text: The nephrectomy specimen of a tumor of a 40-year-old man shows the following histological presentation. Which of the following familial cancer syndromes is this condition associated with?
options: Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome
explanation: The given image shows eosinophilic cells with prominent cell membranes and perinuclear halo, which is suggestive of chromophobe cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC). It is associated with Birt–Hogg–Dubé syndrome. Other familial cancer syndromes and the common malignancies associated with them are: Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome - papillary RCC Large cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, large nuclei, and prominent inclusion-like eosinophilic nucleoli. Tuberous sclerosis - clear-cell RCC Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome (VHL) - clear-cell RCC The image given below shows the histology of chromophobe cell RCC.

question_text: Which of the following subtypes of renal cell carcinoma is matched incorrectly with its respective cytogenetic patterns?
options: Hereditary papillary RCC - loss of Y
Sporadic papillary RCC - loss of Y
explanation: Loss of Y chromosome is a feature of sporadic papillary carcinoma, not hereditary papillary RCC. Various types of renal carcinoma and their cytogenetic abnormalities are given below: Papillary renal cell carcinoma - Sporadic type - trisomies 7 and 17, loss of Y chromosome Familial type - trisomy 7 (mapped to MET gene) Clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma (whether familial, sporadic, or associated with VHL syndrome) Loss of sequences on the short arm of chromosome 3, which harbors the VHL gene
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common histological subtype of renal cell carcinoma?
explanation: Clear-cell renal cell carcinoma is the most common histological subtype of renal cell carcinoma, accounting for 70% to 80% of renal cell cancers. It is most likely to arise from the proximal tubular epithelium as solitary lesions. It has a characteristic tendency to invade the renal vein. The histological features are: Rounded or polygonal tumor cells Abundant clear or granular cytoplasm, which contains glycogen and lipids Arranged in a solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular pattern The histological appearance of clear-cell renal cell carcinoma is shown in the image given below: Note: The Furhman nuclear grading system was previously used for histological grading of RCC (except chromophobe RCC). It is now replaced by the WHO/International Society of Urologic Pathology (ISUP) grading system.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following tumors does not have papillary architecture on histopathology?
explanation: Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)-deficient renal cell carcinoma does not show papillary architecture. It is associated with a bubbly appearance of histopathology. It is a malignant epithelial tumor associated with germline mutations in the SDH gene. It is composed of vacuolated, eosinophilic-clear cells arranged in a solid, nested, or tubular pattern. The presence of the vacuoles imparts the characteristic bubbly appearance, as shown below. Renal cell carcinoma subtypes with papillary architecture in histology: Papillary renal cell carcinoma Hereditary leiomyomatosis renal cell carcinoma Xp11 translocation renal cell carcinoma Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following subtypes of renal cell carcinoma shows large cells having a plant-cell-like appearance with a perinuclear halo on histological examination?
explanation: Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma shows large cells having plant-cell-like appearance with a perinuclear halo. They are arranged in solid sheets with a concentration of the largest cells around blood vessels. Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma can differentiated from oncocytoma and clear cell RCC as follows: Oncocytoma does not show perinuclear halo whereas chromophobe RCC shows perinuclear halo CK7 is diffusely positive in chromophobe RCC but it is negative in clear-cell RCC. Chromophobe RCC cannot be histologically graded because of its innate nuclear atypia. The histological image of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma is given below:

question_text: A patient with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome is found to have a renal tumor and malignancy is suspected. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the renal tumor associated with this condition?
options: It constitutes 5% of all renal tumors
Cytogenetic testing of the tumor shows multiple chromosomal losses
It arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting duct
explanation: The renal tumor commonly associated with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome is chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (RCC). It has an excellent prognosis. It constitutes 5% of all renal carcinomas. It arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting duct. Cytogenetic testing of the tumor shows multiple chromosomal losses and extreme hypodiploidy. The histological image of chromophobe RCC is given below:
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following tumors characteristically shows a hobnail pattern on microscopy?
explanation: Collecting duct carcinoma or Bellini duct carcinoma shows a characteristic hobnail pattern and prominent desmoplastic stroma on microscopy. The hobnail pattern refers to the bulbous nuclear projections of epithelial cells that protrude into the lumen as little bumps. It is associated with tubular, tubulopapillary, or tubulocystic pattern. Collecting duct carcinoma arises from the principal cells of the renal collecting ducts of Bellini. The majority of these tumors are associated with poor outcome, due to their highly aggressive clinical course. The histological section showing collecting duct carcinoma with the characteristic hobnail pattern is given below: Note: The hobnail pattern is also seen in clear cell carcinoma of the ovary.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Individuals with the sickle cell trait are at a higher risk of developing which of the following?
explanation: Individuals with the sickle cell trait are at a higher risk of developing medullary renal cell carcinoma. It is a rare, highly aggressive neoplasm and is morphologically similar to collecting duct carcinoma. The hypoxic microenvironment in the renal medulla created by hyperosmolarity, low pH, and stasis enhances red blood sickling and ischemic damage. This leads to chronic regenerative proliferation of medullary epithelium and activation of hypoxia-induced signaling pathways, which in turn promote neoplastic change. The histological section of renal medullary carcinoma showing prominent cytological atypia is shown below:
subject: Pathology

question_text: A pathologist is studying the histopathological slide from a nephrectomy specimen from a patient with renal carcinoma. He observes neoplastic cells with clear cytoplasm and papillary architecture. Which of the following subtypes of renal carcinoma is this likely to be?
explanation: Xp11 translocation carcinoma contains neoplastic cells with clear cytoplasm with a papillary architecture on histopathology. It is also associated with Psammoma bodies. This condition is caused by translocations of the TFE3 gene located on Xp11.2, which results in overexpression of the TFE3 transcription factor. It often occurs in young patients and is associated with a poor prognosis. The histological section of Xp11 translocation carcinoma is given below:
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding renal cell carcinoma?
options: It can invade the renal vein
It may arise from the proximal convoluted tubule
explanation: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is more common among males, with a male to female ratio of 2:1. Renal cell carcinoma may arise from the proximal convoluted tubules (PCT). The classical clinical features of renal cell carcinoma are costovertebral pain, palpable mass, and painless hematuria. It characteristically invades the renal vein and has a high tendency for distant metastasis. Paraneoplastic manifestations of renal cell carcinoma include: Polycythemia Hypercalcemia Hypertension Hepatic dysfunction Feminization or masculinization Cushing syndrome Eosinophilia Leukemoid reactions Amyloidosis
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common site of metastasis of renal cell carcinoma?
explanation: The most common site of metastasis in renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the lung (more than 50%). Common sites of metastasis of renal cell carcinoma in descending order are: Lungs Bones - osteolytic lesions Regional lymph nodes Liver Adrenals Brain
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following types of renal cell carcinoma has the worst prognosis?
explanation: Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma has the worst prognosis of all renal cell carcinoma subtypes. The renal cell carcinoma subtypes with poor prognosis in descending order are Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma Medullary renal cell carcinoma Clear cell renal cell carcinoma Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma has the best prognosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following genes is not mutated in familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes?
explanation: WT gene is mutated in Wilms' tumor, not renal cell carcinoma. The following gene mutations are associated with familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes: C-met proto-oncogene Fumarate hydratase gene BHD gene VHL gene TSC1 gene PTEN gene
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Which of the following pairs correctly describes the immunohistochemical property of renal cell carcinoma in a cancer of unknown origin?
CK7 positive, CK20 positive
explanation: Renal cell carcinoma is CK7 negative and CK20 negative. The most common subtype of renal cell carcinoma is clear-cell renal cell carcinoma, which is CK7 negative. Therefore, in determining the origin of cancer of unknown primary, immunohistochemistry (IHC) expression of renal cell carcinoma will generally be CK7 negative and CK20 negative. Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma and papillary renal cell carcinoma are positive for CK7. Lower Urinary Tract
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 36-year-old woman presented with intermittent suprapubic pain, increased urinary frequency, and dysuria for 2 months. A cystoscopy revealed the presence of Hunner ulcers. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: Hunner ulcers are chronic mucosal ulcers that are characteristic of interstitial cystitis or chronic pelvic pain syndrome. It is a rare idiopathic condition that occurs most frequently in women. It presents with intermittent severe suprapubic pain, urinary frequency, urgency, hematuria, and dysuria. The following cystoscopic findings are seen in the bladder mucosa: Fissures Punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations) The microscopic findings include: Mucosal ulceration covered by fibrin and necrotic materia Increased numbers of mucosal mast cells Submucosal edema In later stages, transmural fibrosis may occur, leading to a contracted bladder. Biopsy must be done to rule out carcinoma in situ, which may clinically mimic interstitial cystitis. The following image shows a Hunner's ulcer in a patient with interstitial cystitis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 31-year-old man presented with a history of recurrent UTIs and hematuria. Urine culture showed growth of E. coli. Flexible cystoscopy revealed yellow-brown soft plaques with a central umbilication. Microscopy of the plaque showed Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario with the presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies is suggestive of malakoplakia. Malakoplakia is a chronic inflammatory reaction resulting from acquired defects in phagocyte function, commonly affecting the urinary bladder. It can also be seen in other organ systems like the gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and central nervous system. It is seen in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by Escherichia coli or occasionally Proteus species. Grossly, it presents as soft, yellow-brown, slightly raised mucosal plaques. Microscopically, the following findings are seen: Large, foamy macrophages containing - Abundant granular cytoplasm due to undigested bacterial products Michaelis-Gutmann bodies - PAS-positive basophilic concretions due to iron and calcium deposits in lysosomes Occasional multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes Note: Xanthogranulomatous cystitis is morphologically and probably pathogenetically similar to malakoplakia, but it lacks Michaelis–Gutmann bodies.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common cause of polypoid cystitis?
explanation: The most common cause of polypoid cystitis is indwelling catheters. Polypoid cystitis is an inflammatory lesion resulting from mucosal irritation. It may also be associated with radiation therapy and malignant tumors. It usually involves the posterior wall of the bladder. Grossly, it may show bulbous or papillary appearance and may be confused with papillary urothelial carcinoma. Microscopically, the papillary projections are broad-based, non-branching, and without atypia. Stroma is edematous with minimal inflammation. Options A and D: Adenovirus infection and the use of anti-cancer drugs like cyclophosphamide cause hemorrhagic cystitis. Option B: Systemic allergic disorders cause eosinophilic cystitis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A pathologist observed a metaplastic lesion in a biopsy sample taken from the bladder mucosa of a patient. Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis?
explanation: Malakoplakia is not a metaplastic lesion of the bladder. It is a type of chronic granulomatous cystitis due to defective phagocytic function that may mimic malignancy. Metaplastic lesions of the bladder include the following: Nests of urothelium (Brunn nests) may grow downward into the lamina propria resulting in the following lesions - Cystitis glandularis - epithelial cells in the center of the nest undergo metaplasia and take on a cuboidal or columnar appearance Cystitis cystica - epithelial cells retract to produce cystic spaces lined by flattened urothelium Squamous metaplasia - in response to injury, urothelium is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium. Nephrogenic adenoma - due to implantation of shed renal tubular cells at sites of injured urothelium, resulting in replacement of urothelium by cuboidal epithelium with a papillary growth pattern
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common tumor of the urinary bladder?
explanation: The most common tumor of the urinary bladder is transitional cell carcinoma or urothelial carcinoma. Other epithelial tumors like squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, and small cell carcinoma may also occur. Sarcomas are distinctly uncommon in the bladder. However, the most common sarcoma in infancy or childhood is embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, and the most common sarcoma in the bladder in adults is leiomyosarcoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 57-year-old man presented with chronic hematuria and dysuria. Microscopic examination of urine showed the following parasitic eggs. What type of bladder carcinoma is commonly associated with this condition?
explanation: The image shows oval-shaped eggs with the terminal spine which is characteristic of Schistosoma haematobium. It is most commonly associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. The ova are deposited in the bladder wall and incite a brisk chronic inflammatory response. This induces progressive mucosal squamous metaplasia and dysplasia and, in some instances, neoplasia. Schistosomal infection can less frequently result in adenocarcinoma or transitional cell carcinoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a carcinogen for bladder cancer?
explanation: Isopropyl alcohol is not implicated in the causation of bladder cancer. Benzidine, arylamines, and phenacetin are well-established risk factors for bladder cancer.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following genetic changes is not associated with bladder carcinoma?
explanation: Activating mutation in HRAS (not NRAS) is responsible for bladder carcinoma. Genetic changes associated with carcinoma bladder: Noninvasive low-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma is associated with: Gain-of-function mutations of FGFR3 and HRAS genes Chromosome 9p and 9q deletions High-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma (either papillary or flat) is associated with: Loss-of-function mutations of TP53 and RB genes Note: Erdafitinib (kinase inhibitor) is the first targeted drug therapy approved by the FDA for the treatment of metastatic urothelial carcinoma especially in patients with mutations of FGFR3 or FGFR2.
subject: Pathology

question_text: The most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma is:
explanation: The most consistent and persistent feature of carcinoma bladder is painless hematuria. Bladder tumors produce a wide range of clinical features including: Painless hematuria - classical feature and may be the only clinical manifestation Irritative urinary symptoms (frequency, urgency, dysuria) - diffuse tumors or tumors at the bladder neck Pyelonephritis or hydronephrosis - when the ureteral orifice is involved Obstructive symptoms, palpable suprapubic mass, or lower extremity edema - late presentation with a large tumor mass Weight loss and/or localized bone pain - metastatic disease
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not included in the latest International Society of Urological Pathology grading of urothelial tumors?
options: Urothelial neoplasm of low malignant potentia
explanation: International Society of Urological Pathology (ISUP) grading system classifies papillary urothelial carcinoma into 2 grades - low grade and high grade. The classification of papillary urothelial carcinoma into grades 1, 2, 3 was was part of the earlier WHO classification. Grading of urothelial (transitional cell) tumors: WHO/ISUP grades: Urothelial papilloma Urothelial neoplasm of low malignant potentia Papillary urothelial carcinoma, low grade Papillary urothelial carcinoma, high grade WHO grades (old classification): Urothelial papilloma Urothelial neoplasm of low malignant potentia Papillary urothelial carcinoma, grade 1 Papillary urothelial carcinoma, grade 2 Papillary urothelial carcinoma, grade 3
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 67-year-old chronic smoker with gross painless hematuria was diagnosed with infiltrating urothelial carcinoma. What is the most important prognostic factor for his condition?
Size
explanation: The staging (extent of spread) at the time of initial diagnosis is the most important prognostic factor in infiltrating urothelial carcinoma. The prognosis of bladder carcinoma depends on the histologic grade and the stage at diagnosis. As most infiltrating urothelial carcinomas are high-grade, staging becomes the major factor to determine the prognosis. Female Genital Tract
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old woman presented with purulent vaginal discharge associated with fever, malaise, and inguinal pain. A Pap smear revealed the following findings. What is the causative agent?
explanation: The given image of Pap smear shows cells with ground glass nuclei, viral inclusions, multinucleation, and margination of chromatin. These findings are characteristic of herpes simplex infection. Some infections of the female genital tract and their diagnostic features are given below: Infections Diagnostic features Herpes simplex Ground glass nuclei with3M's: MultinucleationMargination of chromatinMolding of nucl ei Molluscum contagio sum Pearly dome-shaped papule c ontaining cells withcytoplas mic viral inclusions Trichomonas vagina lis Strawberry cervix; pear-shap ed flagellated organism. Gardnerella vaginali s Clue cells -squamous cells co vered with a shaggy coating c occobacilli Candida Pseudospores and filamentou s fungal hyphae
subject: Pathology

question_text: What are the cystic remnants of mesonephric ducts in the cervix and vagina called?
explanation: Cystic remnants of mesonephric ducts in the cervix and vagina are termed Gartner duct cysts. The mesonephric (Wolffian) ducts normally regress in females. Its remnants may persist into adult life as epithelial inclusions adjacent to the ovaries, tubes, and uterus. In the cervix and vagina, these ducts may be cystic and are termed Gartner duct cysts. The following images show the embryological development of the mesonephric duct and its persistence into adult life.
subject: Pathology

question_text: The following histological image depicts a pathology in which of the following sites?
explanation: The given histopathological image shows benign papillary projections covered with columnar secretory epithelium and underlying myoepithelial cells. These are commonly seen in papillary hidradenoma of the vulva. It presents as a sharply circumscribed nodule, most commonly on the labia majora or interlabial folds. Like the breast, the vulva also contains modified apocrine sweat glands. Its histologic appearance is identical to that of intraductal papilloma of the breast.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 3-year-old girl presents with a mass protruding from the anterior vaginal wall that appears like grape clusters. Histopathological examination reveals tadpole cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis is embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (sarcoma botryoides). It is an uncommon vaginal tumor composed of malignant embryonal rhabdomyoblasts. It is most frequently found in infants and in children < 5 years of age. They are locally invasive tumors that cause death by penetration into the peritoneal cavity or by obstruction of the urinary tract. Grossly, polypoid, rounded, bulky masses that appear like grape clusters can be seen. On microscopy, small tumor cells with oval nuclei, and small protrusions of cytoplasm from one end resembling a tennis racket (tadpole cells) can be seen. Beneath the vaginal epithelium, the tumor cells are crowded in a cambium layer, in the dermis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding precursor squamous epithelial lesions of the cervix?
options: LSIL progress directly to invasive carcinoma
LSILs are 10 times more common than HSILs
HPV-16 is the most common HPV type in both LSIL and HSIL
They progress to invasive carcinoma over many years
explanation: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL) does not progress directly to invasive carcinoma. They initially progress to a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL), then invasive carcinoma. The WHO currently recommends a 2-tier system of classification for cervical lesions - low and high-grade intraepithelial lesions (LSIL and HSIL). HPV-16 is the most common HPV type associated with both LSIL and HSIL LSILs are 10 times more common than HSILs. Most of these lesions regress spontaneously. Progression to invasive carcinoma is unpredictable and can take place over years.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common type of human papilloma virus causing cervical carcinoma?
explanation: Human papillomavirus (HPV)-16 is the most common type of HPV causing cervical carcinoma. It accounts for almost 60% of cervical cancer cases. The ability of HPV to act as a carcinogen depends on the viral proteins E6 and E7. These proteins interfere with the activity of tumor-suppressor proteins that regulate cell growth and survival. E6 - binds with p53 gene and promote its degradation E7 - binds with RB gene and promotes its degradation
subject: Pathology

question_text: A young woman comes to the gynecology OPD for cervical cancer screening. What is the staining technique used for this?
explanation: Cervical cancer screening test, commonly known as Pap smear, is stained using the Papanicolaou method. The time for initiating Pap smear screening is 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse. The sample is collected using Ayre's spatula and endocervical brush. 2 samples are taken: 1st slide - prepared from a sample taken from portio vaginalis of the cervix 2nd slide - prepared from the sample taken from the endocervix (transformation zone) 95% ethanol is used as a fixative. It is a highly specific test. Colposcopic examination and biopsy are recommended in case of abnormal Pap smear results.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about type I endometrial carcinoma?
options: It is associated with obesity and diabetes
Smoking is a high risk factor
It is caused by unopposed estrogen stimulation
explanation: Smoking is strongly associated with mucinous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary, but not endometrial carcinoma. Endometrial carcinoma is the most common invasive cancer of the female genital tract. Type 1 endometrial carcinoma shows endometrioid morphology and is associated with: Unopposed estrogen exposure (endometrial hyperplasia) Obesity Diabetes mellitus Hypertension PTEN tumor-suppressor gene is mutated in approximately 20% of endometrial hyperplasias. Genomic sequencing of endometrial carcinoma has revealed 4 major molecular subtypes of endometrioid and serous carcinomas: Ultramutated/ POLE tumors - mutations in DNA polymerase  (POLE) Hypermutated/ MSI (microsatellite instability) tumors - mutations involving mismatch repair genes Copy number low/ MSS (microsatellite stable) tumors - mutations involving the PI3K/AKT pathway Copy number high/ serous-like tumors - TP53 mutations and numerous genomic copy number variants
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a criterion to distinguish leiomyosarcoma from leiomyoma?
explanation: The size of the tumor is not a criterion to distinguish between leiomyosarcoma and leiomyoma. The following features are seen in leiomyosarcomas: Mitotic index - 10 mitoses / 10 hpf Nuclear atypia - in the presence of nuclear atypia, 5 mitoses / 10 hpf Tumor cell necrosis - Characterized by an abrupt transition from viable to non-viable areas Within the necrotic zones, atypical cells can be seen
subject: Pathology

question_text: Histopathological examination of an ovarian mass sent to the pathology department revealed the following. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: It is more common in women with low parity
The pathogenesis is related to family history and heritable mutations
High-grade tumors are associated with TP53 mutations
explanation: The given image denotes Psammoma bodies which are a histopathological finding seen in ovarian papillary serous cystadenoma and cystadenocarcinoma. These tumors are most commonly bilateral. The majority of serous tumors of the ovary are benign or borderline. But the serous carcinomas of the ovary include the most common malignant tumors of the ovary. Nulliparity, family history, and heritable mutations play a role in the development of these tumors. Mutations in the oncogenes KRAS, BRAF, or ERBB2 result in low-grade tumors, and mutation in TP53 is associated with high-grade tumors. There is a higher frequency of carcinoma in women with low parity. Women on oral contraceptive pills or those who have undergone tubal ligation are at a lower risk. The marker for ovarian tumors is CA-125.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding mucinous tumors of the ovary?
options: It occurs principally in middle adult life
Mutation of the KRAS proto-oncogene is seen
explanation: The vast majority of mucinous tumors of the ovary are benign or borderline tumors (not malignant). It occurs principally in middle adult life and is rare before puberty and after menopause. The surface of the ovary is rarely involved, they are rarely bilateral. It is associated with the mutation of KRAS proto-oncogene. Grossly it is multiloculated and filled with sticky, gelatinous fluid (rich in glycoproteins).
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old woman underwent an evaluation for an abdominal mass. A laparotomy was decided upon for the removal of the mass. The gross appearance of the mass is as follows. Histopathological examination revealed no malignant change. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario and image showing unilocular cystic space containing hair and sebaceous material are suggestive of mature teratoma. Dermoid cysts or mature teratomas are benign tumors, usually found in young women during the active reproductive years. It is bilateral in 10% to 15% of cases. Microscopically, the cyst wall is composed of tissues from all 3 germ layers. This includes stratified squamous epithelium, with underlying sebaceous glands, hair shafts, and other skin adnexal structures. Sometimes cartilage, bone, thyroid, and neural tissue can be seen. About 1% of the dermoids undergo malignant transformation, most commonly to squamous cell carcinoma. It can also transform into other cancers (e.g., thyroid carcinoma, melanoma). The component tissue of immature malignant teratomas resembles embryonal and immature fetal tissue. It often consists of primitive neuroepithelial cells. The tumor is found chiefly in prepubertal adolescents and young women, the mean age being 18 years. Monodermal or specialized teratomas: Struma ovarii - composed entirely of mature thyroid tissue, which may be functional and cause hyperthyroidism. Ovarian carcinoid - arises from intestinal tissue, may be functional causing carcinoid syndrome in the absence of hepatic metastasis
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the gynecology OPD with a history of abdominal pain and distension of abdomen. Ultrasound imaging revealed tumor in the right ovary. Serum level of inhibin was raised. The histopathology of the tumor is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and histopathology showing Call-Exner bodies are suggestive of granulosa cell tumor. Call-Exner bodies are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material resembling immature follicles. Additionally, small, cuboidal to polygonal cells are seen which may grow in anastomosing cords, sheets, or strands. Granulosa cell tumors are composed of cells that resemble granulosa cells of a developing ovarian follicle. It can be of adult and juvenile types. Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product of granulosa cells, are associated with this tumor. Mutations of the FOXL2 gene are seen in most adult granulosa cell tumors.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 12-year-old girl, who is yet to attain her menarche, presents with an ovarian mass. Her serum biomarkers are normal except for elevated AFP. Staging laparotomy was performed and the histopathological image is given below. What is your diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical features and the histopathological image showing Schiller Duval bodies are suggestive of endodermal sinus tumors. It is also known as yolk sac tumor. The Schiller-Duval body is a glomerulus-like structure composed of a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells. It is the second most common malignant tumor of germ cell origin. It is a unilateral tumor usually affecting children or young women.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following are sex cord-stromal tumors?
explanation: Sex cord-stromal tumors include the following: Granulosa cell tumor Sertoli cell tumor Fibroma Brenner tumor is an epithelial tumor and dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 40-year-old woman presented with bilateral adnexal masses. Histopathological examination of the resected specimen showed sheets of mucin-producing signet-ring cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and histopathology findings are suggestive of metastatic carcinoma of the ovary or Krukenberg tumor. It can arise from primary carcinomas of the stomach (most common), colon, appendix, and breast (invasive lobular carcinoma). It is often bilateral and on microscopy shows mucin-laden signet-ring cells with eccentric hyperchromatic nuclei. Metastatic tumors of the ovary include: Tumors of Müllerian origin (most common) - the uterus, fallopian tube, contralateral ovary, or pelvic peritoneum Tumors of extra-Müllerian tumors - breast and gastrointestinal tract carcinomas Pseudomyxoma peritonei - derived from appendiceal tumors Krukenberg tumor
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 32-year-old woman was diagnosed with molar pregnancy and underwent suction and evacuation. The resected specimen is shown below. Histopathological examination revealed thin-walled, cystic structures consisting of hydropic villi with extensive trophoblastic proliferation along its entire circumference. Immunohistochemistry was negative for p57.
Which of the following is false about this condition?
options: The genetic material is completely maternally derived
Embryo dies very early in development and therefore is usually not identified
It is associated with a 2.5% risk of subsequent choriocarcinoma
explanation: The given clinical scenario and image showing grapelike vesicles are suggestive of a complete mole. It results from the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes, and as a result, the genetic material is completely paternally derived. The pathogenesis of complete mole is as follows: Androgenesis (most common) - 46XX karyotype stemming from the duplication of the genetic material of 1 sperm Dispermy - 46XX or 46XY karyotype due to fertilization of an empty egg by 2 sperms Microscopically, thin-walled, cystic, grapelike structures consisting of hydropic villi are seen. Trophoblastic proliferation involving the entire circumference of the villi is seen. The embryo dies very early in development and, therefore, is usually not identified. Patients have a 2.5% risk of subsequent choriocarcinoma and a 15% risk of the persistent or invasive mole. The following image shows the pathogenesis of molar pregnancy.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 26-year-old woman with a positive pregnancy test presented with vaginal bleeding in the first trimester. On examination, grape-like vesicles were noted in the vagina. A transvaginal ultrasound revealed the presence of fetal tissues. A suction evacuation was performed. What is the most likely karyotype of the evacuated material?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with grape-like vesicles in the vagina and the presence of fetal tissues on transvaginal ultrasound are suggestive of partial mole. The karyotype in a partial mole is triploid (e.g., 69XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92XXXY). It results from the fertilization of an egg with 2 sperms. There is an increased risk of persistent molar disease but it is not associated with choriocarcinoma. Given below is an image showing the karyotype of molar pregnancy.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common site of metastasis in gestational choriocarcinoma?
explanation: Lungs are the most common site of metastasis in gestational choriocarcinoma. It is followed by the vagina, brain, liver, bone, and kidney in descending order of frequency. Gestational choriocarcinomas are malignant neoplasm of trophoblastic cells derived from a previously normal or abnormal pregnancy, such as an extrauterine ectopic pregnancy. The hCG levels are elevated to levels above those encountered in hydatidiform moles. It shows hematogenous spread. It is rapidly invasive and metastasizes widely. Gestational choriocarcinomas are chemosensitive whereas non-gestational choriocarcinomas are chemoresistant.
subject: Pathology

question_text: The genetic profile of malignant mixed Müllerian tumors resembles that of:
explanation: Malignant mixed Müllerian tumors (MMMTs) are carcinosarcomas whose genetic profile closely resembles endometrial carcinomas. They involve mutations in the same genes - PTEN, TP53, and PIK3CA. The usual genetic alterations found in sarcomas are absent in MMMTs. MMMTs are endometrial adenocarcinomas with malignant mesenchymal components. The mesenchymal component may resemble uterine mesenchymal elements (stromal sarcoma, leiomyosarcoma) or contain heterologous malignant cell types (striated muscle, cartilage, adipose tissue, and bone). It occurs in postmenopausal women and presents with bleeding. It is associated with a poor outcome.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following are the components of Meig's syndrome?
explanation: Meigs' syndrome triad includes the following: Solid benign ovarian tumor (fibroma) Right-sided hydrothorax Ascites - disappears after the removal of the tumor Pseudo-Meigs' syndrome is characterized by the following: Non-malignant ascites Pleural effusion Pelvic tumors - other than solid benign ovarian tumors Note: Ovarian fibroma is also associated with nevoid basal cell carcinoma. This association is known as Gorlin syndrome.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 35-year-old woman was operated for an ovarian mass and the sample was sent for histopathological examination. The findings are given below. Which of the following is false about the given condition?

It is a malignant tumor
options: It expresses OCT-3, OCT4, and NANOG
It occurs in patients with gonadal dysgenesis
explanation: The given histopathological image shows large cells with clear cytoplasm (fried egg appearance), tumor cells arranged in sheets, and cords of fibrous stroma infiltrated by lymphocytes. These findings are suggestive of dysgerminoma. It is highly responsive to radiotherapy. Dysgerminomas are the ovarian counterparts of testicular seminoma. They may occur in childhood, but most commonly occur in the 2-3rd decades. It may occur in patients with gonadal dysgenesis, including pseudohermaphroditism. The majority of these tumors are unilateral. They express OCT-3, OCT4, and NANOG. All dysgerminomas are malignant, but the degree of histologic atypia is variable. Only about one-third of these lesions are aggressive. These neoplasms are responsive to chemoradiation, and overall survival exceeds 80%. Male Genital Tract
subject: Pathology

question_text: A young sexually active man presented with multiple polypoid growths over his penis. Histopathological image of an excised lesion is as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given histopathological image showing papillary (villous) architecture with acanthosis, hyperkeratosis and koilocytosis of squamous epithelium, are characteristic findings of condyloma acuminatum. Koilocytes have a prominent cell membrane, hyperchromatic resinoid nucleus, and perinuclear halo. Grossly, they consist of single or multiple sessile or pedunculated, red papillary excrescences on the coronal sulcus, and the inner surface of the prepuce. Option A: Condyloma lata is a maculopapular/nodular lesion seen in secondary syphilis. Option B: Bowen's disease is carcinoma in situ of the penis characterized by the hyperproliferative epidermis and dysplastic epithelium. Option D: Verrucous carcinoma / very well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, shows hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and keratin pearls.
subject: Pathology

question_text: All of the following are true regarding Bowen's disease except:
options: Marked dysplasia and hyperproliferative epidermis are seen
Virtually never develops into an invasive carcinoma
explanation: Bowen's disease starts as a premalignant lesion and transforms into infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma in approximately 10% of patients, usually over a span of many years. Bowen's disease occurs in the genital region of both men and women, usually in those older than age 35 years. These lesions have a strong association with infection by high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV), most commonly type 16. Grossly, it appears as a solitary, thickened, gray-white, and opaque plaque. The below histological image of Bowen's disease shows dysplastic cells with large hyperchromatic nuclei, koilocytic atypia and an intact basement membrane. Premalignant lesions of invasive penile SCC: Erythroplasia of Queyrat Condyloma acuminatum Bowen's disease Bowenoid papulosis occurs in young, sexually active adults. It presents as multiple reddish-brown papular lesions and it is histologically indistinguishable from Bowen's disease, but virtually never develops into invasive carcinoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: The biopsy of a resected inguinal mass from a patient shows marked fibrotic changes with prominent Leydig cells and hypoplastic Sertoli cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given histopathological features are strongly suggestive of cryptorchidism. Cryptorchidism is histopathologically characterized by the following: Testicular atrophy: thickening of the basement membrane, arrested germ cell development, marked hyalinization Tubules showing Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis Increase in the interstitial Leydig cells. Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac. It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The testes can arrest anywhere during descent, and the most common site is the inguinal region. Phases of testicular descent: Transabdominal phase: Testes come to lie in the lower abdomen or pelvis. This phase of descent is regulated by Mullerian-inhibiting substances. Inguinoscrotal phase: Testes descend along the inguinal canal and reach the scrotal sac. This phase of the descent is regulated by androgen-induced calcitonin gene-related peptide from the genitofemoral nerve. The exact pathogenesis remains unknown, however, deficiency in gonadotropins and Mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) and increased expression of estradiol in the placenta are thought to play a role. It is associated with testicular atrophy and dysfunction, which result in sterility. Cryptorchid testes carry a 3–5-fold higher risk for testicular cancer (usually seminoma).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Testicular atrophy is not seen in which of the following conditions?
explanation: Torsion testis does not cause testicular atrophy. It may cause intense congestion to widespread hemorrhage to testicular infarction. Causes of testicular atrophy: Progressive atherosclerotic narrowing of the blood supply in old age End-stage of an inflammatory orchitis Cryptorchidism - associated with progressive tubular atrophy and sterility Hypopituitarism Generalized malnutrition or cachexia Irradiation Prolonged administration of antiandrogens (treatment for advanced carcinoma of the prostate) Liver cirrhosis - may cause testicular atrophy as a result of increased levels of circulating endogenous estrogens not metabolized by the diseased liver Exhaustion atrophy, which may follow persistent stimulation by high levels of the follicle-stimulating pituitary hormone Occasionally occurs as a primary failure of genetic origins, such as in Klinefelter (XXY) syndrome The histological image below of testicular atrophy shows small tubules with few or no germ cells, thickening of the basement membrane of the spermatic tubules, and prominent Leydig cells. The near-normal seminiferous tubules are seen side-by-side with atrophic seminiferous tubules.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old man undergoes testicular biopsy as part of infertility work-up. Sperm count shows oligospermia. Microscopy shows only Sertoli cells in the seminiferous tubules. What is the most likely finding seen in the condition?
explanation: The above clinical scenario depicts that the patient is having Sertoli cell-only syndrome, and patients with this syndrome will have increased levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). The below image shows normal histology of testis: In normal males, as spermatogenesis and testosterone production increase, the Sertoli cells produce inhibin, which inhibits the release of FSH. The Sertoli cells are supporting cells that are under the action of FSH. Leydig cells, which are present in the interstitial spaces, are under the action of luteinizing hormone(LH) and produce testosterone. Testosterone has a feedback inhibition on LH. In Sertoli cell-only syndrome, within the seminiferous tubules, only Sertoli cells are seen and no germ cells. Hence, there are no spermatozoa and there is no feedback inhibition, which results in increased FSH levels. So, testosterone levels, and LH levels remain unaffected since Leydig cells are not affected. Hence, the patient will have male secondary sexual characters. The most important indication of testicular biopsy is infertility workup.
subject: Pathology

question_text: An 18-year-old boy presents with acute onset of testicular pain. On examination, the left testis is enlarged, tender and positioned higher than the right at an unusual angle. Pain is not relieved on elevation of the scrotum. What histopathological changes can be seen in this condition?
options: Marked fibrosis with prominent Leydig cells and hypoplastic Sertoli cells
Dysplastic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, koilocytic atypia
Intense congestion, hemorrhage, and areas of infarction
explanation: The most likely diagnosis is testicular torsion. The pathological changes range from intense congestion to widespread hemorrhage to testicular infarction. In advanced stages, the testis is markedly enlarged and consists entirely of soft, necrotic, hemorrhagic tissue. Adult torsion is typically seen in adolescence and presents with the sudden onset of testicular pain. Neonatal torsion can occur either in utero or shortly after birth and the cause is unknown. It results from a bilateral anatomic defect that leads to increased mobility of the testes (bell- clapper□ abnormality). Twisting of the spermatic cord typically cuts off the venous drainage of the testis. But, thick-walled arteries remain patent, producing intense vascular engorgement, followed by hemorrhagic infarction. If the testis is manually untwisted within approximately 6 hours of the onset of torsion, there is a good chance that the testis will remain viable.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following infections primarily affects the testis?
explanation: Syphilis and mumps affect the testis primarily and later spread to surrounding structures. Syphilis can affect both the testis and epididymis, but invariably, the testis is involved first as gummas and diffuse interstitial inflammation. Mumps most commonly affects school-aged children, but testicular involvement is uncommon in this age. Mumps infection in postpubertal males can lead to acute interstitial orchitis in 20 to 30% of cases. Gonorrhea and tuberculosis affect the epididymis first, which can later spread to the testis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following testicular tumors is derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ?
explanation: Germ-cell neoplasia in situ (GCNIS) is a common precursor lesion of seminoma. Most testicular germ-cell tumors originate from a precursor lesion called GCNIS. It is believed to arise in utero and stay dormant until puberty, after which it may progress to seminoma or non-seminomatous tumors. The exceptions to this rule are: Prepubertal yolk-sac tumors Teratomas Adult spermatocyte tumors The lesion consists of atypical primordial germ cells, which have large nuclei and a clear cytoplasm and fail to develop into spermatogonia. This is because these cells retain the expression of the transcription factors OCT3/4 and NANOG, which maintain the pluripotency of germ cells and prevent their maturation.
subject: Pathology

question_text: All of the following are true about tumors of the testis except:
options: Pure choriocarcinoma has an excellent prognosis
Seminomas only rarely occur in infants
Non-seminomatous germ-cell tumour metastasize using hematogenous route
explanation: Pure choriocarcinoma is a rare, but aggressive, tumor and has a poor prognosis. It generally does not cause any testicular enlargement. It spreads rapidly via the bloodstream. This results in the frequent involvement of the lung and liver. However, pure germ-cell tumors (GCTs) are rare and about 60% of testicular GCTs are mixed tumors. Teratomas in children usually follow a benign course. But, in the postpubertal male, all teratomas are regarded as malignant because they are capable of metastatic behavior.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common testicular tumor in infants?
explanation: Yolk sac tumor is the most common testicular tumor in infants and children up to 3 years of age. Prepubertal teratoma is the second most common testicular tumor in infants and children. In adults, pure yolk sac tumor is rare. The yolk sac elements frequently occur in combination with embryonal carcinoma (as a mixed tumor).
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old man presented with a painless testicular mass. Inguinal orchidectomy was done and the gross and histological image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The gross specimen showing a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface that bulges around the surrounding parenchyma is characteristic of a seminomatous germ-cell tumor or seminoma. The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance), delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate. Seminoma is the most common type of GCT. The peak incidence is the 3rd decade and almost never occurs in infants. It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, (regardless of KIT mutational status), OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP). Option B: Yolk sac tumor is non-encapsulated with mucinous appearance. Schiller–Duval bodies are characteristic. It is seen in children less than 3 years. Option C: Teratoma shows derivatives of more than one germ layer like cartilage, hair, sebaceous glands. Option D: Testicular lymphoma is a rare extranodal presentation of non-Hodgkin lymphoma Testicular biopsy is contraindicated in case of a suspicious testicular mass because it is associated with a risk of tumor cell spillage. High inguinal orchidectomy followed by histopathological evaluation is the preferred standard management. Fixative used for testicular biopsy is Bouin's fluid.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old man presented with a testicular mass. Microscopic examination of the orchidectomy specimen was done. It showed highly anaplastic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli growing in alveolar and tubular patterns. They stained positive for PLAP, cytokeratin, and CD30 and negative for KIT. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The above clinical scenario of the germ-cell tumor is suggestive of embryonal carcinoma. It is a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCTs) that occurs mostly in the 20 to 30 year age group. These tumors are more aggressive than seminomas. Embryonal carcinomas share some markers with seminomas such as OCT 3/4 and PLAP but differ by being positive for cytokeratin and CD30 and negative for KIT. Most patients present with a testicular mass, which can be painful due to rapid growth and may be mistaken for torsion. Grossly, the tumor is often variegated, poorly demarcated at the margins, and punctuated by foci of hemorrhage or necrosis. Histologically, the cells grow in alveolar or tubular patterns, sometimes with papillary convolutions; the neoplastic cells have an epithelial appearance, are large and anaplastic, and exhibit hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli. The below image is the histology of embryonal carcinoma showing anaplastic cells with large hyperchromatic nuclei. Option A: Seminoma will have sheets of uniform cells with poor, demarcated lobules divided by delicate fibrous septa infiltrated by lymphocytes. Seminomas are positive PLAP and KIT, but negative for cytokeratin and CD30. Option C: Teratoma will show derivatives of more than one germ layer like cartilage, hairs, sebaceous glands in the histology. Option D: Yolk sac tumor affects children up to 3 yrs of age, will have elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), and exhibit Schiller–Duval bodies on histology.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A young man presented with a testicular mass and increased AFP levels. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: Marked elevation of serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels is produced by the yolk sac tumor / endodermal sinus tumor. It is the most common testicular tumor in infants and children up to 3 years of age (prepubertal yolk sac tumor). Postpubertal yolk sac tumors are associated with germ-cell neoplasia in situ and almost always occur in mixed forms. Grossly, pure yolk sac tumors have a homogenous, mucinous appearance. The below image is of a yolk sac tumor showing lace-like architecture and Schiller–Duval bodies (Arrow) (a hallmark of YST), and hyaline-like globules. These structures consist of a mesodermal core with central capillary as well as a visceral and parietal layer of cells (glomeruloid pattern)
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is true about teratomas?
options: In post-pubertal males, all teratomas are considered benign.
All teratomas are benign even if they show immature elements.
All teratomas are considered malignant in post-pubertal males.
Orchidectomy is curative for testicular teratomas.
explanation: In post-pubertal males, teratomas are considered malignant, regardless of the presence of immature elements. Teratomas are non-seminomatous germ cell tumors (NSGCTs), which are characteristically composed of more than one germ layer derivative (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm). Teratomas have complex histopathology and 2 variants may be seen: Mature: Adult-type, well-differentiated cells or organoid structures Immature: Embryonal-type, undifferentiated cells or primitive neural elements In ovarian teratomas, immature elememts are needed to consider it malignant. However, the degree of immaturity is clinically insignificant in testicular teratomas. In prepubertal children, testicular teratomas have a benign course. However, in postpubertal males, teratomas are considered malignant. The below image shows the histology of teratoma of the testis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 35-year-old man presents with hemoptysis and loss of weight. Chest radiograph shows multiple canon-ball metastases. Physical examination revealed no palpable mass. The serum HCG level is raised, but no change in AFP and CEA levels. Biopsy from the lung lesion reveals the following finding. What is the most likely primary tumor?
explanation: From the given clinical scenario and image showing cytotrophoblasts and multinucleated syncytiotrophoblasts in a hemorrhagic background, the most likely primary tumor appears to be choriocarcinoma. The syncytiotrophoblasts secrete  -hCG, at levels that serve as important serological markers. Pure choriocarcinoma, although rare, is the most aggressive non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT). It often does not cause any testicular enlargement; instead, it spreads rapidly via the bloodstream. This results in the frequent involvement of the lung(cannon-ball metastases) and liver and a poor prognosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: All of the following are true for spermatocytic tumors except:
options: It affects individuals generally younger than 35 years.
It does not have any extra-testicular sites of origin.
It is a slow-growing tumor that does not produce metastases.
explanation: With a spermatocytic tumor, affected individuals are generally older than 65 years. A spermatocyte tumor (previously called spermatocytic seminoma) is a rare, slow-growing germ cell tumor that is distinct from classical seminoma, both clinically and histologically. GCNIS: Germ-cell neoplasia in situ PLAP: Placental alkaline phosphatase The below image is the histology of spermatocytic tumor showing a population of small, medium-sized, and large cells and mucoid lakes Characteristics Seminoma Spermatocytic tumor Age 20–40 yrs >65 yrs Association with GCNIS, othe r GCT, cryptorchidism Present Absent Histology Uniform looking cellsLymph ocytes and granuloma Presen t Small, medium and large cell sLymphocytes and granulom a Absent Intracytoplasmic glycogen Present Absent PLAP reactivity Present Absent Extra testicular origin, metas tasis Present Absent
