question_text: A 40-year-old man presents with gynecomastia. Ultrasonography reveals a 1 cm solid mass within the body of the testis. His serum testosterone is 600 ng/dL and estradiol is 35 pg/mL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of Leydig cell tumor of the testis. It is the most common sex-cord stromal type of testicular neoplasm. It is mostly benign and invariably unilateral. Most cases occur between 20 and 60 years of age. However, they can present at any age. The most common presenting feature is testicular swelling or gynecomastia (~15% of cases). In children, hormonal effects manifested primarily as sexual precocity, are the dominant features. Tumors of Leydig cells may secrete androgens and estrogens, and even corticosteroids. Grossly it shows golden brown, homogeneous circumscribed nodules <5 cm in diameter. Histologically: large, round, or polygonal cells round central nucleus and prominent nucleoli abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm containing lipid droplets, vacuoles, or lipofuscin pigment crystalloids of Reinke, rod-shaped eosinophilic cytoplasmic bodies are seen in about 25% of the tumors Option A: Spermatocytic tumor mainly occurs in older adults as a slow-growing testicular mass. They are usually hormonally silent Option B: Sertoli cell tumor mostly presents as a painless testicular mass. They are usually hormonally silent. Hence, gynecomastia and precocious puberty are very rare. Option C: Granulosa cell tumor usually presents as a slow-growing and non-functioning testicular mass. Gynecomastia is rare. They usualy secrete estrogen.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common testicular neoplasms in men older than 60 years?
explanation: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is the most common testicular neoplasm in men older than 60 years. The most common types of testicular lymphomas in decreasing order of frequecy: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma Burkitt lymphoma Epstein–Barr virus - positive extranodal NK/T cell lymphoma. Testicular lymphomas are aggressive tumors with a poor prognosis. They have a higher propensity for CNS involvement.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In patients with testicular tumors, what lymph nodes are primarily involved?
explanation: Retroperitoneal para-aortic nodes are the first to be involved in the lymphatic spread of testicular tumors. Testicular tumors have a characteristic mode of spread: Lymphatic spread is common to all forms of testicular tumors. Initially, it spreads to retroperitoneal para-aortic nodes, then spreads to the mediastinal and supraclavicular nodes. Hematogenous spread is primarily to the lungs, but the liver, brain, and bones may also be involved.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Laboratory testing of a 30-year-old man diagnosed with a testicular mass showed increased levels of alpha-fetoprotein. All of the following can be included in the differential, except:
explanation: Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) level is raised in all the above conditions except pure choriocarcinoma and pure seminoma. Choriocarcinomas have elevated levels of HCG, which can be readily demonstrated in the cytoplasm of syncytiotrophoblastic cells. AFP is a marker of hepatocellular cancer and non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of testes, mainly yolk sac tumors.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which tumor responds best to radiation therapy?
explanation: Seminomas are extremely radiosensitive tumors. The counterpart of seminoma, which arises in the ovary, is dysgerminoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common malignant paratesticular tumor in children?
explanation: The most common malignant paratesticular tumor in children is rhabdomyosarcoma. The paratesticular region is an extratesticular anatomical area, which includes the contents: Spermatic cord, Testicular tunics, Epididymis Vestigial remnants, such as the appendices epididymis and testis. The most common malignant paratesticular tumor in adults is liposarcoma. The most common benign paratesticular tumor is an adenomatoid tumor. The most common paratesticular mesenchymal tumor is a lipoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not used as a tumor marker for germ cell testicular tumors?
explanation: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is not used as a tumor marker for germ-cell testicular tumors. It is an oncofetal antigen used as a tumor marker in adenocarcinoma of the colon, pancreas, lung, breast, and ovary. Markers of germ cell testicular tumors include alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), human chorionic gonadotropin, placental alkaline phosphatase, placental lactogen, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH).
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 61-year-old male patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia is planned for transurethral resection of the prostate. Which of the following is removed during the procedure?
explanation: Benign prostatic hyperplasia originates almost exclusively in the transitional zone, hence it is surgically removed. Nodular hyperplasia or benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is the most common benign prostatic disease in men above 50 years. It arises from the inner aspect of the prostate gland, i.e., the transitional zone. It is characterized by benign, hyperplastic proliferation of prostatic stroma and epithelial elements, which is driven by dihydrotestosterone. This growth progressively compresses the urethra resulting in urinary obstructive symptoms. The normal prostate contains several distinct regions, including a central zone (CZ), peripheral zone (PZ), transitional zone (TZ), and periurethral zone, as shown in the image below. Note: Most carcinomas arise from the peripheral zone and maybe palpable during the digital examination of the rectum.
subject: Pathology

question_text: An elderly man presenting with the features of urinary retention was thoroughly investigated and diagnosed with prostate carcinoma. All of the following statements about the Gleason system used for prognosis/survival of the patient are true except:
options: Grade group 1 represents the most well-differentiated tumors.
Tumors with Gleason scores 8 to 10 tend to be advanced cancers.
Gleason system correlates with pathologic stage and prognosis.
Gleason Score is reported from 1 to 10.
explanation: The Gleason score is currently reported from 6-10. WHO/ISUP modified Gleason score is the histopathological grading system, which corresponds with the clinical behavior of prostate cancer. It is one of the key methods used in confirmation of the diagnosis, prognostication, and staging of prostate cancer (adenocarcinoma). The Gleason grading system is primarily based on analyzing the architecture of the tumor cells in the biopsy specimens obtained. The architecture, i.e., the Gleason Patterns are classified as: Pattern 3: Well-formed glands Pattern 4: Poorly formed/Fused/Cribriform glands/Glomeruloid glands Pattern 5: Sheets of the tumor, individual cells, cords, and solid nests of cells, Comedo necrosis Pattern 1 and 2 are no longer defined Most tumor specimens contain more than one pattern. Therefore, a numeric grade is assigned to both the primary pattern and the next most frequent secondary pattern. The sum of the numeric grades provides the Gleason score. Scores 2–5 are no longer assigned. Scores of 6 - 7 are potentially treatable cancers Scores 8 - 10 are advanced cancers that are less likely to be cured. Based on the gleason score, they are classified into the following grade groups: Grade group 1: score<=6 Grade group 2: 3+4=7 Grade group 3: 4+3=7 Grade group 4: score 8 Grade group 5: scores 9-10
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 68-year-old man presented with hesitancy, incomplete voiding, and pelvic pain. On a digital rectal examination, an irregularly enlarged prostate with a nodular surface was felt.
Transrectal biopsy revealed poorly formed glands arranged in a cribriform pattern. According to the modified Gleason score, how would you classify the pattern seen in this patient?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of prostate cancer and all cribriform patterns are now defined as Gleason pattern 4 according to the 2014 WHO/ISUP grading consensus conference. The below image of prostate cancer with Gleason pattern 4 shows cribriform pattern Highlights of 2014 WHO/ISUP modified Gleason score: Gleason Pattern: Pattern 3- Well formed glands Pattern 4- Poorly formed/Fused/Cribriform glands/Glomeruloid glands Pattern 5- Sheets of the tumor, individual cells, cords and solid nests of cells, Comedo necrosis Pattern 1 and 2 are no longer defined Gleason Score: The current Gleason score ranges from 6–10. Scores 2–5 are no longer assigned. Grade group: Grade group 1: score 6 Grade group 2: 3+4=7 Grade group 3: 4+3=7 Grade group 4: score 8 Grade group 5: scores 9–10
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the normal upper limit of prostate-specific antigen value for a 75-year-old man?
explanation: The upper-age-specific reference value of serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) in men of age 70–79 is 6.5 ng/mL. PSA is a product of prostatic epithelium secreted in the semen. Measurement of serum PSA levels is widely used to assist the diagnosis, prognosis, and management of prostate cancer. Older men have a higher serum PSA level than younger men, so the normal range varies with age. The serum PSA levels as a screening test for prostatic cancer has poor sensitivity and specificity. This is because various other factors such as trauma, infections, BPH, instrumentation/digital exam of the prostate, and ejaculation can increase serum PSA levels. A value of 4 ng/mL usually warrants serial testing or further evaluation. In an effort to improve the sensitivity and specificity of serum PSA levels, many novel indices are used: Age-specific PSA reference ranges PSA velocity: Rate of change of PSA values with time. It is considered that PSA velocity of 0.75 ng/mL per year measured at least 3 times over a period of 1.5 to 2 yrs is significant to diagnose Prostate cancer. PSA density: Serum PSA/volume of the prostate gland The ratio of free to bound serum PSA Age Upper age-specific PSA(ng/m L) 40–49 yrs 2.5 50–59 yrs 3.5 60–69 yrs 4.5 70–79 yrs 6.5
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 68-year-old patient was diagnosed with prostate cancer. Hematogenous spread of this cancer would occur predominantly to which of the following?
Bones
explanation: Hematogenous spread of carcinoma prostrate occurs predominantly to the bones and are typically osteoblastic. The commonly involved bones in decreasing order of frequency: Lumbar spine Proximal femur Pelvis Thoracic spine Ribs Alcoholic and Infectious Liver Disease

question_text: A 50-year-old man who developed myocardial infarction 3 days ago now presents with jaundice. Lab investigations done are given below. Which region of the liver lobule is most likely affected here?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hepatocellular injury due to ischemia. Zone 3 (centrilobular zone) of the liver is most susceptible for ischemia because this zone is the farthest from the blood supply. On the basis of blood flow, liver parenchyma can be divided into three zones. Zone 1 is closest to the blood supply and zone 3 is the farthest. They are: Zone 1 - Periportal (around portal triad) Zone 2 - Midzonal parenchyma Zone 3 - Centrilobular (around hepatic vein) A schematic diagram showing the hepatic lobule indicating the direction of blood flow and the zones of decreasing oxygenation is given below. Note: Zone most susceptible to toxin damage is zone 1.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Patients with which of the following conditions are least likely to develop centrilobular necrosis of liver?
explanation: Centrilobular necrosis is not seen in yellow fever. In yellow fever, swelling and necrosis of hepatocytes are seen in the midzone of the liver lobule. Conditions causing tissue injury in the different zones of liver: Centrilobular (Zone 3) Chronic venous congestion (cardiac failure) Acetaminophen toxicity Budd Chiari syndrome Ischemia Alcoholic hepatitis Midzonal (Zone 2) Yellow fever Periportal (Zone 1) Viral hepatitis A schematic diagram showing the hepatic lobule indicating the direction of blood flow and the zones of decreasing oxygenation is given below.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A chronic alcoholic developed cirrhosis of the liver. Which is the principal cell type involved in scar deposition in this condition?
explanation: The principal cell type involved in scar deposition in cirrhosis of the liver is the hepatic stellate cell or Ito cell. Hepatic stellate cells deposit primarily type I and type III collagen in the lobule and cause fibrosis. In their quiescent form, these cells store lipids and vitamin A.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Histopathological examination of liver biopsy reveals steatosis. Which of the following conditions is least likely to cause this change?
explanation: Steatosis or fatty change of liver is not seen in hepatitis B infections. Steatosis is the abnormal accumulation of triglycerides within a cell due to impaired lipid metabolism. In the liver, pathological steatosis is defined as fatty change involving >5% of hepatocytes. In the histologic sections, they appear as empty vacuoles within the hepatocyte cytoplasm. Hepatitis C genotype 3 is reported to cause periportal steatosis. It is due to its association with metabolic syndrome and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). In Wilson's disease, there is focal hepatocyte necrosis and steatosis due to toxic injury by the excess copper. In protein malnutrition, fatty liver results from the reduced synthesis of the carrier protein component of lipoproteins.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following conditions causes macrovesicular steatosis of liver?
explanation: Macrovesicular fatty liver (steatosis) is seen in obesity. Macrovesicular steatosis is characterized by a single, large vacuole of fat that fills up the hepatocyte and displaces the nucleus to the periphery. Causes include: Late alcoholic liver disease Obesity Protein-energy malnutrition Non-alcohlic steatohepatitis (NASH) Chronic hepatitis C Microvesicular steatosis is characterized by small intracytoplasmic fat vacuoles, which accumulate in the cell. Causes include: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy Reye syndrome Early alcoholic liver disease Drugs and toxins The image given below shows macrovesicular and microvesicular steatosis of liver:
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 4-year-old girl, with a history of URTI, now presents with severe vomiting, lethargy, and altered mental status. You are suspecting Reye's syndrome. Which of the following liver biopsy findings will confirm your diagnosis?
options: Portal tract edema and perisinusoidal fibrosis
Cirrhosis and periportal eosinophilic inclusion bodies
explanation: The liver biopsy in Reye's syndrome will show marked microvesicular steatosis. Reye's syndrome is an acute illness, encountered exclusively in children <15 years. Its onset usually follows upper respiratory tract infections. The actual cause is unknown, although viral agents and salicylates (aspirin) have been implicated. Pathogenesis behind this condition is generalized mitochondrial dysfunction with structural and functional alterations of mitochondria in the liver, brain, and muscle. Liver is enlarged but jaundice is absent or minimum. It is characterized by clinical features such as: Vomiting Signs of progressive CNS damage Signs of hepatic injury Hypoglycemia Extensive accumulation of fat droplets within hepatocytes (microvesicular steatosis) can be seen in histopathology. Extra-hepatic changes include fatty changes of renal tubular cells, cerebral edema, and neuronal degeneration of the brain. The image given below shows microvesicular steatosis of liver. Note: Aspirin is generally contraindicated in children, except in the treatment of Kawasaki disease and juvenile idiopathic arthritis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Histopathological examination of liver biopsy in a patient with jaundice shows the following finding. Which of the following conditions is least likely in this patient?
explanation: The marked structure in the image is Mallory hyaline body which is not seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis. In this condition, onion skin fibrosis is seen. Mallory hyaline bodies (Mallory–Denk bodies) are usually present as clumped, amorphous, eosinophilic material in ballooned hepatocytes. They are made up of cytokeratin 8 and cytokeratin 18. They have a twisted rope-like appearance. On trichrome stain, they appear green/dark brown. They are seen in: Alcoholic liver disease Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease Wilson's disease Hepatocellular carcinoma Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency Primary biliary cholangitis (formerly called primary biliary cirrhosis) Indian childhood cirrhosis The image given below shows Mallory hyaline bodies.

question_text: Which of the following causes Laennec cirrhosis?
explanation: Laennec cirrhosis is the classic micronodular cirrhosis seen in end-stage alcoholic liver disease. question_text: Which of the following histopathological findings will be seen in patients with chronic alcoholism?
explanation: Chicken-wire fence pattern of fibrosis is seen in the liver biopsy of patients with alcoholic steatohepatitis. This pattern is due to perisinusoidal fibrosis encircling small clusters of hepatocytes. Trichrome staining of liver biopsy specimen showing perisinusoidal fibrosis (stained blue) in characteristic chicken-wire fence pattern is given below. explanation: Viral hepatitis is associated with macronodular cirrhosis. question_text: In patients with non-alcoholic steatohepatitis, which of the following features is not seen on liver biopsy?
explanation: The presence of lymphoid follicles is not a feature on liver biopsy in patients with non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). It is a feature of chronic hepatitis C infection. question_text: What is the most common hepatotoxin causing acute liver failure?
explanation: The most common hepatotoxin causing acute liver failure is acetaminophen. Acetaminophen itself is not toxic. The toxic metabolite produced by the cytochrome P-450 system in zone 3 hepatocytes causes hepatocellular necrosis. The most common hepatotoxin causing chronic liver failure is alcohol.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following does not cause chronic infection?
explanation: Hepatitis A does not cause chronic infection. It is usually a benign, self-limited disease. Hepatitis B, C, and D can cause chronic infection. Hepatitis E causes chronic infection only in immunocompromised individuals, not in immunocompetent.
subject: Pathology

question_text: There is an outbreak of hepatitis A infection in a college hostel. Which of the following is false about this infection?
options: It does not cause hepatocellular carcinoma
Liver failure is not a complication
explanation: Hepatitis A virus (HAV) can cause acute hepatic failure in a few patients. However, it does not cause chronic hepatitis or a carrier state. HAV is a usually benign, self-limited disease, with an incubation period of 15- 50 days (2 - 6 weeks). HAV is spread by feco-oral route and is shed in the stool for 2 to 3 weeks before and 1 week after the onset of jaundice. It can also spread by sexual route. Diagnosis is by the detection of serum IgM anti HAV. Since it does not progress to chronic infection, it does not cause hepatocellular carcinoma. The fatality rate associated with HAV is only about 0.1-0.3%.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which among the following is the most common cause of sporadic acute hepatitis in India?
explanation: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection accounts for most of the cases of sporadic acute hepatitis in India. It exceeds the frequency of hepatitis A virus infection. A feature of HEV infection is the high mortality rate among pregnant women, approaching 20%.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 53-year-old man who has a history of chronic hepatitis B is diagnosed to have hepatocellular carcinoma. Which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
explanation: HBx protein has been implicated in the pathogenesis of hepatocellular carcinoma in hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. HBx protein is involved in the intracellular regulation of virus replication, transcription, and signal transduction. Option A: HBsAg (surface antigen) indicates current hepatitis B infection. Option B: HBeAg (precore antigen) is an indicator of active viral replication. It is a qualitative marker of infectivity. Option C: HBV DNA polymerase is an indicator of active viral replication. It is a quantitative marker of infectivity.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following serological markers can be used to diagnose hepatitis B infection during the window period?
explanation: During the window period of hepatitis B, the serologic diagnosis can be made by the detection of IgM anti-HBc antibody. The window period of hepatitis B refers to the time between the disappearance of the HBsAg antigen and appearance of Anti-HBs antibody. The window period for a test designed to detect a specific disease is the time between the first infection and when the test can reliably detect that infection.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In a patient who is both HBsAg and HBeAg positive, what does declining IgM anti-HBc and rising total anti-HBc indicate?
explanation: In patients who are both HBsAg and HBeAg positive, declining IgM anti-HBc and rising total anti-HBc are indicative of chronic infective hepatitis. Anti-HBc IgM antibody signifies acute infection/window period, whereas, the presence of IgG anti-HBc indicates chronic infection. However, there is no test available to directly detect the IgG anti-HBC. Over a period of months, the IgM anti-HBc antibodies are replaced by the IgG anti-HBc antibodies. Thus a decline of IgM antibodies in the presence of rising total anti-HBC indicates that the IgM is being converted to IgG and thus the infection is chronic. HBeAg, HBV-DNA, and DNA polymerase appear in serum soon after HBsAg, and all signify active viral replication. Occasionally, mutated strains of HBV emerge that do not produce HBeAg but are replication-competent and express HBcAg.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse turns out to be HBsAg positive. Which of the following is the best predictor for development of chronic disease?
explanation: The age at the time of infection is the best predictor of chronicity. Younger the age at the time of hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, higher the probability of chronicity. Other predictors in the development of chronic disease: comorbid conditions (including exposure to other infectious agents) host immunity Presentations of hepatitis B infection: Asymptomatic - 65% Non-specific symptoms - 25% Chronic disease - 5-10% Acute fulminant liver disease - 0.1-0.5%
subject: Pathology

question_text: An IV drug abuser has been found to be seropositive for HBsAg, HBeAg, and anti-HBc IgM. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in the liver biopsy of such patients?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hepatitis B infection. Ground-glass hepatocytes are not seen in the liver biopsy of such patients. Histopathological findings in acute hepatits are: Ballooning degeneration - due to inflammation Portal or lobular inflammatory infiltration - lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils Necrosis Confluent necrosis - group of hepatocytes Panlobular or panacinar necrosis - entire lobule Bridging necrosis (in severe cases) - connecting vascular structures Ground-glass appearance of hepatocytes is due to the endoplasmic reticulum which is swollen with HBsAg accumulation. It is a diagnostic hallmark of chronic hepatitis B infection. The image given below shows ground glass hepatocytes in the liver biopsy.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A man with a history of intranasal cocaine abuse is at most risk for which of the following infections?
explanation: Intranasal cocaine abuse is a risk factor for hepatitis C. Contaminated implements (like straws used to inhale cocaine) inserted into the nasal cavity might come into contact with hepatitis C virus (HCV)-infected mucus or blood. This might then be transmitted to a susceptible individual while sharing the same implements. Transmission of hepatitis C infection: Intravenous drug abuse (54%) - Most common Multiple sex partners Needle-stick injury Multiple contacts with a person with hepatitis C virus infection Employment in medical or dental fields Blood transfusion Perinatal - major route of infection in children
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common clinical course in patients diagnosed with hepatitis C infection?
explanation: The most common clinical course seen in hepatitis C infection is chronic carrier state. Acute clinical illness is often asymptomatic/mild with a high rate of conversion to chronic hepatitis (~85%).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which genotype of hepatitis C virus is associated with metabolic syndrome?
explanation: Hepatitis C virus (HCV) genotype 3 is associated with metabolic syndrome. HCV can give rise to insulin resistance and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 40-year-old male patient with chronic hepatitis B infection comes for a follow-up visit. Which of the following is not a histopathological feature of the liver in such cases?
explanation: Ballooning degeneration is not associated with chronic hepatitis. It is seen in acute hepatitis. Histopathological findings in chronic viral hepatitis are: Portal lymphocytic/ lymphoplasmacytic inflammation Interface activity - inflammatory cells cross the limiting plate and cause periportal hepatocyte injury Portal, periportal, and portoportal bridging fibrosis Specific findings in viral hepatitis: Hepatitis B - ground glass hepatocytes Hepatitis C - lymphoid aggregates and steatosis
subject: Pathology

question_text: In patients with liver failure, which of the following tests is not used to evaluate the synthetic function of hepatocytes?
explanation: Serum alkaline phosphatase is used to evaluate biliary excretory function. It is not used to evaluate the synthetic function of hepatocytes. Serum ammonia, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), and serum albumin are used to evaluate hepatic synthetic function. Prothrombin time (PT), aPTT and serum ammonia levels are increased in liver failure, whereas serum albumin level is decreased.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not seen in the histopathological examination of the liver in patients with malaria?
explanation: Macronodular cirrhosis is not seen in the histopathological examination of patients with malaria. Histopathological changes in the liver in cases of malaria include the following: Kupffer cell hyperplasia Hemozoin pigment deposition within Kupffer cells and macrophages Focal necrosis Mild mononuclear portal infiltrate Fatty change and periportal inflammation
subject: Pathology

question_text: Identify the incorrect match.
explanation: Councilman bodies are apoptotic hepatocytes seen in acute hepatitis and yellow fever. Option A: Mallory–Denk bodies are eosinophilic materials made of keratin intermediate filaments. They are seen in alcoholic liver disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, Wilson's disease, and chronic biliary tract diseases. Option C: Ground-glass hepatocytes are liver cells that have eosinophilic granular, glassy cytoplasm seen on light microscopy. The appearance is due to the swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum by HBsAg and is a diagnostic hallmark of chronic hepatitis B. Option D: Circumferential onion skin fibrosis around a degenerating bile-duct lumen is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with ascites, melena, and splenomegaly is diagnosed with portal hypertension. Which of the following is not an intrahepatic cause of this condition?
explanation: Obstructive portal vein thrombosis is the prehepatic cause of portal hypertension. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, cirrhosis, and schistosomiasis are intrahepatic causes of portal hypertension. The most dominant cause is cirrhosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a feature of liver histology in patients with non-cirrhotic portal fibrosis?
options: Thrombosis of the medium and small portal vein branches
explanation: Bridging fibrosis is not seen in non-cirrhotic portal fibrosis. In this condition, there is periportal and perisinusoidal fibrosis. The fibrous septa end blindly in the lobule and do not bridge with other portal tracts, unlike those seen in cirrhosis. Idiopathic non-cirrhotic portal hypertension (INCPH) is a rare disease characterized by intrahepatic portal hypertension in the absence of cirrhosis or other causes of liver disease and splanchnic venous thrombosis. A liver biopsy is essential in making a diagnosis of INCPH. The features observed are as follows: Luminal narrowing or obliteration of portal vein branches Micronodular transformation Sinusoidal dilatation with formation of mega sinusoids Periportal and perisinusoidal fibrosis
subject: Pathology

question_text: Match the histopathological sections of liver and the different conditions.
explanation: In the given image, images marked 1 is normal liver, 2 is alcoholic steatosis, 3 is micronodular cirrhosis and 4 is alcoholic hepatitis. Histopathological findings in the following conditions are: Alcoholic steatosis: A mix of small and large fat droplets Ethanol inhibits fatty acid metabolism, leading to lipolysis and increased triglyceride. These triglycerides accumulate and cause steatosis. Liver enzymes are normal at this stage. Micronodular cirrhosis: The average nodule size is 3 mm in this close-up view, which is typical of the micronodular cirrhosis of alcoholic liver disease Alcoholic hepatitis: Mallory-Denk bodies - clumped, amorphous, eosinophilic material in ballooned hepatocytes. These inclusions are characteristic, but not a specific feature of alcoholic liver disease.
subject: Pathology

Match the following:
1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B
explanation: The liver findings seen in the hepatotoxic drugs are: Drugs Liver findings Valproat e Microvesicular steatosis Allopurin ol Fibrin ring granuloma Amiodar one Mallory-Denk bodies Isoniazid Noncaseating epitheloid gran ulomas Autoimmune and Metabolic Liver Disease
subject: Pathology

question_text: Mutation in which of the following genes causes Wilson's disease?
explanation: Wilson's disease is caused due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene. It an autosomal recessive condition. The ATP7B gene is located on chromosome 13q. The gene encodes a copper transporting ATPase (ATP7B) which has 2 functions: Maintains copper in bound form by binding copper to apoceruloplasmin Helps excrete free copper in bile. The resulting ATP7B deficiency leads to reduced bound copper and impaired free copper excretion. This causes excess deposition of free copper in the tissues, particularly in the liver, brain and eye. Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive condition leading to impaired absorption of copper and subsequent copper deficiency. Here, the mutation is in the ATP7A gene.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 35-year-old man with tremors and chronic hepatitis is found to have the following ophthalmic finding. This patient is also likely to have which of the following?
explanation: The given image shows the Kayser-Fleischer ring. This,along with the background of hepatitis and neuropsychiatric features is characteristic of Wilson's disease. The patient is thus likely to have basal ganglia atrophy. In the majority of cases, neuropsychiatric manifestations follow hepatic manifestations. It is due to the deposition of free copper in the basal ganglia and cortex. Free copper deposition in the basal ganglia leads to bilateral degeneration and atrophy.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following would you use to screen an asymptomatic sibling of a patient with Wilson's disease?
explanation: Genetic testing for the ATP7B gene is used to screen asymptomatic 1st and 2nd-degree relatives of patients with Wilson's disease. This helps to differentiate the heterozygous from the homozygous individuals. This can be useful in the early initiation of treatment before the onset of symptoms. Low serum ceruloplasmin, raised 24 hr urinary copper and Kayser-Fleischer rings are diagnostically helpful. Estimation of hepatic tissue copper is the gold standard for diagnosis. It is measured using neutron activation analysis / atomic absorption spectrometry.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with personality changes and jaundice. Slit-lamp examination confirmed the diagnosis of Wilson's disease. Which of the following statements is true regarding the condition?
options: Ceruloplasmin in blood increases and urinary copper excretion decreases
Ceruloplasmin in blood decreases and urinary copper excretion decreases
Ceruloplasmin in blood increases and urinary copper excretion increases
Ceruloplasmin in blood decreases and urinary copper excretion increases
explanation: The ceruloplasmin level in the blood decreases, and the copper content in urine increases in Wilson's disease. Lab markers Change in Wilson's diseas e Reason Serum ceruloplas min  ATP7B deficiency results in r educed bound copper 24h urinary coppe r  Excess free copper excreted i n urine
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following stains can be used to demonstrate excess copper deposition in Wilson's disease?
explanation: Excess copper deposition in Wilson's disease is demonstrated by rhodanine stain. Microscopic findings in Wilson's disease include: Fatty infiltration (macrovesicular) Glycogen deposition in periportal hepatocytes Macronodular cirrhosis in decompensated stages. Orcein stain is used to stain copper-associated proteins (eg: ceruloplasmin).
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 55 yr old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. This patient most likely suffers from
explanation: The patient most likely suffers from hemochromatosis. In the given scenario, the liver microscopy image shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with Perl's Prussian blue stain. Hemochromatosis is an inherited or acquired metabolic disorder caused by excessive iron absorption. Iron overload leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs. The image below shows the triad of haemochromatosis. The image below is the liver microscopy image showing hepatocellular iron, stained with Perl's Prussian blue. The total body iron pool ranges from 2 to 6 gm in normal adults. In hemochromatosis, total iron accumulation may exceed 50 gm, more than one-third of which accumulates in the liver.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with hereditary hemochromatosis is found to have a mutation in the HFE gene. On which chromosome is it located?
explanation: HFE gene is located on the short arm of chromosome 6 (6p). It is the most commonly mutated gene in patients with hereditary hemochromatosis. HFE encodes an HLA class I–like molecule that regulates the synthesis of hepcidin in hepatocytes. The most common HFE mutation is a cysteine-to-tyrosine substitution at amino acid 282 (C282Y).
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 34-year-old man evaluated for chronic abdominal pain is found to have hepatomegaly and serum ferritin level of 1800 micro g/l. Which of the following complications is he at the greatest risk of developing?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hemochromatosis. A patient with hemochromatosis is at risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma. Hepatocellular carcinoma is a significant cause of death in hemochromatosis. The risk is much greater than in the general population. The disease progression of hemochromatosis is as shown below:
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is true regarding hemochromatosis?
explanation: Neonatal hemochromatosis is not an inherited disease. It is a disease of unknown origin manifested by severe liver disease and extrahepatic hemosiderin deposition. It might be related to maternal alloimmune injury to the fetal liver. Adult hemochromatosis is generally a milder disease than the juvenile form. With treatment, life expectancy is normal. Bantu siderosis or African iron overload is due to dietary iron overload. Consumption of beer prepared in iron pots or drums is the cause of dietary iron overload. Skin pigmentation in hemochromatosis mostly results from increased melanin synthesis. This is due to iron deposition and not hemosiderin deposition. In severe hemochromatosis, total iron accumulation may exceed 50 gm. More than one-third of this accumulates in the liver. In normal adults, it is in the range of 2 to 6 gms.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following organs does not show hemosiderin deposits in hemochromatosis?
explanation: The testes do not show hemosiderin deposits in hemochromatosis. Hypogonadism in hemochromatosis is not due to the deposition of iron in the testis. It is due to a derangement in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. This results in decreased gonadotrophins and testosterone levels. The testis will appear small and atrophic. Deposition of hemosiderin is seen in the following organs in the decreasing order of severity: Liver Pancreas Myocardium Pituitary gland Adrenal gland Thyroid Parathyroid gland Joints Skin
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 35-year-old male patient with emphysema was found to have elevated liver transaminases. His liver biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The liver biopsy image shows periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes. These are characteristic of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of 1 antitrypsin into the serum. 1AT deficiency results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema. It also causes liver disease as a consequence of an abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. Cutaneous necrotizing panniculitis also occurs in a minor subset of patients. Hepatocellular carcinoma develops in 2% to 3% of cases. The image given is a photomicrograph of a liver biopsy from a patient with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The PAS with diastase stain shows the diastase-resistant pink globules that are characteristic of this disease.
subject: Pathology

question_text: On which chromosome is the gene for alpha-1 antitrypsin present?
explanation: The gene for alpha-1 antitrypsin is located on the long arm of chromosome 14. Alpha-1 antitrypsin is a plasma glycoprotein synthesized predominantly by hepatocytes. For 1-antitrypsin genes, the general notation is “Pi” for “protease inhibitor." An alphabetic letter is given for the position on the isoelectric gel. This gene has different alleles that produce different amounts of alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT). M allele - normal levels of the AAT protein S allele - moderately low levels Z allele - very low levels The alleles are expressed in a codominant manner.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common clinically significant mutation causing alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency?
explanation: The most common clinically significant mutation causing 1-antitrypsin deficiency is PiZ. Homozygous individuals, with PiZZ, have only 10% of normal circulating 1-antitrypsin. So, they are at high risk of developing clinical disease. PiMM is the most common genotype seen in normal individuals, present in about 90% of individuals. PiS variant is clinically asymptomatic. Pi-null is a rare variant with no detectable serum alpha-1 antitrypsin.
subject: Pathology

question_text: An 11-year-old girl with persistently elevated serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) has been diagnosed with autoimmune hepatitis. Which of the following pathological features would you not expect in this patient?
explanation: Bile duct injury and granulomas are uncommon in autoimmune hepatitis except in case of overlap with primary biliary cirrhosis. Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterised by extensive inflammation, fibrosis and ultimately cirrhosis. The pathologic features include: Emperipolesis - Lymphocytes and plasma cells within the cytoplasm of hepatocytes. Interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis. Rosette formation due to necrosis of groups of hepatocytes and resultant regeneration. The image given below shows autoimmune hepatitis with lymphoplasmacytic interface hepatitis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false with regard to autoimmune hepatitis?
options: Type 2 autoimmune hepatitis shows antinuclear antibodies (ANA).
It can progress to liver failure.
Inflammatory infiltrate is predominantly composed of plasma cells.
explanation: Type 2 autoimmune hepatitis shows anti-liver kidney microsomal autoantibodies (anti-LKM1) and anti–liver cytosol-1 (ACL-1) antibodies not ANA. Type 1 autoimmune hepatitis shows anti-nuclear (ANA), anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA) and anti–soluble liver antigen / liver pancreas antigen (anti-SLA/LP) antibodies. It less commonly shows anti-mitochondrial (AMA) antibodies. Autoimmune hepatitis is a chronic disorder characterized by continuing hepatocellular necrosis and inflammation. It can progress to cirrhosis and liver failure. Histocompatibility haplotypes such as HLA-B1, HLA-B8, HLA-DR3, and HLA-DR4 are common in patients with autoimmune hepatitis. Histopathological features include: Plasma cell predominance in inflammatory infiltrates Extensive interface hepatitis (piecemeal necrosis) Hepatocyte rosettes The image given below shows autoimmune hepatitis showing characteristic lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate and interface hepatitis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following antibodies would you not expect to see in a patient with autoimmune hepatitis?
explanation: Anti-TIF1 antibodies are not associated with autoimmune hepatitis. Anti-TIF1 antibodies are found in patients with dermatomyositis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Identify the incorrect match.
explanation: Chronic hepatitis D is associated with anti-LKM 3 antibodies.
subject: Pathology

question_text: The histopathological findings obtained after a liver biopsy is given below. What would be the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: Onion-skin fibrosis is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis. The smaller ducts in primary sclerosing cholangitis show a striking circumferential “onion skin” fibrosis around an increasingly atrophic duct lumen. This eventually leads to the obliteration by a “tombstone” scar. The image shows primary sclerosing cholangitis. There is a degenerating bile duct that is entrapped in the dense concentric onion-skin fibrosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a feature of primary sclerosing cholangitis?
explanation: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. There is dilation of preserved segments. On histopathologic examination, large ducts show acute neutrophilic inflammation of the epithelium. The inflamed areas develop strictures. Small ducts show onion-skin fibrosis around the atrophic duct lumen. There is an obliteration of ducts by a tombstone scar.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Primary biliary cholangitis is most commonly associated with which of the following conditions?
Sjogren syndrome
explanation: Primary biliary cholangitis is most commonly associated with Sjogren's syndrome. Other associated conditions are: Thyroiditis Scleroderma Rheumatoid arthritis Raynaud phenomenon Celiac disease PBC is an autoimmune disease. It is characterized by nonsuppurative, inflammatory destruction of small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. Large intrahepatic ducts and the extrahepatic biliary tree are not involved. It is a disease of middle-aged women, with a female predominance of 9:1. Antimitochondrial antibodies are the most characteristic laboratory finding in PBC. Histopathologic examination shows diagnostic florid duct lesions. These are lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates with or without granulomas centred around the bile duct. They also show Mallory–Denk bodies. The image given below shows primary biliary cholangitis. Neoplasms of Liver and Biliary tract
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common benign tumor of the liver?
explanation: Cavernous hemangioma is the most common benign tumor of the liver. It appears as a red-blue, soft nodule, usually < 2 cm in diameter. It may be mistaken radiographically or intraoperatively for a metastatic tumor.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of abdominal pain. She has been taking oral contraceptives for the past 7 years. CECT reveals an isodense lesion in the liver with homogenous enhancement in the arterial phase and washout in the portal venous phase. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?
options: It can be associated with MODY-3
Serum amyloid A may be upregulated
 -catenin-activated adenoma has no risk of malignant transformation
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hepatic adenoma.  -catenin-activated adenomas have a high risk of malignant transformation. Hepatic adenomas are benign tumors of hepatocytes. Spontaneous rupture of the hepatic adenoma may cause intraabdominal bleeding, which is a surgical emergency. Hepatic adenomas are classified into 3 subtypes: HNF1--inactivated adenomas - No risk of malignant transformation Often associated with oral contraceptive pill use (OCP) and MODY-3  -catenin-activated adenoma - High risk of malignant transformation Associated with oral contraceptive pills (OCP) and anabolic steroids usage Inflammatory adenomas - Associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) Upregulation of C-reactive protein (CRP) and serum amyloid A 10% may have concomitant  -catenin activating mutations Moderate risk of malignant transformation The gross specimen of hepatic adenoma is shown below.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Patients with cirrhosis of the liver are at a higher risk of developing which of the following?
explanation: Dysplastic nodules are associated with liver cirrhosis. High grade dysplastic nodules may eventually develop into hepatocellular carcinoma in viral hepatitis and alcoholic liver disease.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought with abdominal swelling. On examination, a mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory evaluation shows serum alpha-fetoprotein level of
1,50,000 ng/mL. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical history and elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein level are suggestive of hepatoblastoma. Hepatoblastoma is the most common malignant liver tumor of early childhood, usually < 3 years. Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is the most important clinical marker for hepatoblastoma. It remains the key clinical marker of malignant change, response to the treatment, and relapse. Histological section of hepatoblastoma showing proliferating hepatoblasts consisting of round epithelial type cells is given below.

question_text: Patients with all of the following are at a higher risk of developing hepatoblastoma except:
options: A 6-year-old child diagnosed with new-onset hypertension
A premature infant with low birth weight
A 5-year-old child diagnosed with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome
A 9-year-old child with a family history of familial adenatomatous polyposis
explanation: Hypertension is not a risk factor for hepatoblastoma. Risk factors for hepatoblastoma include: Prematurity and low birth weight (LBW) Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)

question_text: Which of the following parameters indicates a good prognosis in hepatoblastoma?
explanation: Pure fetal histology hepatoblastoma is associated with a very good prognosis. They may be cured by surgical resection without adjuvant chemotherapy. Prognostic factors in hepatoblastoma include: Prematurity and low-birth weight (LBW) are associated with hepatoblastoma but do not affect its outcome. question_text: Which one of the following syndromes is associated with a higher incidence of hepatoblastoma?
explanation: Gardner syndrome, a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) syndrome is associated with hepatoblastoma. Activation of WNT signaling plays a major role in hepatoblastomas. This occurs by a variety of mechanisms including mutations in APC gene. Hence, patients with FAP syndromes frequently develop hepatoblastomas. The following syndromes are associated with hepatocellular carcinoma: Hereditary tyrosinemia Alpha-1 antitrypsin defeciency Familial hemochromatosis
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of hepatocellular carcinoma?
explanation: The most common cause of hepatocellular carcinoma is chronic hepatitis B virus infection. More than 85% of cases of hepatocellular carcinoma occur in countries with high rates of chronic hepatitis B virus infection. Risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma are: Hepatitis B virus Hepatitis C virus Alcoho Aflatoxin Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency Hemochromatosis Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis Tyrosinemia Smoking Activation of  -catenin and inactivation of p53 are the two most common early mutational events seen in hepatocellular carcinoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following are the precursor lesions for hepatocellular carcinoma?
explanation: Focal nodular hyperplasia and nodular regenerative hyperplasia are not precursors for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The precursors of HCC inlcude: Hepatocellular adenoma - especially those with  -catenin-activating mutations Small cell and large cell change - cellular dysplasias Dysplastic nodules - low-grade and high-grade
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 25-year-old woman presents with chronic abdominal discomfort. Imaging reveals a solitary well-encapsulated hepatic mass with a central fibrous scar and stellate calcification. Further investigations reveal elevated neurotensin levels and negative hepatitis B serology. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?
options: Histology reveals oncocytic hepatocytes separated by collagen bundles
It is associated with a relatively good prognosis
Majority of these tumors are resectable
It is associated with liver cirrhosis
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fibrolamellar carcinoma. It is usually not associated with liver cirrhosis. Fibrolamellar carcinoma is a distinctive and rare variant of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). It usually occurs < 35 years of age. There is no gender predilection and no identifiable predisposing conditions. It has a good prognosis compared to the classical HCC. Majority (50-75%) of these tumors are resectable. It usually presents as a single large, hard scirrhous tumor with fibrous bands coursing through it. Microscopically, it is composed of oncocytes growing in nests or cords separated by parallel lamellae of dense collagen bundles. The histological section of fibrolamellar carcinoma is given below. It shows malignant-appearing, oncocytic hepatocytes separated by dense bundles of collagen.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following agents is not associated with the development of hepatic angiosarcoma?
explanation: Hepatic angiosarcoma is associated with exposure to arsenic, thorotrast and vinyl chloride. Angiosarcoma is a malignant endothelial neoplasm. There is equal gender predilection. The tumor may occur at any site, but most often involves skin, soft tissue, breast and liver. Various hepatic tumors and associated etiological agents are given below: Tumor Etiological agents Hepatocellular adenom a Oral contraceptives, anabolic steroids Hepatocellular carcino ma Alcohol, thorotrast Cholangiocarcinoma Thorotrast Angiosarcoma Thorotrast, vinyl chloride, ar senic
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common tumor of the liver?
explanation: The most common tumors of the liver are metastatic tumors. The common primary sources of liver metastasis are: Colon carcinoma Breast carcinoma Lung carcinoma Pancreatic carcinoma
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 53-year-old patient with anorexia and weight loss is found to have non-tender hepatomegaly on physical examination. CT scan of the abdomen shows multiple nodules in the liver and investigations reveal elevated ALP and AST levels, with no elevations in AFP. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a metastatic liver tumor. Metastases are the most common malignant neoplasms of the liver. The most common primary sources are the colon, breast, lung, and pancreas, although any cancer at any site of the body may spread to the liver. Patients with metastases typically have multiple nodules replacing the normal liver parenchyma. There may be no clinical or laboratory evidence of hepatic insufficiency. Often, the only telltale sign of secondaries in the liver will be hepatomegaly.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Patients with which of the following conditions are not at risk for cholangiocarcinoma?
explanation: Typhoid carriers are not at risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma. Cholangiocarcinoma is the second most common primary malignant tumor of the liver after hepatocellular carcinoma. It is a malignancy of the biliary tree, arising from bile ducts within and outside of the liver. The risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma include the following: Infestation by liver flukes (particularly Opisthorchis and Clonorchis ) Primary sclerosing cholangitis, and other chronic inflammatory diseases of the large bile ducts Chronic hepatitis B and C infections Cirrhosis Inflammatory bowel disease Diabetes mellitus, obesity, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) Alcohol and tobacco Precursor lesions - Biliary intraepithelial neoplasias Mucinous cystic neoplasms Intraductal papillary biliary neoplasia
subject: Pathology

question_text: What does Klatskin tumor refer to?
explanation: Klatskin tumors are extrahepatic cholangiocarcinomas located in the perihilar region. These tumors are located at the junction of the right and left hepatic ducts. Distal tumors arise in the common bile duct posterior to the duodenum. Regardless of the site, the prognosis is poor.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding gallbladder carcinoma?
The common type is adenocarcinoma
options: Gallstones are the most important risk factor
Her2 overexpression is seen in about 2/3 of the cases
It usually has a good prognosis
explanation: Gallbladder carcinoma carries a poor prognosis because it is typically detected late due to non-specific symptoms. Carcinoma of the gallbladder is the most common malignancy of the extrahepatic biliary tract. Most carcinomas of the gall bladder are adenocarcinomas. Gallbladder cancer is at least twice as common in women than in men. The most important risk factor for gallbladder cancer (besides gender and ethnicity) is gallstones, which are present in 95% of cases. Her-2/neu is overexpressed in around 2/3 of the cases, and therefore, they can be targeted for therapy. Gall Bladder and Pancreas
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common congenital anomaly of the gallbladder?
explanation: The most common congenital anomaly of the gallbladder is the Phrygian cap. It refers to an inward folding of the fundus of the gallbladder. It is named for its resemblance to a conical hat. The other common congenital anomalies of the gallbladder are: Agenesis - absence of all or any portion of the hepatic or common bile ducts Biliary atresia - hypoplastic narrowing of biliary channels Choledochal cysts - congenital dilations of the intra and/or extrahepatic biliary system
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 24-year-old man presented with severe right upper quadrant pain for 8 hours associated with nausea and vomiting. A diagnosis of acute cholecystitis was made and he underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The specimen is shown below. This finding is associated with all the following conditions except:
explanation: The given image shows pigmented gallstones, which are not associated with hyperlipidemia syndromes. Pigmented gallstones are made of bilirubin and calcium salts. They can occur in: Chronic hemolytic syndromes Ileal resection Biliary infection Cystic fibrosis with pancreatic insufficiency Cholesterol stones are made of crystalline cholesterol monohydrates. Dyslipidemia is a risk factor for the development of cholesterol gallstones. The following image shows cholesterol gallstones:

question_text: A 52-year-old man was rushed to the ER with right upper quadrant pain for the last 6 hours. He had been diagnosed with gallstones 10 years ago but had not undergone any treatment. Imaging revealed gallbladder wall thickening. He underwent a cholecystectomy which revealed a shrunken and nodular gallbladder with a thick wall. The following was noted on microscopy. This condition is associated with:
options: Dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall
explanation: This clinical scenario of chronic cholecystitis and image showing lipid-laden xanthoma cells are suggestive of xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis. This condition results due to the rupture of Rokitansky–Aschoff sinuses. Rokitansky–Aschoff sinuses are bile-filled outpouchings of the gallbladder mucosa through the gallbladder wall. They develop in reaction to chronic inflammation of the gallbladder. Eventually, they may rupture into the wall of the gallbladder. This results in the accumulation of macrophages that have ingested biliary phospholipids, which are called xanthoma cells. Chronic cholecystitis may have other sequelae: Porcelain gallbladder - dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall Hyalinizing cholecystitis - replacement of the gallbladder wall by dense fibrosis, with or without calcification (leads to higher incidence of gallbladder carcinoma) Hydrops of the gallbladder - atrophic, obstructed, dilated gallbladder containing clear fluid Acute cholecystitis includes the following variants: Emphysematous cholecystitis - acute infection of the gallbladder by gas-forming organisms Acalculous cholecystitis - due to gallbladder stasis and ischemia
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas?
explanation: Pancreas divisum is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas. The pancreas develops by fusion of the larger dorsal and smaller ventral pancreatic buds. The dorsal duct is the dominant duct during development and it drains into the minor papilla. The ventral duct drains into the major papilla. After fusion, the following ducts are formed: Main pancreatic duct (of Wirsung) - formed by fusion of ducts of dorsal and ventral buds, drains into the major papilla Accessory pancreatic duct (of Santorini) - formed by the proximal portion of the dorsal duct, drains into the minor papilla In pancreas divisum, the ventral and dorsal ducts fail to fuse. Hence, the majority of the pancreas continues to drain through the dominant dorsal duct that enters the duodenum at the minor papilla while the ventral duct, along with the bile duct, drains into the major papilla. These patients are more prone to pancreatitis. The other congenital anomalies of the pancreas are: Annular pancreas - band-like ring of normal pancreatic tissue encircling 2nd part of duodenum, may cause obstruction Ectopic pancreas - common in stomach, duodenum, and jejunum (found in about 2% of postmortem exams) Agenesis - rarely seen, associated with mutations of PDX1 (homeobox gene)
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 19-year-old boy presented with severe abdominal pain for the last 24 hours with radiation to the upper back. He has had multiple similar episodes since his childhood. Family history revealed similar episodes in the father. Investigations revealed elevated serum levels of amylase and lipase. Which of the following statements is not true about the given condition?
options: It is commonly associated with mutations in the PRSS1 gene
This boy has a 40 % lifetime risk of developing pancreatic cancer
It may be associated with mutations in the CFTR gene
Hypocalcemia is an important triggering factor this condition
explanation: This clinical scenario in a young patient with positive family history of similar episodes is suggestive of hereditary pancreatitis. Acute episodes of pancreatitis can be precipitated by hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia. The following genes are implicated in hereditary pancreatitis: Gain-of-function mutation in trypsinogen gene (PRSS1) - most common Loss-of-function mutation in trypsin inhibitor gene (SPINK1) Loss of CFTR - abnormal secretions that promote protein plugging, duct obstruction, leading t pancreatitis Hereditary pancreatitis is associated with a 40% lifetime risk of developing pancreatic cancer.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 65-year-old man presented with vague abdominal pain, anorexia, weight loss for the last 6 months. He also reported spontaneously appearing and disappearing painful, linearly arranged nodules at different locations on his body. On examination, thrombophlebitis and epigastric tenderness were noted. Investigations revealed elevated serum CEA and CA 19-9. Which of the following genetic mutations is most frequently associated with this condition?
explanation: The presence of the above clinical symptoms with migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome) and elevated serum levels of CEA and CA 19-9 in an elderly man point to a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer. The most frequently associated mutation with this condition is K-RAS. It is attributed to the production of platelet-aggregating factors and procoagulants from the tumor or its necrotic products. Both venous and arterial thrombi can occur. Venous thrombi can embolize to the lungs. Molecular alterations involved in pancreatic carcinogenesis are: Following genes are associated with an inherited predisposition to pancreatic cancer: BRCA2 mutation - pancreatic cancer, breast cancer, prostate cancer, and ovarian cancers PRSS1 mutation - pancreatic carcinoma secondary to hereditary pancreatitis Gene Type Chromo some KRAS(most common oncoge ne) Oncogene (activated by point mutation) 12p CDKN2A(most common tum or-suppressor gene) Tumor suppressor gene 9p TP53 Tumor suppressor gene 17p SMAD4 Tumor suppressor gene 18q
subject: Pathology

question_text: A pathologist was studying a biopsy specimen from a patient with pancreatic cancer. He observed that it resembled ovarian stroma. What is it likely to be?
explanation: Mucinous cystic neoplasms of the pancreas have dense stroma, similar to the ovarian stroma. These tumors have large cystic cavities filled with thick, tenacious mucin. They are lined by columnar, mucin-producing epithelium with dense stroma. This results in similarity to ovarian stroma. They usually arise in the tail of the pancreas and can be precursors to invasive carcinomas. They are associated with mutations in the KRAS oncogene, and the tumor-suppressor genes TP53 and RNF43.
subject: Pathology

question_text: All of these are characteristic features of pancreatic carcinoma except:
options: Cigarette smoking is a risk factor
Carcinoma of body of pancreas often present with jaundice
explanation: Patients with carcinoma of the head of the pancreas develop jaundice due to obstruction of the biliary tract. Cigarette smoking doubles the risk of pancreatic cancer and is the leading preventable cause. The clinical features depend on the location of the tumor. Head - painless, palpable gallbladder with mild jaundice is suggestive of malignancy (according to Courvoisier's law) Body and tail - may remain asymptomatic until later stages as they do not impinge on the biliary tract and do not cause jaundice Other common pathological features of this condition are: Desmoplastic reaction - growth of fibrous or connective tissue Perineural invasion, as well as lymphatic and large vessel invasion
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Patients with which of the following have the highest risk of pancreatic cancer?
FAMMM syndrome
explanation: Patients with Peutz–Jeghers syndrome have the highest risk of pancreatic cancer. question_text: What is the most common site of fistulization in GIT?
explanation: The esophagus is the most common site of fistulization in the gastrointestinal tract (GIT). A tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) is an abnormal fistula communication between the esophagus and trachea. The fistula is usually present near the tracheal bifurcation, with or without esophageal atresia. A blind proximal pouch with a distal tracheooesophageal fistula is the most common type of tracheoesophageal fistula (Type C). 10% of the patients have associated VACTERL anomalies (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb).
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most frequent site of ectopic gastric mucosa?
explanation: The most frequent site of the ectopic gastric mucosa is the upper third of the esophagus, where it is referred to as an inlet patch. It is congenital and mostly asymptomatic. Occasionally, it can release acid, which can result in dysphagia, esophagitis, Barrett esophagus, or, rarely, adenocarcinoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 57-year-old man came with complaints of difficulty in swallowing and a persistent feeling of something stuck in his throat. He also reports bad breath and regurgitation of food particles. Barium swallow revealed the following. This condition occurs due to a defect in which of the following?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and barium swallow image are diagnostic of Zenker’s diverticulum. It occurs due to a defect in the Killian's triangle (Killian's dehiscence). Killian's triangle is an anatomical triangular area bordered superiorly by the firm oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus muscle and inferiorly by the horizontal fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle. It is located immediately above the upper esophageal sphincter. Although the Killian-Jamieson diverticulum is an anterolateral defect, it is rarely symptomatic.
subject: Pathology

question_text: All of the following may be seen in patients with Plummer-Vinson syndrome except:
explanation: Paterson–Brown–Kelly or Plummer–Vinson syndrome is associated with non-progressive dysphagia, especially with incompletely chewed food. This syndrome is common in women aged >40 years. The other components of this syndrome are: Post-cricoid webs in the upper esophagus Iron-deficiency anemia Glossitis Cheilosis Esophageal webs are idiopathic, semi-circumferential lesions composed of fibrovascular connective tissue and overlying epithelium. They are usually limited to the proximal esophagus and may cause obstruction. They are associated with: Plummer–Vinson syndrome Gastroesophageal reflux disease Chronic graft-versus-host disease Blistering skin diseases The images below show endoscopic and barium swallow appearances of esophageal webs.

explanation: The given image shows an esophageal ring. Rings located above the gastroesophageal junction are classified as type A esophageal rings. Esophageal rings are circumferential and thick. They include mucosa, submucosa, and occasionally, hypertrophic muscularis propria. question_text: A 52-year-old woman is being evaluated for dysphagia and chest pain. She traveled to Brazil on a business trip 5 months ago. Barium swallow reveals the following finding. Which of the following could have caused this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and barium swallow showing the bird-beak appearance are suggestive of achalasia cardia. With respect to this patient's travel history, Chagas' disease due to infection with Trypanosoma cruzi must be suspected. The infection destroys the myenteric plexus which results in failure of peristalsis and esophageal dilatation. Duodenal, colonic, and ureteric myenteric plexuses can also be affected by Chagas' disease.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is true about the pathology of achalasia cardia?
options: Decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus
Decreased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter
explanation: Achalasia cardia is characterized by decreased release of NO(nitric oxide) and VIP(vasoactive intestinal polypeptide) in the distal part of esophagus. Normally, NO and VIP are secreted by the inhibitory neurons of the Auerbach's plexus in the distal esophagus. This leads to relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). In achalasia cardia, these inhibitory neurons degenerate leading to decreased release of NO and VIP. This causes increased LES tone. The triad of achalasia cardia is as follows: Incomplete relaxation of LES Increased tone of LES Absent peristalsis (aperistalisis)
subject: Pathology

explanation: The given clinical scenario and image showing multiple stacked esophageal rings are characteristic of eosinophilic esophagitis. question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about eosinophilic esophagitis?
options: Majority of patients have associated atopic conditions
Feline esophagus is an endoscopic finding
Treatment of choice is systemic steroids
May be associated with food products like cow’s milk and soy products
explanation: Treatment of choice are proton pump inhibitors, which when started as primary therapy is effective in 30 - 50 % of affected individuals. Additionally, elimination of allergenic proteins from diet as it is is associated with atopy and exposure to food allergens like cow’s milk and soy products. Swallowed topical steroids are used as well. Immunocompromised patients are treated with acyclovir, famciclovir or valacyclovir. question_text: A 47-year-old woman comes to you with progressive heartburn and difficulty in swallowing. She also describes episodes of painful blanching and bluish discoloration of her fingers and toes on exposure to cold. The following findings are noted on examination. Antibodies to which of the following are most likely to be seen in this patient?
explanation: The symptoms of the patient in the above case scenario and the image showing calcinosis are the characteristic findings of the CREST syndrome or limited scleroderma. Patients with this condition characteristically have antibodies directed against centromeric proteins (anti-centromere antibodies). CREST syndrome is characterized by the following: Calcinosis Raynaud phenomenon Esophageal dysmotility Sclerodactyly Telangiectasia In the esophagus, progressive atrophy and fibrous replacement of the muscularis propria leads to hypomotility and dysphagia. The lower 2/3 of the esophagus develops a rubber-hose–like inflexibility. The associated dysfunction of the lower esophageal sphincter gives rise to gastroesophageal reflux, Barrett metaplasia, and stricture.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 50-year-old man presented with blood in his vomitus. He gives a history of binge drinking followed by multiple episodes of vomiting the prior night. He is hemodynamically stable.
Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?
options: It is due to longitudinal mucosal tears
The gastroesophageal musculature fails to relax
The tears cross the gastroesophageal junction
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of a Mallory–Weiss tear. They require only conservative management and healing tends to be rapid and complete. They are longitudinal mucosal tears that may cross the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ). F rceful retching or vomiting along with failure of reflex relaxation of the gastroesophageal musculature results in tears involving the mucosa and submucosa. It usually occurs secondary t conditions like acute alcohol intoxication or hyperemesis gravidarum. Boerhaave syndrome is a much more serious disorder characterized by transmural rupture of the distal esophagus. This results in acute mediastinitis with severe chest pain, tachypnea, and shock. Such patients generally require urgent surgical intervention.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most frequent cause of esophagitis?
explanation: The most frequent cause of esophagitis is reflux of gastric acid into the lower esophagus. The most common cause of gastroesophageal reflux is transient lower esophageal sphincter relaxation. Reflux esophagitis leads to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). This can cause Barrett's esophagus and eventually can cause adenocarcinoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which organism can cause esophageal infections in healthy individuals?
explanation: Esophagitis in healthy individuals can be caused by the Herpes simplex virus. However, it is relatively uncommon. In immunosuppressed individuals, infections can be caused by: Herpes simplex virus Cytomegalovirus Candida
subject: Pathology

question_text: Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus are caused by:
explanation: Infection with Herpes simplex virus (HSV) typically results in punched-out ulcers in the esophagus. HSV esophagitis commonly occurs in immunocompromised patients. For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer. The following microscopic findings are noted: Ballooning degeneration Ground-glass changes in nuclei Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies Note: CMV esophagitis causes shallow ulcerations. The biopsy is taken from the base of the ulcer and shows characteristic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions bodies.

question_text: A 2•-year-old patient with haematemesis is found to have the following finding on upper GI endoscopy. He has traveled to Zambia several times over the past 3 years. What could be the likely cause of this condition?
explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing bleeding esophageal varices are suggestive of hepatic schistosomiasis. It is the second most common cause of varices worldwide. Liver cirrhosis, mostly in association with alcoholic liver disease, is the most common cause of varices.
subject: Pathology

question_text: All are true about Barrett oesophagus except:
options: Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD
Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma
explanation: Barrett's esophagus increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma, not squamous cell carcinoma. Barrett's esophagus is a complication of GERD and it is estimated to occur in as many as 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD. Microscopically, it is seen as the replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells (intestinal metaplasia). question_text: Which of the following statements is false?
options: The most common site of extranodal lymphoma in GIT is the esophagus
The most common benign tumour of esophagus is leimyoma
The most common esophageal cancer overall is squamous cell carcinoma
The most common esophageal cancer in Western countries is adenocarcinoma
explanation: The most common site of extranodal lymphoma in GIT is the stomach, not the esophagus.

question_text: Which of the following is not a predisposing factor for esophageal cancer?
explanation: Mediastinal fibrosis does not predispose to esophageal carcinoma. Risk factors for esophageal carcinoma include the following: Alcohol and tobacco use Poverty Caustic alkali burns Diverticula Achalasia Tylosis Plummer–Vinson syndrome Frequent consumption of very hot beverages Radiation exposure to the mediastinum Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection - squamous cell carcinomas

question_text: A patient with recurrent gastritis has been diagnosed with Helicobacter pylori infection. Which of the following is true in this patient?
options: Increased risk of adenocarcinoma of esophagus
Decreased risk of adenocarcinoma of esophagus
Increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma of esophagus
Decreased risk of squamous cell carcinoma of esophagus
explanation: Helicobacter pylori infection is associated with decreased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma. Long-standing H. pylori gastritis (chronic inflammation) causes multifocal gastric mucosal atrophy, which in turn leads to reduced parietal cell mass, acid secretion. This leads to reduced incidence of Barrett's esophagus and decreased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma. H. pylori infection, however, increases the risk of gastric adenocarcinoma.

Endoscopic and barium swallow images of a lesion in the oesophagus of a patient are as shown below. What is the expected histopathological finding?

Image 2
Image 1
Image 4
explanation: The given images showing an esophageal exophytic growth on endoscopy and apple core appearance in the middle 1/3 of the esophagus on barium swallow are suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma.
