question_text: A 3-weeks-old baby presents with projectile non-bilious vomiting after every meal. Abdominal examination reveals prominent peristalsis in the epigastrium and an olive-sized mass is felt on deep palpation of the right upper abdomen. Which of the following drug exposures is associated with this condition?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. It is associated with exposure to azithromycin. Risk factors for congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Turner syndrome Trisomy 18 Erythromycin or azithromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life either orally or via mother's milk. Hyperplasia of the pyloric muscularis propria obstructs the gastric outflow tract. It is three to five times more common in males. Generally presents between 3rd and 6th weeks of life as new-onset regurgitation, projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding. Physical examination reveals a firm, ovoid, 1 to 2 cm abdominal mass. In some cases, abnormal left to right hyperperistalsis is seen. Treatment is the surgical splitting of the muscularis (Ramstedt pyloromyotomy).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Endoscopy of a patient with chronic upper gastrointestinal bleeding showed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The endoscopy findings of the watermelon stomach are suggestive of gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE). In GAVE, endoscopy reveals longitudinal stripes of edematous erythematous mucosa that alternate with less severely injured, paler mucosa giving the appearance of watermelon. GAVE is responsible for 4% of non-variceal upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Dieulafoy lesion is a non-stress-related cause of GI bleeding. It is due to a submucosal artery that does not branch properly within the wall of the stomach. It is shown in the image below.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 60-year-old man with hypertension and diabetes mellitus is on dialysis for chronic renal failure. Which of the following forms of gastritis is the patient at risk of development?
explanation: Patients with renal failure develop acute gastritis as a consequence of uremia. In uremia, gastric injury is due to inhibition of gastric bicarbonate transporters by ammonium ions. Causes of acute gastritis: Alcohol Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) Smoking Ischemia/shock Steroid use Uremia Chemical ingestion Stress Histologically, the presence of neutrophils above the basement membrane in direct contact with epithelial cells signifies acute gastritis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common cause of chronic gastritis?
explanation: The most common cause of chronic gastritis is infection with the bacillus Helicobacter pylori. Causes of chronic gastritis: Helicobacter pylori - 1st most common Autoimmune gastritis - 2nd most common Radiation injury Chronic bile reflux Mechanical injury (e.g., an indwelling nasogastric tube) Systemic diseases such as Crohn disease, amyloidosis Graft-versus-host disease Options B and C: Acid hypersecretion and alcohol ingestion are the causes of acute gastritis. Note: Autoimmune gastritis is the most common cause of diffuse atrophic gastritis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcers underwent an upper GI endoscopic biopsy of the stomach. The biopsy was stained with a special stain as shown in the image. Identify the special stain used.
explanation: The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the Helicobacter pylori bacilli. On antral biopsy, H. pylori organisms are seen abundantly within the surface mucus layer, but they are difficult to visualize with routine hematoxylin (H&E) stains. Organisms are most easily demonstrated with special stains like Warthin-Starry silver stain or Giemsa stain. The image given below is GI biopsy stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain. The below image is a Giemsa stain showing Helicobacter pylori in a case of chronic gastritis.

question_text:
A 34-year-old man presents with nausea and upper abdominal pain. He experiences vague discomfort mostly in the afternoon and night, which is relieved by food. The urea breath test is positive. Upper GI endoscopy reveals a small ulcer with a clean base in the duodenum.
From which of the following sites should the biopsy be taken to confirm the diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of H. pylori gastritis. The preferred site for biopsy is the antrum as H. pylori are most often found in the antrum of the stomach. H. pylori display tropism for gastric epithelia and are generally not found in the duodenal epithelium. Long-standing H. pylori gastritis may extend to involve the body and fundus, resulting in patchy mucosal atrophy. The below image is a Warthin-Starry silver stain showing Helicobacter pylori colonized on the surface of the regenerative epithelium of the antrum.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In patients with autoimmune gastritis, what part of the stomach is least likely to get involved?
explanation: Autoimmune gastritis typically spares the antrum. Autoimmune gastritis causes diffuse mucosal damage of the acid-producing mucosa, within the body and fundus. It accounts for less than 10% of cases of chronic gastritis. CD4+T cells directed against parietal cell components, including the H+/K+ ATPase, are considered to be the principal agents of injury in autoimmune gastritis. Characteristic features of autoimmune gastritis: Antibodies to parietal cells and intrinsic factor Reduced serum pepsinogen I concentration Hypergastrinemia Endocrine cell hyperplasia leads to carcinoid tumors Vitamin B12 deficiency (pernicious anemia) Defective gastric acid secretion (achlorhydria)
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common site of peptic ulcers?
explanation: The most common site of peptic ulcer is the anterior wall of the proximal duodenum, within a few centimeters of the pyloric valve. Gastric peptic ulcers are predominantly located along the lesser curvature near the interface of the body and antrum. Locations of peptic ulcers (in decreasing order of frequency): Duodenum (first part) Stomach (lesser curvature near the junction of body and antrum) Gastroesophageal junction in gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or Barrett’s esophagus Margins of jejunostomy Stomach, duodenum, and/or jejunum in patients with Zollinger–Ellison syndrome Ileal Meckel’s diverticulum containing ectopic gastric mucosa The below image shows a peptic ulcer with a round to oval, sharply punched-out defect, and clean mucosal margin
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 55-year-old man presents with periodic abdominal pain. The pain is associated with meals and is relieved by antacids. Physical examination is unremarkable. Endoscopy shows a mucosal ulcer. What is the most common complication of this condition?
explanation: The most common complication of peptic ulcers is bleeding. An ulcer on the posterior wall of the duodenum causes bleeding from the gastroduodenal artery. Gastric ulcer on the lesser curvature of the stomach causes bleeding from the left gastric artery. Other complications are perforation, obstruction, and malignant transformation. Note: The most common cause of death in peptic ulcers is perforation followed by bleeding. Perforation accounts for two-thirds of ulcer deaths.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 26-year-old man with severe burns is most likely at risk of developing which of the following ulcers?
explanation: Curling's ulcers are associated with severe burns or trauma. Curling's ulcers occur in the proximal duodenum. Systemic hypotension or reduced blood flow caused by stress-induced splanchnic vasoconstriction results in gastric mucosal injury. Note: Cushing's ulcers arise in individuals with intracranial disease. They occur in the stomach, uodenum, and esophagus and carry a high incidence of perforation.
subject: Pathology

question_text: The upper gastrointestinal endoscopy of a patient is shown below. Excessive secretion of which of the following is associated with this condition?
explanation: The given endoscopy image showing irregular enlargement of the gastric rugae in the body is suggestive of Ménétrier disease. It is due to excessive secretion of transforming growth factor  (TGF-). Menetrier disease is one of the causes of hypertrophic gastropathy. It is associated with diffuse hyperplasia of the foveolar epithelium and hypoproteinemia due to protein-losing enteropathy. There is an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma in adults. Below histological image shows hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cystically dilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Fundic gland polyps are associated with which of the following conditions?
explanation: Fundic gland polyps are associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). Fundic gland polyps may also occur sporadically or with proton pump inhibitor use. They occur in the gastric body and fundus. They may be asymptomatic or associated with nausea, vomiting, or epigastric pain. Dysplasia and neoplasia may occur in FAP-associated fundic gland polyps. Another gastric polyp associated with FAP is gastric adenoma. The below histological image of fundic gland polyp shows cystically dilated, irregular glands lined by flattened parietal and chief cells. Inflammation is typically absent or minimal.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common site of gastric adenoma?
explanation: The most common site of gastric adenoma is the antrum. Gastric adenomas are premalignant neoplastic lesions. Patients are usually between 50 and 60 years of age. Males are affected three times more often than females. The majority of adenomas are composed of intestinal-type columnar epithelium that exhibits varying° of dysplasia.
subject: Pathology

question_text: All are predisposing factors for the development of gastric adenoma except:
explanation: Zollinger–Ellison syndrome is not a predisposing factor for the development of gastric adenoma. It may predispose to carcinoid tumors. Risk factors for gastric adenoma: Chronic gastritis with atrophy Intestinal metaplasia Familial adenomatous polyposis The risk of adenocarcinoma in gastric adenomas is particularly increased in lesions greater than 2 cm in diameter. Overall, carcinoma may be present in up to 30% of gastric adenomas.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which germline loss-of-function mutation is strongly associated with patients diagnosed with familial gastric cancer?
explanation: Familial gastric cancer (diffuse type) is strongly associated with germline loss-of-function mutations in the tumor suppressor gene CDH1. It encodes the cell adhesion protein, E-cadherin. Half of the sporadic diffuse gastric cancer cases occur due to loss-of-function mutations in CDH1. In the remaining cases, E-cadherin expression is decreased, due to hypermethylation and silencing of the CDH1promoter. Thus, the loss of E-cadherin is a key step in the development of diffuse gastric cancer. Sporadic intestinal-type gastric cancers are strongly associated with increased signaling via the Wnt pathway (loss-of-function mutation of APC/gain-of-function mutation of  -catenin). Mutation of TP53 is also found in the majority of sporadic gastric cancers of both types.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Linitis plastica is seen in which of the following?
explanation: Linitis plastica or leather bottle stomach or Brintons's disease is seen in diffuse gastric cancer. Diffuse gastric cancer is an infiltrative tumor and often evokes a desmoplastic reaction that stiffens the gastric wall. When there are large areas of infiltration, diffuse rugal flattening and a rigid, thickened wall may impart a leather bottle appearance as shown below.
subject: Pathology

question_text: All are true about diffuse gastric cancer except:
explanation: The diffuse-type gastric adenocarcinoma does not form bulky tumors. It grows in a diffuse infiltrating pattern that stiffens the gastric wall (linitis plastica). In contrast, the intestinal type tends to form bulky masses. Loss of E-cadherin is the key step in the development of diffuse gastric cancer, resulting in discohesive cells. These single cells have large, intracytoplasmic mucin vacuoles that push the nucleus to the periphery, creating a signet-ring cell morphology. Mutation of TP53 is found in a majority of sporadic gastric cancers of both diffuse and intestinal types. The below H&E-stained smear shows normal gastric mucosa (red arrow) and the characteristic signet cells (green arrows) in a patient with diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma. Note: Loss of E cadherin is also seen in lobular carcinoma of the breast.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 55-year-old woman with severe unintentional weight loss was found to have gastric cancer. This cancer is least likely to metastasize to which of the following sites?
explanation: Right axillary lymph nodes are least likely to be involved in gastric cancer metastasis. Sites most commonly involved in gastric cancer metastasis include the following: Supraclavicular sentinel lymph node (Virchow node) Periumbilical nodes (Sister Mary Joseph nodule) Left axillary lymph node (Irish node) Ovary (Krukenberg tumor) Pouch of Douglas (Blumer shelf)
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common translocation seen in patients with gastric MALToma?
explanation: The most common translocation in gastric MALToma is t(11;18)(q21;q21). Three translocations are associated with gastric MALToma: t(11;18)(q21;q21) - Most common t(1;14)(p22;q32) t(14;18)(q32;q21)
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 68-year-old woman with long-standing chronic gastritis undergoes an endoscopic biopsy. The biopsy showed dense lymphocytic infiltration with lymphoepithelial lesions in the gastric glands. The cells of this tumor are likely to express all of the following markers except:
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of gastric MALToma. The tumor cells express the B-cell markers CD19 and CD20. They do not express CD5 or CD10. They are positive for CD43 in about 25% of cases, a T-cell marker that can be diagnostically helpful.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is least likely to be secreted by gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors?
explanation: Gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors can secrete all of the above-mentioned secretory products except noradrenaline. Carcinoid products at different sites: Stomach - Histamine, somatostatin, serotonin Duodenum - Gastrin, somatostatin, cholecystokinin Jejunum and ileum - Serotonin, substance P, polypeptide YY Colon - Serotonin, polypeptide YY.
subject: Pathology

question_text: At which site are the most aggressive carcinoid tumors of the gastrointestinal system seen?
explanation: The most aggressive carcinoid tumors of the GIT are seen in the jejunum and ileum. Carcinoid tumors occur throughout the GI tract. The most common site is the appendix followed by the ileum and rectum. Ileal carcinoid with metastasis to the liver cause carcinoid syndrome because the vasoactive substances escape the filtering actions of the liver. This is characterized by cutaneous flushing, sweating, bronchospasm, colicky abdominal pain, diarrhea, and right-sided cardiac valvular fibrosis. The behavior of the carcinoid tumors differs according to their location: Foregut carcinoid tumor Stomach; duodenum, proximal to the ligament of Treitz; and esophagus Gastric carcinoid tumors originate from gastric enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells Well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors Variable behavior Rarely metastasize and are generally cured by resection Gastric carcinoid tumors without predisposing factors are often more aggressive Midgut carcinoid tumor Arise in the jejunum and ileum Often multiple Tend to be aggressive Hindgut carcinoi Arise in the appendix and colorectum Appendiceal tumors are usually < 2 cm in diameter and are almost always benign Metastasis of rectal carcinoid tumors is uncommon Gastric carcinoid tumors may be associated with endocrine cell hyperplasia, autoimmune chronic atrophic gastritis, MEN-I, and Zollinger–Ellison syndrome.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 50-year-old woman presents with complaints of abdominal pain and diarrhea. On examination, her face appears flushed and her pulse is 120/min. Increased levels of 5-HIAA
are observed in a 24-hour urinary sample. Which of the following is not a prognostic factor for this condition?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of carcinoid tumors. The most important prognostic factors include the degree of histological differentiation, mitotic rate, and Ki-67 proliferative index. The diagnosis of carcinoid tumor is made by increased levels of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) in a 24-hour urine sample. It is positive in larger tumors or if metastases are present. Note: The most important prognostic factor for esophageal carcinoma and stomach carcinoma is the depth of invasion.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 62-year-old man underwent resection of a localized gastrointestinal tumor arising from the stomach. Histopathological examination showed a gain-of-function mutation in the KIT gene and positivity for CD117 and CD34. What is the most likely origin of the tumor?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). It arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal, or pacemaker cells, of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria. It is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen. The peak age of incidence is 60 years. In sporadic GIST, the most common mutations seen are gain-of-function mutation in KIT (75-80%) and PDGFRA mutation (8%). Inherited/germline GIST is seen in Carney–Stratakis syndrome. It is due to loss-of-function mutation of SDH which has increased risk for GIST and paraganglioma. GIST at a younger age is associated with the following: Carney triad: Gastric GIST Paraganglioma Pulmonary chondroma Neurofibromatosis type 1 Grossly, it usually forms a solitary, well-circumscribed, fleshy mass covered by ulcerated or intact mucosa. Histologically, the tumor is composed of spindle cells (most common), epithelioid cells, or mixed cell types. The below image shows microscopy of GIST composed of bundles, or fascicles, of spindle-shaped tumor cells Complete surgical resection is the primary treatment for localized gastric GIST. Imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat CML, can be used to treat GIST with mutations in KIT or PDGFRA.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most specific marker for a gastrointestinal stromal tumor?
explanation: The most specific marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) is DOG-1. KIT (CD117) is the best diagnostic marker (most sensitive marker) of GIST. However, 5–10% of GIST lack KIT expression. DOG-1 is expressed in all GIST, including CD117-negative cases. Hence, DOG-1 marker is most specific for GIST.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is an epithelial tumor of the stomach?
explanation: Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor of the stomach. Adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy (90% cases) of the stomach. Option A: Carcinoid tumor is a neuroendocrine tumor. Option B: Lymphoma is a lymphoid tumor. Option C: GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
The absence of the structure marked as A will present with all except:

Pernicious anemia
explanation: The eosinophilic appearing cells marked as A are the parietal cells, the absence of which is not associated with Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome. The cells marked as B are Chief cells. Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome is caused by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors, which leads to parital cell hyperplasia. Gastrinomas are almost always found in the small intestine or pancreas. The most remarkable feature found in the stomach is an increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia. Other options: Option A and C: Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies that impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF) that is released from the parietal cells, which is required for the uptake of vitamin B12. There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include: Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intrinsic factor (IF). Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors. Autoantibody type III acts against the  and  subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factor. These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells, and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells. Option B: Gastric carcinoid tumors originate from gastric enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells. They are referred to as well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors. The peak incidence of carcinoid tumors is in the 6th decade. These tumors occur throughout the GI tract, most commonly in the appendix, ileum, and rectum, in decreasing order of frequency. Gastric carcinoid tumors may be associated with endocrine cell hyperplasia, autoimmune chronic atrophic gastritis, MEN-I, and Zollinger–Ellison syndrome. Ileal carcinoid may cause carcinoid syndrome which is characterized by cutaneous flushing, sweating, bronchospasm, colicky abdominal pain, diarrhea, and right-sided cardiac valvular fibrosis. Small Intestine
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common cause of intestinal obstruction in children younger than 2 years of age?
explanation: The most common cause of intestinal obstruction in children < 2 years of age is intussusception. Intussusception occurs when a segment of the intestine, constricted by a wave of peristalsis, telescopes into the immediately distal segment. It is usually idiopathic at younger ages. However, it can be associated with viral infections and rotavirus vaccines, perhaps due to reactive hyperplasia of Peyer patches. Untreated intussusception may progress to intestinal obstruction, compression of mesenteric vessels, and infarction. Note: The most common form of congenital intestinal atresia is imperforate anus. It occurs due to failure of the cloacal diaphragm to involute.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old man presented with a history of long-standing diarrhea. Serologic evaluation showed positive anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. Duodenal biopsy showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. Which of the following HLA alleles is associated with this condition?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of celiac disease or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. It is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 alleles. It is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by the ingestion of gluten-containing foods such as barley, rye, oats, and wheat (mnemonic: BROW) in genetically predisposed individuals. In these individuals, digestion of the gluten-containing diet leads to the formation of gliadin peptides. These peptides result in the following immune reactions: They can activate the epithelial cells to express certain cytokines (IL-15), which result in CD8+ T cell proliferation They undergo deamidation and interact with HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 on the antigen-presenting cells. This leads to CD4+ T cell stimulation and further cytokine production These mechanisms result in epithelial tissue damage. Antibodies associated with celiac disease are: Anti-gliadin antibodies Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-ttG) Anti-endomysial antibodies Microscopic findings include: Villi atrophy and flattening Crypt hyperplasia Increased intraepithelial T cells
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 34-year-old male patient presented to the clinic with a history of diarrhea and poor appetite. He has been having 4-5 episodes of non-bloody, loose stools per day for the last 3 months. A duodenal biopsy is taken and the histopathology is as shown below. Which of the following is the most common cancer associated with this condition?
explanation: The given scenario and histopathology findings are suggestive of celiac disease. Enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma is the most common cancer associated with celiac disease. Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also associated with celiac disease. Celiac disease or celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy is triggered by the ingestion of gluten, which is the major storage protein of wheat and similar grains. It usually affects the 2nd part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum. Antibodies associated with celiac disease are: Anti-gliadin antibodies Anti tissue transglutaminase antibodies Anti endomysial antibodies MARSH's score is used to assess celiac disease histologically. Dermatitis herpetiformis occurs in about 10% of patients with celiac disease.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Malabsorption is not due to intestinal mucosal defects in which of the following disorders?
explanation: In cystic fibrosis, malabsorption occurs due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, not intestinal mucosal defects. Cystic fibrosis is caused by pathogenic mutations in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7 that encodes the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein. The absence of CFTR protein interferes with Na+, HCO3-, and water secretion resulting in defective luminal hydration. This causes the formation of pancreatic intraductal concretions and causes exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 33-year-old man presented to the ER with severe abdominal pain. He gives a history of fever for the past 2 weeks. On examination, faint salmon-colored macules were noted on the trunk and abdomen. Which of the following diseases would you suspect?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of faint salmon-colored macules is suggestive of rose spots that are seen in typhoid fever. Rose spots are small erythematous maculopapular lesions that are seen on the chest and abdomen. In the second week of illness, abdominal pain develops and rose spots may be seen, as shown in the following image. Note: Typhoid ulcers are oval ulcers oriented along the axis of the ileum and carry the risk of perforation. They usually develop in the 3rd week of typhoid.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following phases is impaired in patients diagnosed with Whipple's disease?
explanation: In Whipple's disease, the cause of malabsorption is impaired lymphatic transport. In Whipple disease, clinical symptoms occur because organism-laden macrophages accumulate within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes, causing lymphatic obstruction. These bacteria-laden macrophages also accumulate within mesenteric lymph nodes, synovial membranes of affected joints, cardiac valves, brain. The clinical presentation of Whipple disease is usually a triad of diarrhea, weight loss, and arthralgia.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive man is referred for evaluation of malabsorption. A duodenal biopsy shows the following finding. Which special stain can be used further to confirm the diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing distended foamy macrophages inside the lamina propria are characteristic of Whipple's disease. The diagnosis can be confirmed by acid-fast staining. Distended foamy macrophages inside the lamina propria of the duodenum can be seen in: Whipple's disease Intestinal tuberculosis, particularly in immunocompromised hosts As both organisms are PAS-positive, PAS staining cannot differentiate between the two diseases. On the other hand, acid-fast staining can be used to confirm the diagnosis, as only mycobacteria are acid fast, whereas Tropheryma whipplei is not.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 2-year-old boy was brought by his parents with complaints of vomiting, watery diarrhea, and fever. A rapid ELISA test for rotavirus was positive. Which of the following viral proteins causes damage to the intestinal epithelium?
explanation: Rotavirus damages the intestinal epithelium by a viral factor called non-structural protein 4 (NSP4), which can induce epithelial apoptosis. Rotavirus is a common cause of severe childhood diarrhea and diarrheal mortality worldwide. Rotavirus selectively infects and destroys mature enterocytes in the small intestine. This causes repopulation of the villus surface by immature secretory cells.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common parasitic pathogen in humans?
explanation: Giardia lamblia is the most common parasitic pathogen in humans. The following image shows teardrop (pear)-shaped Giardia with paired nuclei:
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 55-year-old man who presented with diarrhea and flushing was found to have an ileal tumor. The histological image of the resected specimen is given below. Which of the following markers will these cells be positive for?
explanation: The given history and histological image are diagnostic of ileal carcinoid. The tumor cells are typically positive for synaptophysin on immunohistochemistry. Histology of carcinoid typically reveals islands and nests of uniform cells with scant, pink granular cytoplasm and salt and pepper chromatin. Electron microscopy reveals cytoplasmic dense-core neurosecretory granules. Carcinoid tumors most commonly occur in the gastrointestinal tract. The most common sites in decreasing order of frequency are the appendix, ileum, and rectum. These tumors may cause carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by cutaneous flushing, sweating, bronchospasm, colicky abdominal pain, diarrhea, and right-sided cardiac valvular fibrosis. Immunohistochemical (IHC) markers for carcinoid tumors are: Neuron-specific enolase Synaptophysin Chromogranin A Leu 7
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 10 month old infant is brought to the OPD with complaints of intractable diarrhea. His past history is significant for autoimmune thyroiditis. On examination, eczematous rashes were seen on the chest and back. Sequencing of which of the following genes would help to arrive at a definitive diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of autoimmune enteropathy or IPEX syndrome. Definitive diagnosis requires gene sequencing to identify mutations in the FOXP3 gene. FOXP3 is a transcription factor expressed in CD4+ regulatory T cells. Autoimmune enteropathy is an X-linked disorder characterized by severe persistent diarrhea and autoimmune disease in young children. A particularly severe familial form is termed IPEX an acronym denoting immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, and X-linked inheritance. The classic presentation of IPEX is a triad of: Failure to thrive with severe chronic diarrhea due to an autoimmune enteropathy Autoimmune endocrinopathy (neonatal type 1 diabetes or thyroiditis) Dermatitis (usually eczematous)
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 7-day-old infant was brought with complaints of profuse watery diarrhea and severe dehydration. On detailed evaluation, labs showed metabolic acidosis and electron microscopy of small bowel biopsy showed characteristic intracellular microvillus inclusions. Mutations in which of the following genes is associated with this condition?
Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of microvillus inclusion disease (MVID) which is associated with MYO5B gene mutations. Microvillus inclusion disease or Davidson disease is an autosomal recessive disorder due to mutations of MYO5B gene. This gene encodes a motor protein that is required for the transport of normal nutrients, ions, water, and plasma membrane components. Hence, it leads to defective vesicular transport that causes deficient brush-border assembly. Clinical features of MVID are: Profuse watery, secretory diarrhea - before 3 months of age (often in the first few days of life) Metabolic acidosis Hypotonic dehydration Diagnosis of MVID include: Electron microscopy - Inclusion containing microvilli in the apical cytoplasm of the intestinal cells. Brush border microvilli are poorly developed with only a few/blunted microvilli Immunostaining of villin (the brush border protein) CD10 immunohistochemistry to detect microvillus inclusions Treatment is total parenteral nutrition and small bowel transplantation. The following electron microscopy image shows characteristic intracytoplasmic inclusions that are lined by intact microvilli along the absorptive surfaces of the intestinal cells. Large Intestine - Non-Neoplastic Conditions
subject: Pathology

question_text: Match the following conditions with their most commonly involved sites.
explanation: The most common sites of the following conditions are: A true diverticulum is a blind outpouching of the alimentary tract that communicates with the lumen and includes all three layers of the bowel wall. The most common true diverticulum is Meckel's diverticulum. It most commonly occurs in the ileum. It occurs as a result of the failed involution of the vitelline duct, which connects the lumen of the developing gut to the yolk sac. The following image shows a Meckel's diverticulum. Condition Site 1. True diverticulum B. Ileum 2. Acquired diverticulu m D. Sigmoid colo n 3. Crohn's disease A. Terminal ileu m 4. Polyps C. Colorectum On the other hand, false or acquired diverticula either lack the muscularis entirely or have an attenuated muscularis propria. Though Crohn's disease most commonly occurs in the terminal ileum, it may occur in any area of the GI tract. Polyps are most common in the colorectal region. They can be sessile (without stalk) or pedunculated (with stalk). Intestinal polyps can be classified as non-neoplastic or neoplastic in nature. The nonneoplastic polyps can be further classified as inflammatory, hamartomatous, or hyperplastic. The most common neoplastic polyp is an adenoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease?
options: Failure of migration of neural crest cells
explanation: Hirschsprung disease occurs due to the failure of migration of the neural crest cells to the bowel wall. During normal embryogenesis, the neural crest cells migrate from the caecum to the rectum. The enteric neuronal plexuses develop from these migrated neural crest cells. In Hirschsprung disease, there is an arrest in the migration of these cells, which leads to the development of a distal intestinal segment that is devoid of Meissner (submucosal) and the Auerbach (myenteric) plexus. Hence this segment is referred to as the aganglionic segment. As a result, there is a lack of coordination in the peristaltic contractions and functional obstruction, which further leads to the dilation of the intestine proximal to the affected segment, leading to congenital megacolon. Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating the absence of ganglion cells in biopsy sections. Some conditions may cause acquired megacolon. These include: Chagas disease, due to the loss of ganglion cells Visceral myopathy Obstruction by neoplasm or inflammatory stricture Toxic megacolon complicating ulcerative colitis Functional psychosomatic disorders
subject: Pathology

question_text: A male infant, with a history of not passing meconium, presented with abdominal distension 2 days after birth. Barium enema showed marked colonic dilation above a narrow segment in the sigmoid region. A biopsy specimen from the narrowed region demonstrated absence of ganglion cells. This disease may be associated with which of the following conditions?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. It is associated with Down's syndrome. Hirschsprung disease is also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon. 10% of all cases occur in children with Down's syndrome. The premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum produces aganglionosis of the distal intestinal segment. This causes functional obstruction of the affected bowel and proximal dilation. The absence of ganglion cells in the affected segment in biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Gastrointestinal abnormalities associated with Down's syndrome include: Duodenal atresia Annular pancreas Hirschsprung disease Gastrointestinal abnormalities associated with Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18) include: Meckel's diverticulum Malrotation Gastrointestinal abnormalities associated with Patau syndrome (trisomy 13) include: Omphalocele Incomplete rotation of the colon Meckel's diverticulum
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common site of volvulus?
explanation: The most common site of volvulus is the sigmoid colon. The twisting of a loop of the bowel about its mesenteric point of attachment is termed volvulus. Segments involved in volvulus in the decreasing order of frequency are: Sigmoid colon Cecum Small bowe Stomach Transverse colon
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common site of gastrointestinal ischemia?
explanation: The most common site of gastrointestinal ischemia is the colon. Intestinal segments at the end of their respective arterial supplies are particularly susceptible to ischemia. These are termed watershed zones. These include: Splenic flexure - where the superior and inferior mesenteric arterial circulations terminate Junction of sigmoid colon and rectum - where the inferior mesenteric, pudendal, and iliac arterial circulations end
subject: Pathology

question_text: Campylobacter infection can result in all of the following complications except:
explanation: Aplastic crisis is associated with parvovirus infection, not Campylobacter infection. Campylobacter infection can cause: Reactive arthritis, primarily in patients with HLA-B27 Erythema nodosum Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS) Molecular mimicry has been implicated in the pathogenesis of GBS because serum antibodies to Campylobacter jejuni lipopolysaccharide crossreact with peripheral and central nervous system gangliosides.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A pathologist is examining the following histopathological specimen from a patient with watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given histopathological image shows superficially damaged crypts with a typical pattern of mucopurulent exudates (neutrophils) emanating from a crypt that resembles a volcanic eruption. This is pathognomonic of Clostridium difficile colitis. In this condition, disruption of the normal colonic microbiota by antibiotics allows C. difficile overgrowth. Risk factors for Clostridium difficile colitis are: Antibiotic use Advanced age Gastric suppression- PPIs, H2 receptor blockers Immunosuppression
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 30-year-old man presented with loose stools and right lower abdominal pain for the past 6 months. Endoscopy was done which showed skip lesions with a cobblestone appearance.
Histopathological examination showed aphthoid ulcerations and focal crypt abscesses. Which of the following genes is associated with this condition?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease. It is strongly associated with mutations in the nucleotide oligomerization binding domain 2 (NOD2) gene. Crohn's disease occurs due to the host response against microbes. NOD2 encodes an intracellular protein that binds to bacterial peptidoglycans and activates the NF-B pathway. Antibodies against the bacterial protein flagellin may be seen in NOD2-associated disease. Other Crohn's disease-related genes are autophagy-related 16-like (ATG16L1), and immunity-related GTPase M (IRGM), which are critical for cellular responses to intracellular bacteria. Crohn's disease most commonly involves the terminal ileum but can affect all parts of the GIT. The following microscopic changes may be seen: Aphthoid ulcerations Focal crypt abscesses Non-caseating granulomas can be found in all layers of the bowel, lymph nodes, mesentery, peritoneum, liver, and pancreas Note: Ulcerative colitis-associated genes are ECM1 and HNFA.
subject: Pathology

question_text: An endoscopy was performed on a patient who presented with lower abdominal pain and severe diarrhea. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
explanation: The given scenario along with cobblestone appearance on endoscopy is suggestive of Crohn's disease. This condition is associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis, not primary biliary cirrhosis. Extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn's disease include the following: Uveitis Migratory polyarthritis Sacroiliitis Ankylosing spondylitis Erythema nodosum Clubbing of the fingertips Primary sclerosing cholangitis (less frequently than ulcerative colitis) Cutaneous granulomas form nodules referred to as metastatic Crohn's disease (a misnomer since there is no cancer)
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following gross findings would you see in the resected bowel segment of a patient with ulcerative colitis?
explanation: In ulcerative colitis, regenerating mucosa often bulges into the lumen to create pseudopolyps and the tips of these polyps may fuse to create mucosal bridges. Features characteristic of ulcerative colitis are: Proctocolitis/ backwash ileitis Mucosa and superficial submucosal involvement Broad-based ulcers Pseudopolyps and mucosal bridges Toxic megacolon Note: Granulomas, strictures, and mural thickening are features of Crohn's disease.
subject: Pathology

question_text: ANCA is positive in which of the following conditions?
explanation: Henoch-Schönlein purpura is associated with IgA immune complex deposition in the small vessels, not p-ANCA. The following conditions are positive for perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA): Ulcerative colitis Crohn's disease Churg–Strauss syndrome Microscopic polyangiitis Antibodies Ulcerative colitis Crohn's disease p-ANCA Present in majority (75 %) Present in minority (11 %) Antibodies toSaccharomyces cerevisiae Absent Present
subject: Pathology

question_text: A pathology resident notes flask-shaped ulcers in an intestinal biopsy sample. This is characteristic of infections caused by which of the following?
explanation: Flask-shaped ulcers are characteristic of amoebiasis, which is caused by Entamoeba histolytica. It most often affects the cecum and ascending colon. Parasites may also penetrate splanchnic vessels and embolize to the liver to produce amoebic liver abscesses. Image showing flask-shaped ulcers of amoebiasis: Option A: In TB, ulcers are perpendicular to the axis of the intestine (transverse ulcers). Option B: In typhoid, ulcers are oriented along the axis of the intestine (longitudinal ulcers). Option C: Ulceration is not a feature of giardiasis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Microscopic colitis encompasses which of the following?
explanation: Microscopic colitis encompasses two types of disorders - collagenous colitis and lymphocytic colitis. Lymphocytic colitis shows a strong association between celiac disease and autoimmune diseases, including Graves disease and rheumatoid arthritis. These idiopathic diseases both present with chronic, non-bloody, watery diarrhea without weight loss. Collagenous colitis Lymphocytic colitis Dense subepithelial collagen layer Subepithelial collagen layer i s of normal thickness Increased numbers of intraep ithelial lymphocytes Higher ratio of intraepithelial lymphocytes
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 19-year-old boy with suspected acute appendicitis underwent laparoscopic appendectomy and the resected specimen was sent for histopathological examination. Presence of which of the following is considered confirmatory of this condition?
Neutrophilic infiltration in the mucosa
options: Neutrophilic infiltration of the muscularis propria
Eosinophilic infiltration of the muscularis propria
explanation: The diagnosis of acute appendicitis is confirmed by the presence of neutrophilic infiltration of the muscularis propria. Surgical exploration is done when clinical suspicion for appendicitis is high but imaging studies are negative, nondiagnostic, or unavailable. In such situations, appendicitis can only be diagnosed intraoperatively or pathologically. Large Intestine - Neoplastic Conditions
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common malignancy of the GI tract?
explanation: Adenocarcinoma of the colon is the most common malignancy of the GI tract. Tumors in the proximal colon often grow as polypoid, exophytic masses. These tumors rarely cause obstruction. Carcinomas of the distal colon tend to be annular lesions that produce napkin-ring constrictions and luminal narrowing.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following patients is at an increased risk of developing malignancy?
options: A 40-year-old man with sessile serrated polyps
explanation: Patients with sessile serrated polyps are at an increased risk of developing malignancy. Histologically, sessile serrated polyps appear like hyperplastic polyps, but a serrated architecture throughout the full length of the glands and lateral growth is the differentiating feature. They lack cytological features of dysplasia.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following sites is most commonly involved in patients with juvenile polyps?
explanation: The most common site of juvenile polyps is in the rectum. Juvenile polyps are focal malformations of the epithelium and lamina propria. They may be sporadic or syndromic. They typically present with rectal bleeding in children < 5 years. Sporadic juvenile polyps - solitary lesions, also called retention polyps Juvenile polyposis - autosomal dominant syndrome with multiple hamartomatous polyps that have malignant potential
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp. Juvenile polyps are malformations of epithelium and lamina propria commonly located in the rectum. It is seen in children <5 years of age. The typical presentation is painless rectal bleeding. Sometimes there may be a proliferating rectal mass. The disease may be sporadic or syndromic. Sporadic juvenile polyp occurs as a single mass and is called retention polyp. Juvenile polyposis syndrome is characterized by multiple hamartomatous polyps, which may be premalignant. Morphologically, both of these types are indistinguishable. Gross appearance: They appear as pedunculated, smooth reddish lesions, and with cystic spaces. Microscopic appearance: The cysts appear as dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris. Note: Complex glandular architecture and the presence of smooth muscle cutting through the lamina propria are seen in Peutz-Jeghers polyps.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Patients with which of the following diseases have the highest risk of developing colorectal cancer?
explanation: Patients with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) have the highest risk of developing colorectal cancer. 100% of untreated patients with FAP develop colorectal carcinoma, often before the age of 30 years.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the minimum number of polyps necessary for the diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis?
explanation: The diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) requires 100 polyps. The current definition of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) requires evidence of any one of the below: Germline mutation in APC gene 100 colorectal adenomatous polyps (classical definition) Any colorectal adenomas < 30 years in a patient with a family history of FAP Intra-abdominal desmoid fibromatosis, osteoma of the mandible, or multiple epidermoid cysts in a patient with a family history of FAP Colorectal adenocarcinoma develops in 100% of untreated FAP patients, often before age of 30 years and nearly always by age of 50 years. Attenuated FAP is a less severe form of FAP with the following features: Usually <100 adenomas First appear usually in late childhood Adenomas usually 1 cm until adulthood Adenomas fewer and later Adenomas and carcinomas 60–75% right-sided The mean age of carcinoma is 55 years The following image shows a gross specimen of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP):
subject: Pathology

question_text: Indirect ophthalmoscopy of an infant revealed congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium. This is seen as an extraintestinal manifestation in association with which of the following conditions?
explanation: Classic FAP and Gardner's syndrome are associated with congenital retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) hypertrophy. Congenital hypertrophy of the RPE can be generally detected at birth and is, therefore, an adjunct to the early screening of FAP.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect about Peutz-Jeghers syndrome?
options: It has an autosomal recessive inheritance
Baseline colonoscopy must be done at 20 years of age
There is increased risk of ovarian and uterine cancer
It is associated with loss-of-function mutations in STK11
explanation: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant syndrome. It is commonly associated with germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the gene STK11. It is characterized by: Multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation Increased risk of gastrointestinal and extraintestinal malignancies (including ovarian and uterine cancer) Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy for screening are done at 20 years of age, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 60-year-old man presented with complaints of chronic diarrhea, loss of weight, and hair loss. On examination, pallor, nail atrophy, and abnormal skin pigmentation were noted. On endoscopic evaluation, multiple sessile polyps were visualized in the small bowel and colon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario of intestinal polyps, cutaneous pigmentation, and diarrhea points toward a diagnosis of Cronkhite–Canada syndrome. It is a non-hereditary polyposis syndrome that occurs at a mean age of 50 years. Clinical features include: Diarrhea and abdominal pain Nail atrophy, hair loss, and cutaneous hyperpigmentation Cachexia and anemia Characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the stomach, small intestine, and colon due t abnormalities in the nonpolypoid mucosa
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following acts as the initiating mutation in the majority of sporadic colon cancers?
explanation: The majority of sporadic colon tumors typically include loss of function mutation of APC gene, early in the neoplastic process (the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence). About 10-15% of sporadic colon cancers involve the microsatellite instability pathway, which is associated with DNA mismatch repair defects (Lynch syndrome).
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 70-year-old man with hematochezia and weight loss is diagnosed with colorectal cancer. Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor for this condition?
explanation: The two most important prognostic factors of colorectal cancer are the depth of invasion and the presence of lymph node metastases. The liver is the most common site of metastasis from the colon due to its portal drainage.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 52-year-old lady has just been diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma. On taking history, she revealed that both her mother and her elder sister had been diagnosed with synchronous colorectal and endometrial cancer in their forties. She should be tested for mutations in which of the following genes?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) or Lynch syndrome. She should be tested for mutations in MSH genes. It occurs due to defective DNA mismatch repair. It is caused by inherited mutations in genes that encode proteins responsible for the detection, excision, and repair of errors that occur during DNA replication. They include MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2 or EPCAM genes. It is the most common syndromic cause of colon cancer. It tends to occur at younger ages than sporadic colon cancers and often involves the right colon. Familial clustering of cancers occurs at several sites including: Colorectum, small bowel, and stomach Endometrium and ovary Ureters Brain Hepatobiliary tract and pancreas Skin
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Which of the following is incorrect about tumors of the appendix?
The most common tumor is carcinoid
options: Goblet cell variant of carcinoid is more aggressive
Peritoneal dissemination can result in pseudomyxoma peritonei
explanation: Primary adenocarcinoma of the appendix is usually of mucinous type. Peritoneal dissemination of mucinous tumors can cause pseudomyxoma peritonei. The most common tumor of the appendix is carcinoid tumor. This neoplasm, which is almost always benign, most frequently forms a solid bulbous swelling at the distal tip of the appendix. Goblet cell variant of carcinoid tumor is more aggressive. Congenital anomalies, ARDS, Infections
subject: Pathology

question_text: What are neuroendocrine cells in the bronchial mucosa called?
explanation: Neuroendocrine cells in the bronchial mucosa of the lungs are called Kulchitsky cells. Bronchial mucosa contains a population of neuroendocrine cells that have neurosecretory-type granules and can release a variety of factors including serotonin, calcitonin, and gastrin-releasing peptide (bombesin). The main cell types of the bronchial mucosa are: Clara cells - non-ciliated cuboidal epithelial cells that secrete important defence markers and serve as progenitor cells after injury Type I pneumocytes - seen in the alveolar epithelium and are responsible for gas exchange Type II pneumocytes - seen in the alveolar epithelium and produce surfactants Basal cells Neuroendocrine (Kulchitsky-type) cells Ciliated cells Serous cells Goblet cells
subject: Pathology

question_text: In which of the following are the pores of Kohn located?
explanation: Pores of Kohn (alveolar pores) are seen in the alveolar wall. They are the interalveolar connections that permit the passage of bacteria and exudate between adjacent alveoli. This plays an important role in the pathogenesis of lobar pneumonia. During the gray hepatization phase, fibrin also spreads through these pores. When the lung is partially deflated, collateral ventilation can also occur to some extent through these pores.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is false about alveolar epithelium?
options: Type 1 cells are not involved in surfactant production
Type 1 cells form the lining epithelium of alveoli
Type 2 cells are involved in the repair of the epithelium
Type 2 cells are involved in gaseous exchange
explanation: Type II pneumocytes are not involved in gaseous exchange. They are only involved in repair and surfactant production. Alveolar epithelium is a continuous layer of two cell types: The following image shows types of cells in the alveoli. Type I pneumocytes Type II pneumocytes Flattened, plate-like Rounded The lining epithelium of alve oli (covers 95% of the alveola r surface)Gaseous exchange Synthesize surfactantRepair of the alveolar epitheliumReg eneration of type I cells
subject: Pathology

question_text: Ciliocytophthoria is seen in:
explanation: Ciliocytophthoria refers to the degeneration of ciliated cells. It occurs in viral infections, such as acute respiratory infections. Options B and C: Kartagener syndrome is also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia/ immotile cilia syndrome. It occurs due to a defect in the dynein arm of cilia. It is characterized by the triad of: Sinusitis Situs inversus Bronchiectasis Option D: In cystic fibrosis ciliary ultrastructure remains normal.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common site of foregut cyst?
explanation: Foregut cysts are most often located in the hilum or middle mediastinum. They are the congenital cysts that arise from abnormal detachments of primitive foregut. Foregut cysts are classified as bronchogenic, esophageal, or enteric. The most common type of foregut cyst is bronchogenic cyst. Microscopically, the cyst is lined by ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a reversible disorder?
explanation: Contraction atelectasis is an irreversible disorder. It occurs when focal or generalized pulmonary or pleural fibrosis prevents full lung expansion. Atelectasis refers either to an incomplete expansion of the lungs (neonatal atelectasis) or to the collapse of the previously inflated lung. The main types of atelectasis in adults are: Resorption atelectasis stems from complete obstruction of an airway. Over time, the air is resorbed from the dependent alveoli, which collapse. E.g. mucous plugs, foreign body aspiration Compression atelectasis occurs whenever significant volumes of fluid, tumor, or air accumulate within the pleural cavity. E.g. pneumothorax, pleural effusion. Contraction atelectasis occurs when focal or generalized pulmonary or pleural fibrosis prevents full lung expansion.
subject: Pathology

question_text: An infant born to a diabetic mother develops difficulty in breathing within 30 minutes of birth. Within a few hours, cyanosis becomes evident. Fine rales are heard over both lung fields. A chest x-ray film shows ground-glass picture. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?
options: It is associated with respiratory failure and poor prognosis despite treatment
There is deficiency of surfactant produced by type II alveolar cells
Increased corticosteroid release lower the risk of developing RDS
On microscopy, hyaline membranes with fibrin and necrotic cell debris are seen
explanation: This clinical scenario is characteristic of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) or hyaline membrane disease. With treatment, it rarely leads to respiratory failure and has a good prognosis. The fundamental defect is a deficiency of pulmonary surfactant, produced by type II pneumocytes. Microscopically, the hyaline membranes are largely made up of fibrin admixed with necrotic cell debris. Grossly, the lungs are of normal size, solid, airless, reddish-purple, and they usually sink in water. Corticosteroids help in surfactant production and are given prophylactically to at-risk pregnant women.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A newborn baby born at term was noted to have respiratory distress. Radiography revealed diffuse ground-glass opacities in all lung fields. Exogenous surfactant administration resulted in a brief improvement, but his condition continued to worsen once surfactant therapy was
stopped. Which is the most common genetic mutation associated with this disorder?
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of surfactant dysfunction disorder. It is most commonly caused by mutations of ABCA3 gene. In this disorder, lack of production of surfactant leads to severe respiratory failure in neonates. There is transient improvement with administration of exogenous surfactant, but it worsens once surfactant therapy is stopped. This condition occurs due to mutations in genes encoding proteins involved in surfactant trafficking or secretion such as: ATP binding cassette protein member 3 (ABCA3) Surfactant protein C Surfactant protein B
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the casualty with high-grade fever, dysuria, and flank pain. On examination, she is disoriented with suprapubic and costovertebral angle tenderness. Her BP is 70/40 mm Hg, pulse rate is 130/min, and her temperature is 103 ºF. She becomes increasingly hypoxic after admission and requires ventilation. What is the likely reason for respiratory failure?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of urosepsis. This presentation is likely the result of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or shock lung. It is characterized histologically by diffuse alveolar damage. It is also known as acute lung injury and is clinically characterized by the abrupt onset of significant hypoxemia and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates in the absence of cardiac failure. Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates, known as white-out appearance. The prognosis is poor with mortality up to 40%.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 68-year-old man presented with episodes of shortness of breath and coughing at night that awaken him from sleep. He was diagnosed with COPD 7 years ago. On examination, distended neck veins were observed and S3 was heard on auscultation. Bronchoalveolar lavage of this patient is given below. Identify the marked cells.
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of heart failure. The image shows heart failure cells, which are siderophages or hemosiderin-containing macrophages. They are seen in the alveoli of patients with chronic pulmonary edema. The alveolar walls become thickened and fibrosed. These pigmented macrophages result in a brown induration of the lung. The following image shows siderophages.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A pathologist is examining the following histopathological section of an alveolus. All of the following can be associated with this finding except:
explanation: The given image shows diffuse alveolar damage which is the characteristic histologic finding of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Heart failure is not associated with ARDS. ARDS is characterized by bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and hypoxemia in the absence of heart failure. The causes of ARDS are: Sepsis Diffuse pulmonary infections Infectious - viral, Mycoplasma, and Pneumocystis, miliary tuberculosis Gastric aspiration Mechanical trauma, including head injuries, burns Near-drowning
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following occurs in the stage of gray hepatization in pneumonia?
options: Accumulation of WBCs in the alveoli
Accumulation of RBCs in the alveoli
Accumulation of fibrin in the alveoli
explanation: In the stage of gray hepatization in pneumonia, there is an accumulation of fibrin along with disintegration of RBCs within the alveoli. Bacterial pneumonias can be classified morphologically as: Lobular pneumonia (bronchopneumonia) - patchy consolidation of the lung Lobar pneumonia - consolidation of an entire lobe Stages of lobar pneumonia are as follows: Stages Durati on Description Congestion 1-2 day s RBCs andexudatefluid in the alveoli Red hepatizatio n 2-4 da ys Accumulation ofneutrophils, RBCsandfibrinin the alveoli Gray hepatizati on 4-8 da ys The disintegration of RBCs w ith thepersistenceoffibrinosu ppurativeexudate Resolution 9-10 da ys Most common outcome
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not seen in patients with viral pneumonia?
options: Multinucleate giant cells in the bronchiolar wall
explanation: The predominance of alveolar exudates is a feature of bacterial pneumonia, not viral pneumonia.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 65-year-old HIV-positive man presented with fever and breathlessness for 2 weeks. Imaging shows dense infiltration in the lower lobe and the lung biopsy showed the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo known as owl’s eye appearance. Along with the given clinical scenario, it is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia. CMV is a  -group herpesvirus. It causes the following conditions: Immunocompetent individuals - asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection Neonates - devastating systemic infections Immunosuppressed individuals - serious, life-threatening, disseminated CMV infections of the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis) Option A: Small-cell carcinoma has small cells with scant cytoplasm, salt-and-pepper chromatin with inconspicuous nucleoli. Option C: In cryptococcal infection, encapsulated yeasts are seen on direct microscopy. Option D: Tuberculosis is associated with well-defined epithelioid granuloma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 28-year-old woman underwent an emergency LSCS under general anesthesia to deliver a term, healthy infant. Two hours later, she developed sudden tachypnea, cyanosis, and massive pulmonary edema and died despite resuscitative measures. The histopathological picture of her lung is shown below. What is the likely cause of death?
explanation: The given scenario and image showing massive neutrophilic infiltration are suggestive of Mendelson’s syndrome or aspiration pneumonitis. Mendelson's syndrome is a chemical pneumonitis caused by the aspiration of sterile gastric contents during general anesthesia, especially during pregnancy. The most common cause of maternal mortality associated with general anesthesia is either due to a pulmonary aspiration or a failed endotracheal intubation. The risk factors for Mendelson's syndrome include: Gastric volume > 25 mL (0.4 mL/kg) Gastric pH < 2.5 Incidence of aspiration can be reduced by administration of: Non-particulate antacids like sodium citrate 30-45 minutes prior to intubation H2 receptor antagonists like intravenous ranitidine Metoclopramide 1-2 hours prior to induction Option B: Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is a type of ILD associated with Masson bodies and plugs of loose connective tissue on histology. Option C: CMV pneumonia is associated with the owl's eye appearance on histology. Option D: PCP pneumonia is associated with black-walled cysts on silver staining.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 35-year-old depressed man came with complaints of sudden onset breathlessness, with desaturation. Chest x-ray showed bilateral diffuse infiltrates with predominant involvement of right middle and lower lobes. The patient could not be revived despite treatment. On autopsy, the lungs appeared grossly normal. The histopathology image of the lung is as shown below. Which among the following is the appropriate cause?
explanation: The given histopathological image clearly shows a granuloma with refractile granules indicative of a foreign body. It is seen in aspiration pneumonia due to vegetative matter (such as food). In this condition, the chest x-ray shows bilateral diffuse infiltrates especially in the right middle and lower lobes. Patients with altered sensorium are at high risk (stroke, medications).
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 25-year-old man presented with fever, productive cough, and breathlessness of 2 months duration. CECT chest revealed bilateral upper lobe fibrotic lesions and enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes. Lymph node biopsy revealed the following. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given image shows the presence of granulomas of epithelioid cells with central caseous necrosis and Langhan's giant cells. These findings point towards the diagnosis of tuberculosis. Langhan's giant cells show horseshoe or slipper-shaped arrangements of nuclei.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to several weeks of occasional hemoptysis, weight loss, and fever. He has lost 7 kg over the past 3 months. Sputum culture grows acid-fast bacilli and his chest X-ray is shown below. What is this lesion called?
explanation: The given x-ray of this patient with tuberculosis shows an infraclavicular lesion. It is known as Assmann's focus. Primary tuberculosis occurs on first exposure and involves lower part of upper lobe and upper part of lower lobe. The following findings may be seen: Ghon's focus - focus of infection located subpleurally Ghon's complex - Ghon's focus with lymph node involvement Ranke complex - a calcified Ghon's complex Secondary tuberculosis occurs due to the reactivation of TB. It affects the apex. The following findings may be seen: Puhl's complex - supraclavicular lesion Assmann's complex - infraclavicular lesion Disseminated or miliary tuberculosis is characterised by 1-2 mm disseminated lesions all over the lung. The following findings may be associated: Simon's focus - early hematogenous seeding in the apex of lungs Rich focus - tuberculous caseous foci in brain, meninges and spinal cord
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 61-year-old man presented with fever, night sweats, and weight loss. The patient subsequently died a few weeks later. Gross specimen of the lung is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the gross image showing individual lesions which are small (2-mm) foci of yellow-white consolidation scattered through the lung parenchyma is suggestive of miliary tuberculosis. Miliary tuberculosis (TB) refers to the widespread dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis via hematogenous spread. It occurs when organisms draining through the lymphatics enter the venous blood and circulate back to the lung. Miliary TB may infect any number of organs, including the lungs, liver, and spleen. The adjective 'miliary' is derived from the resemblance of these foci to millet seeds. Mantoux test is negative in miliary TB.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 48-year-old patient with a history of IV drug abuse had presented to the casualty with shortness of breath and fever with chills. Clinical examination had revealed marked hepatosplenomegaly and diffuse rales in all lung fields. His spot HIV test was positive. The admission chest X-ray and a repeat X-ray taken 3 days later are shown below. The patient died a few hours after the 2nd X-ray was taken. Which of the following statements regarding his diagnosis is true?
options: The cause of death likely a malignant pleural effusion
The spread is mostly due to lymphatic dissemination
Pancytopenia may be seen due to infiltration of the bone marrow
It is a form of disseminated extrapulmonary tuberculosis
explanation: The given history, clinical features, and chest X-Ray point towards a diagnosis of miliary tuberculosis. Pancytopenia may be seen due to infiltration of the bone marrow in such cases. The second X-ray shows acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Chest x-ray appearance of ARDS varies depending on the severity and typically appears as bilateral diffuse alveolar opacities with dependent atelectasis in some cases. The opacities may have a patchy ground-glass appearance. The cause of death here is likely ARDS. (option A) In immunodeficient individuals (eg.- patient having HIV), there may occur widespread dissemination of M. tuberculosis, via the hematogenous route (option B) that leads to the seeding of bacteria in various organs (hepatosplenomegaly). This is known as miliary TB. It is a form of disseminated pulmonary tuberculosis, and not extrapulmonary (option D) The risk factors of miliary TB include- Extremes of age Alcohol use Malignancy HIV Corticosteroids Connective tissue disease Renal failure Diabetes, and pregnancy
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 52-year-old woman diagnosed with COVID-19 developed severe shortness of breath and died 5 days after admission. What lung pathology can be expected in this patient on autopsy?
Fibrin thrombi in capillaries
explanation: Diffuse alveolar damage may be seen in patients suffering from COVID-19, on histological analysis. It is the most common lung finding in COVID-19 pneumonia. Other COVID-19 related histopathological changes in the lungs include: Hyaline membrane formation Desquamation of pneumocytes Fibrin deposits in lungs Inflammation with mononuclear cells However, diffuse alveolar damage is not specific to COVID-19. It may be seen in all cases of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) including pneumonia, burns, near drowning, etc. Obstructive and Restrictive lung diseases
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following conditions does not involve the bronchus?
explanation: Emphysema does not involve the bronchus, it involves the acinus. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) includes both emphysema and chronic bronchitis. Other obstructive lung diseases include: Bronchial asthma - characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli Bronchiectasis - destruction of smooth muscle and elastic tissue by chronic necrotizing infections eading to permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles Emphysema Chronic bronchitis Irreversibleenlargementof th e airspaces distal to thetermi nal bronchioledue to wall des truction (without obvious fibr osis) Mucushypersecretion and pe rsistentinflammationin thelar ge airways Patients with this condition a re known aspink puffers Patients with this condition a re known asblue bloaters
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with severe emphysema underwent lung volume reduction surgery. The resected specimen is shown below. What type of emphysema is this?
explanation: The given gross image is characteristic of centriacinar emphysema. In paraseptal emphysema subpleural spaces are mainly affected (shown below). In panacinar emphysema all air spaces within acini are evenly enlarged (shown below).
subject: Pathology

question_text: In patients with COPD, the emphysematous damage is most likely to involve which of the following structures?
explanation: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) usually have centriacinar emphysema which involves respiratory bronchioles. Emphysema is classified into four major types: Centriacinar Panacinar Parasepta Irregular
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old woman with a long history of dyspnea, chronic cough with sputum, and wheezing died of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was not a smoker or an alcoholic. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely to cause the pathological changes shown?
explanation: The above gross specimen shows emphysematous damage involving enlargement of the entire acinus suggestive of panacinar emphysema. It is caused due to alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency. In panacinar (panlobular) emphysema, the acini are uniformly enlarged from the level of the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli. It occurs commonly in the lower zones and in the anterior margins of the lung and is most severe at the bases. The image below shows panacinar emphysema.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 25-year-old man is being evaluated for dyspnea and cough for 2 months. He is not a smoker. Workup revealed emphysematous changes at lung bases. He reports that his father and uncles were diagnosed with liver failure and lung disease at relatively young ages. Where
is the gene encoding the defective protein located?
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of 1-antitrypsin deficiency. The 1-antitrypsin is encoded by the proteinase inhibitor (Pi) locus on chromosome 14. 1-AT is a polymorphic gene located on chromosome 14. It is part of a larger family of structurally unique serine protease inhibitors, referred to as serpins. The most common clinically significant mutation in 1-antitrypsin deficiency is PiZZ. 1-antitrypsin, normally present in serum, tissue fluids, and macrophages is a major inhibitor of proteases (particularly elastase) secreted by neutrophils during inflammation. The absence of 1- antitrypsin activity results in excessive digestion of elastic tissue by elastase. Patients with 1-antitrypsin deficiency have a markedly increased tendency to develop panacinar emphysema.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the normal value of y/x in the following representation?
explanation: In the above image, y/x denotes the ratio of the thickness of the submucosal gland layer to that of the bronchial wall. This is called as Reid index and it is normally 0.4. It is increased in chronic bronchitis. Chronic bronchitis is defined by the presence of a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years. The single most important cause is cigarette smoking. The distinctive features of chronic bronchitis are as follows: Hypersecretion of mucus Hypertrophy of submucosal glands Goblet-cell hyperplasia Inflammation Difference between clinical presentation of emphysema and chronic bronchitis: Predominant Bronchitis Predominant Emphysema Age (year) 40-45 50-75 Dyspnea Mild; late Severe; early Cough Early; copious sputum Late; scanty sputum Infections Common Occasional Respiratory insufficiency Repeated Terminal Cor pulmonale Common Rare; terminal Airway resistance Increased Normal or slightly increased Elastic recoil Normal Low Chest radiograph Prominent vessels; large hear t Hyperinflation; small heart Appearance Blue bloater Pink puffer
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 55-year-old man was brought to the ED with fever, cough with expectoration, and difficulty in breathing for 1 day. He is a chronic smoker and he has had similar progressive symptoms for the last 4 years. Past PFT findings showed reduced FEV1 and increased RV with normal diffusion capacity. Which of the following is the most common organism implicated in this condition?
explanation: The above clinical scenario gives a picture of acute exacerbation of COPD. The most common bacterial cause of acute COPD exacerbation is Haemophilus influenzae. Moraxella is the second most common bacterial cause of acute exacerbation of COPD.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A middle-aged woman presented with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheeze, and chest tightness. Auscultation of the chest revealed bilateral wheeze. Sputum microscopy reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the sputum microscopy showing Charcot–Leyden crystals (arrows in below image), lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma. Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants. Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma: Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows: Charcot–Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic membrane protein called galectin 10 Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles Creola bodies - desquamated epithelial cells Numerous eosinophils Note: The hygiene hypothesis was previously used to explain the development of asthma and other hypersensitivity disorders.
