question_text: A resected specimen of a lung is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image above shows markedly distended bronchi involving the middle and lower lobe of the lung which is seen in bronchiectasis. Bronchiectasis is a suppurative lung disease with abnormal and irreversible dilatation of the bronchi. It is an end-stage condition of various diseases that result in destruction of the bronchial wall and its surrounding supporting tissues. The normal clearing mechanisms are impaired, either due to congenital causes or due to bronchial obstruction. This results in pooling of secretions, secondary infection, and inflammation, often with necrosis, fibrosis, and eventually cystic dilation of airways up to four times the normal size. Note: Kartagener syndrome is a primary ciliary dyskinesia characterized by the classical triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Transbronchial biopsy from a patient showed the following microscopic finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image above shows alveolar spaces filled with balls of fibroblasts (Masson bodies). This is characteristically seen in cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP). Masson bodies are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within alveolar ducts, alveoli, and bronchioles along with foci of fibrosis. The clinical presentation of COP is the development of nonspecific systemic and respiratory symptoms. It is associated with filling of the lung alveoli that is visible on a chest X-ray as patchy unilateral or bilateral consolidation. COP was previously known as bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP).

question_text: What is the most common pneumoconiosis in the world?
explanation: Silicosis is the most common pneumoconiosis in the world. Silicosis is caused by the inhalation of crystalline silica (e.g., quartz). Individuals involved with the concrete work, sandblasting, stone carvers, and jewelers using chalk molds are at high risk. Pneumoconioses encompass a group of chronic fibrosing diseases of the lung resulting from exposure to organic and inorganic particulates, most commonly mineral dust.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common manifestation of asbestosis?
explanation: Pleural plaques are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure. They are well-circumscribed plaques of dense collagen, often containing calcium. They develop most frequently on the parietal pleura and over the domes of the diaphragm. They do not contain asbestos bodies, and only rarely occur in persons without prior asbestos exposure. Asbestos occurs in two distinct forms - serpentine chrysotile (more common) and amphibole (more pathogenic). Exposure may result in the following conditions: Localized fibrous plaques or, rarely, diffuse pleural fibrosis Pleural effusions Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis) Lung carcinoma Mesotheliomas Extrapulmonary neoplasms including laryngeal, ovarian, and colon carcinomas The image below shows fibrous pleural plaques seen on the diaphragmatic pleural surface in asbestosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient working in a factory presented with lung fibrosis and thickening of pleura. Biopsy was done. Diagnosis from the histopathology picture is:
explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing typical asbestos bodies are suggestive of asbestosis. Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis associated with asbestos exposure. The disease-causing capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and solubility. This condition is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis. Asbestos bodies are a typical finding. They are golden brown, fusiform, or beaded rods with a translucent center. They consist of asbestos fibers coated with an iron-containing proteinaceous material and arise when these fibers are phagocytosed by macrophages. Other inorganic particulates may become coated with similar iron-protein complexes and are called ferruginous bodies.

question_text: Patients A, B, and C presented to the OPD with symptoms of progressive dyspnea and cough. Further history and workup revealed the following findings. Who among them is more susceptible to developing tuberculosis?
explanation: Patient B is a worker in the sandblasting industry with eggshell calcification on x-ray. This is suggestive of silicosis. Patients with silicosis have a higher risk of tuberculosis as the crystalline silica impairs the ability of pulmonary macrophages to kill phagocytosed mycobacteria. The given clinical picture of patient A is classical of asbestosis and that of patient C is suggestive of anthracosis. question_text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of low-grade fever, dry cough, and progressive dyspnea. Examination reveals the following painless skin lesion. Chest X-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Lung biopsy shows non-caseating granulomas. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
options: Anergy to common skin test antigens
explanation: The given clinical scenario and image showing the lesion of lupus pernio point towards sarcoidosis. It is a multisystemic disease characterized by polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia. Lupus pernio is seen in cutaneous sarcoidosis and presents as infiltrated erythematoviolaceous plaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks, telangiectasia is characteristic. It is usually painless. As it does not ulcerate, it is not as mutilating as lupus vulgaris. Immunological abnormalities include: Polyclonal hyperglobulinemia A CD4/CD8 ratio > 3.5 T- cell expansion and macrophage activation Impaired dendritic cell function Anergy to common skin tests. The hallmarks of sarcoidosis include: B/L hilar lymphadenopathy Non-caseating granulomas Lupus pernio Erythema nodosum (acute sarcoidosis) Syndromes associated with sarcoidosis are: Mikulicz syndrome - sarcoidosis combined with uveoparotid involvement Lofgren's syndrome - acute presentation of sarcoidosis, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum, and bilateral hilar adenopathy The image below shows the characteristic non-caseating sarcoid granuloma. The image below shows stellate inclusions known as asteroid bodies that are found within giant cells in approximately 60% of the granulomas. The image below shows laminated concretions composed of calcium and proteins known as Schaumann bodies that are found within giant cells in approximately 60% of the granulomas.

question_text: What is the most common gene mutation associated with pulmonary hypertension?
explanation: Bone morphogenetic protein receptor 2 (BMPR2) is the most common gene mutation in pulmonary hypertension. Inactivating mutations in this gene are found in 75% of the familial cases of pulmonary hypertension, and 25% of sporadic cases. The BMPR2 receptor is a cell surface protein belonging to the TGF- receptor superfamily. It is involved in the regulation of growth, differentiation, and apoptosis of pulmonary artery endothelial and smooth muscle cells. Due to the mutation, there is enhanced proliferation and reduced apoptosis of vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells leading to pulmonary hypertension.

question_text: A 57-year-old man presented with a persistent dry cough and progressive dyspnea. HRCT showed a crazy-paving pattern. Microscopy of BAL aspirate is shown below. Antibodies against which of the following are seen in this condition?
explanation: The given scenario and microscopy showing alveoli filled with a dense, amorphous, protein-lipid granular precipitate are suggestive of autoimmune pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP). It is caused by circulating neutralizing antibodies specific for granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF). PAP is a condition characterized by the accumulation of surfactants in alveoli and terminal airways. It can be due to impaired clearance or abnormal production of surfactants. PAP can be of three forms: Primary (most common): There is impaired GM-CSF-dependent surfactant clearance by the alveolar macrophages. It can be due to: Autoantibodies against GM-CSF (acquired/idiopathic/autoimmune PAP) Mutation in GM-CSF receptors (hereditary PAP) Secondary: There is a reduction in the number or ability of alveolar macrophages that causes impaired surfactant clearance. It can be due to: Silicosis Immunodeficiency disorders Hematopoietic disorders and malignancies Congenital: It affects neonates and children. There is abnormal surfactant production due to mutation in the genes coding for: Surfactant protein B Surfactant protein C ATP binding cassette protein member 3

question_text:
A 70-year-old patient presented with cough, fatiguability, and weight loss. He was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) on bronchoscopy. The resected specimen had a hilar lymph node that was 1cm in size and showed a black pigment. What is the black pigment likely to be?
Anthracotic pigment
explanation: The black-colored pigment in the hilar lymph node of the resected bronchoscopic specimen is likely to be an anthracotic pigment. The black color is due to the deposition of carbon particles. The inhaled carbon particles are engulfed by the lung macrophages and then transported to the hilar lymph nodes. This accumulates and causes the blackening of the lung tissues or anthracosis. It is commonly seen in people who work in environments where there is high air pollution with carbon particles, such as coal mines. It is also the most common exogenous pigment found in the human body as a result of air pollution in urban areas. The aggregates of the carbon dust may induce fibroblastic reaction or emphysema that may lead to a condition called coal worker's pneumoconiosis. The following image shows anthracosis with deposition of black carbon particles, within the cytoplasm of macrophages. Option B: Melanin is brown-black in color which occurs as a result of oxidation of tyrosine in melanocytes, as shown in the following histopathology of a lymph node. Option C: Lipochrome or lipofuscin (brown lipid) is seen as a yellow-brown pigment in histopathological sections of the liver and heart of normal aging patients, patients with severe malnutrition, and cancer cachexia. It is derived through lipid peroxidation and indicates free radical injury and lipid peroxidation. The following image shows a cardiac myocyte with fine yellow-brown lipofuscin granules in the perinuclear region. Option D: Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived golden-yellow colored pigment seen in conditions associated with iron overload such as hemochromatosis. The following image shows extensive intra-alveolar hemosiderin deposition following pulmonary hemorrhage. Lung tumors

question_text: Which of the following statements is incorrect?
options: The most common cancer worldwide is lung cancer
The most common malignant tumors of the lung are metastases
The most common cause of cancer mortality worldwide is lung cancer
The lung is the most common site of metastatic neoplasms
explanation: According to Globocan 2020, the most common cancer worldwide is breast cancer. However, lung cancer remains the leading overall cause of cancer mortality. Lung cancers: The most common malignant tumors of the lung are metastases/ secondaries. The most common primary malignant tumor of the lung is bronchogenic cancer. The most common histology is adenocarcinoma (43.8%), followed by squamous cell (26.2%).

question_text: Which of the following is the most common symptom seen in patients with lung cancer?
explanation: The major presenting complaints of lung cancer patients are cough (75%), weight loss (40%), chest pain (40%), and dyspnea (20%). question_text:
Histopathological findings of a lung tumor biopsy are shown below. Which of the following is the most sensitive and specific marker of this tumor?
[Image unavailable]
explanation: The given image shows keratin pearls and islands of large polygonal malignant cells. These as seen in squamous cell carcinoma of the lungs. P40 is the most sensitive and specific marker for squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lungs. Other markers include cytokeratin 5/6 and P63. TTF-1 and napsin-A are the markers for adenocarcinoma. Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma. Note: The 2015 World Health Organization Classification of Lung Tumors has made a recommendation that at least one antibody each for squamous (P40 or P63) and glandular (e.g. TTF-1) differentiation should be used for an initial workup. Thus a simple panel of TTF-1 and p40 may be able to classify most non-small cell carcinoma-not otherwise specified cases.

question_text: Which is the most aggressive type of lung cancer?
explanation: Small-cell carcinoma of the lung is the most aggressive type of lung cancer. This tumor originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (Kulchitsky cells), which are present in the lining bronchial epithelium. Histopathological examination of small cell lung carcinoma shows: Clusters of small cells with scant cytoplasm Ill-defined cell borders Finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern) Absent or inconspicuous nucleoli The cells are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent. The image below shows the histopathological findings of small cell lung carcinoma.

question_text: A 53-year-old man who is a chronic smoker is diagnosed with lung carcinoma. Histopathology of the lung tissue is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical features and the histopathology showing the Azzopardi effect are suggestive of a small cell carcinoma of the lung. Azzopardi effect is described as basophilic staining of vascular walls due to encrustation by DNA from necrotic tumor cells.

explanation: Non-smoker patients with lung carcinoma are most likely to have a mutation in the EGFR gene. question_text: A woman presents to the OPD with complaints of bloody cough, dyspnea, and weight loss. During the evaluation, a CT-guided lung biopsy reveals the following picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of adenocarcinoma lung. It is the most common form of lung cancer. It is an invasive malignant epithelial tumor with glandular differentiation. The tumor cells produce mucin. It is usually located peripherally (it arises from the terminal bronchiole). Molecular genetics show frequent mutations in EGFR, ALK, ROS, MET, and RET (Receptor tyrosine kinase genes) or KRAS mutations. Histologically, lepidic growth patterns are seen. It refers to the pattern of spread of the tumor in which the tumor cells “crawl” along normal-appearing alveolar septae and resembles butterflies resting on a fence. Adenocarcinomas grow in various patterns, including acinar, lepidic, papillary, micropapillary, and solid with mucin formation. Tumor cells are positive for mucin and thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) Tumors 3 cm or less in diameter characterized by lepidic growth pattern without stromal invasion are now called adenocarcinoma in situ (formerly called bronchoalveolar carcinoma). The image below shows histopathological findings of adenocarcinoma of the lung.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following immunohistochemical markers would be positive in a patient with adenocarcinoma lung?
explanation: Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1), mucin, and napsin-A are positive in adenocarcinoma lung. TTF-1 is required for normal lung development. It can be used to distinguish primary adenocarcinoma of the lungs (TTF-1 positive) from other histological types of lung cancers, metastatic adenocarcinoma, and mesothelioma (TTF-1 negative). P40 and P63 are the markers for squamous cell carcinoma. Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 75-year-old man presents with a cough and shortness of breath. He has been working in a shipping factory for 30 years. On x-ray, a mass is seen in the right apical region of the lung. A biopsy sample is taken from the mass. Which of the following tumor markers is likely to be positive in this tumor?
explanation: Calretinin is most likely to be positive in this tumour as the given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma. Malignant mesothelioma is a rare malignant tumour of the pleura, associated with heavy asbestos exposure (shipping factory). The lifetime risk of developing mesothelioma in heavily exposed individuals is as high as 7% to 10%. It has strong male predilection (3:1). There is a long latent period of 25 to 45 years for the development of asbestos-related mesothelioma. The image below shows a lung autopsy sample with mesothelioma. Grossly, it appears as a diffuse lesion arising either from the visceral or parietal pleura. The affected lung becomes ensheathed by a thick layer of soft, gelatinous, grayish pink tumor tissue. Microscopically, they are of three types: epithelioid (60%), sarcomatoid (20%), and mixed (20%). Electron microscopy in mesothelioma will show numerous long, slender microvilli and abundant monofilaments but absent microvillous rootlets and lamellar bodies. The image below shows the epithelioid type of mesothelioma showing cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma. Inset shows strong positivity for Calretinin immunostain.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 59-year old man presented with persistent wheezing, episodes of hemoptysis, and dry cough. Bronchoscopy revealed a mass occluding the left bronchus. Biopsy of the specimen revealed polygonal cells with fine stippled chromatin and eosinophilic cytoplasm arranged in nests. The tumor was positive for CD 56, synaptophysin, and chromogranin. What is the cell of origin of this tumor?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchial carcinoid. Bronchial neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) arise from Kulchitsky cells. WHO divides neuroendocrine neoplasms into four categories: Typical carcinoid Atypical carcinoid Large-cell neuroendocrine carcinoma Small-cell carcinoma Carcinoid tumors are low-grade malignant epithelial neoplasms that represent 1% to 5% of all lung tumors. It is not related to smoking. Carcinoids may occur in patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1. On gross examination, these tumors grow as fingerlike or spherical polypoid masses that project into the lumen of the bronchus or as collar button lesions, penetrating the bronchial wall to fan out in the peribronchial tissue. Histologically, the tumor is composed of organoid, trabecular, palisading, ribbon, or rosette-like arrangements of cells separated by a delicate fibrovascular stroma. On electron microscopy, the cells exhibit the dense-core neurosecretory granules. Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for serotonin, neuron-specific enolase, bombesin, calcitonin, or other peptides. 10% of the cases may produce carcinoid syndrome. Most carcinoids follow a relatively benign course and have good prognosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What percentage of patients with bronchial carcinoids present with carcinoid syndrome?
explanation: Approximately, 10% of bronchial carcinoids give rise to the carcinoid syndrome. Most bronchial carcinoids follow a relatively benign course, do not have secretory activity and do not metastasize to distant sites. Classic carcinoid syndrome is characterized by intermittent attacks of diarrhea, flushing, bronchospasm and cyanosis. Carcinoid syndrome is due to excessive production of serotonin, a specialised product of tryptophan metabolism by argentaffin cells (cells in the carcinoid tumor). It is then metabolised and excreted in urine. If urinary levels of 5- HIAA exceed 25 mg/day, a diagnosis of carcinoid syndrome can be made.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A solitary coin lesion was seen on a routine X-ray of a patient. After evaluation, he was diagnosed with lung hamartoma. Which of the following is the most common tissue seen in these lesions?
Bone
explanation: Cartilage is the most common connective tissue in lung hamartoma. Pulmonary hamartoma consists of nodules of connective tissue intersected by epithelial clefts. There are islands of cartilage, fat, smooth muscle, and entrapped respiratory epithelium in pulmonary hamartoma. It is a benign clonal neoplasm associated with chromosomal aberrations involving either 6p21 or 12q14-q15. Lung hamartoma is usually discovered as an incidental coin lesion on a routine chest radiograph. The given below is an image of lung hamartoma. Pituitary ,Parathyroids and Pancreas

question_text: A 30-year-old woman is being evaluated for chronic headaches, infertility, and galactorrhea. MRI of the brain shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario and brain MRI showing a pituitary adenoma are suggestive of a lactotroph adenoma (prolactinoma). Pituitary adenomas are usually found in adults. The most common genetic alterations in this condition are mutations in G proteins (particularly GNAS). Depending on their size, they are classified as: Microadenomas - diameter < 1 cm Macroadenomas - diameter > 1 cm They may be functioning or non-functioning. The most common type of functioning pituitary adenomas are prolactinomas. The clinical features of prolactinoma include: Due to mass effect - Features of raised intracranial tension Visual field disturbances (bitemporal hemianopia) - due to compression of optic chiasm Hypopituitarism - due to compressed hypophyseal stalk Due to hyperprolactinemia - Galactorrhoea Amenorrhoea or oligomenorrhoea Infertility Loss of libido Gynecomastia Serum prolactin concentrations tend to correlate with the size of the adenoma. The normal range of serum prolactin is 5-20 g/L. The diagnosis of prolactinoma is most likely to be associated with a prolactin level >200 g/L.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Presence of which of the following features is required to diagnose a patient with pituitary carcinoma?
explanation: The following features are required for the diagnosis of pituitary carcinoma: A pituitary tumor that has metastasized to distant sites, either craniospinal or systemic sites (and/or) Presence of a pituitary tumor that is not contiguous with the primary sellar tumour Pituitary carcinoma is extremely rare (< 1% of total tumors). They are associated with activating mutations of the HRAS oncogene. The diagnosis of pituitary carcinoma cannot be made based on histologic appearance alone. Though pituitary adenomas normally show cellular monomorphism and the absence of a reticulin network, they can have some overlapping features with malignant tumors such as: Atypical adenomas - show pleomorphism and atypical mitosis Invasive adenomas - Non-encapsulated Show local invasion into cavernous and sphenoid sinuses, dura, brain However, they remain confined to the primary tumor site
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following cells secrete parathyroid hormone?
explanation: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is secreted by the chief cells of the parathyroid glands. The function of the parathyroids is to regulate calcium homeostasis. This gland is composed of two cell types: Chief cells - Polygonal cells with uniform nuclei and pink cytoplasm Water-clear appearance - due to presence of large amounts of cytoplasmic glycogen Secretory granules containing PTH Oxyphil cells - Slightly larger cells with acidophilic cytoplasm with no known function. The following image shows the normal histology of the parathyroid gland: C-cells or parafollicular cells are present in the thyroid. They secrete calcitonin.

question_text: What is the most common cause of asymptomatic hypercalcemia?
explanation: The most common cause of asymptomatic hypercalcemia (isolated hypercalcemia without signs or symptoms) is primary hyperparathyroidism. It is also the most common cause of hypercalcemia overall. Primary hyperparathyroidism results in autonomous overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH), resulting in elevated levels. It usually results from an adenoma or hyperplasia of parathyroid tissue. The most common cause of symptomatic hypercalcemia is malignancy. The most common mechanism through which osteolytic tumors induce hypercalcemia is the secretion of the PTH-related peptide (PTHrP).
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 40-year-old woman presented with bone pain and abdominal cramps for the past 1 week. She has had multiple prior hospital admissions for management of recurrent renal calculi. Investigations revealed elevated serum calcium and PTH levels with reduced phosphate levels. Which of the following is the most common pathological change responsible for this condition?
explanation: The given clinical picture is highly suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. The most common cause is a sporadic, solitary parathyroid adenoma. Parathyroid tumors may be associated with cyclin D1 gene inversions and MEN1 mutations. Hyperparathyroidism refers to elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH). It is classified into: Primary - autonomous overproduction of PTH Secondary - compensatory hypersecretion of PTH in response to prolonged hypocalcemia Tertiary - persistent hypersecretion of PTH even after correction of prolonged hypocalcemia. (e.g. after renal transplant) The classical symptoms and signs of primary hyperparathyroidism are due to hypercalcemia as well as increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. The features of hypercalcemia are as follows: The features of elevated PTH levels are as follows: Osteitis fibrosa cystica Osteopenia/osteoporosis Hyperuricemia and gout Pseudogout Increased production of calcitrio Nephrolithiasis Hypophosphatemia Anemia The clinical signs associated with primary hyperparathyroidism can be remembered with the mnemonic - “bones, stones, groans, moans with fatigue overtones” System Clinical features Musculoskeletal Bone painSkeletal deformitie sPathological fracturesMyalgi a and arthralgia Renal Renal stones(Calcium oxalate > calcium phosphate)Nephro calcinosisPolyuria and dehyd rationRenal failure GIT ConstipationNausea, vomitin g, anorexiaAbdominal painPe ptic ulcer diseaseAcute pancr eatitis Neuropsychiatric Anxiety, depressionCognitive dysfunctionIrritabilityHalluc inations Cardiac Short QT intervalBradycardia Hypertension Ectopic calcification Cornea: Band keratopathyExt ravascular tissues: calcinosis Small arteries: calciphylaxis

question_text: A 47-year-old woman was evaluated for chronic backache and abdominal pain. Investigations revealed the following. What is the most likely bone finding seen in this condition?
explanation: The clinical scenario and lab findings point towards a diagnosis of hyperparathyroidism. The bone finding associated with this condition is osteitis fibrosa cystica. This condition is also called brown tumor or von Recklinghausen disease of bone. In hyperparathyroidism, high levels of PTH result in increased osteoclast activity. This results in bone loss which predisposes to microfractures and secondary hemorrhages. This results in the following changes: An influx of macrophages that form giant cells Mass of reparative fibrous tissue Increased vascularity, hemorrhage, and hemosiderin deposition - results in brown color The image given below is showing a brown tumor with numerous giant cells with interstitial hemorrhage, hemosiderin. Option B: Fraying and cupping of the metaphysis of the bones are classically seen in patients suffering from rickets. Option D: Punched out lytic lesions of the bone are seen in patients with multiple myeloma.

question_text: A 46-year-old woman is referred with recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia. During the evaluation, she is found to have high serum levels of insulin. Measurement of which of the following can help in reaching the diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of hypoglycemia due to hyperinsulinemia. As C-peptide is a marker of endogenous insulin secretion, its levels would help in identifying the source of insulin: High C-peptide - excess insulin production (insulinoma) Normal/ low C-peptide - exogenous insulin administration (factitious disorder) The precursor molecule of insulin is pre-proinsulin, which gets cleaved to form proinsulin. This proinsulin gets cleaved to form insulin and C-peptide (by-product). Hence, both are secreted in equimolar quantities during insulin secretion. Hence, the level of C-peptide corresponds to the level of endogenous insulin. The levels of C-peptide decrease with the loss of  -cell mass in type 1 diabetes.

question_text: Patients with which of the following chromosomal anomalies are least likely to develop diabetes mellitus?
explanation: Edward's syndrome or trisomy 18 is not associated with diabetes mellitus. Genetic syndromes associated with diabetes mellitus include: Down's syndrome (trisomy 21) Klinefelter's syndrome (XXY karyotype) Turner's syndrome (XO karyotype) Prader–Willi syndrome (deletion of paternal chromosome 15) Other causes of diabetes mellitus include: Genetic defects in insulin action - Type A insulin resistance Lipoatrophic diabetes Exocrine pancreatic defects - Chronic pancreatitis Pancreatectomy/trauma Neoplasia Cystic fibrosis Hemochromatosis Fibrocalculous pancreatopathy Endocrinopathies - Acromegaly Cushing syndrome Hyperthyroidism Pheochromocytoma Glucagonoma Infections - Cytomegalovirus Coxsackie B virus Congenital rubella

question_text: A pathologist is studying a Congo red-stained slide of pancreatic tissue. He observes it under polarized light and notes the following finding. This finding is commonly associated with which of the following conditions?
explanation: The image shows a Congo red-stained biopsy specimen with apple-green birefringence under polarized microscopy. It is indicative of amyloid accumulation within the pancreatic islets. This is commonly associated with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Amyloid deposition begins in and around capillaries and between cells. In advanced stages, the islets may be virtually obliterated and fibrosis may also be observed.

question_text: Which of the following is not a detrimental effect of advanced glycation end-products in patients suffering from diabetes mellitus?
options: Deposition of excess basement membrane material due to TGF- release
Generation of reactive oxygen species in endothelial cells
Increased anticoagulant effect on endothelial cells and macrophages
Increase in vascular smooth muscle cells and extracellular matrix
explanation: Advanced glycation end products (AGEs) result in increased procoagulant effects on endothelial cells and macrophages, not anticoagulant effects. AGEs are formed by nonenzymatic reactions between intracellular glucose-derived dicarbonyl precursors with the amino groups of proteins. They bind to a specific receptor (RAGE) that is expressed on inflammatory cells (macrophages and T cells), endothelium, and vascular smooth muscle. The detrimental effects of the AGE-RAGE signalling axis within the vascular compartment include: Release of cytokines and growth factors, including TGF- - leads to deposition of excess basement membrane materia Generation of reactive oxygen species in endothelial cells. Increased procoagulant activity on endothelial cells and macrophages. Enhanced proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells and synthesis of extracellular matrix These effects are responsible for the microvascular and macrovascular complications in diabetes mellitus.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasm?
explanation: Insulinoma ( -cell tumors) is the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasm. It produces sufficient insulin to induce clinically significant hypoglycemia. The three most common and distinctive clinical syndromes associated with functional pancreatic endocrine neoplasms are as follows: Hyperinsulinism Zollinger–Ellison syndrome (hypergastrinemia) Multiple endocrine neoplasias (MEN)

question_text: A 39-year-old man was referred to a higher center for further evaluation of peptic ulcer disease refractory to high doses of proton pump inhibitors. There is a history of pituitary and parathyroid tumors in his family members. Serum gastrin level was found to be 1690 pg/ml (normal < 100) and a neuroendocrine tumor is suspected. Which of the following is false about this condition?
options: It is associated with intractable jejunal ulcers
This patient likely has a solitary tumor
Tumors usually originate in Passaro's triangle
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a gastrin-producing tumor or gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). The family history of pituitary and parathyroid tumors is suggestive of MEN1 syndrome. This syndrome is associated with multifocal gastrinomas. On the other hand, sporadic gastrinomas are usually single. Gastrinomas usually arise in the duodenum, peripancreatic soft tissues, pancreas. The site of origin is the duodenum when ZES is associated with MEN1. Most tumors are locally invasive and metastasize early. Hypergastrinemia gives rise to extreme gastric acid secretion and peptic ulceration, that is refractory to proton pump inhibitors. It results in multiple ulcers in duodenum, stomach, and uncommon areas like jejunum.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with longstanding diabetes mellitus came with complaints of bulky stools. Ultrasound abdomen showed the presence of multiple gallstones. Hypersecretion of which of the following leads to this presentation?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of a -cell tumor or somatostatinoma. It results in hypersecretion of somatostatin. Somatostatin inhibits pancreatic and biliary secretions. Patients with somatostatinoma usually present with vague abdominal pain along with the triad of: Gallstones - due to bile stasis Diabetes mellitus - due to inhibition of insulin secretion Steatorrhea - due to inhibition of pancreatic exocrine secretion and bile secretion

question_text:
A patient presented with profuse watery diarrhoea and muscle cramps for the past few weeks. The diarrhoea was intractable to antibiotics and stool culture was negative for organisms. He also complained of indigestion and frequent bloating. On investigation, he was found to have microcytic hypochromic anaemia. Serum potassium was 2.4 mmol/L. Upper GI endoscopy was normal. Excess of which of the following hormones leads to this condition?
VIP
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of WDHA syndrome. It is due to hypersecretion of VIP (vasoactive-intestinal peptide). WDHA syndrome includes the following features: Watery diarrhea Hypokalemia (Serum K+< 3.5 mmol/L) Achlorhydria (bloating, indigestion, iron deficiency) Neural crest tumors, such as neuroblastomas, ganglioneuroblastoma, ganglioneuromas, and pheochromocytomas can also be associated with VIPoma syndrome. Thyroid Glands

question_text: What is the most common cause of endogenous hyperthyroidism?
explanation: Graves' disease is the most common cause of endogenous hyperthyroidism. It is an autoimmune disorder due to the production of TSH-receptor stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) which cause hyperthyroidism. It is characterized by the triad of: Thyrotoxicosis Infiltrative ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos) Dermopathy (pretibial myxedema) Glycosaminoglycan deposition, lymphoid infiltrates, and fatty infiltrates are responsible for ophthalmopathy and dermopathy. Grossly, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland and a beefy deep red parenchyma. Histology shows tall crowded follicular cells with scalloped margins and lymphoid infiltrates. Laboratory features include elevations in free T3 and T4 and decreased TSH.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 32-year-old lady presents with loss of weight, tremors of the hand, and irritability for the past 4-5 months. Examination findings and investigations are given below. All of the following contribute to these eye findings except:
options: Lymphocytic infiltration in the retroorbital space
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the given image showing exophthalmos is suggestive of Graves' ophthalmopathy. Sympathetic overactivity of Muller's muscle results in a wide, staring gaze and lid lag, but not exophthalmos. Exophthalmos is characterized by abnormal protrusion of the eyeball. It is due to increased volume of the retroorbital connective tissues and extraocular muscles because of: Marked lymphocytic infiltration of the retro-orbital space Inflammation with edema and swelling of extraocular muscles Accumulation of hydrophilic glycosaminoglycans such as hyaluronic acid and chondroitin sulfate Increased numbers of adipocytes (fatty infiltration)
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following disorders does not lead to hyperthyroidism?
explanation: Hashimoto thyroiditis is not associated with hyperthyroidism. It is associated with transient thyrotoxicosis, followed by chronic hypothyroidism. Thyrotoxicosis is a hypermetabolic state caused by elevated circulating levels of free T3 and T4. On the other hand, hyperfunctioning of the thyroid gland itself is referred to as hyperthyroidism.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the finding seen in the following histopathological examination of a biopsy specimen from a patient with an enlarged thyroid?
options: Dense lymphoid infiltrate with germinal centre
explanation: The given image shows follicular hyperplasia with a scalloping colloid. The clinical scenario along with the image is suggestive of Graves' disease. In Graves' disease, the thyroid is diffusely hyperplastic. The follicles are lined by tall columnar epithelial cells that project into lumina. The cells actively resorb the colloid in the center of the follicle which results in a scalloped appearance of the edges of the colloid.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 50-year-old woman presented with diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 6 months. She says that it has increased in size over the last 1 month. Investigations reveal elevated TSH levels. Histopathological examination is done, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical picture and image showing Hurthle cells are suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. In this condition, the following microscopic features are seen: Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well developed germinal centers Atrophied thyroid follicles The epithelial cells lining the follicles contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm (oncocytes) This is called oncocytic metaplasia These cells are called Hurthle cells Ultrastructurally, these cells have numerous mitochondria Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease, characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is commonly seen in women between 45 to 65 years of age. It is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase. Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well demarcated from the adjacent structures. Note: Oncocytes can arise in various tissues and are referred to as follows: Hurthle cells/ Ashkenazy cells - thyroid gland Oxyphilic cells - parotid gland Apocrine metaplasia - breast
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following findings will you not observe in a thyroid gland biopsy taken from a patient suffering from Hashimoto thyroiditis?
explanation: Orphan-Annie eye nuclei are a feature of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, not Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual and progressive thyroid failure. It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in areas of the world where iodine levels are sufficient. The thyroid gland is often diffusely enlarged, painless, with some degree of hypothyroidism. This may be preceded by transient thyrotoxicosis (Hashitoxicosis). It is associated with an increased risk of: Other autoimmune conditions Extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphomas Papillary carcinoma Histologically, the following findings are seen: Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well developed germinal centers Atrophied thyroid follicles The epithelial cells lining the follicles contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm This is called oncocytic metaplasia These cells are called Hurthle cells
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas of the world?
explanation: Autoimmune hypothyroidism is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas of the world. The thyroid gland is typically enlarged. The circulating autoantibodies found in this disorder are: Antimicrosomal antibodies Antithyroid peroxidase antibodies Antithyroglobulin antibodies Note: Wolff-Chaikoff effect refers to iodine-induced hypothyroidism.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 48-year-old woman presented with fever, malaise, and painful enlargement of the thyroid gland after a few days following viral fever. On investigation, thyroid antibodies were normal and serum T4 was slightly raised. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical condition is suggestive of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis. It is the most common cause of a painful thyroid. It is also known as painful subacute thyroiditis, de Quervain thyroiditis, or migratory thyroiditis (this is because the pain can shift to different locations in the thyroid). Option A: Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis (postpartum thyroiditis) is typically painless. It often occurs after pregnancy and is characterized by lymphocytic inflammation in the thyroid. Option B: Riedel's thyroiditis is a rare disorder characterized by a painless, rapidly growing thyroid mass with extensive fibrosis involving the thyroid and contiguous neck structures. Option C: Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that presents as painless enlargement of the thyroid associated with some degree of hypothyroidism in middle-aged women.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements about solitary thyroid nodule is incorrect?
options: They are more common in women
Solitary nodules are more likely to be malignant than are multiple nodules
Nodules in younger patients are less likely to be malignant
explanation: Nodules in younger patients are more likely to be malignant than those in older patients. The solitary thyroid nodule is a palpably discrete swelling within an otherwise apparently normal thyroid gland. A higher incidence is seen in areas with endemic iodine deficiency. They are more common in women than in men. Malignant transformation is more common in: Solitary nodules > Multinodular goiter Solitary nodules in males > females Cold nodules > Hot nodules However, benign neoplasms are more common than thyroid carcinomas by a ratio of nearly 10:1.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common thyroid cancer?
explanation: The most common thyroid cancer is papillary carcinoma. Major subtypes of thyroid carcinoma and their relative frequencies are as follows: Papillary carcinoma - most common Follicular carcinoma Medullary carcinoma Anaplastic carcinoma - least common Thyroid carcinomas are derived from the thyroid follicular epithelium, except medullary carcinoma which is derived from parafollicular C cells.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with a long-standing history of thyroglossal cyst develops a neck swelling. The biopsy of the lesion is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given image shows psammoma bodies, which are seen in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. This type of carcinoma is associated with a history of long-standing unresected thyroglossal cyst. Psammoma bodies are concentrically calcified structures often present within the cores of papillae in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. These structures are almost never found in follicular and medullary carcinomas. They arise from: Infarction and dystrophic calcification of papillae tips Calcification of intra-lymphatic tumor thrombi. Psammoma bodies are seen in: Papillary carcinoma (thyroid, kidney, endometrium, lungs) Prolactinoma Meningioma Papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary

question_text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a solitary, non-tender, firm nodule on the left side of her neck. Thyroid function tests were within normal limits. A fine-needle biopsy revealed malignant cells. The tumor was excised and examined under light microscopy as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The presence of empty appearing nuclei, also called Orphan Annie eye nuclei as seen in the above image is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma include: Branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk Covering epithelium is simple or stratified cuboidal Orphan Annie eye nuclei - Empty-appearing nuclei due to dispersed chromatin They are diagnostic, regardless of papillary architecture Psammoma bodies - concentric calcified structures Foci of lymphatic invasion Note: Orphan Annie refers to a comic book character with empty appearing eyes, as shown below.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements regarding papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is incorrect?
options: It is the most common form of thyroid carcinoma
Diagnosis can be made based on nuclear features, even in the absence of typical architecture
It is associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation
explanation: Hematogenous spread is rare in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Metastases to lymph nodes are more commonly associated with this condition. It is associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation. The presence of nuclear features such as Orphan Annie eye nuclei (empty-appearing nuclei) are diagnostic, regardless of papillary architecture.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A pathologist is studying the following FNAC from a patient's thyroid nodule. Which is the most common site of metastasis for this condition?
explanation: The FNAC image is suggestive of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Among the given options, the most common site of metastasis is the lungs. The histological features of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid are: Papillary architecture Nuclear findings (enough to diagnose the condition even in the absence of papillary architecture) Nuclear overlapping, grooving, crowding Ground-glass appearance (Orphan Annie eye nuclei) Dusty and pale chromatin Intranuclear inclusion bodies The most common mode of spread overall is through the lymphatic route, with lymph node metastases being common at initial presentation.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In patients with papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which of the following genes may be involved?
explanation: Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is associated with gain-of-function mutations in the following genes: NTRK1 (receptor tyrosine kinase) RET (receptor tyrosine kinase) BRAF (serine/threonine kinase)

question_text: Which of the following is the most common variant of papillary thyroid cancer?
explanation: The most common variant of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is the follicular variant. It has the following features: Characteristic nuclear features of papillary carcinoma Almost entirely follicular architecture Can be either - Encapsulated - favorable prognosis (or) Poorly circumscribed and infiltrative - requires aggressive treatment The variants of papillary carcinoma include: Variant Description Tall-cellvariant 50% of cells withheight 2 tim es the widthSeen inolderindi vidualsHave higher frequenci es of vascular invasionExtrat hyroidal extension, and cervi cal and distant metastases Diffuse sclerosingvariant In younger individuals, inclu ding childrenDiffuse fibrosist hroughout the glandLymph n ode metastasesare present in almost all cases.Lacks BRAF mutations Cribriformvariant Associated withfamilial aden omatous polyposis(FAP)Beta- cateninmutation Variant Description Columnar-cellvariant Elongated nuclei with pseudo stratificationof the nucleiPoo r prognosis Solidvariant More common in childrenAss ociated with Chernobyl nucle ar accident Note: According to the latest WHO classification of thyroid tumors, the non-invasive encapsulated follicular variant of papillary thyroid carcinoma (FVPTC) has been renamed as non-invasive follicular thyroid neoplasm with papillary-like nuclear features (NIFTP) to better reflect the indolent course of this tumor. This was done to prevent potential overtreatment and reduce the burden to patients of a cancer diagnosis.

question_text: Which of the following patients is likely to have the best prognosis?
options: A 30-year-old man with papillary carcinoma thyroid
A 45-year-old woman with follicular carcinoma thyroid
A 78-year-old man with anaplastic carcinoma thyroid
A young man with MEN- II syndrome having medullary carcinoma thyroid
explanation: Papillary thyroid cancers have the best prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate seen in more than 95% of the patients. The prognosis of papillary thyroid cancers is dependent on several factors, including age (being less favorable among patients older than 40 years), the presence of extrathyroidal extension, and presence of distant metastases. The thyroid cancer with the worst prognosis is anaplastic carcinoma.

question_text: A 56-year-old woman coming from a hilly area presents with a hard swelling in the neck which moves up with deglutition and does not move with protrusion of the tongue. The biopsy of the frozen section is given below. What is your diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the given histopathological image showing uniform sheets of cells with capsular invasion by tumor cells is suggestive of follicular carcinoma thyroid. The following images show follicular carcinoma of the thyroid. Option A: In follicular adenoma, there is no capsular invasion. Option C: Anaplastic carcinoma is associated with rapidly progressive swelling with obstructive features and undifferentiated cells on histopathology. question_text: Which of the following mutations may be found in patients with follicular carcinoma?
explanation: RAS mutations are associated with follicular carcinoma. It is also associated with acquired mutations in the PIK3CA gene (PI3K/AKT arm of the receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathway) and the PAX8-PPARG fusion gene.

A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. The histology of the swelling is as shown below. Investigations reveal elevated calcitonin levels. Which of the following is associated with this condition?

Cowden syndrome
explanation: The given clinical scenario and histological appearance showing amyloid stroma are suggestive of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. This condition can occur in the setting of MEN2A (Sipple syndrome) or MEN2B. Medullary carcinomas of the thyroid are neuroendocrine neoplasms derived from the parafollicular cells or C cells of the thyroid. They may be: Sporadic (70%) Familial or associated with MEN2 syndromes (30%) - More aggressive and metastasize more frequently than sporadic Usually bilateral and multicentric Both forms can be associated with RET mutations. These tumors may present with: Mass in the neck Dysphagia Hoarseness Diarrhea due to the secretion of VIP Cushing's syndrome due to ACTH secretion Histopathology shows polygonal to spindle-shaped cells, which may form nests, trabeculae, and even follicles. question_text:
A 40-year-old woman presents to the OPD with rapid weight gain and easy bruisability over the past 1 month. She was started on oral prednisolone for dermatomyositis 2 months ago. On examination, moon facies and abdominal striae are noted. Her BP is 160/110 mm Hg.
Which of the following pathological changes is seen in this condition?
options: Corticotroph cells with homogenous and pale cytoplasm
Accumulation of keratin filaments in adrenal cells
Eosinophilic inclusion bodies in adrenal cells
Basophilic nuclear inclusion bodies in corticotroph cells
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome. In this condition, the normal basophilic cytoplasm of the corticotrophs of anterior pituitary becomes homogeneous and pale. This is termed the Crooke hyaline change and is due to the accumulation of intermediate keratin filaments in the cytoplasm. This change occurs due to high levels of circulating glucocorticoids in Cushing's syndrome. Based on the cause of Cushing's syndrome, the following pathological changes are seen in the adrenals: Iatrogenic - atrophy of zona fasciculata and zona reticularis (as zona glomerulosa functions independently of ACTH) ACTH-dependent - diffuse hyperplasia (due to high ACTH levels) ACTH-independent - nodular hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma Note: Eosinophilic inclusion bodies in adrenal cells are called spironolactone bodies. They are seen in Conn's syndrome.

question_text: What is the most common clinical feature of Cushing syndrome?
explanation: Obesity is the most common clinical feature of Cushing's syndrome. Clinical features of Cushing’s syndrome are attributed to the glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and sex steroid actions of cortisol. question_text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the casualty with severe abdominal pain, diarrhea, and dizziness for the past 3 days. On examination, the following findings are noted. Blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg and blood glucose is 48 mg/dl. Which of the following would you expect in this patient?
options: High ACTH and low renin levels
High ACTH and high renin levels
Low ACTH and normal renin levels
Low ACTH and low renin levels
explanation: The clinical scenario and the image showing hyperpigmentation of palmar creases and oral mucosa are suggestive of primary adrenal insufficiency. It presents with low aldosterone, high renin, and high ACTH levels. In primary adrenal insufficiency, lack of aldosterone production results in compensatory rise in ACTH and renin levels. The high ACTH results in hyperpigmentation. The most common causes are autoimmune in developed countries and tuberculosis in developing countries. In secondary adrenal insufficiency, there is pituitary dysfunction leading to low ACTH levels. Renin and aldosterone levels are normal, as they function independently of ACTH.

question_text: A 6-year-old boy was referred with fever, altered sensorium, and non-blanching rash for the past 2 days. He developed rapidly progressive shock and DIC. Despite resuscitation measures, he died. The following appearance of his adrenals was noted on autopsy. All of the following can cause this condition except:
explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing bilateral adrenal hemorrhage are suggestive of Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is not a cause of this condition. It is caused by highly virulent organisms such as: Neisseria meningitidis or meningococci (classically) Streptococcus pneumoniae or pneumococci Pseudomonas aeruginosa Haemophilus influenzae Staphylococcus species This condition is more common in children. Overwhelming bacterial infection leads to bilateral adrenal hemorrhage, thereby causing acute adrenal insufficiency. This is likely a result of direct bacterial seeding of small vessels and endothelial dysfunction caused by microbial products and inflammatory mediators. It usually presents with rapidly progressive hypotension and shock and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with widespread purpura. Without prompt recognition and treatment, death occurs within hours to a few days.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common cause of primary hyperaldosteronism?
explanation: Bilateral nodular hyperplasia of the adrenal glands is the most common cause of primary hyperaldosteronism. Adrenal adenoma is the second most common cause. It is usually solitary, but multiple adenomas may occur occasionally. Other rare causes include: Ectopic aldosterone-producing tumors Familial idiopathic hyperaldosteronism - due to germline mutations of KCNJ5 (encodes a potassium channel)
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the underlying pathology in patients with Conn's syndrome?
explanation: The underlying pathology in patients with Conn's syndrome is adrenal adenoma. Hyperaldosteronism may be primary or secondary. Primary hyperaldosteronism is due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone with resultant suppression of RAAS. It can occur due to adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma. It presents with the following features: Hypertension (most common) Hypokalemia Metabolic alkalosis Polyuria (due to ANP) Polydipsia (due to polyuria) Muscle weakness It is confirmed by elevated ratios of plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity (PAC / PRA). When primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone-secreting adenoma, it is called Conn syndrome. Patients are usually treated with spironolactone followed by surgical removal of adenoma. In patients treated with spironolactone, the adenomas contain eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions called spironolactone bodies. In secondary hyperaldosteronism, aldosterone release occurs in response to the activation of the renin-angiotensin system (RAAS).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Patients with which of the following conditions are not at risk of developing adrenocortical carcinoma?
explanation: MEN2B syndrome is associated with pheochromocytoma and medullary carcinoma of thyroid, not adrenocortical carcinoma. Adrenocortical carcinoma is associated with the following hereditary cancer syndromes: Li–Fraumeni syndrome - due to germline TP53 mutations Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome - a disorder of epigenetic imprinting MEN1 syndrome - due to mutations of MEN1 gene
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought for the evaluation of recurrent seizures over the last 3 months. Past history is significant for chronic oral candidiasis for 2 years. On examination, nail
dystrophy is noted. Further investigation reveals serum calcium of 6.9 mg/dl and prolonged QT interval. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of autoimmune polyendocrinopathy (APS) type 1. It is also called APECED (autoimmune polyendocrinopathy, candidiasis, and ectodermal dystrophy). It is caused by mutations in the autoimmune regulator (AIRE) gene. This gene usually increases tolerance of central T-cells to peripheral tissue antigens. When this function is lost, the T-cells become more prone to mount immune reactions against tissue antigens, promoting autoimmunity. These patients develop autoantibodies against IL-17 and IL-22, which are crucial for defense against fungal infections. It presents in childhood with the following features: Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis Ectodermal dystrophy (abnormalities of the skin, dental enamel, and nails) Organ-specific autoimmune disorders such as - Autoimmune adrenalitis Autoimmune hypoparathyroidism Idiopathic hypogonadism Pernicious anemia Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome (APS) type 2 usually presents in early adulthood as a combination of the following: Adrenal insufficiency Autoimmune thyroiditis or type 1 diabetes

question_text: A 24-year-old woman presented with recurrent episodes of palpitations, headaches, and sweating. Her BP was 155/95 mm Hg and HR was 135/min. Investigations revealed elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrines and a right adrenal mass on CT abdomen. She should be examined for the presence of all of the following except:
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. This patient does not need to be examined for a shagreen patch. It is a feature of tuberous sclerosis syndrome, which is not associated with pheochromocytoma.
