question_text: Which of the following is most commonly involved in Wermer syndrome?
explanation: Primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common manifestation of Wermer’s syndrome or MEN-1 syndrome. MEN1 syndrome is due to germline mutations in the MEN1 tumor-suppressor gene, which encodes a protein called menin. The most commonly secreted products are pancreatic polypeptides.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is an indicator of malignant transformation in a patient with pheochromocytoma?
explanation: The definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based exclusively on the presence of metastases to regional lymph nodes as well as distant sites like liver, lung, and bone. Capsular and vascular invasion may be encountered even in benign lesions. Malignant pheochromocytomas are histologically and biochemically the same as benign ones. Hence, typical histological criteria like cellular atypia, mitotic spindles, and vascular invasion are insufficient to confirm malignancy in pheochromocytomas.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A pathologist is studying the following slide from the biopsy of a patient with an abdominal mass. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given histopathology slide shows nests of cells arranged in an organoid pattern, with fibrovascular septae, and finely granular cytoplasm. This is called the zellballen pattern. It is typically seen in paragangliomas and pheochromocytomas. Paragangliomas are benign neuroendocrine tumors arising from paraganglia in the neck or abdomen. They are composed of chief and sustentacular cells arranged in an organoid pattern.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 38-year-old woman was being evaluated for persistent hypertension. Workup revealed a tumor located near the bifurcation of the aorta. Surgical excision was done and HPE examination revealed a zellballen pattern of cells. Where did this tumor likely originate from?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of a paraganglioma (ectopic pheochromocytoma) located in the abdomen. They commonly arise from the organ of Zuckerkandl, located at the bifurcation of the aorta. It is part of the vertebral paraganglia (clusters of chromaffin cells along the autonomic nerve chains). Other sites of origin of paragangliomas include: Urinary bladder - rarely Carotid and aortic bodies Ganglion nodosum of the vagus nerve Jugulotympanic ganglia
subject: Pathology

question_text: What mutation is likely to be seen in patients with familial paraganglioma syndrome?
explanation: Familial paraganglioma is most likely associated with mutations in the SDH (succinate dehydrogenase) gene. The SDH complex is involved in mitochondrial electron transport and oxygen sensing. It is believed that SDH mutations also lead to the upregulation of HIF-1, which is a key oncogenic driver in this type of tumor.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 21-year-old young man presents with a neck mass. Past history is significant for surgical removal of a pheochromocytoma 6 months ago. On examination, a marfanoid habitus is noted along with the following finding. Which of the following should the patient be screened for?
explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing mucosal neuromas are suggestive of MEN2B syndrome. This condition is associated with medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. The MEN syndromes are a group of inherited diseases of multiple endocrine organs. Tumors occur at a younger age than sporadic tumors, either synchronously (at the same time) or metachronously (at different times). MEN2 syndrome occurs due to abnormal activation of the RET gene. Medullary carcinoma is seen in both MEN 2A and 2B syndromes. However, it tends to be more aggressive and metastasizes more frequently in MEN2B syndrome. Note: RET gene is deactivated in Hirschsprung disease.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
What gene is mutated in polycythemia paraganglioma syndrome?
RET
explanation: Polycythemia paraganglioma syndrome occurs due to germline mutations in the EPAS1 gene. This syndrome presents with neuroendocrine tumors and early-onset polycythemia. RET gene mutation is seen in MEN2A and MEN2B syndromes. SDHD and SDHB mutations are seen in hereditary paraganglioma 1 and hereditary paraganglioma 4 syndromes respectively. The Breast
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following lesions does not arise from the terminal duct lobular unit of the breast?
explanation: Periductal mastitis arises from the large lactiferous ducts. It is also known as squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ducts, recurrent subareolar abscess, or Zuska disease. The terminal duct lobular unit (TDLU) is the basic functional and histopathological unit of the breast. Successive branching of large ducts eventually leads to the TDLU. Sclerosing adenosis, blue dome cyst, and carcinoma breast arise from the TDLU.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following lesions arise from the large ducts of the breast?
explanation: Duct ectasia and Paget's disease arise from the large ducts of the breast. Normal anatomy of the breast includes ducts, lobules, and stroma. Successive branching of the large ducts eventually leads to the terminal duct lobular unit. Atypical hyperplasia arises from the terminal ducts and lobules, whereas, fibroadenoma and phyllodes tumors arise from the intralobular stroma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 28-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast. On examination, you notice her nipple is erythematous and tender with a purulent exudate. Which of the following is the most common cause of this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute mastitis. The most common cause of acute mastitis is Staphylococcus aureus. Acute bacterial mastitis typically occurs during the 1st month of breastfeeding (lactational breast abscess). It is caused by a local bacterial infection when the breast is most vulnerable due to cracks and fissures in the nipples. Staphylococcal acute mastitis typically results in localized abscesses. Option A: Breast abscess caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa is uncommon, only a few cases have been documented in immunocompromised patients. Options B and C: Streptococcal infections tend to spread throughout the breast in the form of cellulitis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following diseases is most strongly associated with a history of smoking?
explanation: Periductal mastitis is strongly associated with a history of smoking. More than 90% of the affected individuals are smokers. Periductal mastitis is also called recurrent subareolar abscess or squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ducts or Zuska disease. In this condition, a relative deficiency of vitamin A associated with smoking or toxic substances in tobacco smoke alters the differentiation of the ductal epithelium. Histologically, there is keratinizing squamous metaplasia of the nipple ducts. Keratin shed from these cells is trapped and plugs (keratin plug) the ductal system, causing dilation and eventually rupture of the duct. This results in keratin spillage into the surrounding periductal tissue forming a chronic granulomatous inflammatory response. It presents with a painful erythematous subareolar mass that clinically mimics bacterial abscess. It has a high recurrence rate.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a painless palpable lump in her left breast. She had sustained a traumatic blow to her left breast 1 month back. Mammography showed a radiolucent cystic lesion with rimmed calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The typical history of a breast lump following trauma and mammography findings of a radiolucent cystic lesion with rimmed calcification suggests a diagnosis of fat necrosis. About half the affected women with fat necrosis of the breast have a history of breast trauma or previous surgery. It can present as a painless palpable mass, skin thickening or retraction, or mammographic densities or calcifications. Histologically, necrotic adipose tissue with foamy macrophages, multinucleated giant cells, and chronic inflammatory cells are seen often with hemosiderin deposits, fibrosis, and calcification. The following image shows an area of fat necrosis within breast tissue. Note: Calcifications are seen on mammography in the following conditions - Apocrine cysts Hyalinized fibroadenomas Sclerosing adenosis Duct ectasia Breast carcinoma- shows irregular densities and small, numerous, clustered calcification (microcalcifications).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is a proliferative breast lesion?
explanation: Papillomas are classified under proliferative breast diseases without atypia. Proliferative breast lesions without atypia are not clonal and usually have no genetic changes. Thus they are predictors of risk but are not true precursors of carcinoma. Benign epithelial lesions are classified into three groups, according to the subsequent risk of developing breast cancer. These are: Non-proliferative breast changes Proliferative breast disease without atypia Atypical hyperplasia Note: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) has recently been classified as a benign lesion with associated risk for developing carcinoma in the future but not as a malignancy capable of metastases.
subject: Pathology

question_text: All of the following lesions are proliferative breast lesions without atypia except:
explanation: Duct ectasia is a non-proliferative breast change. Radial scar, sclerosing adenosis, and florid hyperplasia belong to proliferative breast lesions without atypia. Proliferative breast lesions without atypia are not clonal and are not commonly found to have genetic changes. Thus they are predictors of risk but unlikely to be true precursors of carcinoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common clinical presentation seen in patients with duct papilloma?
explanation: The most common clinical presentation seen in patients with duct papilloma is nipple discharge. More than 80% of large duct papillomas produce a nipple discharge. Papillomas grow within a dilated duct and are composed of multiple branching fibrovascular cores. It can be serous or bloody. Serous discharge - due to intermittent blockage and release of normal breast secretions or irritation of the duct by the papilloma Bloody discharge - due to torsion of the stalk, causing infarction
subject: Pathology

question_text: A young man presents to your clinic with the following finding. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
explanation: The image given depicts gynecomastia. Seminoma is not a cause of this condition. Gynecomastia occurs due to increased estrogenic action. The most common causes of gynecomastia include: Cirrhosis of the liver Alcoho Mari˜uana, heroin Antiretroviral therapy Anabolic steroids Klinefelter syndrome (››Y karyotype) Functioning testicular neoplasms such as Leydig cell or Sertoli cell tumors Microscopically, there is an increase in the dense collagenous connective tissue. It is associated with epithelial hyperplasia of the duct lining with characteristic tapering micro-papillae. Lobule formation is almost never observed.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A biopsy was performed on a female patient who presented with a lump in her right breast. Presence of which of the following findings is not associated with an increased risk of cancer?
explanation: Apocrine change does not increase the risk of cancer as it is a non-proliferative change. Moderate or florid hyperplasia, fibroadenoma with complex features, and sclerosing adenosis are classified under proliferative disease without atypia with a 1.5- to 2-fold increased risk of carcinoma. Both breasts are at increased risk, although the risk to the ipsilateral breast may be slightly higher.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
While undergoing a routine mammogram, a 45-year-old woman was found to have clusters of microcalcification in her right breast. A needle biopsy was done and revealed the following.
Which of the following markers can be used to rule out invasive disease?
explanation: The given image is suggestive of the comedo type of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Myoepithelial cell markers like p63 can differentiate DCIS from invasive carcinoma. DCIS is a malignant clonal proliferation of epithelial cells limited to ducts and lobules by the intact basement membrane. It is rarely palpable and is almost always detected by mammography. Myoepithelial cells (basal cell layer) are preserved in involved ducts or lobules in DCIS. Hence the myoepithelial cell markers like p63, basal cytokeratin (CK 5/6), calponin will be positive in DCIS whereas it will be absent in infiltrating ductal carcinoma. However, myoepithelial markers may be diminished in high-grade DCIS compared to surrounding normal ducts or lobules. Once the tumor cells penetrate through the basement membrane and grow within the stroma, they are considered to be invasive carcinoma. Note: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) has recently been classified as a benign lesion with associated risk for developing carcinoma in the future but not as a malignancy capable of metastases.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 55-year-old woman presents with persistent soreness and itching in her right nipple. On examination, the following finding is noted. What would be the next best step in her management?
explanation: The given scenario showing a red eczematous rash over the areola of the breast is suggestive of Paget's disease of the nipple. The next best step in management is biopsy of the nipple. Paget's disease can be mistaken for eczema, and hence, biopsy of the nipple should be the initial management of choice. Paget cells are readily detected by nipple biopsy.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Histopathological examination of a middle-aged woman who presented with redness and itching over the nipple of her left breast is given below. Which of the following statements is incorrect about her condition?
options: Prognosis depends on the underlying carcinoma
The cells show overexpression of HER2
explanation: The given clinical scenario and image showing Paget's cells (malignant cells with abundant pale cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei) are suggestive of Paget's disease of the nipple. These cells are ER-negative. Paget's disease of the nipple is a rare form of ductal carcinoma in-situ (DCIS). The characteristic Paget's cells are scattered individually throughout the squamous epithelium. They do not breach the basement membrane but extend via the lactiferous sinuses into the nipple skin. The following images show Paget's cells that do not breach the basement membrane. It presents as a unilateral erythematous eruption with a scale crust. A palpable mass is seen in about half the patients with this disease. The underlying carcinomas are usually poorly differentiated, ER-negative, and overexpress HER2. The prognosis of Paget's disease depends on the features of the underlying carcinoma. Paget's disease may mimic the following conditions: Eczema (clinical appearance) - can be differentiated by the presence of malignant cells on biopsy Superficial spreading melanoma (histological appearance) - Paget's cells are PAS-positive and diastase resistant unlike melanoma cells Note: Paget's disease of the bone is a distinct condition that results in abnormal bone metabolism due to osteoclastic overactivity.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for breast cancer?
explanation: Early full-term pregnancy (younger than 20 years) is protective against breast cancer. It halves the risk of developing breast cancer compared to that of nulliparous women. Women with very dense breasts on mammography have a four- to six-fold higher risk of both ER-positive and ER-negative breast cancer compared to women with low density. Obese women under the age of 40 years have a decreased risk as a result of anovulatory cycles and lower progesterone levels. In contrast, postmenopausal obese women are at an increased risk, which is attributed to the synthesis of estrogens in fat depots. Early menarche, late menopause, and nulliparity are risk factors of breast cancer due to hyperestrogenemia. Exercise and breastfeeding are protective against breast cancer.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common site of carcinoma in the breast?
explanation: The upper outer quadrant is the most common site of carcinoma in the breast. Approximately 50% of carcinomas are located in the upper outer quadrant, 10% in each of the remaining quadrants, and about 20% in the central or subareolar region. A palpable mass is the most common clinical sign of invasive breast carcinoma. Triple assessment is recommended for the diagnosis of any palpable breast lump. It includes: Clinical examination Radiological assessment (mammography/USG) Pathological assessment (FNAC/biopsy) Techniques of palpation for breast examination are: Vertical strip/lines pattern Circular pattern Wedges or radial spokes pattern
subject: Pathology

question_text: On which of the following chromosomes is the BRCA2 gene located?
explanation: BRCA2 gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 13 (13q12.3). Mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2 are responsible for 80 to 90% of single gene familial breast cancers and about 3% of all breast cancers. ER-positive, HER2-negative cancers (luminal type) is the most common subtype of breast cancer in individuals who inherit germline mutations in BRCA2. This gene is associated more frequently with male breast cancer. Single gene mutations associated with familial breast cancer can be categorized into: High penetrance germline mutations (>4 fold increased risk) - BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, PTEN, STK11, CDH I, PALPB2 Moderate penetrance germline mutations (2-4 fold increased risk) - ATM, CHEK2
subject: Pathology

question_text: Immunohistochemical testing was performed on a biopsy sample taken from a patient with breast cancer. It revealed lack of expression of ER, PR, and HER2. Which of the following genes is most commonly mutated in this condition?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of triple-negative breast cancer (ER-negative, PR-negative, and HER2-negative). TP53 is the most commonly mutated gene in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). Common gene mutations in the 3 ma˜or molecular types of invasive breast carcinoma are: Molecular Subtype Common gene mutations Luminal (ER+/HER2 -) Luminal A: PIK3CA (more co mmon), TP53Luminal B: PIK 3CA (more common), TP53 Molecular Subtype Common gene mutations HER2 Positive (HER 2+) TP53 (more common), PIK3C A TNBC (ER-/ HER2-) TP53 (more common), PIK3C A
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 44-year-old woman has been diagnosed with breast carcinoma. Immunohistochemistry staining of a tissue biopsy specimen of this patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?
options: It is not associated with tP53 mutations
explanation: The given immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining shows positive ER, PR (brown nucleus), and negative Her-2 (no membrane-bound brown stain) expression, which is suggestive of luminal A molecular subtype. It shows a poor response to paclitaxel. Hormone receptors (ER, PR) are present in the nucleus. Therefore ER, PR–positive breast cancer cells will stain dark in the nucleus on IHC. Her-2 receptors are membrane-bound receptors, and hence, cells having these receptors are darkly stained on the membranes. Luminal A type is more commonly associated with BRCA2 mutations. Hormone receptor-positive tumors are responsive to hormonal chemotherapeutic agents like tamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors. In Her-2 negative cases, trastuzumab is not effective as it is a recombinant humanized monoclonal antibody directed against HER-2. The following image shows ER/ PR/ Her-2 positivity: Note: At least 10% of luminal type A breast cancers express tp53 mutations. tP53 mutations are associated with triple-negative tumors as well.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Immunohistochemistry test of a breast cancer patient was reported negative for ER and HER2. This molecular subtype includes all of the following except:
explanation: Carcinomas with immunohistochemistry ER and HER2/ negative are all of the above except mucinous carcinomas. Mucinous carcinomas are usually ER-positive and HER2/neu negative (luminal A type) ER-negative, HER2-negative (triple-negative) molecular subtype commonly includes the following histological subtypes: Medullary Adenoid cystic Secretory Metaplastic Spindle ce Squamous Matrix-producing
subject: Pathology

question_text: Patients with all of the following conditions have ER-positive and HER2-negative tumors except:
explanation: ER-positive, HER2-negative status on immunohistochemistry is suggestive of the luminal type of breast carcinoma, which does not include secretory carcinoma. The ER-positive, HER2-negative molecular subtype (luminal type) commonly includes the following histological subtypes: Well and poorly differentiated lobular carcinoma Tubular carcinoma Mucinous carcinoma Papillary carcinoma Secretory carcinomas are usually ER-negative and Her2/neu negative (basal type).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following breast cancers most commonly presents as an occult primary carcinoma?
explanation: Lobular carcinoma is the most common type of breast carcinoma to present as an occult primary carcinoma. Lobular carcinoma of the breast is seen bilaterally and with multicentricity. Loss of E-cadherin is the hallmark of lobular carcinoma. They also have characteristic patterns of metastatic spread, often involving the peritoneum and retroperitoneum, leptomeninges (carcinomatous meningitis), gastrointestinal tract, ovaries, and uterus. The histological hallmark of lobular carcinoma is the presence of discohesive infiltrating tumor cells, often arranged in a single Indian file pattern or in loose clusters or sheets.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a feature of lobular breast carcinoma?
explanation: There is no or very slight desmoplastic response seen in lobular carcinomas. Desmoplasia refers to collagenous stromal proliferation induced by tumor cells which is essential for tumor growth and spread. It results in hard and stony tumors. However, this is not seen in lobular carcinoma. This is likely due to the loss of expression of CDH1, the gene that encodes e-cadherin (normally maintains intercellular adhesiveness). This also results in disaggregation of cells. Lobular carcinomas are often bilateral and multicentric. It shows characteristic metastatic spread, often involving: Peritoneum and retro peritoneum Leptomeninges (carcinomatous meningitis) Gastrointestinal tract Ovaries Uterus Histopathological image of invasive lobular carcinoma of breast showing discohesive cells with few signet ring cells. Note: Individuals with heterozygous germline mutations in CDH1 (loss of E-cadherin) also have a greatly increased risk of gastric signet-ring cell carcinoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 53-year-old woman with breast cancer is found to have TNM staging of T4dN0M0. Which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?
options: There is loss of e-cadherin expression
It has a relatively favorable prognosis
There is obstruction of dermal lymphatics by neoplastic cells
History of trauma to the breast is usually present
explanation: T4d in the TNM staging of carcinoma breast points toward a diagnosis of inflammatory breast carcinoma. It shows extensive invasion and proliferation of tumor cells within the dermal lymphatics leading to obstruction. Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The hallmark of this condition is the overexpression of e-cadherin. This results in increased tumor cohesion and the formation of tumoral clumps which can result in emboli. It has a particularly poor prognosis. These tumors are usually of high grade but do not belong to any particular molecular subtype. More than half (60%) are ER-negative and 40% to 50% overexpress HER2. There is no association with trauma. Due to lymphatic obstruction, it results in brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema called peau d’orange appearance. This may mimic non-neoplastic inflammatory lesions like mastitis. A breast lump may or may not be present. The following image shows a peau d’orange appearance of the right breast.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Immunohistochemistry for HER2 protein expression is performed in 3 patients with breast carcinoma, with the following results. Which of the following patients should be sub˜ected to fluorescence in-situ hybridization?
explanation: The immunohistochemistry (IHC) pattern of patient C reveals moderately strong circumferential staining (faint brown color) in >10 % of cells, which is classified as 2+ or equivocal staining. Hence, she should be sub˜ected to fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) to confirm HER2-positive gene amplification status. The following are classified as HER2-positive tumors: Tumors that show 3+ staining on IHC (here FISH is not needed). Tumors with 2+ staining on IHC, followed by HER2-gene amplification confirmed by FISH Once HER2-positive status is confirmed, targeted therapy against HER2 can be initiated with trastuzumab or lapatinib.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A middle-aged woman is diagnosed with low-grade mucinous carcinoma of the breast. IHC showed HER2 overexpression and a low Ki67 index. Which of the following would be considered as a poor prognostic factor?
explanation: HER2 overexpression in a patient with carcinoma breast is associated with poor survival. The main importance of HER2 status is as a predictor of response to agents that target this receptor. Prognostic and predictive factors in breast carcinoma: Good prognosis Bad prognosis Extent and spread In situ carcinoma Invasive carcinomaLocally ad vanced diseaseLymphovascu ar invasionDistant metastasis Size Size <1 cm Size >2 cm Histological subtype Tubular carcinomaMucinous carcinomaLobular carcinoma Papillary carcinomaAdenoid cystic carcinoma Metaplastic carcinomaMicro papillary carcinoma Histologic grade Low grade High grade Molecular subtype Luminal A subtype Her2-enriched and basal subt ype Proliferation rate(Ki67 index & mitotic counts) Low proliferation rate High proliferation rate
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old woman on cyclosporin-A following renal transplantation developed multiple bilateral breast lumps that regressed after cessation of treatment. ■Her biopsy finding is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing duct proliferation are suggestive of fibroadenomas. The use of cyclosporin-A after transplantation is associated with fibroadenomas that regress after cessation of the treatment. Fibroadenomas are the most common benign tumor of the female breast. Nearly 2/3 cases are associated with mutations in the MED12 gene. They are frequently multiple and bilateral and usually occur in women <30 years of age. They are solid, well-defined, highly mobile masses (also known as breast mice). Fibroadenomas can be classified into 2 types: Without complex features - classified as a non-proliferative condition With complex features - Associated with cysts > 0.3 cm, sclerosing adenosis, epithelial calcifications, or papillary apocrine change Classified as proliferative changes without atypia
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 58-year-old woman presented with a large, rapidly growing painless breast lump. On examination, a smooth, multinodular breast lump was noticed. Microscopic examination of the core biopsy sample is shown below. Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding this condition?
options: Stromal cellularity is increased next to the epithelium
Absence of epithelial elements suggests malignancy
Both epithelial and stromal components can metastasize
explanation: The given clinical scenario and image are suggestive of phyllodes tumor. Here, only the stromal component is involved in metastasis. Phyllodes tumor is a fibroepithelial tumor arising from the intralobular stroma. It presents as a smooth, rapidly growing, multinodular, painless breast lump that is usually palpable. It most commonly presents in the 6th decade of life and is associated with: Gain in chromosome 1q HO›B13 overexpression Phyllodes tumors show stromal cellularity next to the epithelium (subepithelial or periepithelial regions). This feature helps to differentiate it from intracanalicular fibroadenoma. The prognosis of phyllodes tumors depends on their histological grade. Most phyllodes tumors are low grade, with limited stromal cellularity. They recur only occasionally and do not metastasize. The features of malignant (intermediate and high grade) phyllodes tumors are: Markedly increased stromal cellularity Stromal overgrowth - absence of epithelial elements Nuclear atypia Increased mitosis (>10/ 10 hpf) Highly recurrent Regardless of the grade, lymphatic spread is rare in phyllodes tumors. Hence, axillary lymph node dissection is contraindicated.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common stromal malignancy in the breast?
explanation: Angiosarcoma is the most common stromal malignancy in the breast. It arises in the interlobular stroma and accounts for < 0.05% of breast malignancies. It is a high-grade tumor with a poor prognosis. It can either be sporadic or occur in association with radiation therapy. The mean age of affected individuals is 35 years.
subject: Pathology

question_text: BRCA-2 mutation does not predispose to the development of which of the following conditions?
explanation: BRCA-2 mutation does not predispose to the development of renal cell carcinoma. BRCA-2 mutation predisposes to the development of prostate and pancreatic cancer. It is also associated with an increased risk of male breast cancer.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of her breast. Histopathological examination of the mass showed cells in mucin pools and faint nuclei. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Colloid carcinoma
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of colloid or mucinous carcinoma of the breast. Colloid carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intracellular and extracellular mucin deposition. On histopathological examination, extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei, arranged in clusters, floating in lakes or pools of mucin. In intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to the periphery to form a signet ring appearance. Option B: Microscopic image of papillary carcinoma of the breast showing true papillae with a leaf-like arrangement of fibrovascular tissue lined by the tumor cells is shown below. Option C: Microscopic image of medullary carcinoma of the breast consisting of sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures (anaplastic cells), lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate is shown below. Option D: Microscopic image of lobular carcinoma of the breast shows infiltrating small monomorphic discohesive tumor cells arranged in an Indian-file or single-file pattern is shown below. Developmental disorders,infections and tumors of bone
subject: Pathology

question_text: What are the specialized multinucleated macrophages in bone called?
explanation: Osteoclasts are specialized multinucleated macrophages derived from circulating monocytes that are responsible for bone resorption. Osteocytes are formed when osteoblasts are embedded in the matrix within lacunae and canaliculi. They control calcium and phosphate levels in the microenvironment. Osteoblasts are mesenchymal cells that rim the bony spicule, responsible for bone synthesis and mineralization. Chondrocytes are specialized cells that produce and maintain the extracellular matrix of cartilage. The image given below shows different cells present in a bone.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is not a marker of bone resorption?
explanation: Osteocalcin is not a bone resorption marker. It is a protein secreted only by osteoblasts. Thus, it is a bone formation marker (osteoblastic marker).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is the most common benign bone tumor?
explanation: Osteochondroma, also known as exostosis, is the most common benign bone tumor. It is a benign cartilage-capped tumor. 85% of osteochondromas are solitary. The remainder is seen as part of the multiple hereditary exostosis syndromes, an autosomal-dominant hereditary disease. Lesions arise from the metaphysis near the growth plate of long tubular bones, especially near the knee. They are either sessile or pedunculated and range in size from 1 to 20 cm. Histologically, the cap is composed of benign hyaline cartilage varying in thickness and is covered peripherally by perichondrium. Osteochondromas can progress to chondrosarcoma. The image below shows the histopathological specimen of osteochondroma, displaying a cartilage cap lined by perichondrium contiguous with mature bone.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A woman delivered a child who died a few minutes after birth. The infant was found to have blue sclera and fractures of the right humerus, ulna, and femur at birth. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta type II. The type II variant of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is uniformly fatal in utero or during the perinatal period. Type II OI is characterized by extraordinary bone fragility with multiple intrauterine fractures. Osteogenesis imperfecta (brittle bone disease) is caused by deficiencies in the synthesis of type I collagen. It can be separated into four major clinical subtypes that vary widely in severity. The severity of the disease is based on the location of the mutation within the protein. Individuals with type I OI have a normal life span, but experience childhood fractures that decrease in frequency following puberty.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 29-year-old woman gives birth to an infant with less than 5th percentile length. The head and torso are of normal size but extremities are short. The head circumference is at the 95th percentile, and frontal bossing is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This given clinical scenario is suggestive of achondroplasia. A hondroplasia is the most common skeletal dysplasia and a major cause of dwarfism. It has autosomal dominant inheritance. It occurs due to the gain of mutation in fibroblast growth factor receptor (FGFR3). This leads to abnormal cartilage proliferation at growth plates and affects endochondral bone growth. Infants present with: Short stature Rhizomelic shortening of limbs Frontal bossing Midface deficiency The condition is not associated with changes in longevity, intelligence, or reproductive status. The image below shows a baby affected with achondroplasia. Note the prominent forehead, triangular face, and body asymmetry in the image (a); a low nasal bridge in the image (b); trident hands in the image (c); and scoliosis in the image (d).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is also called marble bone disease?
explanation: Albers-Schönberg disease or osteopetrosis is also known as marble bone disease. The term osteopetrosis reflects the stone-like quality of the bones. The bones are abnormally brittle and fracture easily, like a piece of chalk. It occurs due to reduced bone resorption and diffuse symmetric skeletal sclerosis because of impaired formation or function of osteoclasts. Note: Osteogenesis imperfecta is also called brittle bone disease. Paget's disease is also called osteitis deformans; it presents with mosaic pattern of lamellar bone.
subject: Pathology

question_text: An infant is being evaluated for multiple fractures over the last 3 months. On examination, hydrocephaly, cranial nerve defects, and hepatosplenomegaly are noted. Imaging reveals generalized sclerosis and a bone-in-bone appearance. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme to be deficient in this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteopetrosis. It occurs due to autosomal recessive defects in the gene for the enzyme carbonic anhydrase II. Carbonic anhydrase II is required by osteoclasts and renal tubular cells to generate protons from carbon dioxide and water (acidification). The absence of carbonic anhydrase II prevents osteoclasts from acidifying the resorption pit and dissolution of calcium hydroxyapatite within the bone matrix. It also blocks the acidification of urine by the renal tubular cells. This leads to reduced bone resorption and diffuse symmetric skeletal sclerosis. Due to deficient osteoclast activity, bones involved by osteopetrosis lack a medullary canal giving it a bone-in-bone appearance. The ends of long bones are bulbous (Erlenmeyer flask deformity) and misshapen. The neural foramina are small and compress the exiting nerves, leading to cranial nerve palsies. Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis leads to leukopenia and prominent hepatosplenomegaly. As carbonic anhydrase II is widely expressed, mutations of this gene result in a condition called marble brain disease or Guibaud-Vainsel syndrome.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with sudden severe back pain. There is no history of trauma. X-ray findings are given below. MRI shows thinning of trabecular plates of the vertebrae and vertebral collapse. Levels of which of the following will be increased in her condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteoporosis. Cytokines stimulate osteoclast recruitment and activity in osteoporosis by increasing the levels of RANKL. RANKL helps in diminishing the expression of osteoprotegerin (OPG), increasing osteoclast proliferation, and preventing osteoclast apoptosis. Decreased estrogen levels after menopause actually increase both bone resorption and formation. However, the latter does not keep up with the former, leading to a high turnover. Decreased estrogen appears to increase the secretion of inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6, TNF-, and IL-1.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In patients with which of the following conditions will you see a histologically normal bone?
explanation: Histologically normal bone with decreased density is the hallmark feature of osteoporosis. In advanced osteoporosis, both the trabecular bone of the medulla and the cortical bone are markedly thinned leading to progressive microfractures. Option A: Inadequate mineralization in osteomalacia leads to a thickened osteoid matrix. Option C: Paget's disease presents with a mosaic pattern of lamellar bone. Option D: Dissecting osteitis cystica is seen in severe hyperparathyroidism.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient presents with back pain, recurrent headaches, and increasing head size. On evaluation, raised alkaline phosphatase and a mosaic pattern of lamellar bone is seen. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
options: It occurs due to mutations in the SQSTM1 gene
It is polyostotic in about 15% of cases
Sarcoma occurs in less than 1% of all individuals
explanation: Paget disease is monostotic in about 15% of cases and polyostotic in the rest of them. Paget disease (osteitis deformans) is a disorder of increased, but disordered and structurally unsound, bone mass. The onset is in late adulthood (average age at diagnosis, 70 years). It occurs due to mutations in the SQSTM1 gene. This increases the activity of NF-B, which then increases osteoclast activity. Three sequential phases exist: Initial osteolytic stage Mixed osteoclastic-osteoblastic stage Final burned-out quiescent osteosclerotic stage The axial skeleton or proximal femur is involved in up to 80% of the cases. The typical x-ray findings are as follows: Enlargement of the craniofacial skeleton: leontiasis ossea or lion face Invagination of the skull base (platybasia) Chalk stick-type fractures in the long bones of the lower extremities The pathological hallmark is a mosaic pattern of lamellar bone, seen in the sclerotic phase as shown below. It shows a jigsaw-like pattern produced by unusually prominent cement lines, which join haphazardly oriented units of lamellar bone. Laboratory findings show elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and urinary hydroxyproline (normal serum calcium and phosphorus). Following tumors can develop in the affected bones in Paget's disease: Benign tumors - Giant cell tumors Giant cell reparative granuloma Extra-osseous masses of hematopoietic tissue Sarcoma (osteosarcoma or fibrosarcoma) - most dreaded complication. Occurs in < 1 % of all individuals with Paget disease, and in 5% to 10% of those with the severe polyostotic disease.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In patients with hyperparathyroidism, which of the following is least expected?
explanation: Osteopetrosis does not belong to the clinical spectrum of hyperparathyroidism. The features of hyperparathyroidism are as follows: Osteitis fibrosa cystica Osteopenia/osteoporosis Hyperuricemia and gout Pseudogout Increased production of calcitriol Dissecting osteitis and brown tumors Nephrolithiasis Hypophosphatemia Anemia Hyperparathyroidism leads to significant skeletal changes related to unabated osteoclast activity. Increased osteoclast activity is most prominent in cortical bone, but the medullary bone is not spared. Osteoclasts may tunnel into and dissect centrally along the length of the trabeculae, creating the appearance of railroad tracks, diagnostic of dissecting osteitis. Generalised osteoporosis may be seen in the phalanges, vertebrae, and proximal femur. Brown tumor presents with bone loss leading to microfractures and secondary hemorrhages which causes influx of macrophages and ingrowth of reparative fibrous tissue. Generalized osteitis presents with increased bone cell activity, peri-trabecular fibrosis, and cystic brown tumors.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 7-year-old child presented with fever, pain, and swelling around the knee joint for 3 days. Lab investigations showed a WBC count of 23,500/mm3. An MRI was done, which demonstrated an intramedullary abscess of the proximal tibia. Which of the following is the most common causative organism of this condition?
explanation: The given clinical picture is suggestive of acute pyogenic osteomyelitis. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of culture-positive pyogenic osteomyelitis. Osteomyelitis denotes inflammation of bone and marrow, almost always secondary to infection. Organisms may reach the bone by Hematogenous spread Extension from a contiguous site Direct implantation The common causative organisms include: Staphylococcus aureus - the most common cause overall Pseudomonas aeruginosa - most common cause in IV drug abusers Salmonella - common in patients of sickle cell anemia Haemophilus influenzae - was a common causative organism in children, less common now due to vaccination Streptococcus pyogenes - most common in neonates Escherichia coli, Klebsiella- most common cause in patients with genitourinary tract infections
subject: Pathology

question_text: Patients with sickle cell disease are particularly susceptible to osteomyelitis caused by which of the following?
explanation: Salmonella enteritidis is commonly implicated in osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell anemia. The common causative organisms include: Staphylococcus aureus - the most common cause overall Pseudomonas aeruginosa - most common cause in IV drug abusers Salmonella - most common in patients of sickle cell anemia Haemophilus influenzae - was a common causative organism in children, less common now due to vaccination Streptococcus pyogenes - neonates Escherichia coli, Klebsiella- most common cause in patients with genitourinary tract infections
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient who is a known case of TB presents to the orthopedic OPD with a 4-month history of progressively worsening back pain. He also complains of fatigue and irregular fever for 2 weeks. X-ray reveals lytic destruction of the anterior portion of the vertebral body and increased anterior wedging. All of the following are the complications of his condition except
explanation: The patient is most likely suffering from TB osteomyelitis. Brodie's abscess is not a complication of this condition. In tuberculous osteomyelitis, weight-bearing joints - spine (Pott's disease), hips, and knees, are most commonly affected. Complications of tuberculous osteomyelitis include: Scoliosis or kyphosis (gibbus) Neurologic deficits secondary to spinal cord and nerve compression leading to paraplegia - Tuberculous arthritis Sinus tract formation Psoas abscess - may be due to paravertebral “cold” abscess AA amyloidosis
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 25-year-old man presents with back pain that is unresponsive to aspirin. Radiographs show a well-demarcated lesion in the posterior spine. A biopsy is done and the histopathological finding is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
[Image unavailable]
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteoblastoma. Histopathology shows well-circumscribed lesions composed of randomly interconnecting trabeculae of woven bone that are prominently rimmed by a single layer of osteoblasts. Stroma surrounding the neoplastic bone consists of loose connective tissue that contains many dilated and congested capillaries. The image below shows the histopathological findings in osteoblastoma. Osteoid osteoma and osteoblastoma are benign bone-producing tumors that have identical histologic features. The differentiating features between them are given below: Osteoid osteoma Osteoblastoma Less than 2 cm in diameter Larger than 2 cm in diameter Predilection for the appendic ular skeleton involves the posterior spine (l aminae and pedicles) Thick rind of reactive cortical bone is seen on radiography Usually, no marked bony rea ction is seen on radiography Pain that is relieved by aspiri n and other non-steroidal ant i-inflammatory agents Pain which is unresponsive t o aspirin
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 17-year-old man presents with progressive swelling of the upper end of the humerus. He also complains of arm pain and weight loss for 3 months. X-ray findings are given below. Which of the following is associated with a higher risk of developing this condition?
explanation: The given history and classic sunburst appearance on the X-ray are highly suggestive of osteosarcoma. Mutation of p53 (Li-Fraumeni syndrome) is associated with a greater risk of sarcomas, particularly osteosarcoma. The image given below shows sunburst pattern seen in osteosarcoma. Option A: Translocation (X;18) is characteristic of synovial sarcoma. Option B: Translocation (12;16) is characteristic of myxoid liposarcoma. Option D: 1p rearrangements are characteristic of conventional chondrosarcoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about osteosarcoma?
options: It usually arises in the diaphyseal region of long bones
It has a bimodal age distribution
Codman triangle is characteristic of the tumor
Most common subtype is osteoblastic and high grade
explanation: Osteosarcomas usually arise in the metaphyseal region of the long bones of the extremities. It commonly occurs in the knee (i.e., distal femur or proximal tibia). The most common subtype is primary, intramedullary, osteoblastic, and high grade. It is a malignant tumor in which the cancerous cells produce an osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. It occurs in all age groups but has a bimodal age distribution. The formation of fine lace-like neoplastic bone by the tumor cells is diagnostic histopathologically of osteosarcoma as shown below. Radiography shows a large destructive, mixed lytic and blastic mass with infiltrative margins, which breaks through the cortex and lifts the periosteum, resulting in reactive periosteal bone formation. The triangular shadow between the cortex and raised ends of the periosteum, known radiographically as the Codman triangle, is characteristic of osteosarcoma. This is shown in the radiograph below.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following bone tumors is characteristically seen in patients with Ollier disease and Maffucci syndrome?
explanation: Ollier disease and Maffucci syndrome are nonhereditary disorders characterized by multiple enchondromas. Maffucci syndrome is, in addition, distinguished by the presence of spindle-cell hemangiomas. Enchondromas are benign tumors of hyaline cartilage that usually occur in bones of enchondral origin. They are usually diagnosed in individuals 20 to 50 years of age. They present as solitary metaphyseal lesions of tubular bones of the hands and feet. The radiographic features consist of circumscribed lucencies with central irregular calcifications, a sclerotic rim, and an intact cortex. They are usually smaller than 3 cm. They are gray-blue and translucent, composed of well-circumscribed nodules of hyaline cartilage containing cytomorphologically benign chondrocytes. The enchondromas in Ollier disease and Maffucci syndrome are sometimes more cellular than sporadic enchondromas and exhibit cytologic atypia, making them more difficult to distinguish from chondrosarcomas. The image below displays the histopathological picture of an enchondroma showing lobules of hyaline cartilage encased by bone and covered by perichondrium (fibrous tissue).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is not true about chondrosarcoma?
options: Conventional central tumors constitute about 90% of chondrosarcomas.
Clear cell and the mesenchymal variants occur in older patients.
Chondrosarcomas commonly arise in the axial skeleton.
In multiple hereditary exostosis, osteochondromas progress to chondrosarcoma.
explanation: The clear cell and the mesenchymal variants of chondrosarcoma occur in younger patients (teens or 20s). Chondrosarcomas are malignant tumors that produce cartilage. They commonly arise in the axial skeleton, especially the pelvis, shoulder, and ribs. They are subclassified histologically as following variants: Conventional (hyaline cartilage producing) - 90% cases Clear cell Dedifferentiated Mesenchymal In multiple hereditary exostosis, osteochondromas can progress to chondrosarcoma. Increased thickness of the cartilage cap has been reported as an indicator of potential malignancy. The average age of secondary chondrosarcoma is younger than patients with primary tumors.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following can progress to become chondrosarcoma?
explanation: Osteochondromas, multiple enchondromas, and synovial chondromatosis can progress to become chondrosarcoma. The average age of patients with secondary chondrosarcoma is 35 years (less than that of those with primary tumors). These tumors most commonly affect the pelvic bones. The increased thickness of the cartilage cap (normally 1–3 mm) is considered an indicator of potential malignancy. Multiple enchondromas in the setting of Ollier’s disease or Maffucci's syndrome carry a significantly higher risk of transformation to secondary chondrosarcoma than solitary enchondromas. Histological findings of abundant myxoid change, cyst formation, and permeation of existing trabeculae suggest malignancy. Secondary malignancy in synovial chondromatosis has been reported, but it is rare.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A plain radiograph of a patient shows a destructive lytic tumor that extends into the surrounding soft tissues with a characteristic onion-skin appearance. A biopsy image is shown below. Which of the following is not true about the tumor?
options: It is the second most common group of bone sarcomas in children
It arises in the epiphysis of long tubular bones
Most of these tumours contain a (11;22) (q24;q12) translocation
The amount of chemotherapy-induced necrosis is an important prognostic finding
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ewing sarcoma. It arises in the diaphysis of long bones, especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis. Ewing sarcoma follows osteosarcoma as the second most common group of bone sarcomas in children. It generally affects patients < 20 years. Boys are affected slightly more frequently than girls. Usually, the tumor arises in the diaphysis of long tubular bones, especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis. Fever, elevated sedimentation rate, anemia, and leukocytosis may be seen. Plain radiographs show a destructive lytic tumor with permeative margins that extend into the surrounding soft tissues. The characteristic periosteal reaction produces layers of reactive bone deposited in an onion-skin fashion. It arises in the medullary cavity and usually invades the cortex, periosteum, and soft tissue. On microscopy, sheets of uniform, small, round cells with scant cytoplasm are seen, which may appear clear because they are rich in glycogen. The presence of Homer–Wright rosettes indicates a greater degree of neuroectodermal differentiation. The image given below shows the histopathological findings in Ewing sarcoma. Most Ewing sarcoma family tumors contain an (11;22) (q24;q12) translocation. Variant translocations fuse the EWS to other members of the ETS transcription factor family. CD99(MIC2), FLI1, and NSE would be positive in ES/PNET.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 1-month history of pain in the left knee, which is tender on palpation. X-ray shows a 5 cm mass in the distal femoral epiphysis, with a soap bubble appearance. Microscopy is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteoclastoma/ giant-cell tumor (GCT) of bone. GCT is a relatively uncommon benign, but locally aggressive, neoplasm that usually arises in individuals in their 20s to 40s. The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL. It promotes the proliferation of osteoclast precursors and their differentiation into mature osteoclasts via RANK expressed by these cells. GCTs arise in the epiphysis but may extend into the metaphysis. The majority arise around the knee (distal femur and proximal tibia). Most are solitary, multicentric tumors in the distal extremities. The tumors destroy the overlying cortex, producing a bulging soft tissue mass delineated by a thin shell of reactive tissue. Histopathologically, sheets of uniform oval mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast-type giant cells are seen with 100 or more nuclei. Necrosis and mitotic activity may be prominent. The image given below shows the histopathological findings seen in osteoclastoma. Typically, they are treated with curettage, but 40% to 60% recur locally. Up to 4% of tumors metastasize to the lungs, but these sometimes spontaneously regress and they are rarely fatal. The RANKL inhibitor, denosumab, has shown promise as adjuvant therapy in GCT. Note: The E mnemonic for GCT: Epiphyseal Eccentri Egg-shell crackling Expansile
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 19-year old man presents with back pain for 2 months. MRI of the spine reveals a bony ystic mass at the L1 vertebra. Biopsy shows multiple, blood-filled cystic spaces separated by septae, composed of multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cells and reactive woven bone. There is no cartilage or necrosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an aneurysmal bone cyst. It affects all age groups, but generally occurs during the first 2 decades of life and has no sex predilection. It usually occurs in the metaphysis of long bones and the posterior elements of vertebral bodies. This is a tumor characterized by multiloculated blood-filled cystic spaces separated by septae, composed of multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cells and reactive woven bone. Radiographically, an aneurysmal bone cyst is seen as an eccentric, expansile, lesion with well-defined margins. Most lesions are completely lytic and often contain a thin shell of reactive bone at the periphery. The spindle cells of aneurysmal bone cyst frequently demonstrate rearrangements of chromosome 17p13, leading to USP6 overexpression. The majority of secondary aneurysmal bone cysts arise in association with: Benign neoplasms Giant-cell tumor of the bone (most common) Chondroblastoma Osteoblastoma Fibrous dysplasia Osteosarcoma
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 60-year-old patient complains of severe back pain for 2 months, which worsens at night. An MRI shows multiple osteoblastic secondaries on the vertebrae. Which of the following tumors could be the primary source of these lesions?
Renal cell carcinoma
explanation: Prostatic adenocarcinoma is associated with predominantly osteoblastic secondaries to the bones (vertebral column). The radiographic appearance of bone metastases may be purely lytic (bone destroying), purely blastic (bone-forming), or mixed lytic and blastic. Most cancers are associated with predominantly one pattern or the other. Parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) and transforming growth factor- (TGF- ) are implicated in osteolytic secondaries, while proteins such as endothelin-1 and morphogenetic proteins are implicated in osteoblastic lesions. Joints and soft tissue pathology
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 77-year-old woman presents with pain and limited movement of the left hip and knee for 10 years. The pain has increased in severity in the past 1 year. The x-ray of the hip is given below. Laboratory tests do not show RF or ANA in her serum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The x-ray image of the hip shows narrowing of the joint space and subchondral sclerosis which is diagnostic of osteoarthritis (OA), also called degenerative joint disease. OA is the most common type of joint disease, which is characterized by the degeneration of joint cartilage. This results in structural and functional failure of synovial joints. Osteoarthritis can be classified into 2 types: Primary OA: Insidious onset, without apparent initiating cause, as an aging phenomenon Secondary OA: Predisposing conditions such as joint deformity, a previous joint injury, or an underlying systemic disease such as diabetes, ochronosis, hemochromatosis, or marked obesity. The knees and hands are more commonly affected in women and the hips in men. OA lesions occur due to the degeneration of the articular cartilage and its disordered repair. Inflammatory cells are sparse, but cytokines and diffusible factors, particularly TGF- (which induces matrix metalloproteinases), TNF, prostaglandins, and nitric oxide, have been implicated in OA.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 28-year-old woman presents with complaints of joint pain and progressive loss of joint motion. On examination, symmetric joint swelling of the hands is seen. A subcutaneous nodule is seen over her right forearm. Microscopy of the excised nodule shows the findings given in the image below. Which of the following lab findings will be seen in this patient?
options: Uric acid crystals in joint aspirate
Calcium pyrophosphate crystals in joint aspirate
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis. The patient's serum will test positive for rheumatoid factor. Microscopy of the excised nodule shows a necrotizing granuloma with a central zone of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by a prominent rim of activated macrophages and numerous lymphocytes and plasma cells. Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of autoimmune origin that principally attacks the joints, producing nonsuppurative, proliferative, and inflammatory synovitis. The inflammation progresses to the destruction of the articular cartilage and ankylosis of the joints. In RA, the synovium contains germinal centers with secondary follicles and abundant plasma cells, which produce antibodies, some are autoantibodies. Many of the autoantibodies produced in the lymphoid organs are specific for citrullinated peptides (CCPs). 80% of patients have serum IgM or IgA autoantibodies that bind to the Fc portions of their own IgG. These autoantibodies are called rheumatoid factor and may also deposit in joints as immune complexes The characteristic histologic features of RA include: Synovial cell hyperplasia and proliferation Dense inflammatory infiltrates Increased vascularity due to angiogenesis Fibrinopurulent exudate on the synovial and joint surfaces Osteoclastic activity in underlying bone Subcutaneous nodule: necrotizing granulomas with a central zone of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded activated macrophages, lymphocytes, and plasma cells This altogether leads to a mass of edematous synovium called pannus, which grows over the articular cartilage and causes its erosion.
subject: Pathology

question_text: An obese 35-year-old man with renal failure presents with excruciating joint pain in the right knee. It is associated with localized hyperemia. Joint aspiration is done which shows dense neutrophilic infiltrate and the following finding under polarised light. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis is gout. Aspirate from the joint shows dense neutrophilic infiltrate and crystals that are long, slender, needle-shaped, and negatively birefringent. Gout is marked by transient attacks of acute arthritis initiated by crystallization of monosodium urate (MSU) within and around joints. This results in the production of cytokines that recruit leukocytes. Macrophages phagocytose the MSU and the inflammasome activates caspase-1, which is involved in the production of some biologically active cytokines. The distinctive morphologic changes in gout are acute arthritis, chronic tophaceous arthritis, tophi in various sites, and gouty nephropathy. Tophi are the pathognomonic hallmark of gout. These are large aggregations of urate crystals surrounded by an intense inflammatory reaction of foreign body giant cells which may appear in the articular cartilage, ligaments, tendons, bursae, earlobes, fingertips, or kidneys. Gouty nephropathy refers to the renal complications caused by MSU crystals or tophi in the renal medullary interstitium or tubules. Complications include uric acid nephrolithiasis and pyelonephritis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 3-year-old child with knee pain is found to have uric acid crystal deposition in his joints. On examination, excessive nail-biting is seen as shown below. Congenital deficiency of which of the following enzyme is responsible for this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. In this condition, there is a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). Lesch–Nyhan syndrome is charecterised by neurological and behavioral abnormalities such as lip and finger biting and head banging. It also causes the overproduction of uric acid, leading to gouty arthritis and impaired kidney function. It is classified as secondary gout.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 50-year-old patient presents with left knee pain, redness, and swelling for 3 days. Joint aspiration is performed and microscopic findings under polarised light are given in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease (CPPD), also known as pseudo-gout and chondrocalcinosis. The image shows aspirated crystals which are rhomboid, 0.5 to 5 m in the greatest dimension, and positively birefringent (yellow). It usually occurs in individuals older than 50 years of age and becomes more common with old age. CPPD is classified into sporadic (idiopathic), hereditary, and secondary types. It is caused by germline mutations in the pyrophosphate transport channel. The secondary form is associated with Previous joint damage Hyperparathyroidism Hemochromatosis Hypomagnesemia Hypothyroidism Ochronosis Diabetes Inflammation is usually milder than in gout. CPPD may produce acute, subacute, or chronic arthritis that can be confused with osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis. The joint involvement may be monoarticular or polyarticular; the knees, followed by the wrists, elbows, shoulders, and ankles, are most commonly affected.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is not true about liposarcoma?
options: Amplification of 12q13-q15 is characteristic of well differentiated liposarcoma.
The key gene in the amplified region of chromosome 12q is MDM2.
The pleomorphic variant is usually indolent and rarely metastasizes.
Myxoid liposarcoma shows delicate 'chicken-wire' or 'crow’s feet' vasculature.
explanation: The pleomorphic variant of liposarcoma is usually aggressive and frequently metastasizes. Liposarcoma is one of the most common sarcomas of adulthood seen mainly in people in their 50s to 60s in the deep soft tissues of the proximal extremities and in the retroperitoneum. Amplification of 12q13-q15 and t(12;16) are characteristic of well-differentiated and myxoid liposarcomas, respectively. One of the key genes in the amplified region of chromosome 12q is MDM2, which is a potent inhibitor of p53. Well-differentiated liposarcoma contains adipocytes with scattered atypical spindle cells. Myxoid liposarcoma contains an abundant basophilic extracellular matrix, arborizing capillaries (“chicken-wire” or “crow’s feet” vasculature), and primitive cells reminiscent of fetal fat. The well-differentiated variant is relatively indolent, while the myxoid/round cell type is intermediate in its malignant behavior.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 50-year-old man presented with a retroperitoneal mass. Biopsy from the lesion is shown in the image below. Molecular analysis revealed t(12;16). What is the most likely condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myxoid liposarcoma. The image shows abundant ground substance, with branching capillaries and a few immature adipocytes. Liposarcoma is the most common sarcoma in adults and is usually seen in the 5th to 6th decade of life. They commonly occur in the deep soft tissues of the proximal extremities and in the retroperitoneum. Histologically the liposarcomas are divided into three subtypes: Well-differentiated liposarcoma: It consists of mature adipocytes and scattered spindle cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. It is associated with amplification of 12q13-q15. Myxoid liposarcoma: It contains abundant basophilic extracellular matrix with branching capillaries. Few immature adipocytes are found scattered within the matrix. It is associated with t(12;16). Pleomorphic liposarcoma: It consists of sheets of anaplastic cells with bizarre nuclei and few immature adipocytes. Among the three subtypes, the pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while the well-differentiated is least malignant. Myxoid liposarcoma has intermediate malignancy behaviour.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old man presented with a 2-cm, rapidly growing, painful, subcutaneous mass on his left arm. Microscopy revealed immature proliferation of fibroblasts and myofibroblasts with abundant mitotic figures. Immunohistochemistry was positive for vimentin and muscle-specific actin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nodular fasciitis. Nodular fasciitis is a self-limited fibroblastic and myofibroblastic proliferation that typically occurs in young adults in the upper extremity. Etiology is unclear but a history of trauma is present in approximately 25% of cases. The tumors grow rapidly over a period of several weeks, typically no larger than 3 cm. It typically regresses spontaneously and if excised, rarely recurs. Microscopically, it is richly cellular and contains plump, immature-appearing fibroblasts and myofibroblasts, arranged randomly or in short fascicles reminiscent of tissue culture fibroblasts. A gradient of maturation from cellular, loose, and myxoid to organized and fibrous is typical. The cells vary in size and shape (spindle to stellate) and have conspicuous nucleoli; mitotic figures are abundant. Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for vimentin, smooth muscle actin, and muscle-specific actin. Desmoid tumours are firm and poorly demarcated masses which infiltrate the surrounding muscle, nerve and fat. Histologically, fibroblasts are arranged in long parallel fascicles amid dense collagen. (Option 2) The image below shows the histopathological findings of nodular fasciitis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 40-year-old man presented with a swelling in the floor of his mouth for 6 months. Intraoral examination revealed a soft, painless, non-tender mass in the left floor of the mouth, extending posteriorly into the supraglottic region. On histopathological examination, spider cells were seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rhabdomyomas. Rhabdomyoma is a benign neoplasm of skeletal muscle that mainly occurs in the head and neck region. Although the mass is usually asymptomatic, it may compress or displace the tongue or may cause partial obstruction of the pharynx. Rhabdomyomas can be classified into cardiac (most common) or extracardiac. Spider cells are seen in this condition. These are large, rounded, polygonal cells with glycogen vacuoles separated by strands of cytoplasm extending between the cell membrane and nucleus. The image given below shows spider cells.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 17-month-old girl presented with abnormal vaginal bleeding. A gynecological examination showed abnormal vaginal tissue protruding through the introitus. Histopathological analysis showed sheets of spindled cells in a myxoid stroma, which stained positive for desmin and Myo-D1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sarcoma botryoids, which is a variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. It is a malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation. Rhabdomyosarcomas are the common soft tissue sarcomas of childhood and adolescence, classified into four subtypes: alveolar, embryonal, pleomorphic, and spindle-shaped/ sclerosing. Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma: It contains sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma. Sarcoma botryoids is a variant that occurs in the walls of hollow, mucosal-line structures, such as the nasopharynx, common bile duct, bladder, and vagina. Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma: consists of the network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into clusters or aggregates, creating a crude resemblance to pulmonary alveoli. Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma - consists of large, sometimes multinucleated, bizarre eosinophilic tumor cells. Spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma - Consists of fusiform cells with vesicular chromatin arranged in long fascicles or in a storiform pattern. On immunohistochemistry, they are positive for desmin, myoglobin, myogenin, MyoD1, and vimentin. Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is seen predominantly in adults. The botryoid variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma has the best prognosis, while the pleomorphic subtype is often fatal.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 26-year-old man presents with left knee pain for 6 months. MRI shows a
well-circumscribed 4-cm mass superior to the patella within soft tissue. Biopsy shows a biphasic pattern of spindle cells and epithelial cells forming gland-like structures. Karyotype shows t(X,18) translocation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of synovial sarcoma. It can be present in locations (chest wall, head, and neck) that lack synovium. Most lesions occur in people in their 20s to 40s. Patients usually present with a deep-seated mass that has been present for several years. Most synovial sarcomas show a characteristic chromosomal translocation t(x;18)(p11;q11) producing SS18-SSX1, SS18-SSX2, or SS18-SSX4 fusion genes. They are morphologically classified into monophasic or biphasic: Monophasic synovial sarcoma consists of uniform spindle cells with scant cytoplasm and dense chromatin growing, in short, tightly packed fascicles. Biphasic type consists of a spindle cell component with gland-like structures composed of cuboidal to columnar epithelioid cells. Tumor cells, especially in the biphasic type, are positive for epithelial markers (e.g., keratins), differentiating them from most of the other sarcomas.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 13-year-old boy presents with fever, pain, and swelling in the left mid-thigh region. X-ray shows lamellated periosteal reaction resembling an onion skin. A biopsy from the lesion is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma. It is a malignant bone tumor that occurs primarily in children and young adults, in the age group of 10-20 years. It usually affects the long bones, such as the femur, tibia, or humerus. Occasionally, the tumor may begin in the muscles or soft tissues (extraosseous Ewing's sarcoma). Microscopically, solid sheets of small uniform round cells with PAS-positive magenta pink colored cytoplasm are characteristic of Ewing’s Sarcoma/PNET. The cells show PAS positivity due to the presence of large amounts of cytoplasmic glycogen. This is an important feature for the differential diagnosis of Ewing's with other small round cell tumors.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Acid mucin is stained by .
explanation: Acid mucin is stained by Alcian blue.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 36-year-old man with a history of blunt trauma to the left upper arm presents with swelling and redness 3 weeks later. There is a 4-cm mass in the outer aspect of the upper left arm in the soft tissue. Radiographs show a radiolucent center and surrounding irregular bone formation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myositis ossificans (MO). It is a pseudo-inflammatory tumor that originates from skeletal muscle and corresponds to a heterotopic, metaplastic, nonmalignant bone tumor. It is a highly inflammatory, rapidly growing, and painful muscular mass, which is seen following muscular trauma. The late stage is characterized by a typical zonal pattern (zonal phenomenon). It consists of three zones: Innermost zone: made of proliferating fibroblasts and myofibroblasts with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis Intermediate zone: contains osteoblasts with the immature osteoid formation Peripheral zone: the mature bone
subject: Pathology

question_text:
An 18-months-old child is brought to you with complaints of fever with chills and right knee pain for 3 days. On examination, his knee is warm and swollen with localized erythema. Joint aspiration showed 60,000 /mm3 WBCs. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of his condition?
Staphylococcus aureus
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of septic arthritis. The most common organism implicated in this condition in children < 2 years is Staphylococcus aureus. Since the advent of the Haemophilus influenzae vaccine, the predominant causes of septic arthritis among children <5 years of age have been S. aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes (group A Streptococcus), and (in some centers) Kingella kingae. Causative organism of bacterial arthritis: Note: H. influenza arthritis predominates in children younger than 2 years of age, particularly in areas with low Hib immunization rates, but it is not the most common organism.
