question_text: A child was brought with complaints of an eczematous lesion on the scalp. A biopsy from the lesion was taken. The cells stained positively for CD1a and CD207. What are these cells?
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. The image shows Langerhans cells with abundant, often vacuolated cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei containing linear grooves or folds and surrounding eosinophils. They stain positive for CD1a and S-100. They are intraepidermal dendritic cells. The image below shows Langerhans cells. Clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells leads to Langerhans cell histiocytosis, a histiocytic and dendritic cell neoplasm. These cells secrete factors that augment innate immune responses, and also the antigen-presenting cell of the skin, thereby stimulating the adaptive immune system.
subject: Pathology

question_text: An elderly man presented with a rapidly growing lesion as shown below. A biopsy from this lesion showed malignant cells. The immunohistochemical staining was positive for CK-20. The tumor cells in this condition originated from which of the following cells?
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of Merkel cell carcinoma. It arises from Merkel cells. These cells are located in epithelial basal cell layer and have neuroendocrine and mechanoreceptor functions. Merkel cell carcinoma is a rare and aggressive neuroendocrine tumor of the skin, most commonly found in white men and diagnosed at a mean age of 70 years. A rapidly growing, flesh-colored papule or plaque characterizes the disease. About 80% of the cases are seen associated with Merkel cell polyomavirus. Regional lymph nodes are involved in 30% of the patients and 50% will develop systemic disease. CK-20 is a specific marker for Merkel cell carcinoma. Wide local excision is usually necessary. The image below shows Merkel cell carcinoma composed of uniform small round cells having granular chromatin and scant cytoplasm.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A histopathological examination of melanocytic nevus in a patient showed nests of large round pigmented cells superficially. At the deeper extent of the lesion, it showed fascicles of non-pigmented cells resembling neural tissue. What does this signify?
options: Risk of malignant transformation into melanoma
explanation: Nevus cells often become non-pigmented and resemble neural tissue as they grow deep into the dermis. This change is called neurotization and suggests the benign nature of the nevus. This morphological change in nevus cells occurs due to progressive loss of tyrosinase activity and acquisition of cholinesterase activity in deeper “nervelike” nevus cells. Melanocytic nevi (moles) are common benign neoplasms caused by acquired activating mutations in components of the RAS signaling pathway. Based on the location, it may be junctional nevi, intradermal nevi, or compound nevi. Melanocytic nevi are thought to progress through a series of morphologic changes over time. Superficial nevus cells are larger, tend to produce melanin, and grow in nests. Deeper nevus cells are smaller, produce little or no pigment, and appear as cords and single cells. At the deepest extent of the lesions, these cells often acquire fusiform contours and grow in fascicles resembling neural tissue (neurotization). Melanocytic nevi with neurotization indicate normal maturation change and help in differentiating benign nevi from melanomas (which lacks such features).
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following driver mutations is not associated with given skin malignancy?
options: Mutations in receptor tyrosine kinase signalling pathway
explanation: The above image is suggestive of melanoma. Mutations in the hedgehog signaling pathway are associated with basal cell carcinoma. All other mutations are associated with melanoma. Melanoma is a highly aggressive malignancy linked to UV exposure. Most sporadic melanomas are associated with mutations in cell cycle regulators (p16/INK4a, CDK4), proteins in receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathway (KIT, RAS, BRAF), and telomerase (TERT mutation). Dysplastic nevus syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition with inherited CDKN2A mutation that can lead to familial melanoma.
subject: Pathology

question_text: What is the most common type of melanoma?
explanation: The superficial spreading type of melanoma is the most common type of melanoma. The progression of melanoma may be described as: Radial growth phase: the horizontal spread of melanoma within the epidermis and superficial dermi Acral lentiginous - unrelated to sun exposure Lentigo maligna (Hutchinson freckle) - sun-exposed region Superficial spreading (most common) Vertical growth phase: the tumor cells invade downward into the deeper dermal layers as an expansile mass (nodular) The image below shows melanoma in the radial growth phase. It shows the irregular nested and single-cell growth of melanoma cells within the epidermis and an underlying inflammatory response within the dermis. The image below shows melanoma cells that have large nuclei with irregular contours. The chromatin is characteristically clumped at the periphery of the nuclear membrane with prominent red (eosinophilic) nucleoli.
subject: Pathology

question_text: An elderly European man presented with a slowly progressing lesion on his scalp for 2 years. Immunohistochemistry revealed tumor cells that were positive for the S-100 marker. All are favorable prognostic factors for his condition except:
explanation: The above image is suggestive of melanoma. The absence of regression is a favorable prognostic factor in melanomas. Immunohistochemistry markers for melanoma are: S-100 HMB (Human Melanoma Black)-45 LDH MELAN-A Regression is defined as partial or complete disappearance of a previously documented tumor in the absence of therapeutic interventions or physical trauma. Microscopically, it is characterized by the replacement of melanoma cells by dense inflammtory cell infiltrate or dermal fibrosis. This phenomenon explains some apparent discrepancies between expected and observed prognosis based on tumor thickness and also the cases of metastatic melanoma with occult primary. Determinants of a more favorable prognosis in melanoma include: Thinner tumor depth No or very few mitoses (< 1 per mm2) A brisk tumor infiltrating lymphocyte response The absence of regression Lack of ulceration Absence of metastases in the sentinel lymph node
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with FGFR3 mutations?
explanation: Mutations in the FGFR3 gene are not described in melanomas. Fibroblast growth factor receptor-3 (FGFR3) is a receptor tyrosine kinase. Defects in the FGFR3 gene have been associated with several conditions: Hypochondroplasia Thanatophoric dwarfism Seborrheic keratosi Acanthosis nigrican Bladder cancer Craniosynostosi Severe achondroplasia with developmental delay and acanthosis nigricans (SADDAN)
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient presented with multiple, small, pink nodular growths on the temples. A biopsy from the lesion showed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The above image shows a jigsaw puzzle appearance which is seen in cylindroma (turban tumor/Spiegler’s tumor). Cylindroma is a familial autosomal dominant disorder. It is due to the loss of the cylindromatosis gene, CYLD on chromosome 16q12-13. It has also been reported to follow radiotherapy epilation of the scalp. The lesions are frequently multiple, smooth, firm, pink to red, and somewhat pedunculated. They are mostly seen on the scalp. Histologically, it contains mosaic■like masses - a jigsaw appearance. Malignant transformation is very rare. Surgery is the treatment of choice. Note: Genetic syndromes associated with adnexal tumors: Germline mutations in CYLD - familial cylindromatosis, familial trichoepithelioma Brooke–Spiegler syndrome - associated with trichoepithelioma, cylindroma, spiradenoma Muir–Torre syndrome - sebaceous adenoma Cowden syndrome - multiple trichilemmoma
subject: Pathology

question_text: Histopathological examination of a biopsy taken from a rough, scaly macular lesion from a patient's forearm showed neoplastic dyskeratosis. What is the probable diagnosis?
explanation: Neoplastic dyskeratosis is seen in actinic keratosis. Dyskeratosis is premature keratinization of individual keratinocytes. These cells usually have pink or reddish cytoplasm. It can be benign or malignant: Benign dyskeratosis - seen in Darier’s disease, warty dyskeratoma, and familial benign pemphigu Neoplastic dyskeratosis - seen in Bowen’s disease, squamous cell carcinoma, and actinic keratosi Actinic keratoses usually occur in sun-damaged skin and are considered precursor lesions of quamous cell carcinoma. Some lesions produce so much keratin that a cutaneous horn develops. The image below shows the histology of actinic keratosis. It shows atypical basal cells, dyskeratotic cells, and parakeratosis in the stratum corneum (cells with a retained nucleus).
subject: Pathology

question_text: A biopsy from a chronic oropharyngeal lesion of a patient showed the following. Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing this condition?
explanation: The above image shows keratinous pearls and atypical tumor cells suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Human papillomavirus (HPV) subtypes 5 and 8 may predispose to squamous cell carcinoma, but not Epstein–Barr virus (EBV). Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma: Exposure to UV light HPV subtypes 5 and 8 Epidermodysplasia verruciformi Industrial carcinogens (tars and oils) Chronic ulcers and draining osteomyeliti Old burn scars (Marjolin ulcers) Ingestion of arsenical Ionizing radiation Tobacco and betel nut chewing (in the oral cavity) Precursor lesions: Actinic keratosi Xeroderma pigmentosum The image below shows an SCC lesion in the oral cavity.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 60-year-old man presents with a pearly papule over the face containing prominent dilated subepidermal blood vessels and surface ulceration. A histological picture of the tumor is shown below. All are true about the tumor except:
options: Incidence is increased in xeroderma pigmentosum
Presence of multiple such tumors is seen in Gorlin syndrome
explanation: The clinical presentation and histology are suggestive of basal cell carcinoma (BCC). It is a locally aggressive cutaneous tumor, and metastasis is very rare. It occurs in sun-exposed areas with increased incidence in the setting of immunosuppression and in disorders of DNA repair, such as xeroderma pigmentosum. BCCs usually present as pearly papules and locally invasive ulcers (rodent ulcers). Histologically, the tumor cells resemble those in the normal basal cell layer of the epidermis with peripheral palisading and retraction cleft. It is associated with mutations that activate the hedgehog pathway signaling. Gorlin syndrome is an autosomal-dominant disorder with multiple basal cell carcinomas, medulloblastomas, ovarian fibromas, and odontogenic keratocysts, pits of the palms, and soles. The image below shows the histopathology of BCC.
subject: Pathology

question_text: The clinical picture and a biopsy from the skin lesion of a patient are shown below. This condition is associated with which of the following?
explanation: The clinical image shows diffuse erythema and scaling of the entire body surface (erythroderma) and histopathology shows the presence of lymphocytes in the epidermal cell layer (epidermotropism). This is suggestive of Sézary syndrome which is a disseminated and severe form of mycosis fungoides (cutaneous T-cell lymphoma). Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CD4+ T-cells) that presents in the skin. It remains localized to the skin for many years, but it may eventually evolve into a systemic lymphoma. The image of mycosis fungoides showing hallmark features - Sezary Lutzner cells showing epidermal infiltration (epidermotropism),
subject: Pathology

question_text: A child was brought with urticarial lesions on the forearm. On examination, Darier's sign was positive. The cells responsible for this condition can be stained with all of the following except:
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of urticaria pigmentosa caused by cutaneous mastocytosis. The Masson-Fontana stain is used to demonstrate melanin in nevus and malignant melanoma. Darier's sign is seen in urticaria pigmentosa. It refers to the development of urticaria and erythema around the lesions after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. Mast cells may be difficult to differentiate from lymphocytes in routine, hematoxylin, and eosin (H&E)–stained sections. Special metachromatic stains (toluidine blue or Giemsa) are used to visualize their granules. Stains for mast cells: Toluidine blue Giemsa Tryptase Leder stain (Chloracetate esterase) CD 117 The image below shows mast cells stained with toluidine blue.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 40-year-old woman presents with oral ulcers and bullae over the mucosa and skin. On examination, the bullae are flaccid and filled with clear fluid. Histopathology of the lesion shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The above image shows the suprabasal splitting of the epidermis (acantholysis) giving rise to the row of tombstones appearance. This is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris. Pemphigus vulgaris is the most common type of pemphigus. It involves the mucosa and skin. Autoantibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3 are present. Pemphigus is a blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies that result in the dissolution of intercellular attachments within the epidermis and mucosal epithelium. Variants of pemphigus: Pemphigus vulgari Pemphigus vegetan Pemphigus foliaceus - autoantibodies are against Dsg1 alone, leading to superficial, subcorneal blisters. Pemphigus erythematosu Paraneoplastic pemphigus - in association with various malignancies, most commonly non-Hodgkin lymphoma
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 30-year-old woman presented with painful blisters on the skin and oral mucosa. Direct immunofluorescence is given below. Which of the following is false regarding the same?
options: Suprabasal acantholytic blister is a characteristic feature
explanation: Antibodies against hemidesmosomes is the false statement as the given image shows a characteristic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence, which is diagnostic of pemphigus vulgaris. The antibodies are against the desmosomal adhesion proteins such as desmogleins 1 and 3. This pattern is due to intraepidermal intercellular deposition of IgG and C3. The first-line investigation in pemphigus vulgaris is the Tzanck smear. It allows us to visualize the histology by collecting material from the floor of a fresh blister that is stained with Giemsa or any Romanowsky stain. Tzanck cells are seen on microscopy. Direct immunofluorescence microscopy (DIF) is the most accurate test. Antibodies against hemidesmosomes that link basal keratinocytes to the underlying basement membrane are seen in bullous pemphigoid.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 70-year-old woman presents with multiple tense itchy blisters on the trunk and thigh region. Histopathology demonstrates subepidermal, non-acantholytic blisters. Direct immunofluorescence for IgG and C3 shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The above image showing linear IgG and C3 deposits on direct immunofluorescence (DIF) microscopy is characteristic of bullous pemphigoid. Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by tense itchy bulla in the flexor areas and trunk which do not rupture easily. In bullous pemphigoid, the antibodies are formed against bullous pemphigoid antigens (BPAGs)- BP 180 and BP 230, which are components of hemidesmosomes. The separation of bullous pemphigoid from pemphigus is based on the identification of subepidermal, nonacantholytic blisters that are Nikolsky negative. Nikolsky's sign is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin. If the lesion is opened (i.e., skin sloughed off), then the Nikolsky's sign is present/positive.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 28-year-old man with gluten sensitivity presents with severely itchy papulovesicular lesions on extremities, knees, elbows, and buttocks for one year. Direct immunofluorescence staining of the lesions showed IgA deposition as follows. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The above image showing granular deposits of IgA on direct immunofluorescence is suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis or Duhring's disease. These deposits localize in the tips of dermal papillae. Dermatitis herpetiformis presents as grouped vesicles and papules. These lesions are commonly located over the extensor aspects of knees, elbows, buttocks, back, scalp which are associated with intense pruritus. It is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy or celiac disease. It is also associated with HLA DQ2/DQ8/B8. Deposition of IgA antitransglutaminase antibodies in the dermal papillae results in true subepidermal blisters and vesicles. The characteristic microscopic feature is subepidermal blisters with papillary tip microabscesses containing neutrophils. The initial treatment of choice for dermatitis herpetiformis is a gluten-free diet. The image below shows subepidermal vesicles, with papillary neutrophil microabscesses, with neutrophil, eosinophil and lymphocytes infiltrates in the superficial dermis in case of dermatitis herpetiformis. The image below shows vesicular lesions of dermatitis herpetiformis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 36-year-old male with skin-colored umbilicated papules. Microscopy is as shown below. The most likely diagnosis is .
explanation: The given microscopic image shows large, ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum classically seen in molluscum contagiosum. Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limited viral disease of the skin caused by a poxvirus. Poxvirus is brick-shaped and is about 300 nm in size, the largest pathogenic poxvirus in humans Tzanck smear shows intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson–Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30–35 m). Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, pink to skin-colored umbilicated papules (shown below). A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication
subject: Pathology

question_text: A pathology resident notes the following cells while examining a histopathological section. It may be seen in all of the following conditions except:
explanation: The image above shows Touton giant cells having a central ring of nuclei while the peripheral cytoplasm is clear due to accumulated lipid. These cells are formed by the fusion of lipid-containing macrophages. They are not seen in sarcoidosis. These cells are seen in: Fat necrosi Xanthoma Xanthogranuloma Dermatofibroma The cardinal histopathologic feature of sarcoidosis is the non-caseating epithelioid granuloma with occasional other microscopic features: Schaumann bodies - laminated concretions composed of calcium and protein Asteroid bodies - stellate inclusions enclosed within giant cell
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 35-year-old man presented with a single hypoaesthetic and a hypopigmented patch on the lateral aspect of the forearm. Microscopy of a biopsy sample from the lesion revealed granulomatous inflammation but acid-fast bacilli were not identified. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis is tuberculoid leprosy. On microscopic examination, tuberculoid leprosy has granulomatous lesions closely resembling those found in tuberculosis. Because of the strong host defense, bacilli are almost never found, hence the name paucibacillary leprosy. Leprosy or Hansen disease is a slowly progressive infection caused by Mycobacterium leprae, mainly affecting the skin and peripheral nerves.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 25-year-old man from the eastern part of India presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer with heaped-up borders over the face. Biopsy reveals granulomas and the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image shows many histiocytes containing Leishman–Donovan bodies and surrounding chronic inflammatory cells classically seen in cutaneous leishmaniasis. Cutaneous leishmaniasis presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer, often with heaped-up borders. On microscopic examination, the lesion shows granulomatous inflammation, usually with many giant cells and few parasites. Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis is characterized by a single skin nodule, which continues spreading until the entire body is covered by nodular lesions. Microscopically, they contain aggregates of foamy macrophages stuffed with leishmania.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Max Joseph’s space is a histopathological feature of which of the following conditions?
explanation: Max Joseph’s space is a histopathological feature of lichen planus. Histological features of lichen planus: Orthokeratosis, parakeratosis, thickening of the stratum granulosum. Acanthosis with the formation of colloid bodies (also known as Civatte bodies/Sabouraud bodies) Liquefactive degeneration of the stratum basale, with separation from the underlying lamina propria, as a result of desmosome loss, creating small spaces (Max Joseph spaces) Infiltration of T cells in a band-like pattern into the dermis “hugging” the basal layer (interface dermatitis)
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 35-year-old man presents with the following lesions. Which of the following finding is likely to be seen in histopathology?

Papillary tip microabsce
explanation: The image shows silvery-white scaly lesions on the extensor aspect of the knees suggestive of psoriasis. Munro microabscesses are seen in psoriasis. Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory dermatosis that appears to have an autoimmune basis. The lesions are pink to salmon-colored plaque covered by loosely adherent silver-white scales. Auspitz sign and Koebner phenomenon can be demonstrated. Nail changes include pitting, dimpling, separation of the nail plate, onycholysis, thickening, and crumbling. Microscopy shows thinning of stratum granulosum, supra papillary plates, and neutrophils forming small aggregates within the superficial epidermis (spongiform pustules) and within the stratum corneum (Munro microabscesses). Some types of microabscesses and their examples are given below: Predominant cell Name of microabscess Disease Neutrophilic microabscess Papillary tip microabscessMu nro microabscess (superficial) Spongiform pustules of Kogoj (deep) Dermatitis herpetiformisPsor iasisPsoriasis Lymphocytic microabsces Pautrier's microabscess Mycosis fungoides Eosinophillic microabsces Pemphigus vegetans Infective & Vascular CNS pathology
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which cells constitute the resident monocyte-lineage population of the CNS and accumulate in response to injury?
explanation: Microglia are mesoderm-derived phagocytic cells that serve as the resident monocyte-lineage population of the CNS and accumulate in response to injury. They respond to injury by: Activation and proliferating Developing elongated nuclei (rod cells), as in neurosyphilis Forming aggregates around small foci of tissue necrosis (microglial nodules) Congregating around cell bodies of dying neurons (neuronophagia)
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of these are the earliest morphologic markers of neuronal cell death?
explanation: Red neurons are the earliest morphologic markers of neuronal cell death. Acute neuronal injury refers to a spectrum of changes that accompany acute CNS hypoxia / ischemia or other acute insults and reflect the earliest morphologic markers of neuronal cell death. They are evident by about 12 to 24 hours after an irreversible insult. Morphologic features consist of: Shrinkage of the cell body Pyknosis of the nucleus Disappearance of the nucleolus Loss of Nissl substance Intense eosinophilia of the cytoplasm. Stages of neuronal injury and their pathological features are given below: Stages Time Features Early change 12–24 hr Red neuron Subacute cha nge 24 hr–2 we eks Necrosis, macrophages, vasc ular proliferation, gliosis Repair 2 weeks + Removal of necrosis, gliosis c ompleted, loss of CNS archite cture
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 45-year-old male who is a known diabetic and hypertensive suffers a stroke. During this episode, which of the following cells are the least susceptible to injury, considering the stroke was transient and not severe?■
explanation: Astrocytes are more resistant to focal cerebral ischemia than neurons, and die by delayed necrosis. The cells most susceptible to ischemia are: Pyramidal cell layer cells of the hippocampus (especially area CA1, also referred to as Sommer sector) Purkinje cells of the cerebellum Pyramidal neurons of the cerebral cortex(the watershed zones)
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A 50 year old man died of an unknown condition. On autopsy, a sample of the brain was taken as a specimen, and the following fibres were seen on microscopic examination. These
fibres are not seen in which of the following conditions?
explanation: The image shows the presence of rosenthal fibres. Rosenthal fibres are not seen in Pick's disease. Rosenthal fibers are thick, elongated, brightly eosinophilic, irregular structures that occur within astrocytic processes. They contain two heatshock proteins (B crystallin and HSP27) as well as ubiquitin.They are typically found in regions of longstanding gliosis and are characteristic of a type of glial tumor—pilocytic astrocytoma. Alexander disease is a leukodystrophy associated with mutations in the gene encoding GFAP. In this condition, abundant rosenthal fibers are found in periventricular, perivascular, and subpial locations.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Hemorrhage of which of the following areas of the brain are called ganglionic hemorrhages?
explanation: Hemorrhages in the basal ganglia and thalamus are commonly designated ganglionic hemorrhages. Those that occur in the lobes of the cerebral hemispheres are called lobar hemorrhages.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient is rushed into the ER with complaints of sudden excruciating headache and projectile vomiting. CT angiography shows the presence of Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms. These are caused by which of the following?
explanation: Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysms are caused by chronic hypertension. They are most commonly seen within the basal ganglia.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 66-year-old man with chronic hypertension presents to the ER with altered mental status and elevated blood pressure of 210/110 mm Hg. You suspect intracranial hemorrhage. What is the most common site of hemorrhage seen in such cases?
explanation: The given clinical condition is suggestive of hypertensive intraparenchymal hemorrhage. The most common site (50-60%) of hypertensive hemorrhage in the brain is the putamen. Hypertension is the most common cause of intracerebral hemorrhage.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A patient with a known history of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, presents to the ER with a sudden, severe headache, photophobia and nausea. What type of aneurysm would you suspect in this patient?
explanation: In a patient with a known history of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, the most common type of intracranial aneurysm is saccular aneurysm. Although the majority occur sporadically, genetic factors may be important in their pathogenesis of saccular aneurysms. There is an increased incidence of saccular aneurysm in individuals with certain Mendelian disorders like autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, Ehlers–Danlos syndrome type IV, neurofibromatosis type 1 [NF1], and Marfan syndrome, fibromuscular dysplasia of extracranial arteries, and coarctation of the aorta. Other predisposing factors include cigarette smoking and hypertension. The most frequent cause of clinically significant subarachnoid hemorrhage is rupture of a saccular (berry) aneurysm in a cerebral artery.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following statements is not true about CADASIL?
options: It is characterized by mutations in the NOTCH3 gene.
Recurrent strokes and dementia are seen.
explanation: Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL) is an autosomal-dominant disorder caused by mutations in the NOTCH3 gene. This leads to the misfolding of the extracellular domain of the NOTCH3 receptor that is preferentially expressed in vascular smooth muscle. It is clinically characterized by recurrent strokes (usually ischemic, less often hemorrhages) and dementia. Arteries in the CNS and in other tissues such as skin show concentric thickening of the media and adventitia, loss of smooth muscle cells, and the presence of basophilic, periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive deposits. Deposits contain the misfolded NOTCH3 protein. These appear as osmiophilic compact granular material on electron microscopy and are consistently detected in the walls of affected vessels.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
A patient presented to the emergency department with high fever, photophobia and neck stiffness. A lumbar puncture was performed and findings are given below. Which of the
following is the most common cause of this condition?
explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of aseptic meningitis. Enterovirus is the most common cause, accounting for around 90% of the cases.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 34-year-old man is admitted with a history of altered sensorium and abnormal behavior. The patient subsequently died and on autopsy, the following findings are seen in the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. What are these called?
explanation: The image shows characteristic Negri bodies found in the Purkinje cell of the cerebellum. These are the pathognomonic microscopic finding in rabies. This patient's clinical features of altered sensorium and abnormal behavior are suggestive of rabies. Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions that can be found in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. The rabies virus can be detected within Negri bodies by ultrastructural and immunohistochemical methods.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is caused by which of the following?
explanation: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is an encephalitis caused by the JC polyomavirus. The disease occurs almost exclusively in immunosuppressed individuals, most commonly among patients with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). The most prominent symptoms are clumsiness, progressive weakness, and visual, speech, and personality changes. Since the virus preferentially infects oligodendrocytes, demyelination is its principal pathologic effect. It affects the subcortical white matter, particularly that of the parietal and occipital lobes. On microscopic examination, enlarged oligodendrocyte nuclei containing glassy amphophilic viral inclusions are seen. The image below shows a brain biopsy of a progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy patient, showing oligodendrocytes with nuclear enlargement and glassy chromatin.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 35-year-old immunocompromised patient presented with fever, headache, and neurological deficits. MRI showed multiple enhancing lesions and a stereotactic biopsy of the lesion was done. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The above image shows lymphocytes, macrophages and eosinophils surrounding the toxoplasma bradyzoites encased in cysts. Along with the case scenario, the most likely diagnosis is cerebral toxoplasmosis. Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection commonly found in the setting of HIV-associated immunosuppression. Toxoplasmosis of the CNS produces brain abscesses, which are found most often in the cerebral cortex (near the grey-white junction) and deep gray nuclei. Lesions of acute cerebral toxoplasmosis exhibit central necrosis, petechial haemorrhages surrounded by acute and chronic inflammation, macrophage infiltration, and vascular proliferation. Both free tachyzoites and encysted bradyzoites may be found at the periphery of the necrotic foci. Chronic lesions consist of small cystic spaces containing scattered lipid and hemosiderin-laden macrophages that are surrounded by gliotic brain. Option A: In cerebral malaria caused by P. falciparum, brain vessels are plugged with parasitized red cells. Around the vessels, ring hemorrhages and small focal inflammatory reactions (called malarial or Dürck granulomata) are seen. Option C: Herpes simplex encephalitis is necrotizing and often hemorrhagic. Cowdry type A intranuclear viral inclusion bodies may be found in both neurons and glia. Option D: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is an encephalitis caused by the JC polyomavirus. The disease occurs almost exclusively in immunosuppressed individuals. The virus preferentially infects oligodendrocytes and hence demyelination is its principal pathologic effect. The enlarged oligodendrocyte nuclei contain glassy amphophilic viral inclusions.
subject: Pathology

question_text: A 40-year-old man with bronchiectasis presents with progressive focal neurologic deficits and symptoms related to increased intracranial pressure. On lumbar puncture, the CSF is found to have a high white cell count and an increased protein concentration, but the glucose content is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Brain abscess is the most likely diagnosis in the above patient with progressive focal neurologic deficits and increased intracranial pressure. Predisposing conditions for brain abcess: Acute bacterial endocarditis, which may give rise to multiple brain abscesses. Congenital heart diseases with right to left shunt. Chronic pulmonary disease, as in bronchiectasis. Systemic disease with immunosuppression. Organisms involved are: Streptococcus spp. and Staphylococcus spp. (most common aerobic organisms) Bacteroides fragilis and Peptostreptococcus spp.(most common anaerobic organisms). Foci of organisms in brain abscess: Direct implantation of organisms Local extension from adjacent foci (mastoiditis, paranasal sinusitis) Hematogenous spread (from primary foci of heart, lungs, bones of extremities, dental extraction) CSF analysis in brain abscess: Note: In Robbins and Cotran's Pathology of Diseases- edition 9 page no.1273, it is given that in a typical brain abscess patient, the glucose in the CSF will be normal. Paramet ers Observation WBC Increased Proteins Increased Glucose Decreased (but it will be nor mal in a significant proportio of individuals)
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the common locations of CNS infections?
options: Tuberculosis - basal part of the brai
explanation: HIV encephalopathy is seen in subcortical regions of the brain and not in frontal and parietal lobes. It is characterized by defects in short-term memory and executive function. It is also known as subcortical dementia. question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding prion diseases?
options: Creutzfeldt Jakob Disease is most commonly sporadic
Spongiform neurons are seen in fatal familial insomnia
Startle myoclonus is seen in Creutzfeldt Jakob Disease
The disease causing isoform of prion protein is PrPC
explanation: The disease causing isoform of prion protein is PrPSc. Prions are the proteinaceous infectious particle that lacks nucleic acid, composed entirely of alternatively folded proteins that undergo self-propagation. They bind to the normal, cellular isoform of the prion protein (PrPC) which is rich in -helix, and stimulate conversion of PrPC into the disease-causing isoform PrPSc which contain less -helix and a high amount of  -structure.  structured proteins are resistant to digestion by human cellular enzymes. Transmission of prion disease may be sporadic, familial or iatrogenic. This group of diseases include: Creutzfeldt Jakob disease Gerstmann Sträussler Scheinke syndrome Fatal Familial Insomnia Kuru disease Scrapie in sheep and goats Bovine spongiform encephalopathy in cows Most common prion disease in humans is CJD, which is most commonly sporadic. CJD is characterized by a constellation of dementia, myoclonus, and periodic electrical bursts in EEG. Autoclaving at 134 degree Celsius for 5 hours or treatment with 2 N NaOH for several hours is recommended for sterilization against prions (tip: 1234-5 for prions).

question_text: A 15 year old boy is brought to the ER with complaints of seizures, spasticity of limbs and cognitive decline since two weeks. He has no history of recent illness, but mentions suffering from a high fever with a rash 5 years ago. What condition had he likely suffered from?
explanation: The patient is most likely suffering from subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), a delayed late complication of measles. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare, progressive clinical syndrome characterized by cognitive decline, spasticity of limbs, seizures and psychosis. It occurs in children or young adults, months or years after an initial, early-age acute infection with measles. The pathogenesis of SSPE is not well understood but may involve persistent infection with a genetic variant of measles virus within the central nervous system.

question_text:
Berry aneurysm occurs due to:
Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN
explanation: Berry aneurysm occurs due an arterial internal elastic lamina defect. As an aneurysm develops, it typically forms a neck with a dome and the arterial internal elastic lamina disappears at the base of the neck. The media thins and connective tissue replaces the smooth-muscle cells. The site of rupture is most often the dome. Here the wall thins, and the tear that allows bleeding is usually 0.5 mm long. Risk of aneurysm rupture is higher if: Aneurysm is >7 mm in diameter Aneurysm at the top of the basilar artery Aneurysm at the origin of the posterior communicating artery Degenerative, Toxic & Metabolic CNS disorders

question_text: During the autopsy of a 78-year-old man who had progressive memory loss for 2 years, the following histologic finding was noted in the brain tissue. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for this condition?
options: Conformational change in the prion protein
explanation: The clinical scenario and the images showing amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles are diagnostic of Alzheimer's disease (AD), complicated by cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA). The formation and aggregation of A peptides are responsible for AD. Amyloid precursor protein (APP) is neurotrophic and neuroprotective. It is present in astrocytes and neuroglia. This protein is cleaved at 3 sites by secretase enzymes (,  , and ), and the products are known as A peptides. In Alzheimer's disease, A peptides get aggregated in the form of amyloid plaques, which stain positive for Congo red. These get deposited within the neural tissue (A 42) and the cerebral arterioles (A 40 protein, causing CAA), which causes neuronal dysfunction, and is the first sign of AD. Normally, tau proteins within the neurons stabilize microtubules, however, in AD, these get hyperphosphorylated and lose their function. Hyperphosphorylated tau proteins combine with cytoplasmic fibrils, to form neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) and get abnormally accumulated around the neuronal nucleus.

question_text: In which of the following conditions can neurofibrillary tangles be found?
explanation: Neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) are found in: Normal aging Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis Alzheimer's disease NFTs are aggregates of hyperphosphorylated tau proteins (microtubule-associated proteins) found in numerous diseases known as tauopathies. question_text: A 43-year-old man who presented with tremors, bradykinesia, ■lack of coordination, and progressive declining cognitive functions was diagnosed with punch drunk syndrome. This condition is likely due to the deposition of which of the following in his brain?
explanation: Punch drunk syndrome is due to accumulation of tau proteins in the brain. This condition is also called dementia pugilistica or chronic traumatic encephalopathy. It is a dementing illness that develops following repeated head trauma in boxers and other athletes. Affected brains are typically atrophic, with enlarged ventricles. They show accumulation of tau-- containing□ neurofibrillary tangles in a characteristic pattern involving the superficial frontal and temporal lobe cortex.

question_text: A 62-year-old man is brought with tremors of his hands at rest. His son says that he has difficulty initiating movements and seems to be moving very slowly. On examination, shuffling gait, pill-rolling tremors, and rigidity on passive arm movement are noted. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of Parkinson's disease. This condition is not associated with Pick cells and Pick bodies. They are seen in Pick’s disease or frontotemporal dementia. In Parkinson's disease, there is loss of the substantia nigra neurons projecting to the striatum. This leads to pallor of the substantia nigra as well as a decrease or absence of dopamine in the striatum. This leads to slowing of movements and tremors. Lewy Bodies are seen within the neurons of affected patients. They are filamentous projections of the protein ■synuclein or ubiquitin. They are present in surviving neurons and can be found in the cortex.

question_text: LRRK2 mutation is associated with which of the following conditions?
explanation: Mutations in the gene encoding LRRK2 (leucine rich repeat kinase 2) are a common cause of autosomal dominant Parkinson's disease. They are also found in some sporadic cases of the disease.

question_text: A wife brings her 52-year-old husband to the OPD with complaints of involuntary, sudden, jerky movements of his hands. She also tells that he has been occasionally forgetting the route to his office. His older brother also developed similar complaints last year. MRI revealed the following findings. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?
options: It has an X-linked recessive mode of inheritance
The phenomenon of anticipation is seen
Severity is related to the length of the CAG repeats
There is degeneration of GABAergic neurons
explanation: The MRI shows bilateral atrophy of caudate nuclei with compensatory dilatation of lateral ventricles, also known as boxcar ventricles. Along with the clinical features, it is suggestive of Huntington's disease (HD). It has an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. It is commonly seen in the 4th and 5th decades of life. It is a degenerative disease of the caudate and putamen (striate neurons) caused by trinucleotide (CAG) repeats in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4. The severity of the disease depends on the number of repeats. With more repeats, the disease becomes more severe. The disease also manifests at an earlier age, a phenomenon called anticipation. The caudate nucleus is dramatically atrophied, with accompanying atrophy of the putamen, cortex, and hydrocephalus ex vacuo of the 3rd ventricle. The medium-sized GABAergic neurons are especially affected. It causes chorea and dementia. Motor problems like chorea typically precede dementia.
subject: Pathology

question_text: In patients with Huntington's disease, the mutated gene is located on which chromosome?
explanation: In Huntington's disease, the affected HTT gene is located on chromosome 4. The coding region has a trinucleotide repeat (CAG/ glutamine). The severity and age of onset of the disease depend on the number of repeats increases. This phenomenon is called anticipation.

question_text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with difficulty in climbing stairs and walking long distances. His parents say that he has received complaints at school due to progressively worsening handwriting. On examination, pes cavus is noted. Investigations revealed scoliosis and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?
options: Expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Friedrich's ataxia. It is associated with mutations of genes on chromosome 9q13. It is an autosomal recessive disease caused by the expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in the gene encoding frataxin. The clinical features are given by the mnemonic FRIEDRICHS: F - Frequent falls (ataxia), foot deformity (pes cavus or overarched foot) R - Recessive I - Iron accumulation in mitochondria E - Eye movements (nystagmus) D - Dorsal column (loss of fine touch, vibration, position) R - Reflexes (deep tendon) lost, with extensor plantar reflex I - Incoordination C - Cerebellar involvement H - Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) S - Scoliosis (with kyphosis), staggering gait

question_text: While studying a spinal cord section, a pathology resident noted that the nuclei of the Schwann cells of the dorsal root ganglia were enlarged nearly 5 times the normal size. This finding is seen in which of the following conditions?
explanation: In ataxia-telangiectasia, the nuclei of the Schwann cells of the dorsal root ganglia are enlarged to nearly 2-5 times the normal size. This finding is seen in the Schwann cells of dorsal root ganglia, peripheral nerves, endothelial cells, and pituicytes. These cells are called amphicytes. Ataxia-telangiectasia is due to mutations of the ATM gene, located on chromosome 11q. It predominantly affects the cerebellum with the loss of Purkinje and granule cells. There is also degeneration of the dorsal columns, spinocerebellar tract, anterior horn cells, and peripheral neuropathy. Telangiectatic lesions are found in the CNS as well as in the conjunctiva and skin of the face, neck, and arms. The lymph nodes, thymus, and gonads are hypoplastic.

question_text: Bergmann gliosis is due to the loss of which of the following?
explanation: Bergmann gliosis is due to the loss of Purkinje cells. It occurs in advanced cases of chronic alcoholism. There is a loss of Purkinje cells and proliferation of the adjacent astrocytes between the depleted granular cell layer and the molecular layer of the cerebellum.

question_text: A 5-month-old baby was brought to the OPD with complaints of irritability, stiffness, and weakness of limbs. On examination, there was hypertonia of limbs. After a few months, the baby died due to the rapid progression of the disease. A brain autopsy was done and the following cells were seen. What are these cells?
explanation: The clinical scenario showing motor symptoms and rapid progression to death, an autopsy of the brain showing globoid cells is highly suggestive of Krabbe's disease. The globoid cells are macrophages. Krabbe's disease or globoid cell leukodystrophy is a neurodegenerative disorder with severe myelin destruction due to a deficiency of galactocerebroside  -galactosidase. The onset of symptoms is between 3 to 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as stiffness and weakness. Survival beyond the age of 2 years is uncommon. The brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.

question_text: A 35-year-old man presented with frequent falls and tingling in his extremities. On examination, an unsteady gait with a positive Romberg sign was noted. Additionally, there was loss of proprioception and vibration sense and deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. B ood investigations revealed the following. Deficiency of which of the following vitamins is the likely cause of this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with involvement of the dorsal column and investigations showing macrocytic anemia is suggestive of subacute combined degeneration (SACD) of the spinal cord. It is due to a deficiency of vitamin B12 which is involved in myelin synthesis. The most severely affected regions are the posterior columns at the cervical and upper thoracic levels. The clinical features include: Peripheral nerve and spinal cord involvement Paresthesias in the hands or feet Weakness and unsteadiness of gait Loss of vibration or joint position sense in the legs Mental slowing, depression, confusion, delusions, and hallucinations MRI spine shows diffuse myelopathy and areas of demyelination. Treatment involves a replacement regimen of vitamin B12 intramuscular daily injections of 1000 g for the first week followed by weekly 1000 g injections for 1 month. Monthly injections are given thereafter. While vitamin E deficiency can also cause SACD, it is rare and is associated with hemolytic anemia.

question_text:
Korsakoff syndrome is caused by the deficiency of which vitamin?
B1
explanation: Korsakoff syndrome is caused by the deficiency of thiamine. This syndrome is characterized by pronounced anterograde and retrograde amnesia along with impairment in visuospatial, abstract, and other types of learning. It is usually completely or partially permanent in about half the patients. Wernicke's encephalopathy refers to the acute form of thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by nystagmus and ophthalmoplegia, mental status changes, and unsteadiness of stance and gait. It is a medical emergency and IV or IM thiamine should be initiated immediately. question_text: A 6-year-old child is brought with complaints of unsteadiness and gait disturbance. On neurological examination, nystagmus, areflexia, and hypotonia are noted. Contrast-enhanced MRI of the brain shows enhancing nodule within the wall of a cystic mass. The mass is resected and histology shows the given finding. options: BRAF mutation is seen in this tumor
It belongs to WHO grade II tumors
explanation: The given clinical history and the image showing Rosenthal fibers is diagnostic of pilocytic astrocytoma. It belongs to WHO grade I tumors. Pilocytic astrocytoma typically occurs in children and young adults and is usually located in the cerebellum. It is usually a slow-growing tumor and if it occurs in the cerebellum, it can be resected. If it extends into the hypothalamic region from the optic tract, it can have a more ominous clinical course because of its location. It is often cystic, if solid, it may be well circumscribed. It is often biphasic with both loose microcystic and fibrillary areas. The tumor is composed of bipolar cells with long, thin hair-like processes that are GFAP-positive and form dense fibrillary meshworks. Rosenthal fibers and eosinophilic granular bodies are characteristic findings under microscopy. BRAF mutation is seen in this tumor.

question_text: A 65-year-old patient presents with headache, seizures, and focal neurological deficit. question_text: A 40-year-old patient presents to the OPD with recurrent seizures, headache, and projectile vomiting. MRI brain reveals cortical-based heterogeneous tumor with calcification in the frontal lobe. The histological section of the resected tumor shows perineuronal satellitosis. Which of the following is the most common genetic alteration noted in this tumor?
options: Mutation of the isocitrate dehydrogenase genes
Deletion of portions of chromosomes 1p and 19q
explanation: The clinical picture is suggestive of oligodendroglioma and the most common genetic alterations in oligodendroglioma are mutations of the isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH1 and IDH2) genes. IDH1 and IDH2 gene mutations are seen in upto 90% of oligodendroglioma and they are associated with a better prognosis. Deletions of portions of chromosomes 1p and 19q are seen in up to 80% of the cases.

question_text: The histological section of an intracranial space-occupying lesion resected from a patient is given below. Which of the following tumors shows this pattern?
explanation: The histological image shows fried egg appearance of cells and is seen in oligodendroglioma. Oligodendroglioma is an infiltrating glioma comprised of cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. It commonly occurs in the fourth and fifth decades. The lesion is found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, with a predilection for white matter. The tumor is composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm giving a fried egg appearance. Tumor cells infiltrating the cerebral cortex often collect around the neurons (perineuronal satellitosis). question_text: A 12-year-old boy presents with complaints of headache, projectile vomiting, and blurring of vision. CT scan shows a mass lesion in the posterior cranial fossa. His medical records are unremarkable, except for a family history of colon cancer in three of his relatives. What is the most probable syndrome that this patient has?
explanation: The given clinical features and the family history of colon cancer point to the diagnosis of Turcot syndrome. Turcot syndrome is a rare hereditary disorder clinically characterized by the occurrence of primary tumors of the colon and the central nervous system. Two types of tumors are seen in Turcot syndrome. The first is characterized by childhood cerebellar medulloblastoma caused by mutations in the APC gene. The second type is characterized by gliomas, particularly glioblastoma multiforme, arising in both children and adults and is related to mismatch repair gene mutations. question_text: A 40-year-old smoker diagnosed with small cell carcinoma of the lung 1 year back now develops seizures, short-term memory loss, and psychiatric symptoms. Which of the following paraneoplastic conditions can be attributed to this presentation?

question_text: The MRI of a woman presenting with recurrent headaches is given below. Microscopy of the resected tumor shows psammoma bodies and the tumor cells express progesterone receptors. Which of the following is the most common cytogenetic abnormality noted in this tumor?
explanation: The given MRI showing homogeneously enhancing extra - axial, dural based tumor and the microscopic findings are highly suggestive of meningioma. The most common cytogenetic abnormality in meningioma is 22q deletion. Meningioma is predominantly a benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura. It arises from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid. 50% - 60% of the sporadic meningioma harbors mutations in the NF2 gene (in chromosome 22q12) resulting in the absence of functional merlin protein. question_text: Which of the following tumors is most commonly associated with meningeal carcinomatosis?
explanation: Breast carcinoma is commonly associated with meningeal carcinomatosis. Meningeal carcinomatosis presents as tumor nodules studding the surface of the brain, spinal cord, and intradural nerve roots.

question_text: Which of the following types of herniation is characterised by duret hemorrhages?
explanation: Duret hemorrhages are characteristic of transtentorial herniation. Transtentorial (uncinate, mesial temporal) herniation occurs when the medial aspect of the temporal lobe is compressed against the free margin of the tentorium. Progression of transtentorial herniation is often accompanied by secondary hemorrhagic lesions in the midbrain and pons, termed Duret hemorrhages. These linear or flame - shaped lesions usually occur in the midline and paramedian regions and are believed to be due to the distortion or tearing of penetrating veins and arteries supplying the upper brainstem. With increasing displacement of the temporal lobe, the third cranial nerve is compromised, resulting in pupillary dilation and impairment of ocular movements on the side of the lesion. The posterior cerebral artery may also be compressed, resulting in ischemic injury to the territory supplied by that vessel, including the primary visual cortex. When the extent of herniation is large enough, the contralateral cerebral peduncle may be compressed, resulting in hemiparesis ipsilateral to the side of the herniation. The compression in the peduncle in this setting is known as the Kernohan notch.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Which of the following structures is involved in tonsillar herniation?
explanation: Cerebellum is involved in tonsillar herniation. Tonsillar herniation refers to the displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. This pattern of herniation is life-threatening because it causes brainstem compression and compromises vital respiratory and cardiac centers in the medulla.

question_text: Which of the following is the most common CNS neoplasm in immunosuppressed patients?
explanation: Primary central nervous system lymphoma is the most common CNS neoplasm in immunosuppressed individuals, including those with AIDS and immunosuppression after transplantation. The vast majority of primary central nervous system lymphomas are of B-cell origin. Overall, primary central nervous system lymphomas are aggressive and have worst outcome. The Epstein-Barr virus plays an important role in the pathogenesis of HIV-related primary central nervous system lymphoma.

Antoni A area has the nuclei of tumor cells aligned in palisading rows. The nuclear-free zones that lie between nuclear palisading are known as Verocay bodies. question_text:
CSF spread can occur in patients with all of the following tumors, except:
Medulloblastoma
explanation: Most of the meningiomas are benign tumors and very rarely metastasize to CSF. The primary intracerebral malignancies that may cause metastases to the subarachnoid space are: Glioblastoma (GBM) Anaplastic astrocytoma Medulloblastoma Ependymoma Pineoblastomas Oligodendroglioma Leptomeningeal metastases, also known as carcinomatous meningitis, refer to the spread of malignant cells through the CSF space. These cells can originate both in primary CNS tumors (e.g. drop-metastases), as well as from distant tumors that have metastasized (hematogenous spread). The most common secondary tumors that spread to CSF are breast cancer > lung cancer > melanoma > GI malignancies. Contrast MRI is the investigation of choice and shows leptomeningeal enhancement and tumor scattered over the brain in a ‘sugar-coated’ manner. Peripheral nerves & Neuromuscular pathology

question_text: What is the most common cause of peripheral neuropathy?
explanation: The most common cause of peripheral neuropathy is diabetes mellitus. The most common pattern of diabetic neuropathy is an ascending, distal symmetric, sensorimotor polyneuropathy (glove and stocking type). The most common type of hereditary neuropathy is Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease.

question_text: A 20-year-old man presents with distal leg weakness with no complaints of tingling or numbness. On examination, you note reduced muscle stretch reflexes below the knee along with the following findings. This condition is associated with which chromosome?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Charcot–Marie–Tooth (CMT) disease. It is most commonly associated with chromosome 17. It is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. The most common variant of this condition is CMT1A. It is caused by a duplication of a region on chromosome 17 that includes the peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22) gene. It usually presents in the first to third decade of life with distal leg weakness, e.g., foot drop with no numbness or tingling. There is reduced sensation to all modalities with reduced muscle stretch reflexes. Atrophy of the muscles below the knee leads to inverted champagne bottle legs.

question_text: A 32-year-old woman comes with complaints of double vision that gets worse after she reads a book or watches television. She also has drooping of the eyelids that gets better after a nap. Serology is positive for anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. Which of the following is more commonly associated with this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myasthenia gravis. It is most commonly associated with thymic hyperplasia (65% of cases). Thymoma is seen in around 10% of patients with myasthenia gravis. Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by weakness and the fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the neuromuscular junction. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular (myoneural) junction. There is a characteristic pattern of muscle involvement. Lid and extraocular muscles (diplopia and ptosis) are involved early in the disease course. The facial muscles weakness can produce a snarling expression, weakness in chewing, and nasal timbre to the voice. Weakness increases with repeated use of the muscles and improves with rest. The reflexes are normal in this condition.

question_text: A 52-year-old man presents with mild ptosis and proximal lower limb weakness. Nerve conduction studies show incremental response following brief exercise. Further investigations reveal antibodies against presynaptic P/Q voltage-gated calcium channels. Which of the following malignancies is associated with this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). It is associated with small-cell lung carcinoma. It is an autoimmune disorder caused by antibodies that block acetylcholine release by inhibiting a presynaptic calcium channel. In contrast to myasthenia gravis, rapid, repetitive stimulation (muscle activity) results in an increase in muscle response and strength. Patients typically present with weakness of their extremities. In about half the cases, there is an underlying malignancy; most often, neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung (Small cell lung carcinoma). The stimulus for autoantibody formation in paraneoplastic cases may be the expression of the same calcium channel in the neoplastic cells. Patients without cancer often have other autoimmune diseases, such as vitiligo or thyroid disease. Treatment consists of drugs that increase acetylcholine release by depolarizing synaptic membranes (pyridostigmine), plasmapheresis, and immunosuppressive agents, similar to myasthenia gravis.

A 51-year-old woman presents with complaints of weakness for 2 months. She reports that she has difficulty rising from a chair and combing her hair every morning. Physical exam reveals decreased strength in the shoulders and hip. Muscle biopsy findings are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?

explanation: The muscle biopsy shows myofiber atrophy accentuated at the edges of the fascicles (perifascicular atrophy). The biopsy along with the history is suggestive of dermatomyositis. It is associated with perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates. Dermatomyositis is an immunologic disease in which damage to small blood vessels contributes to muscle injury. question_text: A patient with gastric carcinoma develops proximal muscle weakness. Biopsy findings are suggestive of dermatomyositis. Which of the following antibodies are most likely to be present in this patient?
explanation: This patient has developed paraneoplastic dermatomyositis. Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic dermatomyositis and juvenile dermatomyositis. It presents as gradual, symmetric muscle weakness and myalgias, typically affecting the proximal muscles first. Fine movements controlled by distal muscles are affected late in the disease. Myopathic changes and elevation in serum creatine kinase levels suggest muscle damage.

question_text: A patient with muscle weakness is found positive for antibodies against cN1A. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: Antibodies to cN1A are seen in inclusion-body myositis. It is the most common inflammatory myopathy in patients >65 years. Patients present with slowly progressive muscle weakness that tends to be most severe in the quadriceps and the distal upper extremity muscles. Dysphagia from esophageal and pharyngeal muscle involvement can also occur. Laboratory studies usually show modestly elevated creatine kinase levels. Most myositis-associated autoantibodies are absent but are positive for antibodies to cN1A.

question_text: An 8-year-old boy was brought with progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties. The following finding was noted on examination. Genetic testing revealed a dystrophin gene mutation. On which chromosome is the affected gene located?
explanation: The given clinical history and the image showing pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles are highly suggestive of Duchenne's muscular dystrophy. It is an X-linked recessive condition. Duchenne's and Becker's muscular dystrophy are caused by loss-of-function mutations in the dystrophin gene on the X chromosome. It is one of the largest human genes. Dystrophin provides mechanical stability to the myofiber during muscle contraction. Defects in the complex may lead to small membrane tears that permit the influx of calcium, triggering events that result in myofiber degeneration. Duchenne's muscular dystrophy is associated with deletions or frame-shift mutations that result in the total absence of dystrophin. Immunohistochemical studies for dystrophin show the absence of the normal sarcolemmal staining pattern. In contrast, the mutations in Becker's muscular dystrophy typically permit the synthesis of a truncated version of dystrophin, which retains some function. Immunohistochemical studies for dystrophin show reduced staining.

question_text: Glial hamartia is a feature of which of the following conditions?
explanation: Glial hamartia are seen in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF 2). These are microscopic nodular collections of glial cells at abnormal locations, often in the superficial and deep layers of the cerebral cortex. NF2 is associated with the following: Bilateral eighth-nerve schwannomas Multiple meningiomas Gliomas - typically ependymomas of the spinal cord Nonneoplastic lesions - schwannosis, meningioangiomatosis, and glial hamartia Option A: NF 1 is associated with neurofibromas of all types, malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, gliomas of the optic nerve, other glial tumors, hamartomatous lesions, and pheochromocytomas. Option C: Tuberous sclerosis is associated with hamartomas within the CNS in the form of cortical tubers and subependymal nodules. Other lesions include subependymal giant-cell astrocytoma, renal angiomyolipomas, retinal glial hamartomas, pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis, cardiac rhabdomyomas, and cysts in the liver, kidneys, and pancreas. Option D: Von Hippel–Lindau disease is associated with hemangioblastomas of the CNS and cysts involving the pancreas, liver, and kidneys, and have a propensity to develop renal cell carcinoma and pheochromocytoma. NOTE: A hamartia is not considered to be a tumor and is distinct from a hamartoma. A hamartoma is a benign neoplasm characterized by tissue misarrangement similar to a hamartia.

question_text: A pathologist is examining a histopathological slide showing pseudo-Meissner corpuscles. This finding is seen in which of the following conditions?
explanation: Focal collections of pseudo-Meissner corpuscles or tactile-like bodies (cells mimicking the appearance of Meissner corpuscles) is a feature of diffuse neurofibroma. Note: Meissner corpuscles consist of a cutaneous nerve ending responsible for transmitting the sensations of fine, discriminative touch and vibration.

question_text:
An electron microscopic picture of a cut section of a nerve fiber is given. Identify the area which will be affected in the most common variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome.

1
explanation: The most common variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome is acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP). The area affected in this condition is the myelin sheath (marked as 2 in the image). Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute autoimmune disease that causes fulminant polyradiculoneuropathy. It is a T-cell mediated immune response. GBS is usually associated with a history of upper respiratory infection (URI) or acute gastroenteritis (AGE) 1-3 weeks prior. The causative organisms may be Campylobacter jejuni, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae. It presents with the following features: Ascending motor paralysis (lower limbs > upper limbs) Sensory deficits may or may not be seen Deep tendon reflexes - absent Transient bladder dysfunction - severe cases Autonomic manifestations - loss of vasomotor control, postural hypotension, cardiac dysrhythmias Histological examination shows inflammation of peripheral nerves, manifested as perivenular and endoneurial infiltration by lymphocytes, macrophages, and a few plasma cells. On electron microscopy, an early effect on myelin sheaths is seen. There is segmental demyelination induced by the actions of activated macrophages. There are several types of Guillain–Barre syndrome: Demyelinating Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) - most common Axonal Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN) Acute motor-sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN) Regional GBS syndromes: Miller–Fisher syndrome (MFS)
